2023 One step forward, two steps back.I'll start by addressing the elephant in the room. “You have 300 hours in the game, how can you not recommend it?”. Well, let me do a breakdown of how those hours were spent.150 hours - duplicating progress in my own world for sections that I already did with a friend.80 hours - riding around the open world and fighting copy-pasted enemies; exploring dungeons and fighting copy-pasted bosses and enemies.40 hours - the actual fun part of the game, legacy dungeons. These areas follow the format of the previous souls games and feature carefully-crafted, closed-off areas with interesting enemies and well-designed bosses.30 hours - arena PvP, invasions, co-op with randoms.So overall, that makes 70 hours of fun content, and 230 hours of filler. If you’re planning to buy this game to play with a friend, be prepared for a 7:23 ratio of fun to filler content. Now, I’d like to get into my criticisms with the game itself.Open World: The open world is honestly really beautiful and engaging in the first 3 areas, Limgrave, Liurnia, and Caelid. You won’t be able to explore it as intended on a horse while playing in multiplayer, but that’s not a big deal. These first areas have a good amount of content packed into them, and you’ll be seeing enemy varieties for the first time, so you won’t be bored of them yet. The problem begins 1/3 of the way into the game, at Altus Plateau. This area is really beautiful as well, and probably my favorite visually, but you will start to notice some really empty areas and a lot of copy-pasted enemies in the open world. After you get through Leyndell, you arrive at the worst part of the game - the Mountaintops of the Giants. This area has, I think, one single new enemy that is not just copy-pasted from the previous areas with a different skin. It’s not even worth the words to describe how bad this area is. If you buy the game despite my negative review, here’s some advice: hop on your horse and ride straight to the boss, because there’s nothing worth exploring here. Right after this is another empty snow area, but the devs use an innovative trick here - most of the area is covered in a snowstorm. This expertly hides the areas that they didn’t have time to finish, so you can’t see how devoid of content they are.Multiplayer:First of all, the netcode for this game’s multiplayer is absolute trash. Connecting to your friends fails or hangs about 10% of the time, and invading requires you to use the item 1-30 times before you’ll successfully invade someone. As far as anyone can tell, Fromsoft is basically still using the same netcode that they used back in Dark Souls in 2011, just with a couple of bandaids thrown on top to prevent infinite backstabs. Latency is a huge decider of every fight you will have, and a lot of the skill comes from being able to quickly identify the approximate ping difference between yourself and your opponent, and adapting your tactics accordingly.Your skills at PvE will not carry over at all. In PvE, you can look at an enemy’s attack and decide to press dodge if you think it will hit you, but in PvP, you have to press dodge anyways no matter where their weapon is because of the invisible hitboxes and latency. On top of this, Fromsoft decided to make the latency issues even more prominent by introducing powerful status effects that build up on you even if you successfully dodge an enemy attack. The top level of PvP is full of Scarlet Rot and Sleep status abusers who exploit the fact that these status effects build up on you even through dodges, and the “counter” for this is to duplicate items (cheating) which cure Rot/Sleep in the middle of combat. Oh, and if you want to turn their tactics around on them, then you’ll need to duplicate items too, because the sleep and rot grease are both limited in the quantity that you can obtain legitimately in a single playthrough. Watching a high-level invasion honestly makes me laugh with how many limited-use items both players are popping like candies. PvP is just laughably broken.On top of this, there are some multiplayer decisions made by the developers that cannot be described as anything other than stupid. First of all, co-op requires an item to even be allowed to summon people. In the early game, you’ll have to waste some time farming for flowers (and probably 10 minutes trying to figure out why you can’t summon, until you look it up). Next, if you kill a boss, you can’t summon your friend anymore or be invaded in that area. If you kill all the bosses in a particular open-world “chunk”, then that whole area is off-limits for multiplayer. When you kill a boss anywhere in the world, even if it’s just a random dragon in the open-world, you will be sent home as a cooperator. There are random fog-walls preventing you from entering caves with your friend, and you’ll have to disconnect, ride to that spot in your own world, enter the cave in your own world, then re-connect to your friend (logical, right? It obviously improves the gameplay).Finally, even when everything is working properly and the networking issues aren’t getting in the way, Elden Ring co-op is just horribly balanced. After the first couple of early-game bosses, every challenge in the game starts to become easy. Most enemies are simply not coded well to deal with multiple players attacking them. Bosses will change targets anytime they take damage, even if it’s a tiny throwing knife, meaning that aggro-juggling is incredibly easy. The bosses are supposed to be able to kill you by damaging you and then punishing you when you try to heal, but with aggro-juggling, you will always be able to heal unless you mess up horribly and get killed in a single combo. This does happen, so co-oping bosses can still take a few tries, but the difference between multiplayer and singleplayer is night-and-day. Despite the fact that the game increases enemies’ health in co-op, the game is at least 3 times easier. To try to compensate for that, my friend and I turned on the Taunter’s Tongue to attract invaders, but the game was still too easy, because it’s incredibly hard for an invader to fairly beat 2 people. If you try invading, you will probably walk into a blender of 3 people spamming spells and ashes of wars and die in 0.5 seconds. This means that the only people who are left invading at higher levels, the only people who can manage to have fun within this framework, are the players who are willing to use any tactic necessary to win. Be prepared to deal with lots of duplicated rot grease, duplicated Starlight Shards, snipes from across the map with duplicated Golem arrows, and nuke builds that can kill you if you make a single mistake. I don’t even blame the players who are using these tactics, because without them, there would be no invaders at higher levels. The game is simply so broken that players are forced to resort to these tactics to have a >0.5% chance of winning invasions.Story:The story is mostly incomprehensible if you rely solely on playing the game. You have to watch Youtube videos to have any idea of what’s going on. After watching some, though, I came to this conclusion:Every one of the main players is a greedy ♥♥♥♥. George R. R. Martin tried to craft a complicated story, but the gameplay just doesn’t support it. Imagine Game of Thrones, but there are no background civilians in the story. It’s just the lords and ladies fighting over empty castles full of monsters. That’s Elden Ring. Every single creature attacks you on sight, and there are no visible civilians. You are fighting to become the Lord of ashes.Overall, the game is alright, but it’s simply not a good way to spend your time. It all comes back to the 7:23 ratio of fun to filler. Maybe others will find that to be an acceptable ratio, but I don’t. I wish I could get back the hours that I spent on this game, and I implore others not to make the same mistake that I did.

2018 I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

''BURN THE HERETIC, KILL THE MUTANT, PURGE THE UNCLEAN'' - Angels of Death.Joking aside, this game is everything the Warhammer 40k: Space Marine community wanted and expected. Not only is it a well-made continuation of the previous title, but it also serves as a warning to the gaming industry that people want simpler, shorter games with a lot of quality and refinement, which I will present here:Intense Combat: The combination of gunfights with hand-to-hand combat keeps the action immersive and varied.Visuals and Environment Design: Graphical improvements and attention to detail ensure an impressive visual experience.Immersive Storyline: Your exploration of the dystopian universe of Warhammer 40k becomes so immersive with a mature narrative focused on epic battles.Enemy Hordes: The presence of the Tyranids brings an additional element of challenge, forcing the player to always be on the move and plan each attack. Not only that, the traitorous heretics are also very difficult opponents to deal with, especially on higher difficulties, making you have to rethink your strategy.Art direction: Many forget to mention this, but the art direction of this game is incredible, from the large battlefield scenarios to the gigantic cathedrals, the details on the walls of the buildings. Everything in this game seems to be a painting, and sometimes the combat in this game doesn't let you realize this, but when you get a moment of peace to look around you, it's almost impossible not to be impressed.However, there are some points to consider:Possible Repetitiveness: Depending on the game's progression, combat against large hordes can become repetitive.The campaign: It is of average length, depending on the difficulty you're playing on, but it maintains a good narrative. -Anyway, I believe that WARHAMMER 40K: SPACE MARINES 2 is currently a warning beacon for the industry that it is not necessary to make major "innovations" to make a good game, giving an example that with just a little refinement in something that was already good it is enough to make a good game. Anyway, this is my analysis/opinion about this game, I hope that with this I have helped you in some way to decide whether to play the game or not :)

2022 Personally I can't recommend the game in its current state right now, this review comes a fair time after launch and after some patches to fix certain issues/balancing with the game. I pre ordered the game and played on release; the amount of hours I have in the game (48.4 at the time of writing) speaks to how much fun i had with the title. While I know it's been changed now, the main campaign is utterly atrocious with its invasive mechanics and mind numbing realms of chaos mechanics (♥♥♥♥ YOU TZEENTCH RANDOM TELEPORTS), I don't know who thought this was a fun or good idea on the Dev side but it really neutered my enjoymnet of the game after my first play through.The game can legitimately be enjoyable, I won't pretend I've played every faction to a T or explored every nook and cranny of their tech/lord trees as we all have our own personal tastes; what I did play was fun for a bit, but it wore off very quickly. I think they did a superb job with numerous quality of life changes, but overall the game feels like a lesser package than WH2. You could indeed make the argument that WH2 has had years of DLC to accompany it and I'd agree, but if you compare WH1 to WH2 the quality difference compared to game 2-3 is staggering. I waited to make this review to give them time to iron out bugs/do balancing, but mostly wait for immortal Empires which is the big pull for the game, today we learned the BETA for it isn't coming out for another 3-6 months which at least to me is mind boggling. WH2 had ME out if i recall within a month or two, on one hand they're trying to make sure everything works smoothly before releasing it, on the other so many issues in game were so blatant I don't know how they weren't found in QA/playtesting/Beta, by the time content creators got their hands on it it wasn't realistic to expect such ingrained issues to be fixed by then. Lord defeat traits being a joke, some skill trees being a lackluster joke in comparison to others, tech trees also on the seesaw between being fun and engaging/a boring almost not noticeable change, hero traits also being neutered from WH2; it's sad.Overall I think it's an ok game, I'm just very disappointed and I feel bad for getting my friend excited to play it with me only for us to get bored in our co-op campaign within a week. A blunder if i've ever seen one by CA.

2022 I've been a long-time total war player and a fan of both historical and fantasy titles. It breaks my heart to criticize it so, but I cannot recommend this game at this time. It has great potential, and its features and factions are great. However, it is poorly, poorly optimized. At ultra graphics, textures and details in this game still look worse than the beautiful units you'll find in Warhammer 2. The requirements are higher than Warhammer 2, and the base game requires an incredible 120 GB, twice that Warhammer 2 needed WITH its DLCs. Will Warhammer 3 require 200 GB when DLCs are released--or are some of those files pre-installed, forcing players to store files that they have not chosen to purchase yet? Either is unacceptable. We require higher tier GPUs, double the storage space, and 60 dollars to get a product that currently has less content AND worse performance than a game released years ago? Those are just some of the main issues as bugs of all sorts abound:-For some/many players, multiplayer lobbies do not appear properly, instead showing no MP lobbies or showing them cycling in and out in ones or pairs. -There is no in-game chat, which for some unfathomable reason the game was published without. In other words, if you want to play team MP with people who are not your friends, expect zero communication--not to mention people will struggle to even see your lobby, let alone join and play.I really hope the issues are fixed. Some of them are just obvious and the willingness to publish with the game in this stage demonstrates a profound disrespect for players, fans, and total war's own brand. Look no further than Total War: Three Kingdoms to see cause for concern. That was a game they charged everyone 60 dollars with a completely unplayable multiplayer , and they never bothered to fix it, instead discontinuing support for it within a couple of years. The issues were obvious, and surely reparable. Yet they did nothing.

2022 As it stands right now I cannot endorse this game nor recommend anyone to spend their money on it.The reason being that (as many other reviews have pointed out) on release the game had come out with significantly worse performance than I was expecting. With my current set-up I am capable of running the previous game, ultra settings, 1440p and easily maintain 60fps under most conditions with an average GPU temp of 64c.This game however, running at the same settings I was struggling to maintain even 30 fps and had an average GPU temp of 85c with spikes over 90c, in fact I had begun to smell molten plastic. I wasn't able to reach 60fps until I had toned down all the settings to the absolute lowest and went to 1080p, however doing this still resulted in average temps approaching 80c.The weird thing is that performance seems to vary wildly between users and there are people with worse systems (I use a 1080ti and an I7 7700k) having better performance and people with better systems having worse performance and vice versa with no clear pattern. So, granted, you may very well have a smooth ride, though likely isn't worth the gamble considering there's been reports from some users that this game had outright fried their system.In addition it would appear that there are early access folks reporting the game ran better even just the day before release. Then after a patch hit and the game released they had worse performance. When comparing benchmarks they had found that some of them would have of up to 50% reduced performance. It could be the poor implementation of a last-minute denuvo inclusion, it could be that the patch accidentally messed up some other factors, it is not known at this point. Regardless, the game doesn't function as it ought to and until it is fixed, I recommend to anyone reading this to spare your PC this unoptimised mess and wait.

As I face the reality of my terminal illness diagnosis, This game has become a rare light in my life. Growing up I found comfort in the unforgiving challenge and beauty of soulslike games, and now, in what may be my final months, this game has given me a chance to reconnect with that comfort one last time.The developers have created a visually stunning and mechanically precise action RPG that offers both the challenge and the sense of achievement that we crave. The intricate combat, alongside the visually striking environments, makes every moment memorable. It’s given me something to look forward to, allowing me to lose myself in its rich world when I need it most.If you're a fan of soulslike games and appreciate the art of a well crafted challenge, I can't recommend Black Myth: Wukong enough. To me, it's not just a game: it's a gift, providing a final sense of purpose and achievement. My deepest gratitude goes to the developers for creating this masterclass.

Once Human | By Wholf Once Human is a game I've dedicated around 200 hours to, playing every single day and experiencing a range of emotions from fun and laughter to excitement. In my opinion, this game is definitely a contender for Game of the Year, though it does need some fixes. The game offers an open-world survival experience filled with monsters, elite bosses, dungeons, silos, Easter eggs, puzzles, and many other features. There are bizarre creatures, a compelling storyline (which could use some updates), stunning graphics, smooth gameplay, and a robust base-building system (though it could use more features and clipping fixes). Unfortunately, the servers/worlds in Once Human feel empty and inactive. Despite there being hundreds of bases, only a few are in use. With a maximum of 400 players per world, I rarely encounter other players, except during world events. This issue needs addressing soon as finding an active Warband or Hive is currently challenging. For example, I've been looking for an active Warband on my server, but no one seems to engage in world chat or participate in Warband activities, which is disappointing. Luckily, a fix is coming in August, so let's hope for the best. The same issue applies to playing with friends. Some of my friends can't join my server because it's full, even though it feels empty. This problem is also expected to be resolved in August. However, another issue arises with new players joining level 50 players. While we could share items and boost them, it's not ideal. I can't wait to play with my whole group, but I don't want to start over again. Some players complain about two files and claim the game is Pay2Win. First, the two files are harmless, and all information about them is available online. Second, the game is not Pay2Win; you can only buy cosmetics and the battle pass. Once you reach level 50, obtain the best gear and weapons, complete all villages, cities, areas, side quests, and main quests, and build a powerful character, the game feels complete. Personally, I've finished everything significant, maybe missing a few puzzles. Now, I'm making YouTube tutorials, exploring, finding Easter eggs, and reworking my base. I have high hopes for more content in the future and can't wait to see what's next. The game offers a lot: a vast world with plenty of activities, challenges, world events, areas to clear, puzzles, Easter eggs, a compelling storyline, base-building, unique items, and extensive weapon and gear customization. The music and sound effects are also exceptionally well done, especially the main menu music, which reminds me of the good old Call of Duty days. However, the game might be too easy. A level 20 player can fight level 30/40 enemies with the right loadouts. Leveling up is also straightforward if you focus on exploring and doing quests rather than just dungeons. It depends on your playstyle really. The development team is very active and communicative, providing information, answering questions, handling tickets, and more. They are passionate, and I'm happy to work with them. Unlike many companies with big games, this team handles things well, and I wish them all the best. Additionally, if you're on a PvP server and in a PvP zone, sometimes objects and buildings don't render properly over long distances. This can create the illusion that you can hit an enemy when they are actually hidden behind a rock or inside a house. I've encountered this multiple times, and it's quite frustrating. Hopefully, this issue will be fixed soon. Another point to consider in PvP is that if you're getting wrecked by an opponent, it might be because they're using a powerful build, like the Shrapnel build, which deals a lot of damage. Keep that in mind!To summarize, here are the top 5 positives and negatives:Positives:1. The vast array of features Once Human offers.2. The base-building and crafting system.3. The detailed loadout system with blueprints and modifications.4. A large world with plenty to explore, discover, and solve.5. The game's impressive graphics and immersive environment.Negatives:1. The server system, where friends can't join and servers feel empty.2. The game being a bit too easy.3. Overpowered builds if done correctly.4. A clunky building system with alignment and clipping issues.5. Occasional crashes, even on a perfectly capable PC.Overall, Once Human is a highly enjoyable game. It's free-to-play, packed with features, boasts great graphics, and is easy to progress in. Despite minor bugs, well-developed systems, and the need for updates, Once Human feels like a blend of Palworld, Fallout 76, and Rust. I'm giving it a 9.2/10 so far. Great job, and I can't wait to see its future.Here is my YouTube Once Human playlist: YouTube™ Video: Once Human - ALL REDEEMABLE CODES Views: 22,134 Here is the copy/paste list of redeemable codes in Once Human currently. =================== ONCEHUMAN0710 CDYM4MXDNH OH000007 HYD7MY66RT FCNX8NHXJ7 The additional codes listed below are from... When adding me on Steam, make sure to leave a comment on my profile. This is due to my own safety and having to many requests.

2023 I can not in good faith recommend this game in its current state and the developers recent statement of threatening to outright cutting support from this game if we don't buy the overpriced DLC for almost HALF the price of the base game? It's ridiculous. I have over 1K hours between the three games combined and I can not stand by this. The company has let bugs fester for months on end that hinder or prevent users from using PAID content they paid for in game 2 (Nakai recruiting Kroxigors or Ariel spawning as examples) despite the community fixing them day 1, some of the slowest patch cycles for any game dev in this era, and now threatening their customers who are standing up for an unreasonable price increase? 2020 Valve doesn't care about cheaters. They can go 900+ hours without getting banned, maybe even longer, even when the vod clearly shows wallhacks/aimbot. It gets worse and worse the closer to global you get, at supreme. It's not every game, but when it does happen (once a day? Maybe every two days?) It's incredibly frustrating. You believe they're just outplaying you at every turn, but then you watch the vod and see some ♥♥♥♥ that even shroud/kennyS couldnt do. This occurs even at high rank prime matchmaking. You even start to see repeat accounts that get banned over and over, same name same pic, for months. These accounts can rack up 500+ Hours of just cheating and getting to high rank. Valve makes more money off the cheaters than people who buy keys, so they have a super lax anti-cheat. You don't see anywhere near this level of cheating on fortnite, a vastly less competitive game, so it's definitely possible to stop these cheats.

2022 Is this the best souls like game ever? Maybe not, probably yes, but I can whole wholeheartedly say that this is an amazing game. It will probably be my 2022 GOTY.Yes, it has some problems here and there, especially the online connectivity, but I have enjoyed every minute while playing it.The open world gives me plenty of space to explore and find interesting things, the story is the most fleshed out of the latest From Software games, except Sekiro, that one has the story told in more conventional ways, but the combat makes up for that. Here are so many characters in this game and each on of them has so much dialogue. It is a lot easier to make out the story in Elden Ring than any Dark Souls, Bloodborn or Demon Souls. And oh my God, the worldbuilding is so vast.The gameplay is the well known souls-like gameplay, but this time the player has so many more tools to use to overcome hardships in the world of Lands Between. From better spells with longer range to ashes of war that can be put on almost any weapon and summoning ashes to help you during boss fights or while exploring the world. I think even the co-op experience is a lot easier than in the past games. Now you have basically infinite resources to call other players to help and you can no longer be invaded if you play alone. Invasions also have no great rewards so I think most people won't even invade. Yes, some people hate that invasions are mandatory for co-op and I respect their opinion, but I don't agree with it.The game offers a vast array of bosses and weapons, which can be further customized with different ashes of war. This makes the game feel very diverse. I've played 3 different characters from start (with two of them I've completed the game close to 100%, 3rd playthrough is still not finished) and I have to say that it felt very different every time.Elden Ring is one of those games which I will never delete from my hard drive and will always come back to it and play some more.

As an official creator for the game I can't quite grasp what and where they went wrong with the release. While it's known to not play an MMO on release day or on patch day I felt like there have been many things changed and not to the better. Within the 1.4 hours I've already encountered many things which shouldn't be there or are back in the game. As much as I love the concept but let me break down the things that made me slightly sour:- I either have a spontaneous lost of eyesight or there has been a graphic downgrade. On highest settings everything looks like well a blurry mobile game. This wasn't the case in the betas nor the demo- You can't choose your haircolor properly anymore and I have the feel you later on have to pay for different variants for it- The design of Mitsuko looks more "fckable" but also well why? Do we need to do that to catch the horny bois? (personal preference tho so you can ignore that point)- EULA I also made the mistake of not reading in the past the EULA cause I wouldn't think of a STEAM game collecting the data of: my credit card info, my bank info, my profile and password, my exact address, the information about what I consume and click on in the webs, my social media and more. THIS IS A ♥♥♥♥ DANGER- animations apparently don't work as intended and got changed partially to way less animated options like basically everything with your pickaxe or how enemies die- the one character per server and account which is not deletable is a known bug that they want to change but still horrible for launch day- Wrong and partially still not existing translation of objects which should've been fixed by now (or so I hoped)- many enemies looking like plastic figures cause of the graphics (V included)- endlessly loading chat and not sending messages- fell through the map a couple of times- enemies bugged in the groundAll in all I said it in the past and I will say it again. The game should've put more time into development than into it's advertisement. While I also find reviewspamming ♥♥♥♥ I can see where people are coming from and I know that this release will hurt the game enough that the playercount won't recover.I will change my recommendation as soon as things change to the better. But I am not a creator that is sugarcoating things that should've been evened out long ago by all it's betas and demo.So my recommendation is: wait a bit for a couple of patches. I will do too. And DO NOT PLAY it without reading the EULA my dudes. cheers!

2022 I will be revisiting this review later, but 10 hours in and I'm having a great time. This is one of those few games that I can recommend at full price.EDIT: I have beaten the game, and have played for 75 hours. Time for a more comprehensive review.This game is a fantastic entry point into Souls for people who bounced off the series before, while still managing to be a top tier entry into the genre for those who were already on board (such as myself). The open world is expertly done, taking many lessons from Breath of the Wild and improving upon it with a better reward structure for exploration, tense encounters with many different types of adversaries, and a wide possibility of builds for your character to progress through the game with.The sense of discovery found in this game is near unmatched. Every major area feels unique in both visual aesthetic and gameplay requirements. Quite a lot of time and love went into making it a joy for players to stumble into areas that were much grander than initially perceived, and those moments just seem to keep coming. Like all Souls games, Elder Ring has its share of secrets areas and bosses that many people will never see, even after hitting the credits. While I encourage you to explore actively, I would also advise you to not look up those secrets until after you complete the game, and let your first adventure in the world be truly your own. Trust me, you will have plenty of resources without having to resort to any walkthrough.

Product received for free Early negative review: seems like if Gear of War if it didn't have a shred of humanity, and looked really good. It's middling in a lot of ways, and the one way it is exceptional is that it is like Zoolander: really really really ridiculously good looking. Graphically demanding, and while it runs fairly well, it has an upscaling menu that bears some dire implications for the future of graphics (AI upscaling presented as balanced option, native resolution presented as ultra-premium quality option). Overheats your PC for fairly basic gameplay. Guns are good, slightly underwhelming, melee is a very lightweight system with a dash of Arkham and not particularly deep. Could be that it gets better, but I'm not in any hurry to find out. Once again, it feels like Gears of War but with the armor system replacing the cover system. Not in love with the tone, it's very self-serious and dire and slow, and you run into a lot of characters that are just so flat and one dimensional. Not much popcorn appeal there, but it's also hard to take with any gravitas since the game is just about big silly action figures ripping apart lizards. It also lacks the mortality and urgency of Gears characters, since space marines are basically invincible superheroes in their universe walking past expendable nameless IG that they'd be willing to sacrifice without a second's hesitation. Grim, serious (verging on joyless) invincibility fantasy is just an odd wavelength to try and play along with in a basic TPS. Verdict: I wish I was playing Vanquish (2010) instead!

This game is nothing short of a breathtaking experience. From the moment you step into its richly detailed world, you can feel the care and craftsmanship that went into every aspect of the game. The visuals are stunning, with environments that are not only beautiful but also incredibly immersive. Each location is meticulously designed, drawing inspiration from Chinese mythology in a way that feels both authentic and fantastical.The combat system is a standout feature, offering a perfect blend of challenge and satisfaction. Every encounter feels meaningful, requiring skill and strategy rather than button-mashing. The variety of enemies keeps the gameplay fresh, and the boss battles are nothing short of epic, each one a unique test of your abilities.But what truly elevates "Black Myth: Wukong" is its storytelling. The narrative is deep and engaging, weaving together familiar tales from "Journey to the West" with fresh twists that keep you hooked from start to finish. The protagonist, Sun Wukong, is brought to life with a complexity and depth that makes his journey all the more compelling.Had a blast so far, highly recommended.

2022 Dark Souls IIII with jump button and open world Elden Ring is an evolution of established design trends of From Software studio. ER follows the same gameplay formula as Dark Souls 3 with few new added mechanics that don't fundamentally change the gameplay. As a game it's derivative of its predecessors, the new elements rather than changing formula, feel like continuation of it. Open world Out of the all new elements, the open world aspect of the game is best realised. Instead of following usual practise of separating open-world activities and game progression. ER links game progression with exploration and makes its focus. At it's design core it follows principles of thoughtful minimalism and focus. Those combined together create a game world, in which player can navigate without utilising map. Instead player is visually lead and drawn to nearest objective or interesting places. What's impressive is that almost all major locations are visible from a distance, which helps to point player in right direction. The sheer scale and verticality of those location is spectacular. Instead of using elaborate illusions to make huge location like in previous games. ER aims to make its location fully explorable and massive at the same time. Addition of jumping button also allowed for more interesting and intricate level design. Royal Capital Leyndell is the pinnacle of this design - the biggest location in FROM games. Imagine Anor Londo or Yarhnam, but you can explore everything you see. With open world, ER also introduces an element of nonlinearity to the formula, which after Bloodborne became increasingly linear. This nonlinearity allows for greater build variety and gameplay freedom, player can beat almost any boss he wants in order he wants and pursue different rewards as a result. However, with this approach some corners had to be cut and as a result game reuses many assets and isn't as neatly balanced as previous titles.Crafting fits suprisingly well into gameplay loop. Not only it rewards exploration and incentives seeking new cookbooks, but most importantly it gives immadiate access to neccesary consumables without the need to farm them from the enemies as most of crafting resources are plenty and abundant in game world. Furthermore, this system is entirely optional, as crafting isn't tied to character progression and crafting selection is only limited to consumables and projectiles like arrows or knives. Not to mention many of said items are also sold by merchants and found on corpses. Combat ER builds upon and expands on DS 3 combat template. Most of major enemies and bosses follow the same design principles as DS3 enemies with thier delayed attacks and agressive combos. ER goes even further with this by making bosses even more agressive with more delayed attacks and smaller opening windows, some of them even adjust thier attack strings and behaviour to player inputs and position. This puts even more emphasis on evasion and swift attacks. In turn, this makes boss fights even more dynamic and engaging by forcing player to take risk and carfully find opportunities to strike instead of just waiting for a boss to finish his attacks. Furthermore, bosses have been specifically designed to punish the old habits of veteran souls players and to force them to adapt and change thier strategies to overcame the challenge. I feel like addition of summon ashes has negative impact on the game's balance. The enhanced enemy agression and input reading can be in-part explained as way to combat trivializing aspect of this system. As a result, I feel some of the battles were design and balanced with summon ashes in-mind, especially Crucible knights duo. Edit: they fixed this in issue in patch 1.04 by decreasing bosses aggression when they're in group and most obnoxious cases of input reading have been removed since. Summon ashes still are an easy mode, but now the game doesn't corner you to use it as much as before.Ashes of war system is great. It allows player to change weapon arts of armaments and thier scalling at the site of grace. it highly encourages experimentation and weapon switching. Amazing addition that creates even more build variety. Horse combat is entirely uninteresting and becomes dull very quickly. Fortunately, game rarely if ever forces player to fight on horse and majority of open-world bosses can be fought on foot. I think that Torrent was only added as means of transport and combat was just an afterthought. Conclusion Overall, Dark souls IV Elden Ring is natural conclusion of all previous FROM games. Fundamentally, It's just bigger and better than Bloodborne and Darksouls 3. However, this over adherence to already established formula hinders and restrains the studio's creative potential. I don't think they can follow same forumla endlessly. While ER is a great game, I wish they would experiment more with thier games, as it is they are starting to eat thier own tail.Finally, the most importantly I want Sellen to sit on my face

2023 It doesn’t matter what I think of Elden Ring.This game sold over 20 million copies in a year. In the era of games as live service, it demonstrated that an incredibly difficult single-player experience can be a blockbuster. It’s Fromsoft's biggest hit and has cemented them as one of the most iconic developers of all time. The world has spoken - this game is great. The fact that I didn’t like it very much is totally irrelevant. But I value honesty in review, and in this case being honest means going against the grain. That’s kind of daunting as a reviewer - who among you is brave enough to critique the Mona Lisa, or Taylor Swift’s latest album? These sorts of juggernauts are hard to approach, but I’ve summoned up my courage, and I’m ready to be a contrarian.My first complaint is the switch to open world. The Dark Souls games are a series of branching corridors, with paths opening or closing dynamically. There’s a real sense of momentum pushing you forward from bonfire to bonfire, delving ever deeper into your own personal quest. It sets a mood both claustrophobic and expansive.Elden Ring, by contrast, feels too large. Simply following the critical path will get you maimed, so you’re encouraged to spend a lot of time just…wandering around the landscape. It’s a beautiful landscape to be sure, but there’s altogether too little happening in most of it. Liurnia in particular is a dull slog, but all of the areas suffer from a design that emphasizes scenery over a sense of flow.Speaking of a sense of flow, bosses also feel like a downgrade from previous titles. The core of the combat in these games is learning the attack patterns of your opponents. Starting with Sekiro, the design became a bit more ‘meta’; as we predict the bosses, the designers predict us right back. Things like, to use examples from the game, a stomp attack having a little leg hitch to draw out the animation unexpectedly, or a sword swing that is actually a bluff for a downward slam.These little ‘bait animations’ ruin the fun. Dark Souls felt good because the demon lifted his club to strike, you guessed the timing, and the demon missed you. Elden Ring, by contrast, will make the timing janky just to catch you. It moves the combat away from visual prediction and towards rote memorization, which lessens it. All of this could be easily forgiven if the story was gripping, and I was very optimistic on this front, considering George R.R Martin’s involvement. Sadly, the story is garbage, told poorly - and you know this to be true, because you watched a Youtube video in order to understand it, rather than go through the torture of trying to learn the lore through gameplay. Understanding the story is hours of disjointed investigative work, struggling through side quests that become uncompletable at a slight breeze and reading item descriptions for insufferably vague context clues. If it wasn’t for VaatiVidya and his ilk, we’d all be completely lost - that’s simply poor storytelling.It all felt like vague allusion for the sake of vague allusion. So much was left open to interpretation that the line between ‘loose end’ and ‘plot hole’ feels very blurred, which fundamentally weakens the narrative. Nobody’s motives are explicable and thus nobody’s motives are interesting. Elden Ring honestly just feels like a Dark Souls knock-off. One could argue that Bloodborne and Sekiro were the same, but to me, they felt like interesting and compelling innovations on the core mechanics established in Demon Souls. Elden Ring didn’t innovate. It just slapped on a coat of paint, went open world, and called it a day. Souls became Grace, Lords of Cinder became Rune Bearers, and mechanics were almost entirely rehashed from old titles. Boring!Ultimately, none of my complaints are important. 20 million copies, remember? This review is going to get drowned out by positive reviews from people who had a great 150 hours with this game, and honestly, that’s probably for the best. There’s clearly something really special here that a lot of people love, and that should be celebrated. But as a FromSoft fan, as an RPG fan, and as a fan of challenging combat games in general, I was left disappointed by Elden Ring.

Its Game of the Year 2024. This game delivers an experience so exceptional that it feels like a well-deserved slap in the face to certain Western developers and reviewers who criticized it.Wukong is simply too good, weaving a rich narrative that pulls you deep into the mystical world of Chinese mythology. It’s rare to find a game that not only captivates you with its plot but also keeps you engaged through its brilliant execution.Unreal Engine 5, the game pushes the boundaries of what’s possible in gaming graphics today. The visual fidelity is jaw-dropping, with every detail, from the smallest blade of grass to the most epic boss fights, rendered in stunning clarity. The environments are so immersive that you can almost feel the atmosphere and textures around you.The game also excels in its combat mechanics, though only a few boss fights truly test your skills. While some may find these battles challenging, they are a perfect blend of strategy and action, rewarding players who master the game’s intricacies.In a world where many games are starting to feel formulaic, Black Myth: Wukong stands out as a bold and innovative title. It fully utilizes the power of Unreal Engine 5 to deliver not just the best graphics of the year, but also an experience that feels new and exciting. This game is a testament to the talent and vision of its developers and a must-play for anyone looking for a truly unforgettable gaming experience.and do check my yt for some gameplay i have defeated every single boss of this game on - JPxDee

This game has the feel and vibe of a game made in the late 2000s, early 2010s. The way the multiplayer and the PvE modes play wouldn't be out of place in that era, minus the graphics. This isn't as common nowadays, if at all. So in a weird way, it's a refreshing change that I don't hate at all.The game currently lacks any microtransactions, and apparently there's no concrete plans for modern microtransaction models. You want new cosmetics? Play the game modes. You want new weapons? Play the game modes. This is good. I like this.The gameplay feels similar to how the first Space Marine did, with significant improvements in some areas, and a few missteps. The biggest issue comes in the form of the difficulty, as some enemies are just obnoxiously too powerful on their own, with the methods that they swarm you making it all the worse to deal with. This really only is an issue I've found with the Tyranids. The moment you get to your second set of enemies, it's nowhere near as bad.Also what is the point of a heavy bolter if a simple SHIELD can stop it?

A masterpiece that is so rare in today's gaming landscape - reminiscent of a time we called the "golden age of gaming" with absolute Warhammer 40K brutality that we all love.Graphics• Incredible model detail everywhere• High fidelity and dense environments• Loincloth physics is 👌• World just looks amazingly beautiful - sheer scale 'shock and awe' at every horizonGameplay• Simple but satisfying, much polished from Space Marine I• Movement feels super satisfying and heavy as an Astartes should• Gunplay is impactful and smooth, though aiming feels a bit clunky at times due to the way it's configured• Melee is a transcendent experience, as the Emperor intended, with all the right splashes of red• Old school gaming feel, this plays like a true Space Marine successor/sequel shouldStory• Well-paced, Titus, Chairon, and Chadriel have some amazing moments in this campaign to save the Recidious System from annihilation by xenos and Choas scum alike• Background characters like Major Sarkaana, Cpt. Sevastus Acheran and others aboard the battle barge were all memorable in their own rights - though many Ultramarines don the same Primaris power armour their dialogues and faces behind the suit intrigued me enough to warrant their own spin-off campaigns if possible• World-building elements in the story campaign created a larger-than-life immersive experience, thanks to the attention-to-detail when designing the objects in the game - everything feels so authentic to the 41st millennium time period• Epic, grand, dazzling - are all words that are too small to describe the awe I felt when finishing the campaign, it was a religious experience to say the least• Too short, would have loved a longer campaign - easily finish-able in a day. Hopefully future expansions could be added that bring fourth more stories in this game/engine. Overall, this was the successor to Space Marine that was worth waiting 13 years for - in fact there was a time when this game would not have been possible and to see it and play it is a blessing and a great privilege. For anyone who is a fan of the 40K universe I say this is a must buy - my only complaint is that it will leave you wanting more.

Not even mentioning CA openly THREATENING the playerbase in response to bad sales/reviews of latest dlc.My original review was ; "not recommended".Post last DLC state ; more older races from previous games got an pretty influencial upgrade up to the WH TW 3 standards, althou there is still some problems with power creep or dlc units/mechanics being much stronger than then ones left untouched. The updates still seem to be focused mainly for the new caracters/lords, and the old ones just get some reworked (already existing) mechanic or something made from what was already in game eq. cataclysm spells from the mirrors of madness mode. The vanilla game is better now (excluding some factions still needing much love and work - that are supposed to get it sooner or later), but some long term damage was done and a big bunch of great commiunity mods now are no longer being updated. And since CA tends to mess up their game scripts during updates - the modded game experience has been negatively affected, and patchfixes add more bugs than they fix.So far I still cant recommend going for a full 3 game experience with all dlc's at the full price. But its worth it on big sale.

Story:Nothing really that strong here when it comes to the story. You play as a monkey and look for the six parts of Sun Wukong’s spirit when it split. You don’t really know why you’re doing it, and characters don’t explain why. I’m not sure if the characters even know why. The story is as linear as it can get, but the lore is interesting. Characters pop in from time to time to give you an ability then they disappear. All linear and very straightforward. Not one of the strengths of this game.Graphics and environment:Some of the best graphics in this game. My set-up could run the game decently in High settings and it still looked great. As for the environments, this is where it gets frustrating. You can’t access places you think you can. There is no map, so you might get lost or forget what you were doing the last time before you died. Especially if you get far. I spent a lot of time just walking around in circles and trying to get in places you’re not allowed to.Gameplay:This is where the game shines the most. It excels with so many varied combos, skills and spells. If you master it, you become unstoppable and can sometimes beat bosses in the first try. The bosses are well-designed and unique. Some of them are really difficult. The customization is there, but it is limited to just after you beat some bosses. Some armor sets look great.Overall, this is a phenomenal game so far and I recommend it to anyone who likes GOW, Sekiro, Dark Souls, and any of their ilk.Ridiculously overpowered main and optional bosses that are almost invincible with buffs in a list longer than my d*ck. F*ck this game10/10

2022 The Realm of Chaos campaign is worth playing through once. It doesn't have a lot of replayability, as every playthrough, regardless of race, will play the same. You're trying to do your thing and then about every fifteen or twenty turns the world gets invaded by Chaos Daemons and you have to invade the realm of Chaos for a daemon's soul to eventually gain entrance into the Forge of Souls and either save or devour Kislev's god Ursun for your own ends. That said: the tension is real during the experience, you're constantly at odds with the clock and trying to get everything done in time is a fun experience, but it isn't something I'd like to subject myself to every playthrough. Play through it once then wait for the Immortal Empires addon that puts in all the content from the two previous games in the giant world map. I wish I could give it a neutral review but the gameplay itself is still solid enough to give it a recommendation.7/10 for Realm of Chaos Campaign, 8/10 for combat gameplay, Kislev a best. Probably 10/10 whenever Immortal Empires and the mod workshop comes out.

有显著的优点，但也有极其恶劣的缺点。 优点 2~4章的战斗部分做的非常好。尤其是几位虎形态boss，做的都极好。虎先锋可以说牌面boss了，吊打黄金树幽影。 缺点 1. 地型0分。连最简单的关卡设计都没有。看着哪里都能去，哪里都是空气墙。在这样的情况下，制作组甚至不愿意给个小地图来弥补自己在场景设计方面的缺失。2. 地图尺寸与玩家移动速度不匹配。往哪走都是365里路，走到了又屁都没有。3. 美术也是跟地型一起的，0分。几乎所有的场景都是实拍，没有任何地方有美术设计的痕迹。4. 性能表现非常烂。这点跟上面3点是一起的。过于空旷的场景，毫无意义的地型和装饰物，严重拖累的玩家的机器性能。5. 隐藏要素过于阴间。不看攻略，根本无法找到。探索乐趣0分。6. 后期数据崩坏。后期一些boss长时间飞天放激光。7. 阴间掉落与个别阴间地型。8. 最终让我选择差评的原因是，垃圾剧情。也不知道从哪个二游挖过来的垃圾编剧，一坨大便。

2022 Update patch 2.0:Much better overall, IE release, massive bug fixing and optimization effort from CA, but still no cigar just yet.The most aggravating issues (except too few land battles, tedious slogs through minor settlements and incessant tower spamming which are still problems) have been tackled by now, this is how the game should have been released. But it took them a fair while and Immortal Empires reintroduced a plethora of new (or old) balance problems, bugs and features that don't work optimally (or at all). Every small ♥♥♥♥♥♥ alone would not amount to much but the heap is immense and will take them years to fully adresss. So still not a good look for a full-price Total War title. They're getting there, but slowly. Very slowly. If CA retains this vigour, I guess around Christmas it will be a good game, this time next year a great one even, but as of today my review will remain negative. But it's very close to the tipping point now. Original review:After two Warhammer titles we expected (and deserved) better. Much better!The omission of Immortal Empires at release was already a bitter pill to swallow, but then launching with a buggy, undercooked game with horrible performance, countless questionable design decisions and a severe lack of polish is definitely not a good look for a full price title.And taking a look at the roadmap (with ridiculously long ETAs), it's blatantly obvious that the main team already moved on to another project and the DLC team was left with the unthankful task of cleaning up this mess. Which in itself is another smack in the face of customers.I'm certain it will be a decent game in a few years. But if they want to achieve real greatness, Creative Assembly has got a huge workload before them.Until then it is definitely not recommandable, go play Warhammer 2 instead!

"Black Myth: Wukong" is not just an action-adventure game, but also a profound reinterpretation and expression of Chinese culture and mythology.The game's visuals are breathtaking. Every scene, every blade of grass is filled with intricate details. Whether it’s the lighting effects or texture quality, everything is executed with an exceptional level of craftsmanship. The development team has seamlessly blended ancient Chinese landscapes with the fantastical elements of mythology, creating a world that feels both familiar and refreshingly new.The combat system is incredibly deep, with each move designed to be extremely fluid and impactful.The enemy designs are also highly creative, with everything from ordinary demons to massive boss battles offering challenges that require both strategy and skill.In terms of story, the game faithfully recreates classic episodes from "Journey to the West," while also incorporating a wealth of original content. Wukong’s journey is not just an adventure but a spiritual quest, with many dialogues and story elements that provoke deep thought.The music and sound effects are another highlight, with each piece of music perfectly setting the mood, from intense battles to peaceful villages, fully immersing you in the game’s atmosphere.

Space Marine 2Let me preface by saying this is more a list of pros and cons and is biased entirely towards the melee experience, I have played Assault religiously. I love real difficulty, not the artificial crap but the real stuff. Payday 2 DSOD, VM2 Cataclysm and Onslaught, Darktide Auric Storm and countless other hellish experiences. Space Marine 2 absolutely has the ability to deliver this with some fine-tuning in the future but the current experience is rough around the edges the longer you play and advance. Despite that, I believe this game is worth it, and the developers should be supported.Pros: An incredibly beautiful and heartfelt experience, the developers actively listen and respond to the community, clearly care about the source material and they've created some of the most beautiful graphics to immerse yourself in the carnage.Melee combat just clicks, perfect parries, perfect dodges, gunstrikes, beautiful executions. The first few hours you play will blow your mind away, not to mention the difficulty and initial learning curve is perfect.Cons: Critical flaws in the nuances of the pure melee experience: I'd be here all day breaking this down but to put it as simple as possible: If there were 50 melee enemies after me, I can and have beat them before with use of all the aforementioned mechanics alongside the memorised combos they do, but if you were to add just even 3 small ranged units shooting me 50 metres away, I'm dead in probably 20 seconds and there is nothing skillful I can do to counter this as Assault, my preferred class. Assault is easily the weakest because it lacks utility, functionality, and a worthwhile ability; the strongest and most efficient use of the Assault's jump-pack is to simply stall and run away when the chips are down so you can get reinforcements. Vanguard mogs Assault having played both classes, not just in melee efficiency but in immense measurable utility for yourself and team. Spongy and nonreactive enemy rosters: Did I mention they take countless melee attacks? They do not give a damn. Thunderhammer in their face? They do not care, they will just attack. Jump pack attack or charged attack? Nah they get Insane I-frame dodges that break your tracking and teleports that can actually send them behind walls and covers and allow them to instantly counter attack with an unblockable flame attack, SUCK IT Astartes trash! Behold the trickery of Tzeentch! Thousand sons roster: Take every con I've mentioned, now play on the hardest difficulty, now crank it from a 7 to an 11. They. Are. Overtuned. The issues of a pure melee experience is exasperated 100-fold when you play assault against them. Every Majoris enemy will teleport away before you can kill them with melee, this becomes a problem when they teleport off-screen or into a pack of 20 other different chaos marines. You will whittle them down slowly but never be able to efficiently take them down, though this feels very in their ballpark, it just feels plain bad. At least give me a way to counter this. Here is the irony, Extremis thousand sons are easier to kill. Yeah, no seriously, they really are, I can easily parry and perfect dodge their moves and finish them off because they do not teleport away. Every single unit is overtuned.TZAANGORS: IF YOU KNOW, YOU KNOW. I HAVE SPENT 10 ENTIRE SECONDS PRESSING NOTHING BUT PARRY, REACTING TO THEIR JUMPS. THERE IS 0 COUNTERPLAY OR OPPORTUNITY BEYOND THIS, ANY OTHER OPTION WILL RESULT IN HEALTH LOSS. THEY WILL ACTIVELY DISREGARD ANY ATTACK YOU DO AGAINST THEM, HYPER ARMOUR OUT THE WAZOO. No probs if you have a melta though, looking at you Vanguard.Cheap Chinese Crap: The manufactorium unfortunately, does not provide. Instead we have the ali-express power armour that disintegrates when even looked at the wrong way. You do not feel resilient, or tanky in the slightest, in fact, out of all the games I've played, I feel the squishiest in this...

Elden Ring is one of those games that you just need to play at least once in your life. It's probably the closest to an actual work of art mixed in with a combo of some of FromSoft's previous games.The game's music and art direction is so perfect for the setting being presented, and felt incredibly immersive for me. The music feels as though it belongs in a movie with how dramatic and beautiful it sounds. Probably the best in FromSoft's lineup of games in my opinion. Elden Ring's art direction is also phenomenal in about every way. The only gripe I have about it, although it may be just my own opinion, is that some parts and areas get a tad redundant and some parts recycle enemies and ideas from other sections, but it's not enough to say it's bad. Open world in the game is also pretty interesting and does a decent job making sure the player always has something to do, and of course has some of the best vistas I've seen in a game. Honestly I took a little too many screenshots it's so good lmao. Seeing parts of the map that I couldn't get to made me explore looking for ways to get to where I wanted/needed to go, and rather than just being a straight shot to my destination, the game always threw a number of different things that would get me sidetracked and I'd end up going on like three other whole little adventures before doing what I set out to do. It's very good for an open world.The gameplay, I think, is a great combo of Dark Souls, Bloodbourn, and even Sekiro thrown in. FromSoft seems as though they wanted to bring the best of their older games into one, and did that they did. It really opens up the world for exploration, brings out the most interesting combat to always keep you on your toes, and has amazing locations that allow for exploration so you can find different paths through the area with many goodies to find. The story is about as insane as you'd expect. It's FromSoft.The game's insanely good, if you're reading this just thinking about getting the game just get it. Don't think about it, just get it and enjoy it. Trust.

Overall, a really solid game with a few things holding it back.It's got an excellent combat system that allows for all levels of skill expression, where you can use everything the game gives you for lore-accurate Wukong or none at all if you feel the abilities trivialize encounters. The skill tree system is well done which allows you to create a playstyle that fits you, and the ability for players to reset it for free encourages experimentation.Bosses are the main focus of the game, and level & mob enemy design is sacrificed in favor of that. Most levels are just smashing through weak mob enemies until you reach a boss. This design isn't inherently bad, but I would've loved to see more engaging enemies, creative placements of those enemies, and better environment design so there aren't invisible walls.For a developer that is making a game of this scale for the first time, they definitely got a lot of things right.

Now that I've 100% the game and can only derive enjoyment from Legendary (Campaign Difficulty) /Very Hard (Battle Difficulty) anymore I think I can finally leave a well rounded review.This is definitely one of those games that I wish steam had a "Neutral" review option for. To give you an idea of where my thoughts are coming from, I have over a thousand hours across the Total War Series and started over a decade ago in middle school with Medieval II.This is easily the most diverse of the franchise by far with the variety of races and the rosters for each one, and it has an incredibly good modding scene. The battles are as cinematic as it gets, and the game is beautiful on max settings. This entry in the franchise also has the most robust multiplayer campaign with the player slots going up to 10 (Medieval III multiplayer campaigns please.) The variety of lords, heroes, schools of magic, and tech trees for all the races allows for a variety of playstyles as well. However, it's really more of an illusion of choice, because when it comes down to it each Legendary Lord has their bread and butter to the point that with all the stat buffs you get between perks and research you'll steamroll armies that are composed of units that ARE SUPPOSED TO COUNTER YOU. Agents (Heroes) will 99% of the time be incorporated in your armies and be objectively better as a battlefield unit than for their campaign map purposes (I've beaten multiple legendary campaigns without utilizing an agent on the campaign map even once, which I feel shows their lack of impact if they're just a side option instead of being absolutely essential for well rounded play.) Sieges (and settlement battles) honestly feel like a downgrade from previous titles. Medieval II did it perfectly with multi-layered citadels, dedicated military settlements being entirely different than cities, etc. In this game there's multiple scenarios where you attack with a lord that just gets a free "destroy castle wall" button right at the beginning of the battle. You should have an inherent STRONG advantage as a defender in a siege situation, and this game just doesn't facilitate that at all.The largest issue this games suffers from (which plagues essentially every game of the 4x/RTS genre by the way, I just need to point it out here), is difficulty scaling. The AI is DUMB. Want to make the game harder? Give them every cheat known to man stats wise. The only thing AI really know how to do is attack move their entire army at you. Even on Legendary they will regularly send full stacks to their death by initiating battles against you they don't even have any chance of winning (And I don't just mean in battle by the way, I mean the autoresolve will be an 80/20 split in your favor and the AI still attack for some reason).The game is fun, I'll continue to experiment with mods and play with friends when they ask, but when it comes down to it once you crack the formula there's really no situation where you haven't really won the campaign by turn 50-60 and would just continue it for the sake of reaching the tedious win conditions of a Long Victory. (Which vary WILDLY, Wood Elves and Norsca were beyond annoying to complete whereas Chaos Dwarves I beat a Legendary campaign as Zhatan the Black in 2 hours.)The core gameplay loop sees you essentially solve the first 10 turn puzzle for each Legendary Lords start, and once you're able to do that consistently, that illusion of depth for the game shatters and you're left with a quick 30 minutes of conquering and then an end turn simulator as you sweep through the map.I DO recommend this game, the Warhammer lore is one of my favorite universes, and is done extreme justice here. The game is definitely enjoyable up until the point that you've mastered it, and you'll get your money's worth for that time. However after that even with such a diverse cast it's just boring due to the lack of actual challenge. Hitting start campaign feels meaningless (in my opinion), if you know there's no chance of actually losing.

if you're checking to see whether this game is worth the price: the game is fun and has plenty of replayability, but the base game alone entitles you to a small fraction of the content in the game, so you'll need to sink a lot of money into overpriced DLC. always buy at a discount, and be aware that around a quarter of this game's factions can only be unlocked by buying the other games in the trilogy, even if you buy all the DLC for this game.if you're a strategy gamer wondering whether this is a good buy: yes, but not at the normal price, and don't expect the game to play like a historical Total War game. this is a Total War game in a darwinian high fantasy setting, and the gameplay has adapted well. this game is set in the world of Warhammer Fantasy, an old tabletop game that mostly exists nowadays as a collection of licensed video games, but you won't need to have read the sourcebooks because what little story there is is explained in-game and much of it was written for this game. in short, this game takes place in a temporally-fluid pastiche of our world somewhere between the industrial revolution and several centuries BC, but with magic, polytheism, a looming invasion by demons, demon cultists & ratmen, and stereotypical fantasy species pasted over any race that isn't european or chinese. warhammer's analogue of america is populated by a race of backstabbing slavers who became psychopaths, turned on their majestic brethren overseas and now get off on torturing people. take that as you will.returning players from historical Total War might find that the gameplay feels off, and i agree - i personally find that the less realistic design philosophy does cause me to visualize battles as two sets of stat blocks crashing into each other in arbitrary configurations rather than a test of wits between two forces whose units behave intuitively according to appearance. on the other hand, intuition inherently goes out the window to a degree when the game balance was determined by tabletop game designers rather than a collection of centuries-old military records - there's a good reason the human mind is disinclined to believe that a loosely arranged mob of naked people with whips can hope to defeat an equal quantity of heavy infantry with zweihänders. if you're a fan of naval battles, you should know that this game has no naval gameplay, despite having playable pirates (vampire coast), vikings (norsca) and british people (high elves). the only ships in the game are the transport fleets that all armies store in their asses at all times next to their siege ladders, and if two opposing armies meet at sea, they will agree to park at a nearby island and disembark to fight on land. the closest thing to a navy in this game is the dark elves' black arks, mobile settlements that provide ground troops and shore bombardment to friendly armies.the game's only campaign at launch (tutorial excepted) was Realm of Chaos, a narratively-driven race against the other major factions to invade the titular realm and reach the wounded god Ursun, taking place along the northern latitudes of the world. the main attraction of total war: warhammer III, however, is Immortal Empires, a more traditional Total War campaign that combines the three campaign maps from the total war: warhammer trilogy into one large map spanning almost the entire Warhammer Fantasy world. this campaign contains over 200 factions (though the majority are minor NPC factions that exist to be trampled by or absorbed into playable factions), and the world's races are as diverse to fight as or against as they look.there are plenty of playable factions with radically different playstyles and campaign mechanics. every race has a different core strategy in battle, a different approach to empire-building on the strategic map, and emphasize different mechanics. within each race, most factions have a distinct gimmick intended to encourage different uses of the same unit roster or change the player's diplomatic priorities. i'd feel comfortable saying that every faction in this game feels more unique to play than Rome does in Rome 2, and it is almost always better to do realpolitik and set war goals instead of just dividing the world into enemies and future enemies.however, expect to drop several hundred dollars on DLC for this game, and the integrated content from the previous games in the trilogy, if you're interested in playing anyone other than Cathay (fantasy imperial china), Kislev (fantasy imperial russia) or the daemons of chaos (fantasy florida). if you got into Total War through the pre-Empire games like I did, I would recommend picking up the first game in the trilogy (yes, the base game), which will unlock some of the more accessible races in Immortal Empires if you own both games. Reikland or Couronne will ease you in with gameplay familiar to players of historical total war, and the Vampire Counts will force you to adapt. also consider buying the second game to unlock the Knights of Caledor, which is objectively the best faction. owning all three games, without buying any DLC, will unlock around two thirds of Immortal Empires' playable races. some factions within those races will remain paywalled, but this is more than enough content to get a feel for the game.i would advise you to keep a firm grip on your wallet around this trilogy. more than one DLC has been controversial among consumers for high prices & thin content, and the developers have made a grand number of PR blunders, although they have recently been working to reverse their reputation by releasing new content for the Shadows of Change DLC. if, however, you can build up your DLC library and adapt to each faction's gimmick, there are easily 10,000 hours of gameplay before you've seen everything.though they shouldn't factor into your purchase decision, i feel the need to mention mods, given how critical they are to the experience of playing this game. here's a brief primer, so you're not quite as lost if you choose to get into the modding scene: the steam workshop has a rich selection of mods to add new playable factions with unique mechanics, or revamp minor factions to have unique leaders and gimmicks. the community does its best to ensure cross-compatibility between mods (mostly by having every mod author bother one particular person to edit startpos.esf on their behalf), and i enjoy seeing how many mods i can stuff the game with without breaking it. be aware that the owners of the Warhammer IP do not allow workshop content referencing IPs outside of Warhammer Fantasy, so most mods add either original content or canon content that does not appear in vanilla. Mixu's Unlocker, Victory Conditions Overhaul, Heroes of Legend and the suite of faction mods from Team OvN are essential, even if you're not looking for a heavily modded experience. if you are, mods can more than double this game's playtime - just don't expect mods to carry the game if you're not sold on vanilla, and don't install SFO: Grimhammer unless you fancy begging for a compatibility patch whenever you want to use any other mod. consider downloading the fan-made Warhammer 3 Mod Manager if you intend to play with more than a handful of mods; it makes it a hell of a lot easier to figure out which mod is crashing your game or causing conflicts.in summary: it's a good game that will last you a long time, but has a very different design philosophy from the historical games. faction variety is unparalleled. there's a deep pool of mods to choose from, and you can pack a lot of content into one playthrough, as long as you know what you're doing. you will need to make a lot of purchases to get the full experience, however - 20 DLC packs and counting, plus both of the previous games in the trilogy - so be prepared to wait for sales or look for discounted steam keys on third-party sites.conflict of interest notice: i have directly contributed content to Heroes of Legend.

2023 As a long time Total War Warhammer player, I am hugely disappointed by the direction adapted by the game developer with regard to what should have been the pinnacle of the trilogy. Long known bugs & issues are just ignored (luckily mod creators are doing a fantastic job at fixing most of them). The patch cycles we saw in WH1 and WH2, that included free high quality additional content, has been discontinued (a CA post from last year point to a single person working on patches...).Finally, although I may not fully criticize the new pricing policy with regard to DLCs (I may simply not pay for them if I think it's not worth my money, something that for now seems to be true), I am shocked by the subtle threat made by the developer to discontinue WH3 support, if the community does not respond positively to new DLCs (in my opinion an empty threat, very very disrespectful to the fans and the community nevertheless).I love the series and hope that CA returns to deliver high quality content. Although all strategy fans should experience this amazing series, as of now, during the Shadows of Change DLC controversy, it feels very wrong to recommend the game to new players.

I wholeheartedly recommend Black Myth: Wukong to any fan of Souls-like games. This title has become a true addiction for me. While some boss encounters have tested my patience, I recognize that it's more a matter of improving my own skill through trial and error. The game is a masterful work of art, inspired by the classic Chinese novel Journey to the West, yet telling the story in its own unique and captivating way. Every scene, every battle, and every chapter is presented with such stunning visual spectacle that it's impossible not to be drawn in by its beauty. Rich in content, Black Myth: Wukong offers a deeply immersive experience, and with the anticipated DLC on the horizon, I’m eagerly looking forward to diving back in for more challenges and even greater adventures!

2022 Fantastic game that suffers from open world syndrome of having quantity over quality with all the mini-dungeons in the game (at least the loot is good). The quests are all pretty interesting in their own ways and 9 times out of 10 it is fairly rewarding to follow the questlines. Boss fights are for the most part easier than the previous souls games, however in some cases they can be more difficult, especially if you don't use the ash summons (they intend and definitely encourage you to use them however).Enemy reuse is really bad in this game, ranging from simply reusing enemies from previous games to reusing main story big bads (with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moveset) in random dungeons and reusing the enemies (mini-bosses) which are new to this game except now there's two, oh and now there's three of them, and oh there he is again, and again, and again, now he's a common enemy. The horse is also too strong and honestly doesn't add much to the game besides allowing you to platform higher I guess.In any case, the game is still fun if you like souls games, and this is exactly that, just more souls except with a different name and a much bigger (for better or for worse) scale. The new weapons and move sets are neat and they have also added a huge amount of sorceries as well as weapon arts that you can swap around.

i played it over the span of three weeks, and i blissfully enjoyed all the different aspects the game threaded together in a happy harmony of adventure, survival, fights, quests, and teamwork, until the realization i realized sunk in that all my progress would be destroyed in nay, less than a month from today, i broke down in tears, silently playing along with my happily ignorant friends before they came to the same crushing realization, that life in this world is meaningless, a simple cycle of nihilism and naught, a quest that comes to repetitive end, a walking simulator for those who refuse to walk, a merry go round of fun memories covering a turmoil of misery and hellish existence like a thin layer of frosting on a well expired cake...
