2022 Can't stop playing and probably never will. Massive selection of units with different in-depth and unique leaders to choose from that offer massively different game-play options alongside an interesting story and great dialogue with a fun and challenging combat system to boot.

2016 Counter-Strike: Global OffensivePros of the game: A new additional line of weapons to play around with, each having better improvements to handling. Though beware, some updates can nerf these, since CS:GO patches can be unreliable at times. Cool and stylish weapon graphics you can purchase over the market for personalising your own, unique firearm selections. The new game mode selections of competitive, casual, death-match, arms race (formally known as gun-game), and demolition. A whole new range of maps on top of the remastered originals. All the more Counter-Terrorist and Terrorist skins players will have featured during different level matches. They've laid off including the 'lifetime stats' section a fair bit, with only game achievements this time featured on player profiles, making it much more pleasant for perfectionists like myself instead of feeling like always needing to improve on things all the more. I can just get that sense gnawing at me sometimes to ‘do better’ when I always have to see stats in my face, even with it already sound. The achievements themselves being lesser in kill counts for weapons than before, making it much more tolerable and faster to get through. Having the addition of game music, such as the main menu theme, the match-starting theme and the victory themes are quite nice for a game jingle. Plus the addition of custom theme tracks you can get for your client.Cons of the game: The match-making system for Competitive having constant flaws. Competitive players you can come across in 80% of random matches being complete idiots and / or trolls, as well as those who try to get the whole team to surrender from a 'bad start' at the beginning of a game itself - even if you're carrying to give a worthwhile chance. To put it simple; the majority of games have players who are absolutely horrendous at listening to team tactics, then can also try kicking you thinking they’re a 'top-gun', when in reality they’re the ones who suck. Basically; you never got this in CS:S, as everyone knew the usual play of routine and worked together. In this it just seems to have gone right out the window. There's still players you will come across who hack and use aim-bot, walls, etc, legitimately (and not just as some cry out with people hacking since they're actually good). The liberty at least is the game features a player reporting system you can consult while playing, where you can submit a claim for staff to investigate if you feel a player is literally hacking. If they're found guilty; you'll have a confirmation message show up later on your main menu screen that action had been taken against them - most commonly being banned from community servers. As with the Counter-Strike franchise; there shall always be unfortunate hit-box issues - with the all familiar problem of blood splatter appearing on an enemy, yet they have no or hardly any damage rendered at all.Competitive is a joke really. You’re not even getting anything for wins besides a pointless ‘rank’ score (which at that is only effected by your chance of having MVP’s and winning, and not your actual kill / death score as it should be based upon), and if you know you’re good - you’re good. Even getting to 'Legendary Eagle' prior myself, I’m frankly not caring anymore or playing consecutively, as it’s so boring without proper teams of friends like back in CS:S league matches. The 'weapon crates' from the point system you actually have to fork out more than they're worth to open, usually getting something cheap wasting your money.Personal feedback rating: 7.5 out of 10.

This Game will install two Trojans on your PC, flagged by Kaspersky.No wonder why Steam doesn't pick this up, they get patched in during the first game launch.They enable full remote access to your PC on startup. So i hope you don't do any online banking or online shopping on your gaming machine.If you want to get rid of them, get st like revouninstaller that let's you edit the registry and disable the startup. Still not very safe, only way to get rid of them is to reinstall windows.Edit: After some more playtime and reinstalling windows, i can't recommend this game. It is weird to describe but there are so many ups and downs from good to bad. Feels like an Alpha for a mobile port. SO many hidden menus, hidden rewards, tons of feature systems and blinking buttons that make your brain go BRR. Not complete and already full of feature creep.

2023 Great game, best in the entire total war games series. On the PLUS: Huge campaign map, insane number of factions you can play, each feeling different and playing different> Even different starts within the same faction feel different. Overall great game.On the MINUS: Huge game. The learning curve is massively brutal! Playing the 1st and 2nd game before playing this one is basically required. Immortal empires map is the actual game here, however, even if recently the publisher removed the hard requirement for you to own Warhammer I and II in order to play, you still have to own those and DLC in order to play almost all factions. Seeing how many of us own Warhammer I on Epic because we got it free as an old game, it is highly recommended to get this one over on Epic, as ownership does not carry over between Epic and Steam. Sorry Steam!Also, the price tag is just stupid and greedy! 157 eu ON SALE for this full title alone, not to mention the soft requirement to own the old ones and their DLC for the full thing.For this reason alone I do not recommend this title.

2023 As someone who has played the Total War series and was introduced to it through Warhammer 1, it saddens me to see the complete and utter disarray going on with it climactic entry.I've never willingly written a review with the intention to 'review bomb' a title into oblivion as quite often people will do it just because of X,Y or Z reason.However, on this occasion I feel justified in adding my voice to the choir of fans who are tired of simply being used as CA's bottom line to feed their short term monetary gain while being drip fed a patch every several months which tend to break more things than they fix.They say we are listened to but there is no back an forth. Content creators have told them repeatedly about things in the past that the community will end up not liking; they ignore them and push on anyway. They trim down DLC to the bare minimum while increasing the price of it with the excuse of "Everything has went up in price, if you don't buy it, we will kill support for the game." Good luck getting people to purchase your future TW titles with that attitude. Greedy business practises and shareholders have turned the games industry into a money making racket while both developers to an extent and consumers suffer for their greed. Keep the consumer happy and your bank accounts and games will flourish. How many times does this lesson need to be repeated to publishers and studios? It is not my ambition or want to see the TW series or CA close shop. People are employed by them and are trying to make a living. However I cannot in good conscience recommend this game or its DLC content at the current moment in time due to shady, greedy and outright laughably insulting business practises.

2023 EDIT TO PREVIOUS REVIEW: A CHANGE TO POSITIVECA did a great job with the latest DLC. You can tell they actually buckled down on MANY of the common negatives that plagued the game prior.They added value to the DLC. The new packs that came out are really fun. Though I wish a parts of it were complimentary with the game purchase, they did a great job nonetheless. Empire is kind of relevant again, Kislev has a chance of not getting completely steamrolled, hell even Nurgle is fun. They also worked on the good v evil factions in that most of the bad factions will ally with one another, and most of the good factions will align also. Previously if you played say Skaven, you're in a weird spot where no one likes you, good nor bad. It's no longer the case. Good factions also feel relevant again.You can clearly tell they stopped mixing carpet cleaner and bleach at the office parties. Keep up the good work. I've been waiting for the day where I could change my review to positive, and it has finally come.

Product received for free Black Myth: Wukong is not the game that you think it is. The opening is strong, with gorgeous visuals, incredible art direction and mystifying enemy and boss design. The problems begin however when the introduction is over and the real game begins. Black Myth Wukong dresses itself as an RPG but this is only superficial. In reality, Black Myth Wukong is a Boss Rush. There's very little downtime between boss fights, often moving directly from one fight into another. When there is something in-between, the game offers only linear levels with nothing in the way of exploration.That's not to say that the game isn't entirely without merit. Visually the game is a feast for the eyes, and the music and sound design are top quality. The combat system is as visually pleasing as it is mechanically deep, there's an array of skills, spells, transformations, items and equipment at the players disposal.However, this variety is hampered by the totally linear progression, armour and weapons are not found in the game world, they are unlocked in the shop after an arbitrary amount of progress has been made. Likewise for spells and skills which are only unlocked after specific points of the story. This leaves the game severely lacking in player agency, there's no decision making in where to go or in what order you progress the story, each "level" of the game is a beautifully decorated corridor with a boss waiting for you at the end and even within a scant few hours, the shallow game-play loop becomes immediately apparent. The boss rush nature of the game falls flat without the framing behind it. Bosses that have fantastic visual design have no framing within the story, there's little to no lore or explanation behind the enemies you're facing and it can leave you erratically jumping from one quirky boss fight to another with a feeling of disconnect. Without this framing, the significance of the boss is lost and what could have been a grandiose fight becomes a pedestrian affair, each boss becomes just another box to tick on your road to the end of the game.Black Myth: Wukong is a spectacle, for sure, but it feels like it's using that spectacle as a crutch to distract from how little depth there to the gameplay, it feels like all of the mechanics of a good RPG were created, they just forgot to create the world to go with it.

2022 I have been an avid Total War fan for about 20 years. There are only 2 titles in the entire franchise I would not recommend, Attila, and this one. I was first turned off by the blatant money grubbery of the DLC's containing content already in the game, just not usable by the player until you pay. No big deal, I just wont pay. 20 dollars for a new faction with 2 new units? Fuh huh hunnnk you.But I digress. Every other Total War game promotes expansion, this one punishes it. Every other Total War game has massive replay potential. This one had next to none. You ask, but hey guy, you have over 200 hours on this game. That means you like it. I am ashamed to say I was forcing myself to play to get achievements and trying to like it. The rift mechanic in the game is the exact same for every faction you play, and it sucks for all of them. First time play through was OK, slightly annoying. After that, when you get a warning the rifts are about to pop, your heart drops as your fun is about to end and the prostate exam is about to begin.If you are new to the series do not be turned off by this. Get 3 kingdoms, Warhammer 1 or 2 instead. Troy is a very simple version good for new players. Do not pay for the overpriced DLC's. It just makes it seem OK in their eyes, and they will keep doing it.This game may be worth it when the Immortal Empires DLC comes out. Should give you the ability to turn off the rift mechanic and just play Total War.

Game looks very nice. The campaign is only about 10h but multiplayer will add a lot of game time. But there is some severe problems with that part. Hacking is rampant in PvP and ive seen some in PvE, and for some reason there is no report button, and devs dont seem to take it seriously. Which is unfortunate because its hurting the game greatly.There is also some balancing issue with the game. Some mechanic require some locked animation to happen like gunstrikes. The problem is that you cant move while it happens, takes a few seconds and you dont have any invisibility frames during that time. You will die often because of this. There is also ranged enemies, that will spam shoot without end through other enemies and walls. Your armor is very weak and you dont have a lot of health. In the right circumstances, you can execute a gunstrike (being locked in animation) and have a bunch a small range enemies shoot at you and its game over. Gunstrike will also happen by mistake sometime. You are punished for using game mechanics and I dont know if that will be patched yet, as the only thing the devs released was a fix to spread core usage (game was only using like 5 cores and would BSOD your PC from the main menu for some).I do think there is a solid game here, but its apparent that the devs didnt test most of it before releasing, creating all these small problems that adds up to a bad experience sometimes. I will change my review if they ever decide to speak up and fix these issue.

2014 一群人 一个青春 一个游戏 一辈子 CSGO Forever.- IEM ESL KATOWICE 2016- INTEL CHALLENGE KATOWICE 2016- DREAMHACK DALLAS 2019- DREAMHACK SHOWDOWN VALENCIA 2019第一次看比赛是14的科隆Major，15年初我开始在斗鱼转播国外高清的比赛。那时候主播很少，妹子也没有。虽然看不太懂，但是就是觉得很好看。每天半夜四点爬起来转播比赛，用着小银条的技术给大家“解说”。观看的人很多，弹幕被刷的满满的，想想就超级激动。还记当时直播的是15年卡托，Fnatic拿的冠军。那天yicofan也在qq里和直播间里跟我通宵看了一场。已经不再怎么玩游戏的我，一辈子都没有想到...整整一年后我和yicofan站在了卡托维兹的决赛舞台前看比赛那个画面，真的一辈子都忘不了。。。特别的感谢港姐Hazel 两次邀请我一起出去比赛没有你们我也不会有这样终身难忘的体验因为CSGO相识后面基的好友：榛子Hazel，曾哥Yicofan，大眼睛，维维Timing，乔阿姨大哥SAGA，大橙子，小鱼儿tingtian，普京, 毛毛虫MMC, HFFO， 鬼妹Leo, Mayz坐等面基喜+1

2022 ELDEN RING SOULS LIKE FOR EVERYONE What I learned in 50 hours. - During this time, I realized that this is one of the BEST games in its genre! It has all the good mechanics from the old From Software games, and most importantly - the jump to a separate button (Thanks to Miyazaki!). The game has a good balance between weapon classes for pve (not tested pvp). In fact, you can play with what you like. Game Bosses As a plus, I can also include story bosses, they are diverse and not pretentious (suitable for the style of the game). There is little that I can say about optional ones, there are too many of them and they are repeated and boring, the same Erdtree Avatar, of which there are too many, but that doesn't stop you from enjoying the game. The game has bosses for anyone, ranging from junk (Tibia Mariner and the like), ending with Malenia, because of which the game was abandoned a lot, without passing it. The world and its content The world of Elden's ring is beautiful and large, but mostly empty. You will have to run a lot here, but you can find some kind of dungeon with loot and a boss while you are going through the story, this kept me in the game. I love to explore the worlds in these games. For me, as a new player in this genre (before that, ds3 passed, a month before the release of Elden Ring), I was very pleased with the presence of an open world, when avid players of the series criticized the developer for something I don’t understand. In terms of the content of the game world, there is a lot of it, wherever I go, find a new cave, a new boss, a friendly NPC, and the like.storyline of Elden ring (No spoilers) As part of the plot, I will say one thing, I did not understand anything, you need to read the description of objects, read the dialogue between the lines. In general, he is confused, as Miyazaki loves. But it's worth it, at least once to go through the game. Result As a result, I want to say that the developers have done a great job on the game, so I recommend that every gamer go through it, regardless of the fact that he is casual or true hardcore! 10/10

2022 Highlighted keywords in bold so you can skip or read parts of your concern.*UPDATE* 20/04/22 - There is now an option to disable camera auto centering. This is a huge deal for KB/mouse players.tl;dr Pros - Art Direction Variety of unique boss battles and even regular mobs. Just the sheer amount of content, explorable areas, variety of weapons, items, etc. Challenging without feeling unfair 99.99% of the time. Variety of viable builds. Everything in this game including your character's chest hair has a hidden lore behind it.tl;dr Cons - PC Port is extremely lacking. Graphics options doesn't seem to change performance much at all. Feels like a lazy port. Mouse and KB aren't being utilised to their fullest potential, I suspect, to match the limitations of a controller. Leads to some weird and unintuitive controls if you're playing on mouse and KB. (played on both, slightly prefer mouse/KB more) Camera needs some improvement. Wiki/youtube is an essential part of doing some quests. It would be near impossible to figure out what to do in certain side quests on your own on a regular playthrough. Co-op and PvP could be improved, but it's passable.tl;dr Conclusion -Despite the flaws, I think it's still a masterpiece. Game needs a good CPU to get playable FPS. It might be intimidating at first if you've never played a previous souls title like me, but it's definitely a rewarding experience. Definitely recommend buying, you will not regret it. If you're new to the series, try not to screw up your build early on and put some points into vigor if you don't wanna have a miserable time.PC Specific Pros and Cons -I've played on both controller and keyboard/mouse for a fair amount of time. And since it's a review for PC version of a game, I think it's important to talk about KB/mouse implementation. It's much easier and faster to look around on mouse than it is on controller, so you can look around and avoid attacks of colossal/large bosses easier. However there's an annoying auto centering which can't be disabled, so you will be constantly fighting the camera as you move. You also can't use all the on your keyboard and some weird keybindings like "G" key for map are set by default and cannot be changed. You also can't set any key you want for item wheel/secondary item wheel like you would expect on a PC game. You need to use from a limited selection of keys/key combination for primary and secondary item wheel which is really unintuitive if you're playing on KB and mouse and you will find it hard to set up comfortable key configurations due to weird limitations. You will settle for some weird keybindings at the end inevitably. You also can't bind spells and incantation to specific keys. I suspect these are all intentional design choice made to match the controller limitations. I highly dislike these limitation and don't think it's justified to artificially handicap you for playing on a certain platform and not using the platform's fullest potential instead. More than anything, they're just annoying to deal with and I don't expect these to be changed. A lot of the performance issues seem to stem from Easy Anti Cheat from what I've seen.General Pros -The art direction is easily the best part of the game. A lot of the scenary looks like they're straight out of a painting. Pretty much every build type seems viable, except maybe bows and crossbows. You might have to adapt for certain fights if you're playing a mage or a strength/slow attack build but other than that, everything should be viable. Most of the boss design is also great, none of them feel like a throwaway boss design. Speaking of bosses, all of the bosses have unique movesets that you have to learn how to dodge, avoid, etc. 99.99% of them doesn't feel like they're unfair once you get the hang of the game. There are so many locations to explore including a whole underground area, caves, catacombs, dungeons and so many hidden areas/missions/things to find. You will not be disappointed by the amount of content in the game, that's for sure. Also for people that are complaining that the game's too hard and/or wanting an easy mode, there abosultely is easy mode in this game. Spirit summons, AI summons and even multiplayer summons all make the game basically easy mode, if utilised properly. So I think it's unfair to call the game "too hard", the game does give you an option to choose the difficulty you wanna play in. If you don't like certain gameplay mechanic or system, there's always a workaround. I personally think the freedom of choice the game provides is excellent. I'm split on the music, while some of them are absolutely epic (Godskin Apostle, Morgott, Radagon), most of the themes aren't memorable past the fight and the ambient music is lackluster.General Cons -Camera is probably the worst part of souls games. It's inexcusable that after so many years/games, the devs still haven't figured out how to make proper a camera system. A lot of the deaths will be due to you not being able to see where you are on the environment/where the boss is/what move the boss is performing. The camera tracking is poor when locked on, it's too slow to turn around if you aren't locked on due to auto centering. There's input queuing in the game, which is fine for the most part and I get it's there to stop people from spamming buttons. But what I don't get is, when you are trying to dodge an enemy attack but get caught in it, due to input queue, the game will make you dodge roll AFTER you get hit and recover, which leads to you getting hit by a follow up attack a lot of the times and maybe even dying. I don't understand why you should be punished after being punished once already. It creates a lot of frustrations especially since dodge on this game happens on button release so there's already a few millisecond delay from when you tried to dodge roll initially. It's especially noticeable in fast paced fights. A lot of the side quests are impossible to do it on your own without looking up what to do or where to go on wiki/youtube. For example, one side quest requires you to find hidden stairs at a different part of the map (that will reveal itself when hit) in order to proceed. Not to mention, the map in this game is massive so finding out what to do on your own for some quests is practically impossible on a regular playthrough. I know it's a design choice but if it's something that you would not enjoy, it's worth keeping in mind. IMO a decent solution for it would be an optional journal feature like in skyrim that gives you some hints, that way you can completely ignore or look at it if you just wanna get done with the quest and play on your own without looking for external guides. If you're looking to buy this game for co-op reasons, I'd suggest looking into how co op works before you buy. Co-op is quite limited and not straight forward as you'd expect. There's also invasions in co-op where other players will try to kill you if you're in a co-op party. It might be a pro or a con depending on what you might be looking for. PvP is... passable. It's not the most balanced thing ever or anything but it's ok.Conclusion - Flaws of this game aren't so great that they invalidate the experience. I think it's definitely worth the full price. Even if you're new to souls games(like me), you will definitely enjoy the game. Definitely a GOTY contender. With all that said, I do hope the devs iron out the issues facing the PC version.

Spreadsheet simulator My experience so far is that if i hammer&anvil a t3 unit, i'm wasting my time, since it's not going to break anyways, even with cycle charging.Hell, even t1 units will hold through the first two or three rear charges. Nothing ever routs or dies.The AI is content to stand still at the worst position in the entire map, when it is on the defensive, even if there is better ground easily available to it. That doesn't really impact the game much though, because momentum doesn't impact the effectiveness of your charges, and once you've actually closed into melee, the difference of what is high ground and not, is minuscule. Not to mention that even for gunpowder infantry, Line of Sight is just a gentle suggestion. All this together means that Instead of asking you to make the most of where you put your units, the game instead asks you to make the most of the unit matchups, with not only the basics rock-paper-scissors of swords>spears>cav, but actually a whole web of interactions of armor, armor-piercing, magic attacks, regenerating/fire attacks, anti-large, poison attacks, and probably more that i don't know about yet. It's complex, but i don't know that there is actually that much depth to it. Maybe i'll find it later, but while starting out, it's just a knowledge check, instead of more intuitive mechanics, like positioning will be.Then there's the ridiculous power of lords, and heroes that significantly reduces the value of well commanded units, as their unit size means they are fairly agnostic to being surrounded, and just become a stat-block with abilities that you gotta eat through. The spells also generally are more disruptive of good tactics than they can help facilitate them. They further push everything to being blobs of stat-blocks being crunched together. Same goes for artillery: because it's powerful enough that you can't ignore it, it pushes you towards engaging the enemy as soon as possible, meaning you aren't really allowed to have an extended skirmish phase.Also, on a personal preference, it feels like ranged units areeither outputing too much damage, or are too sturdy. The advantage ofthe majority of the units not being able to hit you back is alreadyenough incentive to bring ranged units.Come to think of it, there isn't actually a single core battle system i actually like the design of. Individual units, or faction mechanics, sure, but not the core systems.

Hard to believe that this is the developer's first major work.This is all around a pretty great game, with very well telegraphed enemies and lots of fun to be had. While the game borrows quite a bit from the typical souls-like formula, it manages to distinguish itself enough to offer a unique experience. The game also has a way heavier focus on boss fights, more than you might expect. In fact, at times, it wouldn't be a stretch to call it a borderline boss-rush, as you can sometimes face one boss right after another with barely a minute in between. Theres also the visuals. Honestly, I'm not sure if this even needs to be said, but the overall visual presentation is unquestionably among the best in the medium, just make sure to turn off the god awful framegen. Despite that, the game somehow runs pretty well.Probably the most frustrating aspect of the game so far are invisible walls, which are quite plentiful, fairly disappointing considering i thought those kind of things were left in the PS3 era, but not a huge issue on its own. So far, theres not much else i dislike about the game.Overall, this is very good stuff, and easily worth the full price tag.
2023 Making Immortal Empires available for all owners of Total War: Warhammer III was a great call. There's no better time to get into this game than now.

2022 The Short: I didn’t really think what everyone was clamoring for was the Ubisoft-ification of Dark Souls. The Long: Pros-Jump Button?-Music-Horse Combat (mostly)*-Fun*-Addictive*Cons-Shockingly Laggy-Movement is Jank-The world seems very empty-Stamina consumption feels random-Graphics are often ugly and washed out-Ditches many of the better systems from previous games-Walked back some of the better ideas from the Network Tests-Flailing*-You need the wiki*-Where did my legs go?*- Why did my monitor stop working?*- It Crashed again* Mostly it’s Dark Souls 3, but bigger and with extra tat tacked on, and yet somehow the whole thing feels a bit cheap. It’s a big, mostly empty open world with dodgy traversal mechanics. The few hours I played were mostly hiding in bushes collecting flowers. The new sneaking around can be fun in an Assassins Creed way, but in the one camp I found, enemies tend to be in line of site of one another and the backstab is slow enough to leave you open. From what little I saw you can’t really build a character around stealth. Before too long I found a gatehouse where the archer can spot you through cover and bosses/ boss adjacent monsters really won’t let you get away with it like in the aforementioned Ubisoft sandboxes. Really, the game is done no favors comparing it to Assassins Creed as it’s often a very ugly game. Assets pop in, creatures disappear, and all the colors feel very washed out. That’s not uncommon for From Software games but from the character creation screen it looked like a marked improvement over DS3. Sadly, in game models are low rez, with larger ones having hard corners that show the limited poly count. Many assets seem to be copy pasted giving the whole experience a very cheap feel. Not helped by the fact that the Prolog is a Slideshow. Makes me wonder what could be causing all the lag. I don’t mind dyeing in a Souls game, but when lag keeps killing me, I’m gonna be a bit cross. It’s very odd too, I have a pretty high end PC and can run much, much better looking games on ultra without issue. The early on, supposed to loose fight, bugged out so badly that the thing faded to black before I took any damage. It stayed that way long enough that I thought it had crashed, until I saw the loading symbol… for an uncomfortably long time. That alone would be an issue worth waiting for a patch to buy, but the controls are janky too. There didn’t seem to be analog sensitivity adjustment; so had to keep switching out controllers until I found one that didn’t interrupt me walking across the room in a straight line. How could this have happened, they nailed this before? Yeah, so, the elephant in the room here is Sekiro(not just Sekiro, but we’ll get to that). Traversal, Stealth and combat improvements miles above any of the Souls games were all there, but they ditched them for some reason. I’m not saying we needed a Grappling Hook, but why make the jumps so awkward and imprecise? All the low ledges and walls seem to encourages jumping, but it’s very unclear as to what can be vaulted over. Like Sekiro It does embrace the idea that movement doesn’t consume stamina, sort of. It does when you’re in combat, though that can be somewhat academic due to the poor stealth system and other factors I couldn’t place. Sekiro also nailed parrying, blocking and Dodging. And by that I mean they were balanced enough so that they were all useful. The Perilous Attacks system was a spectacular way to engage foes. Unlike most Soulsborn games you really had to parry. Yet for some reason we are, for the most part, back to Dark Souls 3 style block, dodge and Parries so inexact your better off not bothering. Reviews keep saying it’s a culmination of all From Software has learned, but it’s seems more like a pick-n-mix of middling ideas. Even if you didn’t want to pull from Sekiro for the combat why ignore the other games? The only presence from Dark Souls 2 seems to be the double weapons, nice to have, but hardly that game’s best feature. They seem to keep doing this, Dark Souls was great for it’s time, but Dark Souls 2 and Bloodborn greatly refined the formula. Yet Dark Souls 3 seems to have contained none of what made those games better, and here again. Here as in DS3 we are awash in samey Weapons, I though BB taught you a dozen well designed weapons are better then way, way too many swords. Parrying especially needed to look to these three titles. DS2 made nigh everything Parryable and gave you a big window to counter, BB made parrying at range possible and Sekiro made it fluid enough that it was always a strong option. Here we’re back to DS3’s parrying is here but blocking or dodging is still more viable. In truth this game is proof to me they failed to learn from themselves, but they’re not even looking to what their peers have done. During the Network Tests leveling Strength gave you the ability to wear heavier armor, as in the Nioh games(which let mutable stats dictate this), but they switch it back to only Endurance granting more carry weight. Why? It makes more sense for the Strength based character to have heavier armor. Strength scaling Weapons often have slower windups and longer punishes, as a result you may have to soak a hit to land a blow. It was a good idea; it had been proven to work in other Souls-Like games and they cut it out. On that note, where’s the Rallying system got to? That was such a great feature I’ve seen it crop up in many other games. Is it hidden somewhere in this overstuffed mess? I could go on, I played this game for about five hours and while it felt longer than that, I don’t think I really got anywhere. In point of fact, I think I’ve already gone on too long, but it’s all kind of moot as my primary issue is that; it’s just kinda boring. I mean, haven’t we been here before? I’ve never started a new From Software game and within hour I’m reaching for a podcast. I want more Sekiro, more Bloodborn, heck I’d even take more Dark Souls 2, but just don’t want whatever this is. *Update After many hours I did get into it, the horse combat helped as it is, largely, very fun. But everything comes with a caveat. The mounted sections are good until you get arbitrarily knocked off your alpaca. Now that is admittedly annoying, but what’s worse is there’s nothing you can do about it. There’s no barding you can equip on your beast and while the game says putting points into Dexterity helps keep you from falling off, I’m at 60 Dex and I don’t see much difference. Also, it would only sort of mater if there was a huge difference as you can’t, as far as I can tell, actively do anything to increases your fluffy friends HP. Getting knocked off your horse is often instant death as you just lie on the ground for an age waiting to be mauled. It’s not unlike you’ve had the controller torn from your hand and it is held out of reach until you are ether killed or are obscenely low on health. And just to put a cherry on the alpaca manure Sunday, when your fine beasty does inevitably die, you have to use a health potion to revive them... by way of a menu prompt asking “Are you sure you want to bring your only chance of survival back from the dead at the megger cost of one of your many, easily replenished items?”. Yeah, I’m pretty forking sure Elden Ring, except don’t bother, because I died battling with your superfluous text box, again. Keeping with caveats the bosses are often quite fun, despite their copy paste nature, but some just won’t let up. I’d say learn their pattern, but that only maters if they ever take a break. Dark Souls 2 got critisised for having too many foes per encounter, but I’ll take that over half of them having a HYPER COMBO. By far your best option is to find your favorite utterly broken Spell, Consumable, Ash of War, etc(there’s no shortage) and use it as a crutch when the game decides to change the ru

2022 Huge improvements compared to W2 and new gameplay mechanics both in campaign and on the battlemap makes this a huge recommendations. There are of course early bugs and optimization issues but I have full confidence CA will address every single one of these and the game will be polished in short order due to CA's record of interaction and communication with the fans. The game in its current state is still fun regardless of the current bugs and I have no doubt I will be putting 100's of hours into it.

2022 I can now confidently recommend Warhammer III.The release of Immortal Empires has reduced many of the issues with the Realm of Chaos campaign and the newly added factions and lords have a significantly improved Realm of Chaos experience. That said, it's still unfortunate that the base game factions have such a disappointment Realm of Chaos experience and I'd like to see more iteration on that front, though I suspect this will have to wait until future lord releases for each faction.The game still has many bugs, but they are much less of an issue than before. Settlement battles still have significant issues, but a reduction in the sizes of garrisons combined with the removal of minor settlement battles in most situations has made this a relatively minor irritation. That said, this is still an area that Creative Assembly needs to address at some point. The Immortal Empires experience brings Warhammer III up to the quality of Warhammer II. It should be noted this is over a year from when the game initially launched, which is a significant problem. It should also be noted that the team responsible for the initial Warhammer III experience is separate from the team that has made the most progress in bringing the game up to par. I find this a little concerning for future titles, but it does mean that Warhammer III is in great hands.The Warriors of Chaos DLC was a fantastic addition to the game, creating new mechanics that open up exciting possibilities for future revamps and future titles from Creative Assembly. I didn't think it was possible, but the Chaos Dwarf DLC is also an expansion of mechanics that expands the horizon for what's possible in a Total War game. It's a little expensive, but it is the most well developed faction added to the Total War Warhammer franchise to date across all 3 titles.The game is in a really solid space right now and I think there's a lot to look forward to in the future.

2022 As probably many have said before me, this game was not, and is still not, in a fit state to launch.Whilst some head-scratching design choices for the campaign will hopefully be eliminated with the introduction of the "Immortal Empires", the problem with the game runs far deeper.Units are unresponsive (even after the "massive update" released a few weeks back), and will often run in a completely different direction to the one ordered - this is extremely visible on the new (and, imo, not very enjoyable) settlement battles, where the map designers don't seem to have ever played a game of total war before, but can also happen on an open map, where a unit will walk in the wrong direction and then refuse to move or take any orders for the rest of the battle.Also, missile units will often not fire when enemy units are in range, would randomly swap target from the order given.The fact the game was released in this state shows an utter contempt for the consumer.I have a general rule of never pre-ordering, which I've broken twice recently. And both times (this game and cyberpunk), I've been reminded that you can't trust that a developer's previous work will be any indication of a future product. Executive greed and disrespect for their paying customers is, sadly, just too prevalent in the gaming industry.

At first when I saw the trailer to the game, I thought that Space Marine 2 looked like an amazing game, but due to the track record of modern games being released broken, I was extremely hesitant to pre-ordering the game, however, the more and more I looked at it and heard more and more conversations about it, it wasn't until Sept. 3rd that I finally succumbed to finally pre-ordering the Ultra Edition just so that I could experience the game for myself and not worry about what others tell me. Go big or go home, right?Space Marine 2 was the best pre-order I could have ever spent my money on. Even though this is a pre-release review, and there are some minor bugs here and there, Sabre still has time to polish whatever minor bugs there are before the 9th when the game is fully released.As is now, Space Marine 2 feels like a 1.0 game even during the pre-release. Every 1.0 game known to man has always had it's fair share of minor bugs, and so does this game, but they're only minor at best. No game breaking bugs, or anything! I can absolutely say that this game is a solid 10/10 no matter how I look at it. Great job Sabre Interactive and Focus Entertainment!Disclaimer: Space Marine 2 is a big game in terms of size and performance requirements. Please, do not read this review and bomb it, knowing that your rig may not be the best. Please reed the specs list for this game before you play it, as this game may cause rendering issues with lower end equipment. Note: The GTX 1060 and the RX 580 are the BARE MINIMUM GPUs that you should be running this game with! Anything lower, and you WILL experience rendering issues during gameplay and cutscenes! User discretion is advised!

2022 Builds upon the formula of Dark Souls III with new ways to approach combat such as sneaking, jumping, and mounted combat. The world is huge, with lots of interesting enemies and NPCs to encounter. Replay value will likely be a strong point for this game as there are plenty of new spells and weapons. Some animations and assets have been recycled from previous games, but there is enough new stuff to make it feel like a new experience. Performance can be rough at times, though the team has been rolling out patches to mitigate these issues. Co-op seems to be basically copied from Dark Souls III, except the item used to host a session is much easier to obtain. I'd really like to see them make some design improvements allowing for players to co-op in an area even after the boss has been defeated, similar to the small white soapstone in Dark Souls II. Overall, I've had a lot of fun with the game so far, and expect to experiment with new builds in New Game+ for many hours.

Fantastic Combat Variety with Improved AI (Updated)Space Marines 2 excels in both ranged and melee combat. The game offers a vast array of guns with tons of customization options, allowing you to create unique gun builds to suit your playstyle—yes, there are actual gun builds! This variety, combined with smooth shooting mechanics, adds a lot of depth and fun to combat, keeping things fresh as you tweak and experiment with your loadouts.The melee combat is equally impressive. The game features three distinct types of defense: Block, Balanced, and Fencing. Blocking lets you absorb damage but doesn’t allow for parrying. Balanced offers a mix of blocking and parrying, while Fencing skips blocking altogether, giving you a larger window for perfect parries. Mastering these systems, especially Balanced or Fencing, turns you into a true killing machine in close quarters.The game also shines in its horde-style combat. You'll face a wide variety of enemy types, each with their own fighting style. For example, you might find yourself swarmed by small minions while an elite enemy locks onto you. This adds layers of strategy and intensity. The health system might seem a bit confusing at first, but it consists of both actual character health, which can be lost, and "Contested" health, represented by a white bar. To regain health, you have to fight over this contested health, which can deplete quickly or slowly depending on the situation. You'll also unlock skills that not only enhance your abilities but also provide buffs for your team.While the game is on the shorter side, clocking in at around 7-12 hours depending on your difficulty setting, it’s still a blast to play. The AI has improved significantly, with your teammates now fighting properly and no longer being ignored by the enemy. They’ll also prioritize reviving you when you’re downed, adding more balance to solo play.Overall, Space Marines 2 is excellent, and I hope the devs continue to update and add more content. I’d love to see them take a page from Darktide and make the missions and customization feel more fleshed out.

The Warhammer Game We Have Been Waiting For. But, Space Marine 2 is an amazing game and excellent entry to the Warhammer 40k series. Most of us know that GOOD Warhammer games are hard to come by. Many games were hit and miss & eventually faded away to time. But, this entry to the series in my honest opinion is going to be what puts this amazing series on the map more than ever. New and Seasoned fans are going to be in for a delight as they mow their way through the Tyranid filth & Expel the heretical chaos cults. It has been so long since we felt this way. Warhammer fans rejoice. This game offers something to scratch the needs of almost all players. Looking for a campaign? We got it . Looking for a PVE co-op experience? We got it . Looking for a PVP experience? We got it . Rejoice! Games Workshop finally did something good! Took them a while if you ask me. Huge shout-out to saber. Now for the heresy. As good as the game is. It is far from perfect, this game has a lot of inconsistencies and missing features that I would've not come to expect in a title such as this. So I will try my best to break it down & be honest. ( I am a long time warhammer fan ) for reference. The Campaign The campaign is good but, its not great. It feels like they wanted to combine God Of War & Dark-tide. But ultimately it fell a tad short based on my opinion. For such a series packed to the BRIM with lore and amazing characters. I felt like a-lot was missing from the experience. The voice-acting felt a bit complacent and dull. Some moments where good, some moments where bad. Overall I felt a inconsistent experience. A-lot of the WOW factor starts to wear off pretty quickly. Once you experience it a few times. It starts losing its touch real fast. The Co-op Now Space Marine 2 has two different co-op experiences that it can offer. The co-op campaign & the operations mode. The Co-op campaign is as much as you'd expect from this game. Its fun, moderately paced & great with friends. Operations mode feels like it lacks quite a-lot of repeatability. Every mission is the same with the only change being where you grab an objective off a corpse. There is no "modifiers" or anything else that you can think of to keep a fresh experience or, a less bland one. The only variation you get is your classes and armors. That's all. To me, thats a HUGE let-down. Warhammer: Dark-tide offers more variation in one mission then all the operation missions do combined. Thats a big oof if you ask me. I don't ever really feel like running those missions more than once its really worth my time as it becomes boring and repetitive quite quickly. Truly is a shame as I feel like the selling point for this game was its operations mode. The Versus Mode Ok, if you're looking for call of duty, wrong game. If you're looking for Counter Strike, wrong game. If you're looking for laggy servers, unbalanced classes, unbalanced weapons & bugged multiplayer search lobbies. You're in the right place. The versus mode in this game is heresy. It is the work of a champion of chaos. It is totally a mess, borderline unplayable and just not fun at all. The entire versus experience feels rushed and un-polished. Why is a bulwark in my lobby tanking bullets from 5 different marines shooting directly at him? No idea. But, i don't think that's good design in a PVP scenario. Why does sniper deal almost no damage? No idea. Why would anyone even try to play the jetpack marine just to get instantly shot out of the sky? No idea. all in all, the versus is actually the worst part of the game. I can not recommend against it enough. It is really the worst part to this game and feels rushed and an absolute joke to say the least about it. Don't play it. The servers are horrible, the weapons are unbalanced and frankly some classes just don't belong there. PLEASE DO NOT PLAY IT FOR YOUR SAKE LOL. Achievements Why is there no achievement for beating the game on Angel Of Death. Do you know hard that is. And you mean to tell me there is no recognition for it? Nice. All in all its a great game. Most definitely the one of the best in the series since Soulstorm, Dark crusade, Vermentide, Dark-tide. But, if you payed $89 or $100 for this game. You 100% just got scammed for the lack of content and replayability this game currently offers. I really hope this game gets more and more beef on its bones as time moves on but for now. Get ready for an experience you're only going to feel one time and never come back to again because there is nothing to keep you playing. The Emperor Protects!

2022 Quick summary first I've played every game from Fromsoft starting with dark souls and I view BB as the best, I have roughly 1400 hours across the series and have done everything in this game. Elden Ring fails as a souls game and it is with this opinion I would not recommend, despite that it could be a great open-world game. it has fantastic visuals and the world is interesting (sometimes) but it has awful repetitive bosses, copy-pasted enemies with different coats of paint, zero direction for the player, a useless crafting system and unrewarding exploration.The story is easily missable as the exposition dump character only appears at certain graces and only if you notice the talk to her button appeared. I normally don't have an issue with the story in these games as the environment and item descriptions do the telling but not knowing why I need to become the Elden lord or how the world got the way it did kinda sapped my motivation which consisted of exploring and find a new thing. From what I can tell its the same thing as dark souls with fire being integral, big trees, and really boring naming convention (Eld, Erd, every name starts with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ M. Seriously we have Marika, Mohg, Mohgwyn, Malenia, Melina, Miquela, Millicent, Miriel) and runes instead of souls.Not having a scooby where to go is par for the course with the series but is exponentially worse with the open-world as the graces only point towards the nearest lord, not the medallion you might need, some legacy dungeons are horrific Stormveil comes to mind, I couldn't imagine being a new player and experiencing that fresh hell as the game encourages you to go there first instead of the nice southern area to get +3 tears, having three secret areas within itself is some dumb design the consecrated snowfields, the Haligtree and the blood area can be missed despite the fact they each hold one of the lord bosses that drops a great rune.The reward for exploring is pitiful see that item behind the illusionary wall and protected by a hard mob? It's a crafting flower that has an infinite respawn area. You just killed a hard boss? Useless ash summon for you. 90% of the armour I had was farmed by enemies or bought from merchants.I honestly think dark souls 2 has a better enemy variety which was lambasted as "dudes in armour", in this game when I go to a different area it is the exact same knights and footsoldiers in different coloured armour and composition of allies. I get that some enemies have to be reused but seriously I should not see them in every area, oh and some reskinned mobs from previous games make a visit like the demi-humans are reskinned monkeys from Sekiro.The world looks phenomenal especially the underground environments like Nokron despite some goofy stuff that might be a reference but takes me out of it like the Nights Cavalry aka Nazgul, Godfrey Joestar, Blaidd who is literally guts.The crafting system brings nothing of value to the formula, I think I crafted one stack of arrows and an item discovery boost as arrows can be bought and are of better quality, buildup resist items were never necessary, firebombs and the myriad of variants were borderline useless as hitting the thing with a stick is quicker and less likely to get you punished for missing. Usable items only challenge runs should be more interesting now.The bosses are horrific, there are multiple slightly beefed up mobs with a health bar and name, gank fights happen too often to artificially pump up the difficulty, some bosses are too big for their arenas so you fight the camera (tree spirits suck), some can fly so high you can't see them so dragons consist of "please dive bomb me, don't breathe fire". Most unique bosses have fast high damage attacks, glue-like tracking, multiple distance closing attacks, most standard attacks have AOE effects (think twin princes overhead from DS3 or Lawrence from BB), some form of delayed attack like the nameless king. Now can you see the issue? Bosses went from most of the time playing on similar rules as the player as big weapon = long reach + big damage - slow even Bloodborne to a lesser extent understood this like Ludwig, AOE attacks used to be limited to 1 attack that had an easy tell, a fast backhand attack would do little damage but now borderline one taps even if you overleveled vigour. Not a single boss was enjoyable no memorable greats like O&S, Artorias, Gwyn, Maria or Friede, Gael, Soul of Cinder, Genchiro, Fume Knight, Ludwig. I went through this game praying for a good boss and the closest I got was Malenia who while fast and stupidly hard-hitting felt fair until she spammed one bs attack, killing her was pure luck that she never used that move. Every other souls game I looked forward to the next boss and learning the fight like a dance, now it was sheer dread as to what flavour of Lawrence will kill me this time? With Bloodborne being my favourite game high speed gameplay is what I love but this game suffers for it as you don't have the mobility to keep up with the bosses.Apparently, the optimisation is also rubbish worked fine with me but your mileage may vary.This game was not meant for solo players it was very clearly designed around co-op and spamming ash summons which goes against everything I knew about the series. I honestly do not want to play it again unlike the others where I was excited for NG+. Now because I went against the almighty Miyazaki I expect to see a shill in the comments hitting me with "git gud" or "you have x hours how can you not recommend" please do not disappoint me.

2022 PrefaceElden Ring marks two occasions that are worth mentioning. First, I will be changing my review format from this point on, as the previous format I've used for the last two years does not do games of this caliber justice. Second, Elden Ring has arguably been a firm reminder to gamers of past, present, and future generations that a Renaissance of sorts is long overdue in the gaming industry. Plagued by predatory practices by AAA companies marked by endless greed and exploitation of the general public, the gaming industry as it stands today has been decaying since the late 2000s. I believe Elden Ring, along with a handful of other games, has begun to slowly but surely lead us into another golden era of gaming, which we need now more than ever.Note: Although I 100%-ed the game (in terms of achievements) on my main character within roughly 82 hours, this review was delayed because I wanted to see at least 4 other classes/builds to truly see all that the game has to offer.PositivesBest Open World to DATE- No loading screens, vast world to explore without disruption, and most importantly all executed with ZERO bugs. The moment I walk into certain areas and come to the realization of how big the world actually is, I find myself in awe every few hours. Genuine WTF momentsClass balance- Versatile and large number of classes to choose from, but without any hard restrictions so that players can engage the world however they see fit with appropriate attribute allocation, spell memories, ash of war loadouts, and equipment.Mounted CombatI never thought mounted combat would ever feel better than when I played Witcher 3, but Elden Ring has taken it to another level. Feels so good to just drag around the Zweihander across the ground and throw enemies into the air.Attention to Detail- Many open world games like to disguise themselves as detail-oriented, but Elden Ring has set a new bar. Every nook and cranny is accessible, only invisible walls are locked behind Stone Keys unlike other games that "block you out" for no reason.Open Exploration & QuestingWe've all most likely heard the news about other open-world game devs throwing shade at Elden Ring for not spoon-feeding the players, but I'm definitely on the side that supports Elden Ring's breaking of the status quo. Freedom to explore and right to choose are fundamental factors that make the experience unique and memorable. Companies like Ubisoft have gotten far too content with their design tendencies.DifficultyThis one is the big one. Elden Ring has virtually perfected the art of allowing players to literally choose how difficult the game becomes, from a scale of 0-100. It's such an ingenious move to say "Hey, here's the first story boss. Either go as you are now with starting gear or come back after clearing some dungeons and beefing yourself up a bit." How can you complain about a lack of easy mode at that point?NegativesStorytelling & Lore ExpositionI only have one minor nitpick and this one is most certainly arguable. Personally I find that the FromSoftware games have become more and more vague with their storytelling. This is a different field from my praising their open exploration design. Not to say the lore is bad and I understand to some extent that they like to leave things to open interpretation, but I just wish that they would be a little more revealing in terms of exposing the players to what's going on as they play. There are players like us who are used to interpreting events based on what NPCs tell us with their vague dialogue, but most players (especially those who are new to the Souls-like games) are not too keen on deciphering the story bit by bit. The FromSoftware games are the games that desperately need a Encyclopedia section in the main menu.ConclusionFinal Verdict: S+ 10/10All in all, Elden Ring is a grand masterpiece that justly deserves all the praise. Game of the year. Game of the decade. Let's hope many other companies follow suit. Who said single player games are dead?

2022 UPDATED 8-22: I've been waiting to flip my negative review for a while now. Immortal Empires has turned the ho-hum campaign into the planetwide bloodbath it was meant to be. They've polished up the performance and in two campaigns I've had one crash. Just one. It looks good, it plays good, CA is still dropping content. Did I mention there's something like 280 other nations in game now?First the good - graphics are great and sound design are all top notch, as we all knew they would be. The new map is beautiful, the Chaos Wastes and some of the associated mechanics are interesting. Now time to get past the ego-stroke reviews the media gave this because that's really all the good there is.The new siege mechanics are a nightmare. The old way might have been a slog but instead of just updating city maps (which they did, and they look great) they've added a supply system that lets the defenders build defenses and reinforce units almost indefinitely. Every battle in a walled settlement is now one of those 1990's RTS missions no one likes where one side gets a handful of units while the other gets a fully functional fortress and economy.The campaign is another gimmicky armies-spawning-everywhere-inside-your-borders scenario and some of the battles are just wave after wave of enemies from all sides. I have 2000 hours in Warhammer 2, I struggled to finish the campaign with Kislev on normal. Not one of those good struggles, it's more like passing a kidney stone. I would rather slam my sack in a door than try this on hard+.Hopefully they add the huge Mortal Empires style world map soon. None of the factions from 1&2 are playable in 3 so it's a giant step backward in terms of content. The devs have some work to do, otherwise I'm hopeful a good modder comes along disables all of this siege junk and keeps the new maps and factions.

2013 Global Offensive is a new addition to the Counter Strike series. This game features a unique tactical gameplay with 2 teams.-The Counter Terrorists (CT's): Anti - Terrorist group from over the world. SAS, SWAT, FBI and the Israel Defense Force. Their objective is to rescue hostages in (cs_) maps or in (de_) maps to defend a bombsite from the terrorists.- The Terrorists (T's): Terrorists are the bad guys. They need to defend hostages from being rescued from the CT's or need to bomb bombsites that the CT's must defend.Ofcourse this Counter Strike feature new and the classic maps like de_nuke and one of the best maps : de_dust2 and also features new gamemodes like: -Arms Race an official version of one of the most populair mod gun game. Where people need to make kills with all weapons given. The first one to get a kill with the "golden knife" wins-Demolition a all new gamemode with elements of Arms Race within small demolition maps where T's need to bomb the bombsite.-Deathmatch a deathmatch on Counter Strike maps with the idea of the chaos from game like Quake 3.This game is for everyone. From Counter Strike veterans to people that are new to FPS's altough it can be hard to get started.In my opinion the best thing they added to Counter Strike is the Competetive modes. Counter Strike always was one of the most competetive games ever but you needed to find matches and a team on chatrooms like IRC, Quakenet and those sort of things. Now it doesnt matter if you have a full team or your on your one. You can always find matches like this. This is just the normal Counter Strike maps. But the gameplay changes drastically. This is a dead serious mode so this is not somewhere where you should grief or ♥♥♥♥ around. This is a COMPETETIVE mode. People want to COMPETE. Prepare for battle. However you don't need to be the best in Counter Strike to play competetive mode. After 10 wins you will be set in a skill group. To this skill group you will be matched to people with almost the same skill. So you don't have to worry.The new Arms Deal update provided us with many new skins for you guns. This is a great addition. You can buy and or get weapons for free by playing the game.Also new in this series is temporary map packs like the Operation Payback and the Operation Bravo. This is a mappack that you can pickup for 5 euró's that feature the most liked custom maps on official Valve servers. No lagg and your favorite maps on stable servers.My opinion about Global Offensive is that it is the best Counter Strike. I started playing Counter Strike Source 5 years ago. I loved the gameplay and the tactics. Then Global Offensive came out and i was tought this wasn't gonna be a good game. But it proven itself. Valve did a great job with this game. Most of the things i missed on Source are there in Global Offensive. For example the competetive mode i explained before.

One of the best adventure games everDevelopers had an advantage of taking a very well developed world and one of the most famous story in it. And they not only took it but they delivered on it. Game has wide variety of enemies each of them has it's own backstory (obviously taken from chinese folklore but still) which slightly enlarge our understanding of the world. And just this world and story is enough to give this game a try even if you are not a fan of any other aspects of the game.Game consists of 6 chapters each of which has it's unique enemy cast (with exception of ch5) and corresponding bosses. I remember entering ch5 and my thought "lol those enemies are just reskins of earlier ones lazy devs". But in any other game I would just perceive this as a norm and the fact that I perceived this as a minus speaks very highly about enemy variety in the game.Bosses divides in two parts - chiefs and kings. Difficulty-wise they are mixed up, kings just have more shiny moves I guess...Bosses in a vacuum are all awesome - they has their place in the world, they has a backstory, they have cool moves and good loot. Also they are balanced pretty good for an adventure game even tho I wish they was harder cos amount of bosses I just first try facetanked is unhealthy in my opinion. On the other hand I heard that some people struggles a lot on different bosses so my opinion is not objective here. And yes, I also struggled on those two bosses :)Maps are also awesome - with unique biomes and gorgeous views. They are normal adventure type maps with branching path to the end boss. But game doesn't have any map in menu so navigating and finding all secrets can be quite time consuming (especially in ch3).Chapter 6 map is failed (in my opinion) experiment on openworld type of map. There is literally nothing in it except for a few bad bosses and 1 (one!) chest.Why ch6 bosses are bad? I hate 2 types of bosses: "puzzle" boss and "catch me ♥♥♥♥♥" boss. They are like 90% of ch6 bosses :(But game is not without technical problems of courseFirst of all - camera. Camera can get behind a tree or a wall which is annoying. Also camera tracking is quite loose so if you move around around the boss too much or if boss is has very mobile moveset - he will be out of your field view for a good 30+% of a fight. Also you can just lose target lock during some of boss moves if you don't manually readjust camera during fight (which is annoying if you use gamepad).Minor problem with inputs - for example run button won't register if you pressed it before your run-prohibiting move ends.And annoying problem with lack of target tracking. Like you know how lazy boss designers adds insane target tracking to all moves of bosses - here designers went deeper - heavy attack after roll in 75% of cases will just miss the mark completely - it's not hitting where enemy was, nor where he is going, just some random particle in the air, which is extremely frustrating after you spent like a minute to charge this attack.But despite these problems game is still awesome, bosses are still very manageable due to variety of builds (and ability to redo your build at any time).Solid 9/10

2022 The writing on the tin says "Dark Souls, but open world". And you get exactly what it says on that tin, give or take a few quirks. And it's a rare case of an open-world conversion done right.The combat is the same old soulsborne system that you've already made your mind up about whether you like or not, with some extra tweaks for variety. But what Elden Ring really excels in is the open world of exploration it wraps it in. Strong art direction coupled with intruiging writing make for sights worth seeing, and the reward loop for exploring is borderline addictive. Every single little cave, camp, crevasse and keep has its own boss and unique item as a reward for beating it, making for a ludicrously large assortment of builds to go for. This, of course, comes with the standard high difficulty attached. But in practice the spikes of hardship make for satisfying goals to work towards via leveling.There are other sharp edges, however, that you'll need to acclimate to. In a bit of "have your cake and eat it" design, you'll be showered with lots of weapons, but you'll still need to stick to one and upgrade it. Which can get really boring over the course of a hundred hours if your moveset is narrow. Some items and spells are balanced around PVP instead of solo play. Which can, unintuitively, lead to upgrades being downgrades in practice. And you won't be able to tell until you've invested a lot of resources into unlocking or upgrading them. There's also plenty of things to watch out for that will make the game harder if you're not aware of them:1. The game is designed for co-op. The bossfights are tuned to be challenging even when two players are bouncing aggro between them. Which means that if you're playing solo, your summon is a part of your build as much as anything else. And forgoing it makes things exponentially harder.2. The game expects you to explore and level a lot. If you try to just stick to the critical path to beat it as quickly as possible, you're in for a rude surprise in its later half of the game due to the sheer amount of damage enemies deal there.3. Not all builds are made equal. Your experience will vary a lot based on whether you have a ranged attack, or are going melee only. Especially since some of the bosses are so big that being in melee range means you can't see their swings.But all of those aren't necessarily shortcomings. Think of them as an indirect difficulty setting. You can go for the easiest approach in each scenario, or you can self-impose challenges for extra thrill. It's just a mindset thing that you have to be aware of going in. Other than that, the game is sublime. You'll encounter the odd glitch and weird physics interaction here and there, but other than that it's way more polished that you'd expect for the open-world genre.

Buckle up, fellow adventurer, because I’m about to take you on a mythical journey through the extraordinary realms of Black Myth: Wukong. 🌟🐒🔥The Legend Unfolds: From the moment I stepped into this ancient world, I felt the pulse of its magic. The mist-clad forests whispered secrets, and the pagodas stood like silent sentinels, guarding forgotten knowledge. Wukong, our rebellious hero, radiated charisma. His staff crackled with energy, and his eyes held the weight of centuries.Combat as Poetry: Picture this: Wukong, surrounded by foes, his staff an extension of his will. Each swing, a brushstroke on the canvas of chaos. The combat system dances between elegance and brutality. I pirouetted through enemy formations, deflecting arrows, and delivering spinning kicks that sent demons sprawling. Boss battles? They’re symphonies of strategy and spectacle. I faced a serpent with scales like jade, a thunder deity crackling with lightning, and a shape-shifting fox spirit. Each encounter left me breathless, heart pounding.A Canvas of Dreams: The visuals—oh, the visuals! The artists dipped their brushes in starlight and painted landscapes that defy reality. Cherry blossoms swirled in the wind, and ancient temples clung to cliffs like stubborn memories. When Wukong ascended a mountain peak, the world unfolded below—a tapestry of wonder. And those animated vignettes at the end of each chapter? Pure magic. They revealed the antagonist’s tragic past, leaving me haunted and hungry for more.Threads of Fate: The story weaves threads from the classic Journey to the West. It’s like sipping tea with Sun Wukong himself, listening to tales of gods and demons. Sure, some references might elude newcomers, but they’re breadcrumbs leading to deeper mysteries. I reveled in the lore, piecing together prophecies and ancient scrolls.The Glitches and Grins: Okay, let’s address the quirks. Occasionally, the game hiccupped like a startled dragon. Crashes? Yep. Characters switching languages mid-sentence? Confusing, but oddly endearing. And the gear system? Well, it’s like Wukong got caught in a cosmic thrift store. Upgrading his staff felt like polishing a relic—I yearned for more impactful choices.Verdict: Black Myth: Wukong isn’t just a game; it’s an odyssey. Flaws? Sure, but they’re like cracks in a porcelain vase—part of its charm. So, grab your staff, channel your inner monkey king, and step into a world where myths breathe and legends clash. You won’t regret it. 🌿🔮✨

2022 ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW:Game itself is 10/10. But the PC version stutters a lot, and makes it unnecessarily difficult to play. Masterpiece, best game ever made, it's already ruined my life, but clearly it's unfinished from an optimization point of view. When they fix this issue (which I'm confident they will... it's From Software), I'll rewrite this review and soyjak over the game like a redditor visiting Elon's lithium mines.NEW STUFF:The stutters have become less frequent, but I don't really care anymore. This game is such a masterpiece, I get so enthralled by what's happening on screen that I can't tell if it's running at 20 FPS or 60. When I first played Sekiro, I couldn't go back to Dark Souls for a while because it seemed so slow and boring in comparison. This is giving me the same effect, it makes the previous games feel incomplete in comparison. The melee combat is tied with Sekiro for my fave in any game. It even made magic fun, somehow. Still doesn't run the best, but for me that isn't enough to justify not recommending this game to everyone.

2023 Theres a lot more they have added over the years to your campaign map features, building outposts in other factions settlements, war coordination is better and has more options, quests issued by other factions as well as setting quests for other factions, there are many quests centered around artifacts/gear and map elements as well. Interesting events occur during the campaign and overall I'd say that the turn based campaign portion of total war has never been better. Each faction being so different in warhammer has allowed for interesting faction-unique systems to be implemented that keep each playthrough fresh. The mechanics behind each faction will drive you to play very differently than you played the last and it has really sucked me back in to total war for the first time in years. The "RPG" elements are deeper than ever, which I understand was never the draw of total war, but truthfully, in this fantasy setting I have found that it adds a great layer of gameplay I really enjoy. Sending an army stack off to go on an epic quest for it's leading lord is truthfully fun af and it feels like every lord, even the randomly generated ones, can develop a whole story of their own. Meanwhile you are still playing total war.The engine is the best this time around it has ever been. It runs so smooth I can scarcely believe it. I am using the same cpu I played attila on and the difference is night and day. I have had no AI issues, the unit mass seems perfect, the animations are the best they have been and the game just plays extremely well, even on keep walls. It is really exciting to play through imo and if you have stepped away from total war for a time, coming back will be a huge breathe of fresh air. It is so good, my fiance who has never played this kind of game, took to it immediately. It is still the warhammer versions of total war, so expect extremely powerful lords with rpg features, but this game proves the next historical title will be a home-run because of it's engine and AI improvements alone. A big leap forward for the total war franchise.CA sucks for the way they monetize their games though. I wish steam ratings were star based so I could take a star off for that... but.. I have to admit. They have something locked down that is just insanely unique and impressive and they deserve to be the kings of this genre, it's just so frustrating to stumble through their lists of dlc and insane prices. They STILL sell blood in their games. One thing I will give them is they made it so if you own blood for the blood god in any of the warhammer games it unlocks it for warhammer 3, which is great, but it's not an accolade I feel right giving because it should not be there in the first place.Overall, epic fantasy total war game from a greedy publisher.

2023 Thrones of Decay among other changes is a great change, hopefully CA continues this momentum and they can leave this game in a fantastic state in a year or two. Thanks for listening to fan feedback CA, hope to see either a 40K Total War or even a World War 1 Total War from you at some point!

After 282 hours of gameplay:I logged in tonight only to be greeted with a notice that I was permanently banned from my main server without any clear explanation. The only support available is through their Discord bot, which, after I provided the requested details, informed me that I was banned for using cheat software that allegedly gave me an unfair advantage. They even ended the message with a bizarre note, wishing me a good life and hoping I’d leave a positive review.The issue seems to stem from having "Process Hacker," an alternative task manager, installed on my PC. Many other players have experienced the same problem—wrongfully banned due to false positives from their anti-cheat system—yet have found no real help from customer support. The bot is the only method of contact, and it’s frustratingly unhelpful and impersonal.In my experience, the support for this game is effectively non-existent. I strongly advise anyone thinking of playing to stick to the free-to-play experience and NOT spend any money until they address these issues and establish a proper support team. A Discord bot is not adequate support for a game with paying customers.
