The game features a vast, open world called the Lands Between, filled with diverse landscapes, hidden secrets, and challenging enemies. The world design encourages exploration and discovery. Elden Ring retains the challenging and rewarding combat mechanics of FromSoftware's previous titles, such as Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. Players can choose from various weapons, spells, and abilities to suit their playstyle.The game offers extensive character customization options, including classes, stats, equipment, and abilities. Players can tailor their characters to their preferred combat style. True to FromSoftware's style, Elden Ring features numerous challenging and memorable boss fights that require strategy, skill, and patience. The game’s story is co-written by Hidetaka Miyazaki and fantasy author George R.R. Martin. It features a rich, intricate lore with deep world-building elements. Like previous FromSoftware games, the story is presented in a fragmented manner, encouraging players to piece together the narrative through exploration, dialogue, and item descriptions.

2022 I put lots of time into Warhammer 2 and was excited for Warhammer 3, its been a while since launch now and it is definitely an improvement on Warhammer 2, but not quite the improvement many people wanted. Warhammer 2 was an amazing game and any improvement on that is welcome, but when you are charging a hefty price plus DLC, it's hard to call the improvement we got as good enough. There have even been some steps back that the community has been very vocal about, it's the sieges, they were already a very weak part of the game and they have just been made more complex in an attempt to make them more fun. The larger immortal empires map size and new factions have been great, but Warhammer 3 is a whole new game, a whole new game that feels like warhammer 2 with a few major content updates/DLC and some quality-of-life mods.

Once Human promised an immersive open-world experience in a post-apocalyptic setting, but unfortunately, it fails to deliver on many fronts. The game’s visuals are lackluster and lack the polish one would expect from a title in 2024. The environments feel generic, making exploration feel more like a chore than an adventure.Gameplay mechanics are clunky and unrefined. Combat often feels unresponsive, with hit detection issues that can lead to frustrating encounters. The crafting system, which could have added depth, feels overly complicated and is plagued by repetitive resource gathering that quickly becomes tedious.One of the most frustrating aspects is the six-week reset mechanic. This arbitrary timer not only disrupts progression but also feels like a forced attempt to keep players engaged. Instead of fostering a sense of achievement, it creates anxiety and resentment as players feel pressured to grind through content before the reset hits. This design choice detracts significantly from the overall experience, making it hard to invest time and effort into the game.The story is another major letdown. What could have been an intriguing narrative is bogged down by uninspired writing and poorly developed characters. The dialogue feels forced, making it hard to connect with the plot or care about the outcomes of any of the characters.Multiplayer elements seem tacked on rather than integrated smoothly into the game, leading to disjointed experiences that lack cohesion. The matchmaking can be frustratingly slow, and once in-game, coordination with teammates can be a hassle due to poor communication tools.Overall, Once Human is a missed opportunity that falls short of expectations. It’s a game that feels more like a slog than an engaging experience, leaving players longing for a more polished and innovative approach to the genre.

2022 Quite frankly the best open world I have ever played and will play for a long while. It really is the only game that has perfected open world and that sense of "open". It doesn't force you or tell you to do anything, it throws you into the world with little direction and the wonderment and curiosity of the player take the reigns from there. Very similar to BotW but with an outstanding world, packed to the brim with fun, unique encounters around quite literally every corner. There is always something new just at the end of your line of sight that has this amazing power to draw the player in. The amount of content, and varied at that, that From Soft was able to fit in here will be talked about for years to come.The game wasn't without it's downsides though, albeit few and minor. The performance on PC was terrible and remained for the 2.5 weeks it took me to play. No excuses at this point for framerates locked to 60. The game also for better or worse does not tell you much and while that is a welcome change and makes the discovery feel better, there needed to be some kind of codex for the player to remember the plethora of plotlines. The world is so huge that the next time you return to a plotline you end up forgetting 70% of it. And lastly the balance of the game, something From Soft were absolute masters at with their previous entries, is beyond broken to the point where it is a bit frustrating. I fought Margit completely underpowered because I favored the main story at that point but from then on I explored 95% of the world before tackling the main story portion in the area and found bosses dropping like flies. They need to work in some kind of scaling system if they continue with the open world. For this reason this was hands down, and not even close, the easiest Souls game to date (post Margit).A fantastic entry in the series that also deserves a nod for the world that was created by GRRM. Very unique and very cool with a whole slew of interesting and well designed characters. Will definitely be a game you see high up on many "top games of all-time" lists, and an easy recommendation for anyone, especially due to the low level of difficulty.

Another game that's fun for a while, but that I believe will die out within release year.This is quite an amalgamation of themes and genres. The setting feels similar to games like Control / SCP, while gameplay seems to borrow more from games like Rust & PUBG.Gameplay loop is simple: Loot tier 1 areas, create tier 1 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 2. Loot tier 2 areas, create tier 2 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 3.Loot tier 3 areas, create tier 3 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 4.This is fine, 6.5/10 fun, but:The gameplay loop has 2 big issues for me currently: 1. Enemy AI is not great & being reckless is seldom punished. You can melee every single non-boss enemy with 0 issue. They get stunlocked, no matter the size, no matter the level. They can't fight back. This makes looting cities just feel like a checklist. It's not particularly exciting.2. Building structures doesn't feel great right now. The snapping is terrible and results in a lot of lost time.The game optimization seems overall decent, but at the same time when you're driving a vehicle, a player building will pop up from nowhere 10 meters away. Also I saw some PvP servers, but the netcode isn't that great even for a PvE setting. Me and my friend always claim to be doing things that don't match what the other person saw & we often see eachother teleporting, not having animations or phasing through building floors in bizarre ways.

2022 edit: this was originally a negative review due to performance issues and glitches, these have since been patchedElden ring is a fantastic culmination of fromsofts design lessons from dark souls. While i have some personal hiccups here and there, its undeniably a fantastic game.For the first attempt at making dark souls an open world game, its crazy how well it was executed. The term "open world" might make you wince a bit seeing how for most games "open world" means "we made a big empty map of nothing and filled it with objective markers to pretend there is content. There might also be concerns on how the dark souls formula of tightly designed challenges and areas would function if the world is now meant to be freely explored on your own pace. But i can honestly say they found a good way of mixing both together. The world may be open now but youll come across castles or caverns that are tightly designed like the areas of old titles with shortcuts, bonfires and bosses at the end all without loading screen or obvious level transitions. The game will simply force you off your horse and uses clever level design to prevent major skips from happening so you get that tight level design youre so familiar with. The combat is better than ever and uses many lessons learned from previous titles while also mixing in brand new ones to give a fresh but still familiar dark souls feel. The story has the usual vague feel to it, but puts in a bit more effort to try and convey whats happening than previous games (although its very likely youll still need to look up videos by the end of your journey to really understand what you just went through).I could go on and on on what the game does to well but the review would turn out to be very wordy, its easier to say what i didnt enjoy to allow you to come to your own conclusion on if the negatives are enough to push you away from trying this title. But keep in mind that any negatives mentioned dont outweigh the sheer amount of positives this game has to offer.1. The main story path is actively scaled to curve insanely hard at the first boss, so when you get to them you'll find yourself struggling super hard and start questioning if you're doing things right. The game is designed that way to encourage you to leave the boss alone and explore instead (to get new weapons/armor/abilities etc) but its not at all clear when playing that that is what you're meant to do. 2. While the game boasts an impressive 238 bosses, its worth noting that a massive amount of them end up being just regular enemies with beefed up hp and damage. Not to mention having a ton of repeats of the same boss with slightly different attacks.3. The nature of the open world means that its entirely possible (and arguably unavoidable) that youll end up completely overpowered for some areas/bosses which robs you of a fun fight in a lot of cases. (Luckily the main bosses needed for the main campaign dont really have this issue and are scaled quite well with your progress)4. The multiplayer is once again a pain in the butt to use. If youre playing with friends, prepare to grind tons of flower pedals as youre required to use one every single time you die and want to re-connect with friends which also opens your world up for invasions which are arguably more annoying in this game than any other. Because areas are so incredibly large, its not uncommon to get invaded but spend 30 minutes trying to find out where they are hiding because the pvp invasions are not limited to the small castle/designated areas, its entirely possible to be invaded while out in the open world. It literally turns into an hour long hide and seek session and is more annoying than any fun that could be had from the combat, so its better to disconnect and re-connect with friends than it is to deal with the whole thing. People have taken to modding in a better multiplayer that fixes most of these issues.Thats it! If none of those bother you much then you should have bought this game already.

2014 I bought this game for the chickens, and was not disappointed. After exploring the countless lands the chickens have traveled far and wide, I realized their population was growing too large. The chickens had started to inhabit such horrid locations across the world, such as nuclear plants, and offices without cafeterias. I knew what had to be done. I bought a flip knife off of the steam market, and called PETA. I listened to In the Arms of an Angel in my Microsoft Professional Deluxe Gaming Chair 360 for about twelve hours with no response, so, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I loaded up de_nuke and started to put the chickens out of their misery. I cried harder that night than I have ever before. The next morning, with tears in my eyes, I loaded up Counter-Strike: Global Chicken, and I saw a new item waiting in my inventory. My Flip Knife had turned into a Flip Knife Slaughter. At that moment, I realized what a horrible thing I had done. With my hand shaking, I navigated my mouse, and uninstalled Counter-Strike: Global Chicken. I regret everything I have done. I am writing this review to warn you about the chickens, and to let you know I have made a full recovery, and that I have started my new journey in Goat Simulator. Thank you, and farewell.

It's been a long 13 years waiting to find out whatever happened to Titus after the end of Space Marine, but the day is finally here. Some people think the single player campaign is a little short, but for me it fell right into the Goldilocks zone (just right) and the story was worth the wait.Gameplay-wise, the pacing is very good. The Tyranid swarms can be insanely frenzied and near panic-inducing, while dealing with the Thousand Sons and their Tzaangor and Cultist allies tends to be more methodical but just as deadly.Dealing with the lowest-tier riff-raff goes along like you'd expect it to... they're a breeze individually but dangerous in numbers; still, most weapons will take them out with a single shot/strike. But as the opposition scales up, even the best weapons start to feel like you're just tickling the biggest/baddest opponents. Naturally they should be significantly tougher, but when your biggest and best guns or melee weapons are only knocking off a sliver of their health at a time with headshots or your heaviest blows, it's a little disheartening. In the campaign this is just something you'll have to deal with, but in Multiplayer you level up your gear and unlock various class perks as you win victories and this becomes less of a burden. There are two modes, Operations and Eternal War, PVE and PVP respectively. Eternal War is definitely fun and challenging, but if I'm being honest, I enjoy playing with two others in the Co-Op Operations, where you have a little more feeling of purpose as you go along and achieve your mission requirements.Graphically, it's just a beautiful game. My GeForce 4080 is running it maxed out with no problems but I was worried for my grandson who's PC is just slightly above minimum specs. Happily, he's also running it surprisingly well with a few lower settings than I have but it still looks absolutely tremendous.Honestly the only gripes I've had are the aforementioned problems with weapons not feeling up to the task on the bossier enemies, and Clive Standen taking over from Mark Strong as the voice of Titus. Strong's voice was just so iconic for me, but after not too long, Standen made it his own and all was well again in short order.

2022 This review is written at 31 hours of pure Khorne goodness. So far I haven't seen any bugs of any real note. Only one crash so far, which isn't unusual for a Total War game. I will say Khorne feels OP as ♥♥♥♥ though with my spawning armies ability when I raze a city. It's thematic don't get me wrong, but wow... I've rolled through entire factions in just a matter of a few turns. Eats into my coffers but a properly built economy will support you in that endeavor pretty regularly.Gameplay is fun, and hunting the demon princes is a blast in my opinion. I really am looking forward to Mortal Empires, or now Immortal Empires, with the new gameplay additions.

What I like about this game: The story is very good. It can work quite well as a possible sequel to the original Journey to the West Overall graphics, design of characters and all aesthetics related material are actually quite good, I like it, even the low graphics setting is pretty solid The gear, and the ability to get the mats are not too bad. If you take the time to explore. You will be able to mostly craft a decent amount of armor sets near end game. I think I was able to create at the very least 2 - 3 sets before NG. Combat is not too shabby either, with a but....will be in the "What I don't like/prefer to see change"What I don't like/prefer to see change: One of the biggest things that I recognized almost immediately is the lack of a map, having a map would've been so helpful in exploring these huge maps and areas. Especially since each chapter is quite long. I personally would've preferred that leveling increased your attack and defense, maybe not every level but maybe every other level or two at the least. Some bosses just do so much damage. And if your someone like me that has a bit of a slow brain and takes time to adjust to these attack timings, it would've really helped alot. Now for the combat, I think that for the most part like mentioned above its not bad. You have light attacks, dodging, heavy attacks and the usual. But what I experienced at least is, sometimes the game will not respond to some of my commands and I will have pressed that hotkey...exaggerating....like a bazillion times. Like space bar for dodge. And there were some bosses were my lock on would randomly disappear on its own. Not for when bosses fly high in the sky or something. Like it would be when its just regular combat near/on the ground. Whether this is a bug or my PC I don't know. But this is what I am experiencing. No mana regen mechanic other then a poor restore rate using gourd. This lowkey ruins the game for me.Comp Specs: CPU: Intel i7-9700K GPU: NVidia Geforce RTX 3080 10GB Founders Edition RAM: Corsair Vengeance 32GB

Space Marine 2 is a good example of what we've lost due to games as a service and predatory monetization schemes, with videogames whose sole purpose of development is to serve as a cosmetics and skins virtual store.Saber has transported me back to the first decade of the 2000s when video games were just art and pure entertainment. For sure this is not a perfect game, but it is certainly a great one. A solid campaign, cooperative mode and a multiplayer mode, which is simple, but very fun and entertaining, with a progression system and lots of rewards to unlock for free. Just like in the good ol' days.How good it feels to be able to play a video game with no developer-generated fomo to encourage battle passes sales, with a clear roadmap before release, no microtransactions and no in-game store.Space Marine 2 is visually amazing with stunning graphics, the combat system is smooth and action packed with a blood and gore feast. I'm playing it on a 3080 with no problems or bugs so far, but I think they can optimize the game even more for my fellow brothers who don't own a beefy GPU.The Emperor has delivered. The Emperor will provide. For the Emperor!

2022 Worse than TWW2 (current build) but better release than TWW2 release. I'm sure this will be awesome with a mortal empires/grand campaign added, in the future.Positives:-Many improvements to mechanics, diplomacy especially, saves soooo much time.-Allies are useful now, recruit allied units, coordinate and have fun -You can trade settlements!-Badass demon campaign mechanics, you are actually pretty powerful, and you feel it.-Great soundtracks, animations, landscapes and battle locations (except walled cities)Issues: -Some maps, like Altdorf are still missing textures.-Very poor end game reward, without spoilers.....very underwhelming for what it can do and what it comes with. Same reward for everyone, the narrative reward isn't granted, its just cutscenes and you don't get any new traits, abilities or anything.-Once you beat the campaign, have fun with never ending chaos invasions every 10 turns, forever. this requires you to have a hero stationed at each and every entry point, ready to close the portal for 1.5k gold, every 10 turns. if you want to take over the map, get ready to shell out tens of thousands of gold every 10 turns and bump up your hero cap.-The realms of chaos give little to no rewards. you really only go to slaanesh's penthouse to get fancy trinkets, the rest are trash, leaving you with bad traits.-No mortal empires yet-Walled cities hurt you, dont get them. Currently, when you try to dock archers on walls or whatever, their line of sight is often blocked and they just sit there, so you have to set archers behind walls or somewhere they can shoot from.-Adding walls to a settlement will place two capture points for your town/city, so instead of setting all your forces on top of an objective and defending, you have to split your force. Is it worth it to have 3 more units garrisoning your town but have to defend two capture points, which losing one loses the battle? NO, fight in the strees, no walls.

I absolutely loved this game. Played it in CBT3, did fan art, was a regular on the Discord, planned to build one of the monsters for Halloween but I am quitting now, absolutely not recommending it, and these are my reasons. I have mostly played it on their launcher so my hours here do not reflect time played. I got to 48 in beta and 39 on my main character since release and hundreds hours of play between the two. The good is as follows... The monster and world design is great, combat is fun, the map is fantastic for exploring (which I have spent whole nights doing) and even just getting on your bike to get where you are going for the sheer joy of driving through it. The game loop is quite addictive till you start hitting the friction points and thinking about the looming demise of all your hard work. This company wields FOMO like finely honed sword. That coupled with the short seasons which have 'exclusive items' just generates a feeling of being rushed even though I know there are several more weeks, I just don't feel like I can get everything done in time and I would end up having to start over in many ways (I am very familiar with what you keep between seasons). This might not be such a huge problem with many gamers but I want to clear all the areas, collect all formulas for the items to put in your base, and feel like I have actually accomplished something.On top of the time limit actually getting these formulas is very grindy and I just don't see how anyone could get them all without being very lucky and in game every waking moment. The other issue is the building system is buggy and limited. The aesthetics are hit or miss, mostly miss and you can't really customize cosmetic or house items, (there are a few you can choose between ugly and ugli). All the build pieces are very modern and that's not an aesthetic I enjoy so my attempt at a Queen Anne house ends up looking like a McMansion. It's hard to justify spending a lot in the cash shop when I have a roof corner that will not place for love nor money even though it was there previously before dissapearing randomly so I have a piano on my roof. Absurd problems require absurd solutions. Another glaring issue is character progression. A lot of the abilities for crafting, upgrading, and maintaining your base and equipment are behind RNG with appalingly limited opportunities to reset anything.. This is incredibly frustrating if you have bad luck in getting the critical abilities like being able to make acid from sulfur and if you do get the good ones they will be reset for the next season. Maybe this is encouraging people to work in groups but not everyone can do that so this mechanic makes the game very unfriendly for those that solo. The economy is also frustrating. There is no central, global way to trade. The vending machines you can sell from are local to your territory or truck later in game and you have to place it somewhere and hope people interact with it. We are relegated to the old days of spamming chat to try and sell what you have, hoping someone will come to your vending machine and we are forced to do this because there is a ridiculously low buying cap on the few vendors in the game so it is impossible to actually level the abilities that aren't RNG which cost money as well as points. You also need money to teleport, buy the expensive formluas the vendors have, and some other things cost here and there too. There are too many currencies, too many menus buried within more menus and it's easy to forget where to do something or lose track of all the buttons you have to click on to get the measly rewards you can get from completing season goals, or daily whatever. It's a chore to navigate this nested mess.The game has a lot of glaring instances where it is obviously unfinished. Missing translations, odd animations and mismatched dialog. I question how they are going to provide new content every 6 weeks in perpetuity, as seems to be what's promised, when the starting scenerio is unfinished.I hate having to break up with Once Human. I have a pretty big emotional and time investment if only a limited financial one. This really could have been THE GAME but there are too many problems, too many choices that cause player frustration, and I just can't spend most of my free time anymore knowing I will just have to do it again in a month or so. I am done.

2023 Good Fried Chicken Recipe:In a large mixing bowl, whisk together buttermilk, hot sauce (optional, for added flavor), salt, and pepper in a mixing bowl. Add in chicken pieces. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 4 hours.When ready to cook, pour the vegetable oil in a skillet until it is about 3/4 inch deep. Heat to 350 degrees.Prepare the breading by combining the flour, cornstarch, onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil, white pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, and salt in a gallon sized resealable plastic bag or shallow dish. Mix it thoroughly.Working one at a time, remove chicken pieces from buttermilk mixture. Shake it gently to remove the excess. Place it in the breading mix and coat thoroughly. Tap off the excess.Place the breaded chicken into the 350 degree oil. Fry 3 or 4 pieces at a time. The chicken will drop the temperature of the oil so keep it as close to 350 degrees as possible. Fry each piece for 14 minutes, turning each piece about half way through, until the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 165 degrees F.Remove from the oil and place on paper towels. Let them rest for at least 10 minutes before serving.

2022 Edit: The most recent update is certainly a step in the right direction. Anti-player bias was reduced and a lot of big issues such as replenishment was improved for some factions. Whoever is now managing the project seem to be more receptive/involved with the community. I'll keep this as negative still for now but its FINALLY improving the way people asked.Edit#2: Game has fixed most of its launch issues now. A few lay around waiting to ambush you at annoying moments but overall, it's a far better game now. I'm leaving the review up as I personally am very exhausted of total war games coming out with horrific balance and would like this to serve as a reminder. If this game came out in the state it is now in, it would be a big thumbs up.Ooof where to start? The fact that it wasn't ready? The fact that they doubled down on things people hated in the other games? The freakishly slow updates to get some of the most basic issues fixed? The fact a warhammer game needs almost an entire year to get blood added?... a warhammer game, where you can play as the blood god. The fact the main campaign is an absolute miserable experience? There's just.. so much more. I'll start with the positives.The main positive I could give is that factions have much more engaging mechanics to them than earlier games. Even if their rosters are miserably small... no we're trying to say something nice here. Ogres feel actually finished as a roster, with interesting mechanics and a wide variety of units.The bad.. well it's difficult to explain how extremely bad some of these things are with a character limit so short. I could write multiple pages about the design flaws in the main campaign. Flaws ranging from complex issues that are difficult to deal with to amateur design choices that you'd imagine get thrown out the first time they slip from anyone's lips let alone added to a 60$ AAA title.The campaign is effectively a race, which gets triggered every 20-30 turns. Unfortunately, this absolutely kills the pacing of the base Total War gameplay. Everything comes to a halt, as you enter Chaos realms to get a soul first. Only to realiize that you are the only one playing this game. The AI is not playing the same game as you at all. They do not have the same challenges, they do not get the same debuffs, they do not have to complete the same puzzles, they do not need buildings to recruit units, they do not need to actually do anything you do. They just automatically breeze through while you suffer the most miserable experiences of endless debuffs and being attacked by other enemies while your main army is in some pocket dimension. The game actively punishes you for playing the game as intended. Expanding your settlements and empire means the AI will disproportionately focus you. Allowing their own home to be burned down with no reaction, while sending 3 armies to your doorstep. Maybe get allies? They could be useful if there wasn't an in game design that makes any AI who you alliance with, suddenly become the most passive and weak faction. Yes, if you alliance with an AI, they actually get their AI debuffed to not do anything by themselves. The AI is just so obviously AI due to its comical level of player targeting bias. Shamelessly doing anything it can to stop you while doing nothing else the entire game. An issue so bad, even the developers have had to admit it needs fixing. Just keep in mind, this was not added as a bug, this was the INTENDED DESIGN.The game is such a mess, everything has been put on hold. Months dedicated to fix the horrific design choices that were baked deep into the game. Also, 7 months needed to fix replenishment for 2 factions? What is going on over there? How does it take 7 months to fix things that modders fixed within hours of mods coming out?Give it a year or a little more, then it might be in a launchable state. Sadly it could have been good, but CA decided to ignore feedback and stick with whatever they wanted to do. Lets hope that changes fast.

2022 Its hard to put into words the joy Elden Ring has brought me. Rarely do I see a game where you can explore and fight your way through a huge fantasy world, with so many functional builds to play as, and just so much to explore and so much to see, stuff to find that actually matters for the improvement of your character, and unique underground and hidden areas to find.It expertly blends the grand sense of adventure and discovery in the open world, with the tighter more focused exploration of its large 'dungeon' type areas.. while while blended seamlessly with the surrounding world, also feel like a self-contained experience that is more traditionally Dark Souls like in a lot of ways. You'll see what I mean when you get into Stormveil Castle for the first time and see how the feel of the gameplay shifts to something veterans of the Souls series will feel more at home with.I also think it does a good job of making the game a little more accessible to players who found From's similar games to be too difficult, while still offering a challenge. I particularly like how the world allows you alternatives to just trying to push forward when you're having difficulty.. It's a simple matter to just abandon the area or boss that is giving you trouble, and trying your luck elsewhere for a while.. and maybe out there you'll go up in stats, find some more charges for your Flask, improve your weapons or find better gear, obtain some new magic or learn how to craft a helpful item, and also hone your own abilities as a player with practice without frustration.. then when you come back, that impossible boss won't seem so hard anymore.I love this game. It's just one of those things that checks all the boxes for me, and I'd encourage anyone curious to try it... especially since they're now already patching the game to try to relieve some of the troubles that PC players were having on launch (I count myself lucky to not have those problems myself.. I've seen on stream what the issue looks like and I understand the frustration for those that are experiencing that weird 'chug' or 'stutter')

2022 Let's be real for a second: This game without any DLC or predecessors is not even half a Total War game and the price you are asked to pay for the "full experience" is only stomachable, if you bought the other stuff you want in it over the last years.The balancing is all over the place, since CA ramped up the magic from I to II to III considerably and throws in elite units like it's going out of style, Once you've met a half dead Chaos army that still kicks ass because every single unit is a super elite unit, you'll know what I mean. The difficulty setting essentially just beefs up the AI units to ridiculous levels and reduces their upkeep so a faction a tenth your size may field as many armies as you have, Legendary Lords may have the most special of special effects - or a minor economy buff, so if you meet one in battle, be prepared for nasty surprises. Even just on "hard" difficulty, I've seen the AI attacking me, getting killed to the last zombie (Sylvania) and both attacking armies were back to full strength with the lords I just put in the ground... there may be some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around.Endgame scenarios follow the old CA-route: Just throw a ton of elite fullstacks at the player, because that's fun. Idk if it were an actual horde attack, but the spawning of - for example 15 stacks of elite wood elves who just go on the rampage until you burn their stupid forest - is plainly creativly bankrupt.The design of minor villages is moronic in the extreme and mostly doesn't benefit the defender nearly as much as it should in the case of dwarfs, humans and elfs, who may have things like "firing lanes" and "defensive positions" in mind. There are -for example- often courts which might concentrate the enemy by blocking off the exits, but you can't put any ranged units in good firing positions around it. Sieges are still as stupid as they were in TWWHI. everybody has a ladder up his arse and walls are little more than death traps for your troops. Knocking down reenforced gates with clubs and fists takes about as much time as it takes a unit to leave the wall.I'm not saying I'm not having some fun in this game, but it could be much better, especially since it's the third and final entry in the series. So if you liked the other two TWWHs and have all the DLC races you might want to play, go ahead and buy it, but if you are new to the whole TWWH... go get something else, this game will annoy the hell outta you.

Problems With the Progression System The current progression system in an otherwise great game is a turn-off and is going to drive would be players away from sticking with the game as it evolves over the course of its road map Separate Cosmetic and Class Progression Having a single currency, Requisitions, be required to progress these categories puts players in a position where they are going to make mistakes as they try to kit out their preferred Astartes Chapter. Players will be in search of the correct right shoulder insignia or company pauldron trim paint and this means sacrificing progression of class skills. There is no explanation of this risk to a new player and the system itself is so frustrating its easy to have level 15 in a class and not be able to afford even the first row of its perks. Class skills should just unlock at the appropriate level. There should be no need to also buy them with Requisitions. The amount of Requisitions for victory should be increased at each difficulty level. You should still receive a reduced amount of Requisitions for mission failure. Continue to require victory to progress in unlocking distinct armor parts. Weapon Progression is Simply A Bad Approach The weapon system is convoluted and tying better weapons behind higher difficulty is a guaranteed way to drive players away out of frustration. The Minimal difficulty in this game is hard and recommending "Level 5" to players to take on the next difficulty tier is meaningless if they have spent their Requisitions on cosmetics instead of their class skills. Mastery tokens should simply be removed from the game. As you progress experience on a weapon class the perks should also just unlock without having to acquire a mastery token. Locking the Armory Data required to advance a weapon class to its higher tier is a bad formula. Some players will never be able to achieve those weapon data tiers and as such will remain stuck at a lower difficulty without a means to improve their offensive abilities beyond a point. Armory Data needs an exchange system such as 5 Green can exchange for 1 Purple as so on. This system also needs FAR better in game tools and tutorials without everyone having to refer to out of date early access review information or Reddit posts trying to figure out how this all works Potential But Also Potential To Die Fast This game is going to draw a lot of attention when it fully launches. People will be excited about playing as a Space Marine. Even with the above suggested changes the game is going to be a GRIND to progress. When players find out their progress is also heavily skill gated in what is a seriously difficult game they will move on to the next thing. Its important to preserve the high difficulty for players who have the skill and want that challenge. its equally important that the perks and equipment necessary to play on higher difficulties become available to players of lower skill and that the systems involved here be retooled quickly or this game will end up with a very small player base of nothing but hardcore difficulty seekers. The entire backbone of what is otherwise a great game, its progression systems, are a total miss and I hope you take the above as constructive criticism to improve the game and sustain your audience while you still have the opportunity to do so.I cannot recommend this game until the progression system and economy for multiplayer are addressed, not at the full price asking point.

First off, let me say that everyone has a right to their opinion. I am not here to say whether or not this game is right for anyone else as we are all in different life situations. It is, after all, a thing to do in our free time. Something to get our mind off of life for a while. So below is just "my" opinion on how I see this game. Hopefully it helps those who read it (along with any other reviews listed here) to come to their own conclusion. With all that being said, here are my thoughts..I have been a fan of Games workshop(GW) since the 80's. If you are familiar with the company, then you know they're not cheap. But their commitment to quality models has been stead fast, and my "pile of shame" grows ever larger. This statement shows that I am vested in this hobby and the lore. I don't believe every video game they have released has been great, far from it in fact. BUT Total War: Warhammer I, II, III is truly an amazing game! I have also been a big fan of the total war series since the original Shogun. I bought just about every game in the series and have spent hundreds hours playing them. So when I heard these two companies were coming together, it was a sure thing for me! Below are the hours I have spent on each game and to be honest I'm surprised they are as low as they are.TWW I - 751 hours*TWW II - 3016 hours*TWW III - 1044 hours**at time of this postingThis is a MASSIVE game that includes a least 24 races(not counting rogue armies or mods) with hopefully more to come. Within those races there are multiple factions, each with their own unique play style and goals. I'm pretty sure Creative Assembly(CA) & GW plan on reaching 100 faction leaders! This itself creates an incredible amount of replay ability. Now not all of them you may like, but with such variety, there's something in here for everyone's taste and play style. CA has done an epic job bringing all this together in one massive "immortal empires map". They game can be played as a giant sandbox but GW has so much rich lore that there is a story to follow as well. DLCs were also released with certain factions leaders squaring off with each other which helps with the immersion. The environments in this world are rich and ever expanding with the possibility of Ind, Kuresh, & Nippon opening up in the future. And if that wasn't enough, the AMAZING modding community has such mods as "Dynamic World" to enrich it more.As far as game play, as mentioned above, I was very familiar with Total War game mechanics. So it was very easy to jump right in. For those of you that haven't played any of the series before(whats wrong with you?? jk jk), it may take a little getting use to, but in "my opinion" it is very intuitive on how it works. There are so many reviews on this page that I wont get into everything here but if you are interested I'm sure you can find another review that goes into it in more detail.Now, to address the elephant in the room: the cost.. By now I have said enough about myself that you can tell price isn't a wall for me if I love the product. I can spend WAY more going out these days for this many hours of entertainment (listed above) then what this game has costed me. $237.00* / 4811 series hours played = $0.05 per hr*Price of all available TWW I, II & III content, 10% off (not including Thrones of Decay)I'm sure my math may be off a little but even if it was 10x that amount its worth every cent. And the more I play, the more value I get from it. My suggestion is to wait for a sale and start small. A large part of the player base plays Empire but do your research to see which race sounds most interesting to you. You will need to buy one of the base games to start with and with "Thrones of Decay"(ToD) release right around the corner, all of the base and DLCs will be on sale (good time to jump in!) I've seen the base game I & II up to 50% off in the past. But don't feel pressured to buy all the content at once. For those of you still on the fence, remember steam has that return window policy if you don't like it within the first few days.If I have any complaint about the game, its the series has been so good that I have had trouble playing any of the old Total War historic games since due to the lack of variety in the factions/game play. I remember this being a worry from the Total War historic community before its release and now I see why. Yes, there are some bugs in the game but none of them are game breaking. Most of the time I didnt even notice them until I read the hot fixes. We need to remember few games have ever been this massive before and with all the new content these things can take time. You tube content creators, such as Great Book of Grudges, and the player base are always sure the devs are made aware of these so they are fixed. Maybe not as fast as they would like but again I barely notice them. I will make this part quick.. You may have heard the recent drama over the "Shadows of Change"(SoC) DLC and all the negativity along with it. I will say the player base stood up for what they felt was right, and I "believe" CA finally got the message. The extra content added to SoC DLC and the previews for ToD are looking like a move in the right direction to make the game community supportive again. But only time will tell.So in conclusion I want to again say this is only "my opinion". I am not saying anyone complaining this game is to expensive for them is wrong. What I am saying is that I am willing to pay developers that will bring high level of entertainment and will continue to support them so it keeps coming out. Yes, we should make sure we are keeping the developers honest and the quality of product they are releasing is held at a high standard. But in a respectful and productive way. Thanks for reading and I hope to see you in game! =)Psy

2016 My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

2022 Ideal. A great blend of exploration, skillful combat, freedom, level design, RPG stat/build nerding, immersion, itemization, and storytelling. The open world is comprised of mindful, intentional design, creating a sense of pacing within the fully player-driven exploration experience. It never seems to end, just when you think the game has played all of its cards and will start slowing down, it delivers over and over again. The main dungeons are an experience to behold, often giant towering structures you work your way towards, each of them a feat in level and art design. The character building possibilities are awesome, the game rewards experimentation and critical analysis of your build in ways Souls games never quite nailed down. The gameplay loop is varied and addicting, equal parts exploration, analysis, experimentation, and engaging, responsive combat. It's a huge well-designed & high budget immersive world in an RPG that puts game design & gameplay mechanics first, with an intriguing story that never gets in the way... and it doesn't compromise on difficulty. The controls and movement are responsive (thanks Sekiro), the animations are good, the art and vfx are real nice.If you have any interest in the excitement of discovering a game's world and mechanics, you owe it to yourself to play this game blindly, with minimal outside influence and wiki'ing—the game supports blind play very well, though it will be worthwhile to take basic notes in a journal or notepad file. I think a player written in-game journal or world map editor are my primary desires, but I'm just gonna blame consoles for the lack of these types of features. as they're hard to implement there.Ultimately though, this game gives back what you put in. If you want to progress slowly, exploring every inch of the world to find lots of meaningful secrets and items, it delivers as an incredible open world game. If you want to rush the legacy dungeons, creating a challenging experience by killing all the main bosses with a more limited option set, it delivers as a good action game. If you want to optimize your build, nerding out testing tons of setups and different viable strategies, engaging with the stats, spells, and itemization, it has tons of interesting stuff to play around with and delivers as a solid RPG. If you want to simply play at a medium pace, learning about the world, challenging some bosses, running random dungeons you come across, making your character stronger with the stuff you happen to find, and primarily letting your whims guide you—All of that will be engaging and rewarded. If you're a pure PVP nerd, maybe try showering someday, but yeah that's here too and it seems OK so far.I don't know how FromSoft did it, but they took the "git gud" approach to developing games and simply killed it. They deliver on not just a single intended experience, but an array of experiences, intentionally playing into the best aspects of emergent game design, while maintaining strong encounter and level design... All wrapped in some nerdy open world fantasy RPG that learns important lessons from all their previously developed games. My sincere thanks to Miyazaki & the whole FromSoftware team for their hard work, expertise, and dedication to making big budget gameplay driven games.(♥♥♥ george tho)

One of those games that needs a "meh" middle option. - Campaign is mediocre, individual missions and encounters feel kinda lazy, outdated in design and extremely repetetive. - Enemy AI is extremly basic, most enemies have just 1-2 attacks, bosses maybe 3-4. - Dialogue is kinda lazy and basic, even by cliche 40k standards. - Environments are kinda 40kish, but not enough. Like they're just a tiny step above generic sci fi coridor shooter. - Enemies are bullet spongy as hell. Combat seems to take "inspiration" from dark souls (like literally everything these days..) but just doesnt work with tyranids as the enemy. On veteran (which the game says is the intended difficulty) one hit will take out 50-80% of your hp, while it takes like 10-20 hits to kill the same basic non-boss enemy that hit you. While trash mobs are swarming and stunning you. Its just grindy, tiring and feels like ♥♥♥♥ even after you beat every encounter. Kinda like dark souls 2. - Ranged enemies swarm you and seem to target only the player. - Companion AI i atrociously dumb, but game seems to be designed purelly around coop. enemy hp etc. - Controls feel unresponsive, there's a wierd delay on most things. Especially bad with melee which as a result feel really bad. - AI straight up bugs out in places and does effectivelly or literally nothing - Lots a of different guns with very slightly different names that all feel almost identical - Sounds of SMs walking are ♥♥♥♥, instead of tanks, they're barbies in slipers. - Gun sounds are meh too --- A narative driven sp game designed entirelly around coop mp, even the campaign. In 2024. Seriously? ----- Whoever keeps putting in "hold button to do action" ♥♥♥♥ in video games needs to be publicly excecuted as warning to the next 15 generations. That ♥♥♥♥ doesnt even belong in console games, and is the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing since motion blur in pc games. + Visuals are good + Shooting is mostly satisfying despite meh gun sounds + Its 40k, and you're a space marine fighting xenos + Voice acting is reasonably good. Minor issues - Some stuttering, but fairly rare. - No ultrawide support yet All in all, designed purely for multiplayer that nobody will play because the single player is mediocre.

2023 Im deeply upset to see the way that C.A. has decided to manage the property this late into a trilogy. The times of WH1 and WH2 were filled with fantastic content and much needed maintenance that made the games continually fun to return to over months and years. However, with WH3, C.A. has seemed to change course. The game has been littered with crippling bugs in the AI, the combat, and the lords that have made many aspects significantly less fun that previous titles. This alone wouldn't kill the my interest, as the variety of potential content has always renewed my interest in the game, but that too has fallen into disarray with the pricing changes. With the announcement of their new pricing structure, content that would have previously been in the range of $10-$15 is now $25, with the expectation that will be the standard going forward.Again, alone that wouldnt kill my interest in the game; Had the price change been matched with higher quality and consistent bug fixes like during the duration of WH2 I would have been more than accepting of it. But together though, these two problems create a game that is neither as fun as it once was, nor a good value for the content.With that in mind I have to sadly say that any individual seeking to get into the WH games should just get WH2 on steep discount, and avoid WH3 completely.

2023 With a total of 340 hours poured into WH2 and 166 hours into WH3, not to mention over a thousand hours across all the total war games, it's disheartening to witness what feels like CA's decline. The game itself is fun, yet the direction CA is taking has left me deeply disappointed. The pricing strategy for their DLCs is beyond my comprehension. Despite my consistent support by purchasing DLCs upon release, the recent two DLCs have been priced at an astonishing $25 each. In all honesty, when evaluating the content they offer, this pricing appears not worthy at all.The thought of spending $50 for just two DLCs is perplexing. Why wouldn't I consider buying Baldur's Gate 3 instead? The repeated assurances that each new DLC will introduce an entirely fresh journey led me to maintain faith in the development team. However, it's becoming evident that CA does not care about player at all. Their insatiable greed is devouring their once vibrant creativity. "Shadows of Change" will be my last DLC, unless substantial improvements are made.It's truly disheartening. I believed that CA aimed to craft a gaming experience that would be treasured, a journey etched into players' memories. Yet, it seems that the pursuit of profit has overshadowed that vision.YOU WANT TO MAKE MORE MONEY? THATS FINE, I GET IT. BUT WHAT YOU DO IS NOT MAKING MORE MONEY. INSTEAD, INSTEAD, YOU GUYS JUST GRADUALLY MORPHING INTO ANOTHER BLIZZARD. SHAME ON YOU.

Game of the Year It's been awhile since I played a game that had me hooked to the point I couldn't stop playing. The combat is fluid, the environment is beautiful, the levelling up system is fun to explore, and unlocking new gear not only makes you look badass but also helps you along your journey. Why is combat so fun? Well, you get to capture the souls of monsters that you have defeated and use their skills; you can also transform into bosses you have defeated, and you get to pick which fighting stance to suit your playstyle. All stances can be changed on the fly during combat too. And you get a magic spell on top. Anyone telling you the combat is boring doesn't know what they are talking about.Is this a Soul's-like game? No, but it does have soul-like elements, such as Flask/Gourd, Bonfire/Shrines, and enemies respawn with huge boss battles. If you ever feel put off if this game is too difficult, worry not; I'd say this game is challenging at best and do-able once you practice perfect dodge. Why is this my game of the year? For a start, the music in this game is amazing, from the combat to the story telling and how it hits on the right keynotes for that crescendo moment. Watching the end of the Chapter 5 cutscene and listening to the song, it really fits perfectly when the cord and vocals play out in each scene. Not only was the music amazing, but the art direction, too. Having different styles of art for every cutscene was a fantastic choice. It draws so much attention. I do like how the end of chapter 2 cutscene foreshadows a side mission in the game... Well done, Game Science. That was my favourite side mission. You would think fighting bosses after bosses would get tiresome, but Black Myth manages to make a game where each boss fight feels fascinating and fun. So many times when I play a game, it's just a reskin boss battle with the same attack from a previous level, but not the Black Myth. Each boss fight has their own unique attacks, and it just feels so fresh to see in a video game. Not only is the boss battle exciting, but all the monster designs look interesting too. I had fun reading up about them in your monster encyclopaedia book. This better win an award for music and art direction. The ControversyFollowing Black Myth Wukong from the beginning, it has been so frustrating to see how unfairly treated this game has gotten from journalists, gaming journalists, and even a few content creators, for that matter. For those who are smart enough to know the whole controversy and how obvious it has become once you piece the dots together. DEI asks for money; said company makes DEI friends slander Game Science *Cough IGN*, every news outlet spread it like wildfire, gaming media reviewers purposely give games a low score, and on top of that, it clearly shows they never played beyond chapter 2. To have DEI in Black Myth Wukong would truly break the art in this game. Not only art but the Asian culture and the essence that is rich in its history. It’s "wrong" to include DEI principles in a game based on Journey to the West (a classic Chinese novel); there is cultural authenticity that has historical context that is deeply rooted in Chinese culture and mythology.You also have to respect the artistic vision. Game Science wanted their game to be told. It's their story, their culture, and no outside influence has the right to tell them what to do. It's a game that started from passion. It's also been frustrating to see some content creators turning a blind eye to Black Myth, to either no mention, no coverage, downplaying the game, or no mention how it has broken records and sold X amount of copies and made X amount of millions. Shamefully, even Easy Allies didn't even cover this game, and they were more hyped for Concord, lol. This game is more than just Game of the Year. It has been through a lot, and yet, despite it all, I'm sad to say, it will get snubbed at the Gaming Awards, and if it does, then you and I know, it was rigged. I can't wait for the DLC; it will smash more records to come. Hail To The Monkeyking

I originally had very positive thoughts on this game, but once I found out that they take everything from you after their season ends & I mean they take everything that matters. The only things you get to keep is your journey completion << I think, but not sure on that one, some blueprints, character cosmetics, formulas for your house cosmetics to not be mistaken for the memetic portions & if you knew how or remembered to create it you also get to keep your house blueprint/s, that starchrom, star source, Mitsukos Mark, sproutlet, planula, oh & any friends that you made that stuck around. Now it may let you keep other stuff as well, but since I have a job & a family the other stuff you get to keep was probably something I didn't have time to obtain or even educate myself on within the game. Now the game is pretty & has a lot of in-game content...& if you have real life work & priorities you will never be able to get it all done in 6 weeks *^5*. When the servers reset you are forced to tag along & when you fall into the new server you're starting over from scratch. This means you're pretty much playing the game from the beginning all over again & again & again & again & again & again "Oh my how fun". This is a game with no end, no middle & no progression that matters since your progression & all your hard work & many hours spent in it is taken from you with a "Haha" by the creators. You don't get a new world to explore & you get the same enemies, the same missions, the same NPCs, the same everything with a few different missions but who knows maybe those are the same to since you didn't complete the first part lol. They treat you like you're stupid by making you complete the same tasks as if you could ever forget how to create a base, at least give us a "I've done this effin ♥♥♥♥ already let me skip". Yet because of the wipes there is 0 motivation to even play it. Wipes make more sense for Pvp not for Pve......the fact that we lose our levels & map progression in an mmo is extremely stupid. 6 weeks is not enough time.....a lot of us have jobs & families we can't live on Once Human for 13-20 hours a day. So yes if you have no obligations in real life & you've no job....sure go for it you will be able to play & complete it within the 6 weeks before they f**k you again. I honestly don't think it's worth it since you're not really getting anything new for all of the time you put into the grind. So my final outlook on the game is from their mindset "MMOs are hard to keep up with so lets just not really give anything to them that's new, not give them enough time to complete the world & then take it all so they're forced to spend time on it but we're not forced with the task of giving new content as often." Since for most of you that play MMOs the one thing they seem to struggle with is the upkeep of engaging content that can keep up the majority of it's player base, so perhaps this is their attempt of "keeping it fresh". All in all I'm very disappointed & was hoping that I finally came across a good MMO/survival, but I was mistake....hopefully they make some changes...maybe they can separate PVE from PVP & players can only achieve the battle pass content if they create a PVP character & grind for their battle pass content there....but still have the freedom to play the game in PVE as normal where we cannot grind for the battle pass content. Just a thought that I hope they consider.

2023 CA has decided that after 3 years of hyping up Warhammer 3 as the cherry on the top that would complete the experience of all 3 games to throw that all away for the chance to squeeze your last dime, and threaten to hold it hostage if you don't. Don't like that and think it's scummy, too bad they'll just make up some excuses about "rising development costs" entirely forgetting they have free marketing through youtubers, they also don't have to produce a physical product since it's downloaded over the internet. They also expect you to not realize that they made almost $2 Billion in revenue off of just the first 6 months of Warhammer 3 sales. All this in the name of further development, but this game lacks solid features that old total wars still shine 15 years later from having. Dark elf corsairs, Vampire coast pirates, and the Norscan raiders can't actually participate in naval battles as naval capable factions in the lore. Remember when trade was physically represented on the campaign map by carts and ships moving from one city to another and could be raided. Remember when you could recruit units without a general so you could make custom garrisons for your cities. Don't forget what CA stripped Total war of in the name of selling you less product for more money while hoping you wouldn't pay attention, and don't forget that they'll do it again in a heartbeat,just like they are now.

2022 UPDATE: 08/23/2022 - Alright, so finally they fixed the performance issues with the release of immortal empire and the lighting in the game seems better overall along with many, many improvements to the game in all aspects. Also, immortal empires is now available. At this point I would give the green light. Flipping this review to positive.I'll be honest. I loved Warhammer 2 and accumulated 1200+ hours of gameplay. Perfection. This one, however, was not ready to be released yet. The optimization is abysmal. It feels like a closed beta with access for those who paid. Also the anti-aliasing in this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ugly. You are stuck with FXAA or TAA, which is basically; "Do you want flicker everywhere? Or do you want vaseline screen?" It blows my mind that a PC-only released, in 2022, with an AAA stamp offers only those 2 outdated and ugly forms of AA. The color palete is all ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up too, which I don't know if it's the result of the incredibly ugly AA or just bad work on art department, but something feels very, very off.I have a Ryzen 5800X paired with a 3070, and well configured pair of RAM sticks with tight timings running the game on a m.2 storage, and it's not enough to run this game well. Battles are okay, but in minor settlement there is a micro stutter that won't go away, even though the FPS is above 60. On campaign map your FPS gets tanked hard, no matter the config you use.Just do yourself a favor and go buy Elden Ring or something, and wait for 2 or 3 months until they optimize this. Don't get me wrong, I love this game, but it was simply not ready to be released.When they finally optimize it properly I will change my review to positive. Until then, I can not recommend this.

2014 Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a first-person shooter and the next generation of Counter-Strike running on updated Source Engine and has many new features added.The gameplay is also has been revamped so even new players can play the game without much difficulty. No need to buy weapons ammo anymore. There are many new game modes such as deathmatch, arms race and the competitive online match. There's also the new Arms Deal update where each weapons now has many skins which can be acquired when you play on VAC enabled servers in a timed based item drops or by opening a weapons case with certain bought keys. Weapons skins can be used to show off, traded or sold on Steam marketplace. You can even change your weapons name and add some description about it. You can also submit your own weapon skins or maps if you have the creativity so that maybe Valve will add it in the next game update, therefore supporting the game even further.Graphics in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive has been vastly improved. Characters model are all fresh new while retaining the same design and faction with some new faction added. The map is upgraded even better to look more realistic than ever. The new Source Engine also made the ragdoll physic effect and many effects feels more realistic. Despite all of the upgraded graphics, the game runs amazingly smooth and optimized and doesn't really need high-end system.Oh, but before you buy this or even play the game, you better be ready to throw yourself into a real hot zone out there, as the community of this game is... well... unforgiving. You either die as a noob or live long enough to get a title hacker.This is yet the best Counter-Strike game where casual and hardcore gamers can play. I recommend this.Rating 9/10

2022 **SPOILER FREE** I've put thousands of hours into the FromSoft games over the years, so to say I was hyped for this would be putting it lightly. Somehow... Someway.. This game has managed to blow straight past all my expectations. This is the 'Ali vs Liston' of heavyweight, triple A RPGs. The 'Prince at the Superbowl halftime 2007' of creative ingenuity. La piece de resistance for anyone looking for something fresh and exciting to seriously shake up the monotonous genre that is currently open world games. The ONLY complaint I've had is to do with the performance issues on PC. Which as of the current patch, have been ironed out for the most part.From a Souls fan perspective, this game is absolute bliss. If you've ever found yourself lamenting for a small quality of life change in one of their games before, I assure you its now a part of Elden Ring. For a first time Souls player, this game offers a godlike first taste into the incredible games this company has to offer.Every new mechanic is incredibly thought out and flawlessly executed. At the core, the combat is very much DS3. But, that's a good thing. Too many games nowadays try to reinvent the wheel and end up just over complicating things. Instead, From stuck to their roots, and managed to add these incredible layers to the combat. There are honestly infinite ways to tackle a fight in Elden Ring, and here's the best part... They're basically ALL viable. This game allows you to push through enemies in exactly the way you want to.The open world is not a hybrid, it's not half-assed. It's rich in content and aesthetically jaw dropping. It flows effortlessly and in a way that constantly has you exclaiming 'wow this game is HUGE,' but without overwhelming you. And in some feat of genius, they've managed to incorporate the crazy satisfying Miyazaki vertical level design in a way that just WORKS. This is their first open world attempt. FromSoft do not miss, these guys just don't miss.The story is really, really good. And much easier to follow than their previous games, but the lore still isn't force-fed to you so if you're the kind of player that just likes to get to the slaying, you're covered. The NPC quest lines are the most immersive they've ever been with such engaging and unique characters, and they're so impactful. Makes them very worth following.The difficulty is done amazingly well. The game is exactly as hard as you make it without having to resort to some artificial difficulty slider. The more dedicated exploring and build creating that you do, the more powerful your character becomes, and in turn, the easier the game becomes. The late game difficulty spike is also very welcome. The final bosses really FEEL like super powerful demigods that require you to bust out everything you have to match their power.The general design in this game is on a different level to anything I've ever seen. I was constantly taken aback by the sheer 'cool factor' of bosses and various enemies. The side areas had me in complete awe constantly. A single side area felt like a whole DLC on many occasions, as the design was just immaculate and so thorough.Also worth a mention - both the voice acting and the sound design/score are phenomenal. They amassed a team of really talented voice actors and musicians to create this immense audio immersion that just has you taken aback constantly. This is a game you can play in a thousand different ways, for a different experience every time. And for 50 GBP it's a damn good deal. I cannot recommend it enough.10/10

2022 Product received for free Spoiler Free:If you played the past Total War and/or Warhammer titles, you are in for an absolute treat. TW:WIII is at the top of its game, being one of the best experiences in the series thus far. Honestly, if nothing else, the unit rosters and their diversity alone makes it a far better experience. Doom stacking is less of a meta, and most units are multi roled. The new siege system is an interesting take and definitely expands on the past sieges, though it could be a little more intriguing - the supply & defense building system leaves a little to be desired, but is definitely better than not having it at all. The story-line and campaign is amazing, the Daemon Prince campaign is an absolute treat with unparalleled lord customization that sold me immediately. The game overall feels more intelligent, the AI respond better overall around the map, the land mass really does push you away from some factions nearly the whole game as well. Really, this is just a good title - if its your first in the series, its a great one to begin with.Also, the game runs VERY smooth - I am on a i7 7700K 4.2 ghz, 1080ti and 16gb Ram and its running perfectly - load times are a little high, but nothing terrible.I am also fairly easy to please with the Total War titles, my experience and likes/dislikes will ultimately be different than yours. Update: For clarification on my current playtime, I work in the gaming industry and was granted a press copy. Edits: typo

2022 The posibilities how to start this review are numerous. But i think to adress the biggest change to what fromsoft has done before let's talk about...THE OPEN-WORLDEven though this is Fromsoft's first shot at a real open-world, they did an amazing job with it. The first time I started up the game and came into the open world I just got lost in it. Not like I didn't know where to go because while the game doesn't give you specific directions in form of waypoints, some points of grace (that's what the bonfires/checkpoints are called in this game) have rays of light attatched to them which point in the direction where the story countinues.But no what i meant with getting lost is that i could just ride around in the open-world forgetting about time and just roaming around stumbling from one quest into another, finding dungeons, fighting fieldbosses and before you know it, you rode your trusty horse torrent around for 4 hours. You may not have countinued the story and yet, it's not at all like you didnt do anthing in this time.Elden Ring really does reward exploring of the world. Be it more healing items you can pick up or another area you wouldnt have expected. In one of the first forests I explored I happened to stumble upon a circle shaped building. I didnt think much of it at the time since i was on my way to a castle I spotted on the horizon. After examining the castle I went back to that building I passed in the forest, which i marked on the map so I wouldnt forget about it (I can only recommend to take advantage of the marker tool since you might forget some points of interest with this much to see in the world). Turns out the building was an elevator and brought me far down below the plains I wandered before. On the ride down the wall before me opend up a bit and revealed an underground area with a sky made of sparkling gems resting above it. This is only one of the stunning views you get to see while exploring. Traveling the lands between is not fun and games though. Of course, in these chaotic times the world is littered with enemies. Not just grunts but bosses like giant knights on armored horses or dragons as well. While you encounter most bosses in dungeons you shouldn't go around with a sense of security since although grunts, may just be grunts they are deadly grunts. While we're on the topic let's get into...THE COMBATFor those of you who didn't have the pleasure to enjoy any of the dark souls games yet, I'll just give a quick summary of the most used combat strategie: You look how the enemie is winding up their attack, wait for the strike and then dodge through it. After successfully avoiding the attack you either have a short opportunity to deal damage, which consists for most players just spaming the rb button, or have to dodge out of the way of the next attack. If you didn't time your roll right it's retreat and heal. That's basically what combat consisted of in the dark souls games. The third installment of the series introduced also something called weapon arts. Weapon arts are possesed by every weapon in the game and are a unique move of attack that uses up mana. In Dark Souls III I personally rarely used it tho since the risk-reward factor of hitting such an attack to the damage it dealt just wasn't worth it.In Elden Ring some major improvements were made even though Fromsoft might have overdone it in some aspects. The one thing that is responsible for the biggest change in combat is the new poise stat, that was added by the devs. You can imagine poise as another bar besides the health bar. When it runs out the enemy gets staggered and you get to perform a critical strike that deals massive damage (It is simmular to sekiro but differs in that you cant actually see the bar). How does that change the gameplay you might ask yourself now. Well it gets the player to vary their attacks more. As already mentioned combat mostly relied on the rb button or light attack. Light attacks don't do much damage to the poise of an enemy though. So the player has to decide if they solely want to rely on the damage of their light attacks or risk a longer heavy attack to not only deal damage but bring down the enemy's poise as well. Over all you can play Elden Ring combat whise just like the old dark souls games but there is a good new alternative.The Weapon skills are where Fromsoft might have overdone it a little. There are two or three weapons in the game which let you one shot some bosses or just let you cancel enemies attacks, making some passages a bit too easy in my opinion. If you dont want this you can of course just leave your fingers off of 'em.In conclusion, combat whise Elden Ring improved on Dark Souls and Sekiro massively as well.Last but not least there is still one thing left...THE STORYI'm sad to say, the story is probably not going to be something for everyone. In typical Fromsoft manner, you don't just get the story presented on a silver plate. You have a main story line and yet it might confuse you in some parts. The story is told, not just with cutscenes but with item descriptions, side quests, and dots you have to connect by yourself. The game tells the tales of many dark but also some brighter fates. Be it the swordswoman malenia just trying to desperately protect her brother. Or General Rahdan rotten but Malenia's curse, seeking out one last battle, worthy of a warrior's death and not perish from sickness. All of which, you kinda have to figure out for yourself.To sum it all up: Fromsoft created a masterpiece. They did hell of a job on their open-world and designed their bosses with just as much passion and creativity. The exploring always stays interesting and the combat is very enjoyable. The combination of all this makes up this addicting magnum opus of a game.In my opinion this is a must play title and i can only recommend it to everyone considering getting it just the slightest. Most of all with a dlc on the horizon

5 Out of 10 game, wait for it to go on sale. (also ignore my playtime it is much longer than steam shows).Visually this game is quite impressive, they really nailed the look and feel of the 40k Imperium. Audio is really good, voice acting is good.Where this game falls flat on its face is in the amount of content, and the game-play.This game is extremely bare bones for a 70$ AAA game. The campaign is short, there are only 6 PvE missions, and there is PvP, which I do not really care much about and am not reviewing. The weapon selection is ok at best.Combat is extremely basic, guns feel weak as hell, and this gets worse and worse with difficulty as the enemies get even more bullet spongy with each increase in difficulty. It can take multiple magazines to down a single medium sized enemy at max difficulty. Bolters (incredibly powerful weapons in lore) feel like you are shooting 22 rimfire. Ammo availability also decreases dramatically with difficulty, which ultimately makes most guns worthless.Melee combat is slow and clunky, and your marine feels like their armor is made out of paper. Dodge red attacks, parry and counter yellow attacks, time your dodge or parry and you can counter or shoot your target in the head with your pistol. Executions are ok but often take too long. You get armor from doing executions, otherwise basically lifted from recent doom games.The game loves to mix ranged and melee enemies together so you are often getting shot to bits while being swarmed by in close enemies. Enemies and friendlies can both attack and shoot through each other, so the ranged enemies are in no way blocked by close enemies.PvE is also very grindy and time consuming for improving your character and unlocking new armor bits. Missions are long but uninteresting. Go here, defend that, hit this button, go here, etc.The expansions are also a ripoff in my opinion. Entirely cosmetic, and you have to grind a ton to unlock the cosmetics to actually use them. The price of the season pass is also a joke for what you get. Plus if you want the full set of cosmetics for all weapons, you better have preorederd the Ultra Edition.It is a pity as this game has a lot of potential, but it is ruined by greed and a very bare bones launch.
