2022 I wanted to wait to write this, but seeming as though there will be no content updates for potentially another 6 months. (Q2 2023 as CA says) I thought it would be a good time to inform those of you who scour the depths of steam reviews before you purchase. If you're coming from Total War: Warhammer 2 to this and have not yet purchased, don't. If you're new to the Warhammer games or Total War in general, don't purchase this. Purchase Warhammer 2. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game in it's current state. There have been no improvements since Warhammer 2, in fact there have been many downgrades. This game is buggy, runs poorly, although better than launch. You cannot play Realms of Chaos (Main story for Warhammer 3) without wanting to commit seppuku. The quintessential experience for Warhammer will always be "immortal empires" a sandbox experience where hundreds of factions battle for world conquest. The only problem? The AI. I do not know what they did to this game in comparison to Warhammer 2, and I won't pretend I'm a game developer, but something is terribly wrong. You will be #1 in power ranking the entire campaign and there is almost no challenge, depending on the race you play and how verse you are in strategy. The AI puts up no fight, hides behind their walls, and refuse to expand. 150 turns into a Grimgor campaign (where I purposefully kept losing and giving territory) the second strongest faction was the empire. at 30 settlements. In comparison to my 100+. Needless to say, I with all my heart love Warhammer and I want this game to succeed. However, this game is a pure downgrade in GAMEPLAY. Which is what a game is all about. If you love pretty particles and a massive map (Bigger is better, i guess..) and have no care in the world for when you realize fatigue has been set in after your third campaign because there is no challenege or opposition, then this game is for you. If you adore a fun game with a ton of challenge, I HIGHLY recommend you purchase Warhammer 2 first. I truly want this game to flourish and there could be so much more to come if it does well, but that does not justify the games' current state.

2022 At the moment this feels like a sidegrade to Total Warhammer II. The battles are entirely an improvement to II. If you consider the battles to be the meat of the game, then I believe this to be a great addition to the series and a welcome development of the gameplay. However, the campaign I feel is not in a great place. I would first like to say that I found the prologue a somewhat dull experience, as it holds your hand very firmly, does not provide a significant challenge, and felt very on rails. This being said the prologue campaign is exactly what a game of Total Warhammer's scope has always needed. A proper tutorial that shows many mechanics in a digestible way is very helpful. As a veteran player, I'm not the target audience and I'm very glad it exists.The main campaign has some very interesting ideas, and there is a lot about it I like. I love the art direction and clarity of design. Apart from all the red I think it's very readable, certainly more so than II. I love the little locations of interest on the map. I really like the concept of collecting souls, and visiting each god's realm. I like that the gameplay forces the player to be a little bit more proactive in recruiting and maintaining agents, keeping forces mobile, and pressuring the player with multiple fronts. But there are problems, which range from poor performance for some (I've been ok, but for a large amount of end-turn stutter and a couple of crashes), weak, redundant and pointless research trees, some bugged units and mechanics, and to problems more with how the campaign was laid out.My problem with the campaign as it exists is that is purely reactive gameplay. The player has no agency as to when the events happen, their length, and has very little agency in how to respond to the events. The player must send their most powerful army very quickly to a rift, to go to a Chaos Realm to get the macguffin, or otherwise the AI will get there before you and threaten to win the game eventually. You must close the rifts as quickly as possible, or they will cause so much corruption the penalties become incredibly damaging. I thought perhaps I could farm them for gold and xp, but the corruption penalties don't make it worthwhile. When you go to a Chaos Realm, the process (except for Khorne, fittingly) is very tedious. Each realm takes many turns to go through, and two of the realms have many teleports which consume all of your movement on activation. This means that much of the gameplay (especially in the Tzeentchian Realm gosh) is spent going to a teleport, finishing your turn, then maybe getting attacked by an army in the endturn. This wasn't so bad the first time! In fact, I thought it was pretty creative, and very slick in its implementation. But I'm on my third campaign now, and I've just got my second soul, and I don't want to do them any more. The repetition is getting to me. The goal of the campaign is just a slog. How the campaign is given to the player also removes all player agency. In much of the Total War series player agency impacts all levels of the game, from grand strategy to individual town management on the campaign map, to army composition and real time tactics in the battle screen. Where CA has received strong criticism in the past (Chaos invasion) it was related to player agency being broken in many examples. The Vortex Campaign for II is a good example of player agency being preserved, while the campaign is less mechanically interesting and more on-rails than the campaign in III (some of the DLC Vortex campaigns are the best campaigns in the entire Total War catalogue, both mechanically interesting and open ended). But I prefer the Vortex campaign at the moment. If this campaign gave some ability to influence or manipulate both when and where the Chaos incursions occur I think this campaign may have been better received. I mostly like the settlement battle rework. I do wish that some settlement battles were instead field battles. Maybe tier3 settlements or any defensive structure building rather than every settlement. I would prefer it if some of the maps were wider and that it was more clear what is terrain and what is traversable. Some of the tower placement is absolutely terrible, it's like they're traps for the player to sink currency into, which is feelbad gameplay. I would like wider streets so that I can actually place units properly instead of them autoplacing into bizarre thin regiments, and so that the units don't get into traffic jams. I would like them to immediately fix docked missile infantry not being able to fire. But broadly I like it, at its best it generates dynamic, flowing combats which are defender favoured, and at its worst it's kinda broken but at least different to a field battle. If you're a Total War, or Total Warhammer fan I've been having a lot of fun with it. Creative, diverse factions (if perhaps a little unit light) and some broad improvements to the series are a little let down by some odd and frustrating design choices and some lingering technical issues. It starts pretty good in my opinion, and it's only going to get better.If you're not already a fan, wait until the first round of DLC turns up and the game goes on special. But I've got a hundred hours already and my sleep has been ruined (one more turn) so it will certainly be worth it eventually.

2021 Counter Strike EnglishCounter Strike: Global Offensive is a very cool game. This game has everything a good shooter needs, lots of players, weapons, maps, modes. Above all, the game shines with its own system, which is a lot of fun and rewards good teamwork. In classic mode, anti-terrorists fight terrorists, the task of the terrorists is to place a bomb in one of the two locations (A or B on each map) and to protect it until it detonates. The task of the anti-terrorists is of course to prevent this. You can also simply kill all the players of a team to win a round. The teams are swapped after half of the match is played, this makes it very fair. It is worth using the voice chat to give your mates calls and tips. This way you can improve your English skills significantly (more than at school). Of course you sometimes meet people who are not nice and who have had a bad day, but that's the case in every game. All in all, CS: GO is a good tactical multiplayer shoter, which has remained good to this day. The advantages of this game outweigh the disadvantages. You can't go wrong with taking a look.GermanCounter Strike: Global Offensive ist ein sehr cooles Spiel. Dieses Spiel hat alles was ein guter Shooter benötigt, viele Spieler, Waffen, Karten und Modi. Dieses spiel glänzt vor allem mit seinem eigenen System, welches sehr viel Spaß macht und eine gute Teamarbeit belohnt. Im Klassischen Modus treten Anti-Terroristen gegen Terroristen an, die Aufgabe der Terroristen ist es dabei, eine Bombe an einem der beiden Orte (A oder B) zu platzieren und diese so lange zu beschützen bis sie detoniert. Die Aufgabe der Anti-Terroristen ist natürlich dies zu verhindern. Es können auch einfach alle spieler eines Teams können auch ganz einfach eliminiert werden, um eine Runde zu gwinnen. Die Teams werden nachdem die Hälfte des Match gespielt wurde gewechselt. Das macht es sehr fair. Es lohnt sich den voicechat zu verwenden, um seinen Mitspielern Calls und Tipps zu geben. So kann man sein Englisch deutlich verbessern (mehr als in der Schule). Natürlich trifft man auch manchmal auf leute die nicht nett sind und einen schlechten Tag hatten, aber das ist in jedem spiel so. Alles in allem ist Csgo ein sehr guter Taktischer Multilpayer Shooter, welcher sich bis Heute sehr gut gehalten hat. Die Vorteile dieses Spiels überwiegen. Es lohnt sich einen Blick zu riskieren.

2023 I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in its current state. I really enjoy the game, and believe you can too, but CA has gone out of control. We still have bugs from launch, and the updates aren't fixing them. If anything, updates and DLC's just add new ones in. Things that should be simple to fix are left unfixed, and things that are critical to gameplay are still issues. The fact that they are prioritizing releasing a new DLC and getting $25 out of you for the same amount of content that costs $10 in previous games, all while refusing to fix the underlying issues with the game are why I cannot recommend this to anyone. On top of that, the utter disrespect the community is getting from CA is unforgivable. The bans, the statements, none of that makes us feel like we are valued for what we are: paying customers. We are actively telling the company that we are unhappy and they need to do better, yet all we get is hostility and an implication that we should be grateful to them. I will no longer purchase any CA title or DLC until management recognizes their mistakes and walks back into a rhythm that garners respect from the paying customers, or they are removed. There is no way I am supporting the current mentality in any company. These games aren't a basic necessity, they're a luxury. They better start acting like it and work to get our money.

I STRONGLY recommend this game! They're adding a feature today to let new players join their friends, even if the server is full! I truly enjoy almost every aspect of this game. The open world that entice you to explore all areas, the unique design and art direction of monsters and environment, the base building. And the best thing about it all, no pay to win features. Furthermore they have both PVP and PVE servers, so there's something for each type of players. With a promise to add new content regularly, the game will stay interesting and relevant for a long time. In the near future, the game developers also promise to make seasons longer, and you won't lose most of your hard earned accomplishments like blueprints and so on. The developers really listens so the community and promptly address any issues that the community has.The game needs some work with the questing aspect, more specifically the dialogues.. most of the dialogue is unvoiced and is taking away from the immersion, surely this will be added in future updates. Playing on a PVE server, I also think the devs should consider adding more early game content that promotes Co-op gameplay, as it seems like there's not really a lot of content that makes you seek interactions between Meta-Humans. With almost 100 hours in the game, I still can still see myself playing this game a lot more, and I am looking forward to the future of Once Human!

2023 Rapid Decline of a Former Beloved "For the Players" Developer - Demands Tithes From All Players Followed by Veiled Threats of Death of The GameEdit 11/21/23 I will admit that I had the smallest of hope that they might finally do the right things. But after seeing today's "MASSIVE UPDATE!!", Creative Assembly literally confirmed that they don't care what we say or ask for. All I have to say is, who asked for the stuff they put in today's update? No one did. Maybe the work on the siege battles, but they made it worse!! And they messed up big time on the Hero Training ability. Who asked for new main menu backgrounds? No one ever. This was their last opportunity to turn things around for me and so many other players. I've recently moved to an area where all ISPs have data caps on the home internet. So for games that are 100gb or larger, I will keep on my 2tb ssd so I can play them if I ever want. This was one of the games that I basically had installed permanently. Today, I will be uninstalling this game and that means I will never install it again, unless Creative Assembly actually puts some type of real effort into saving this game. Or if I move to a different area where there is no data cap. Then I'll just install it to play it once and then probably uninstall it shortly after. Creative Assembly is basically rubbing it in our faces that they do NOT care about this game. Shadows of Price Change is $5 off, making it $10 less than the base game currently is on sale..... what a joke. I wouldn't even buy it if it was $10.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Original Review from 8/28/23For the sake of hoping this might make an impact that the company notices. I will be refusing to purchase any DLC from here on out unless they make a meaningful change to the price target they are going for with DLCs. Out of the 3 games, this one has given me the least enjoyment. Months, if not entire quarters go by without any new content (which is radically different from the first 2) and the entire first year of it's release seemed like a whole year went by with nothing, not even a word from them sometimes. The campaign was almost impossible to beat at launch with most factions until they finally corrected it and the fix for that took forever. Any meaningful changes made to the balances, will royally mess up any previous game saves you had if you were specializing in anything so you usually just start over (leading to numerous unfinished runs). I am a big warhammer fan and if it has warhammer or 40k's name on it, you're pretty much guaranteed to have me sucked in.I was salty when I saw the price of the chaos dwarves DLC, salty enough that i didn't pre-oder for the first time since the warhammer series started for total war. I waited until it was on sale and even then, I was still salty as I knew deep down that all I was really doing was pulling my pants down in preparation of their next DLC, shadows of price-change. Creative Assembly did not deviate from mine and numerous others' predictions, that they were preparing us so that they could tear us a new hole. Since said hole tearing, the only option CA has now officially given to us is to apologize to them and to then immediately beg them for more hole tearing. If we do not like that sole choice given to us, well they did mention ONE other option that they themselves are willing to go with. Which is to literally pick up the monopoly board and throw it across the room, all the while screaming about how it's all our faults that we didn't want to be extorted anymore. Ruining things for everyone, more specifically ruining things for their own employees' future job security by completely shutting down the game. I have been a big total war player since shogun 2 and own every one except for atilla, three kingdoms and throne of britannia. For all of the total war games that I do have, I have every single DLC for them. I could speak of how cheap they used to be back in the day, but lets focus on the recent entries that matter. The standard pricing was $8-12 for lords DLC and $15 for faction DLC. I remember holding off on the beastmen and the wood elf dlcs for warhammer 1, solely because of the price of $15. The only thing that got me to buy them in the end, was because they came with their own mini campaigns that whether they were good or not, they usually added a whole different play style for a faction, with other new elements and just plain new content. For warhammer 2, the tomb kings and vampire coast $15 DLCs each with their own new factions, that added new locations onto the then current map and the factions were good and fun enough that they still stay within the top 10-15 factions to play. That was what made it truly worth that price for that content.I remember when CA came out of no where and surprised us with the bretonnian FLC, or when they were coming out with heroes left and right that were lore connected. And now CA wants us to pay $25 for something that used to cost only like $8 in warhammer 1 & 2. And lets not forget about the number 1 thing that CA wants us to remember when we get butt hurt over their price hikes; that if we don't pay up, then they'll just shut the whole thing down. They'll cut any planned projects that don't require the minimalist of effort, they'll either fire or shift their employees around to different departments and/or localities, they'll make sure that any DLC that they will continue with, has the least amount of QA work done on and they'll do all that while doing their best to tell the world that it was all our fault for not paying an outrageous price.

TL DR: 9.2/10W:If you hold any curiosity in Chinese culture, tale of gods, the concept of "Wu Kong" that got abused by countless good/bad games, you should try this game. This game depict the best of the spirit "Wu Kong" and leave you with a tangled story for you to uncover, a good discussion of what is "Wu Kong".The next discussion should go to art, the art is amazing, probably the best Chinese companies have ever yield. The game play is also very fun, there are a large variety of different combination of spells to use, refund skill points are completely free. I had a great fun of thinking about builds for different bosses. This game's most similar comparison is God of War, it does a better job in a lot of aspects. you are constantly fighting mini-bosses and bosses with very little reuse of models. Character developments are amazing EXCEPT what I would discuss in the Ls.The story books tied to all normal mobs and bosses are fantastic too.English translation did a very good job, it conveys the majority of the idea of the hardest content to translate-- traditional Chinese.*** Next part contains a lot of spoilers***L:As the chosen one the you play the role of, "you" have limited character development, the game depict very little of your emotion, reaction to some most shocking, heart breaking, breathe taking events. other than collecting ***THE THINGS***(avoid spoiling here), you feel more like a vessel, even the real vessel feels more vivid (If you get to that fight, you will know what I mean).Quality of chapter 5 and 6 are questionable. Don't take me wrong, chapter 1 is a good starting, chapter 2, 3, 4 are amazing steady incrementing of difficulty and map puzzles, but chapter 5 feels short where you can't get to a lot of places where I think I should be able to go to and chapter 6 feels a rush to end.Camera on some bosses are aids, like really bad and annoying, some thin-leg bosses make that even worse.the hit-box on some boss registering feels not good.

2022 Elden Ring feels like the culmination of everything FromSoftware has learned from the SoulsBorne games and Sekiro. The world is vast and intricate. The characters are intriguing. The music is awesome. The voice acting is convincing. And the gameplay is satisfying. My only issue is that there are occasional frame rate stutters. The game has crashed very infrequently for me. I feel confident that these issues will be resolved. They've been very minor inconveniences for me, though I know others are having much more significant issues.

Warhammer 40k: Space Marines 2 Release Date: 05/09/2024 (PRE-RELEASE) Overview In "Space Marine 2," players once again take on the role of Captain Titus as he battles against the relentless forces of Chaos and the Tyranids, a swarm-like alien race. The game promises intense, visceral combat that combines brutal melee attacks with devastating ranged weaponry, staying true to the original's blend of action and strategy. The game is set to deliver improved visuals, more dynamic environments, and larger battles, taking full advantage of current-gen hardware. It also aims to capture the dark and oppressive atmosphere of the Warhammer 40k universe, appealing to both longtime fans and newcomers. Story Players continue the saga of Captain Titus, a seasoned Ultramarine who is thrust into a desperate battle against the relentless Tyranids, an alien species known for their hive mind and insatiable hunger. As the Imperium of Man faces overwhelming odds, Captain Titus must lead his squad through war-torn environments, using a mix of brutal melee and powerful ranged combat to defend humanity from annihilation. The story explores themes of duty, sacrifice, and the eternal struggle against the dark forces threatening the galaxy. Pros The Story is breath taking, it will make you fully immersed. Character Dialogue is very good – Through out the campaign, you will be your team mates converse conversation / arguments Campaign is an average of 12 hours long on normal difficulty The game is set to challenge you, even on normal difficulty. For me that is a “Pro” The Settings between main hub (Ship) to Planets where the war takes place is unique on every mission. Lots of weapon choices for you to use, some weapons are better than others based the enemies you are fighting against. AI team mates (If playing alone) if you die they will focus to revive you Cons “Saving Checkpoints” don’t really exist when you go back to main menu or quit the game. The missions are a good hour or two long. If you quit halfway through or towards the end. You will have to start that mission all over again. You can’t customise the way you look throughout the campaign (Minor) AI Team mates are a bit dumb, they don’t really fight off bosses and mainly leave it down to you. Executions they will leave for you to do instead of them. Sometimes and I mean sometimes (uncommon) they will do the executions for you. Gameplay The gameplay in "Space Marine 2" centers on fast-paced, brutal combat as players control Captain Titus, blending heavy melee attacks with powerful ranged weapons. It emphasizes the visceral experience of being a Space Marine, allowing players to chain attacks, execute combos, and use tactics to battle the Tyranid hordes. Designed to capture the intensity and scale of Warhammer 40,000, the game offers a mix of strategy, skill, and raw power. Pros Weapons from Hand Guns, Rifles, Snipers and Melee weapons feel great! Melee Weapons are a strong point in the game to take down your foes making you feel powerful against your enemies. From Knife, Chainsaw, Hammer and Sword. Each feeling different but impacting Hand Guns are great to pick off smaller targets but also allowing you to take out “Snipers” in the background that is bothering you and your team. Rifles feel great, Semi-Automatic weapons that allows you to take out swarm of enemies Plasma weapons are strong against larger enemies compared to swarms. Which allows you to pick your weapons for the right fight. I like how the gameplay changes throughout PvE Operations & Throughout the campaign. You can pick your weapons wisely. Cons Minor Bug – Larger Enemies uses a charge attack which then YEETS you into the air (Its Funny) but not a major deal breaker. This is very rare but can happen. Cut-scene, loading screen to Cut-scene and loading screen. It gets annoying on PvE Operations BUT! It does allow players to skip cut-scenes IF all players vote to skip. If you are playing with randoms… You might be watching the same cutscene repeatedly. Server Disconnects – Yes, they use Epic Game Servers, From experience of being an admin maintaining servers on Squad. It is TERRIBLE. Had a lot of server disconnects on the Pre-release but hopefully this will improve overtime. Graphics "Space Marine 2," built on the Swarm Engine, features highly detailed graphics that capture the grimdark Warhammer 40,000 universe. The game includes richly textured environments and meticulously crafted character models, with impressive lighting and visual effects that enhance the dark, immersive experience. Pros Art is AMAZING – They spent a lot of time to every attention to details Customization to your character is amazing, you can edit each armour and colour. You can make yourself look more unique compared to others. Visualization is absolutely stunning. Blood, Gore, Shadows, Environment, War-torn, Lighting, etc. Is a 10 out of 10. For a Pre-release the game is playable, haven’t experienced any Graphical bugs. Cons If you are running low to mid-tier computer like me, its not end of the world. I get average of 50 to 60fps on medium graphics with some shadows / effects of low (GTX 1080). Information from friends who have mid-high end PC’s they get an average of 60FPS on 2K monitor on High Settings (RTX 3080) Replayability Is expected to offer decent replayability through its intense combat mechanics and the potential for multiple difficulty levels, encouraging players to refine their skills and tactics. While the core narrative may be linear, the satisfaction of mastering combat, experimenting with different weapons, and facing various enemy types could motivate multiple playthroughs. Additionally, if the game includes any form of multiplayer, co-op modes, or post-launch content, these would significantly enhance its replayability. However, the extent of replayability will ultimately depend on the variety of content and any additional features beyond the main campaign. Pros Campaign is 12 hours long to complete on Normal Difficulty. PvE Operations (CO-OP) Mode has 6 missions on Pre-Release. There will be more to come according to Road Map the developer’s has released. PvP is Fun, It allows you to unlock more cosmetics for your character which can be used on PvE Operations. PvE Operations allows your to upgrade your weapons mastery and perks. Which allows your to re-play missions on a higher difficulty (Like DarkTide and Vermintide) There are 6 Classes playable for PvE Mode – Assault, Vanguard, Bulwark, Tactical, Heavy and Sniper Cons Levelling each character & Weapons can be very grindy / time consuming Final Verdict Summarise my overall impressions of the game. I absolutely loved the campaign! This game does need day 1 patch to fix some bugs with Match-Making cross platform. I highly recommend this game if you are looking for 3rd Person shooter, killing swarms of enemies which a Rich Story Campaign.

2022 WOW, a game that actually lives up to the hype? It's insane how this hits every nail on the head perfectly. You know it's bad when you expect all triple A games to just be steaming piles of trash that you are shocked when a game works perfectly right away and has actual attention to detail in it. What's that? The water actually moves when you walk and role in it? Not only that but it cleans the blood off your character and weapons and adds a damp look to your character? This game is oozing with detail and works right out of the box. It's crazy and it was well worth the wait. Thank you.Actual review. It's like if Skyrim, Breath of the Wild, and all the Souls/Borne games had a massive orgy and made this masterpiece. There are times the game doesn't even feel like a Souls game anymore and that's a GOOD THING. Just to be lost in it and see it as it's own game rather than decending from something else is amazing. Of course you can't look past the animations and enemies being ripped right from the previous FromSoftware works but honestly, it all works. Just exploring and getting lost in the world and walking around, seeing all the amazing things put into this game is such a treat and with how games have been releasing lately, this should be a technical impossibility yet they did it, they really did it and made something amazing. Souls play-throughs usually take around 16 hours to beat. I'm 16 hours in (currently) and I haven't been following the main path at all. I literally went the complete opposite direction and it actually let me and I didn't get punished for it. Exploration is key and this game does an outstanding job at doing it.Game is so good, it's actually getting people who don't like Souls but love other games like BotW and Skyrim into it. You know they're doing something right when they can break out of their mold and attract other fan-bases like that.
Nintendo really outdid themselves with this year's Donkey Kong.

2022 There are huge caveats with a recommendation of this game.The gameplay when everything comes together is incredible. The feeling of clutching a round for your team, especially when you're with friends, is beaten only by the elation of winning a close-fought match through sheer doggedness and team spirit. Frankly, in those kinds of matches even losing 16-14 can leave you with a smile on your face.However, I don't know how I would get into this game as a beginner nowadays. Though if I didn't know better I'd probably try the free-to-play version, I recommend at least paying for a Prime-enabled account. The problem with cheaters is very large and could lead to a quick disillusionment with the game. Some veterans even leave the game because of this problem. It's such a terrible sinking feeling when you arrive in a match and see an enemy, or even a teammate, spinbotting or obviously hacking. You just know you've wasted the next 15 minutes or, if they only start hacking after they get angry and falsely believe you're hacking, you've wasted even longer. Either that or you can leave, but you will get a cooldown from matchmaking servers for abandoning a match! If you are intent on learning it competitively, I'd suggest researching third-party services like faceit (available for anyone as far as I know) or ECL (I believe currently only hosting servers located in Europe). ECL actively moderates its users and seems to have a fairly welcoming community, perhaps it would be relatively easy to find people of a similar skill level willing to help out a beginner. Unfortunately I think the base experience in Valve's own matchmaking system can be horrible and beginners might have a decent experience, or a completely off-putting one with toxic teammates who can't remember what it was like to be new in the game.Prepare for the worst. I hope you get to enjoy the best of what CS has to offer.

Definitely DO NOT recommend this.I've grown up on a large variety of games, and this game suffers from bad pacing and design.You need a 4080 to play because I've found the input lag unbearable. From technical reviews like Digital Foundry, you *must* turn off frame generation and other settings (global illum, shadows, anti-aliasing, etc) because these cause significant input delay. Why buy a game costing $94 only to kill visual settings?? Its optimization is shockingly bad when other visually stunning games run well. Warframe, Doom Eternal, Elden Ring, etc are all examples of fast-paced gorgeous games at over 200fps on older systems. Act 1 unfortunately runs past 2 hours so by the time these issues become apparent, I can't get a refund.Key problems:1) Buggy input queues for spirits, transformation, and medicines. Sometimes I must keep tapping the button to trigger usage. Sometimes a light tap interrupts my attack combo instead of queuing up. Sometimes nothing happens after spamming repeatedly and I'm standing around while the boss is waiting in the background weirdly.2) Dodge mechanic very inconsistent. e.g. I've managed to dodge bosses OHKO attack, but after repeated experiments, it's inconsistent. The perfect dodge mechanic also doesn't trigger consistently. It feels like you inconsistently have a larger hitbox.3) Horrifically bad camera angles. Most games have an "greasy camera slide" algorithm to detect obstructions between the player and camera origin. It auto-moves the camera. In this game, I got stuck behind a pillar or tree or bush until I'm dead. Also, they did not notice to zoom out on the camera for mega-boss stages, so you're often looking between Wukong's legs or the earth.4) Inconsistent stage design. In act 1, the game has shrines right before main bosses. Later on, you must run back across entire stages to get back to a boss. If you die many times... Good luck.5) Toxic community. Astroturfing by China fanboys makes it impossible to get help or raise attention to the devs for fixes. No dissent is allowed. Everything else is downvoted or harrassed. You can't even make recommendations on tuning graphic settings. Even asking to tune down the difficulty traps you into needless arguments about how to get good. It's amazing how rude they are to older adults with jobs and kids, but still want to enjoy the story.Devs have not communicated on improving the game. Best to wait for actual substantial updates before making a purchase.-----------------28 Aug 2024Made it into act 4. Act 3 is easily 3 times larger than act 1 and 2, which is extremely tedious. Invisible walls everywhere. Many corners look like they can be explored, but are dead ends with no visual design to prevent us from wasting time. You can't interact with the environment unlike Genshin Impact. There's no flying. No wall climbing. Even warframe, a FREE game, I can bullet jump and wall latch. The movement here makes the monkey king look lame.Boss fights in act 3 were also lame. You dance between the boss legs, so your camera is always twitching between his legs and floor. The company calls itself Game Science, claiming to be a serious science and engineering studio... But learned no lessons by GOTY games over the past decade for such things.After unlocking most skills, the game play is also... boring. A few enemies have long attack chains, yet you must keep dodging because upgraded attacks cannot disrupt them. Thus, Dodge Fest Simulator.So you'll cheese it by charging up thrust stance right? That's even more boring. You can't spam magic as magic does NOT recharge until you get special gourd much later. So you have to save your spells and transformation by cheesing through the entire stageORbe forced tododgedodgedodgedodgebecause enemies cannot be interrupted without charged heavy attacks. So keep dodging until your focal points are enough to heavy attack. Then repeat dodging.Finally, the story?It's as if the devs have never studied their own culture or history. The reasons that I love Journey to the West, even studied asian religions and philosophies in university, was because of the deeply respectful and profound allegorical discourses absent from other civilisations. From a story writing perspective, this is important. 3000+ years of profound and rich source material exists for story writers.There's an abundance to create a beautiful cast of characters, each with deep complex portrayals that could have made the story profoundly moving. But none of that was seen."Journey to the West" was written at a time (circa 1592) when Buddhism had thrived in a huge sprawling dynastic empire (circa Tang Dynasty 618-907). Before Buddhism came (circa BCE 206), Shamanism, rich regional folk lore, Taoism (circa BCE 450), Confucius (circa BCE 551, Hundred Schools of Thought era), and all manner of secular sects were already deeply rooted. "Journey to the West" is a rare culmination of allegorical novel writing popular over centuries. Yet, none of this was used in game.Instead, the characters are shallow and lacking depth. Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are liars neglecting vows. Celestial court is full of superficial violent immortals. Humans are weak animals at their mercy. Demons are always evil because it is their birth nature. The profound essence of China's culture no longer exists in the game. Like China cities today, all that exists in the game is a beautiful facade. What is China culture?In the original novel, countless profound moments exist. The one I love is about the length of their journey in chapter 24:"你自小时走到老，老了再小，老小千番也还难。只要你见性志诚，念念回首处，即是灵山。""You can walk from young till old, from old till young again, and even for 1000 cycles, it would still be difficult (to reach the end of your journey). But once you truly achieve the resolute perception (of wisdom), (realising that) Buddha-nature (exists) in all things, then you will have immediately arrived at Spirit Mountain (at the end of your journey)."There are countless lines of beautiful prose and poetry peppered across the original novel.Moments when loyalty and brotherhood stand in contrast to easy victories and unscrupulous tactics. Moments when you realise, for all of Wukong's fiery temper and violence, he is a person that deeply cares about doing the right thing with a deep penetrating wisdom that cuts through the commonly accepted social beliefs. Disappointingly, all of that. Gone. Lost.All we have left is a beautiful spectacle mired by aggressive toxic fanboys and a superficial court (studio)?Maybe this is the ultimate allegory; spiritual successor in the lamentation of modern China. 表面美化，盖掉缺点，心中百烂。Maybe that is the true intent of the game developers.

An excellent third-person shooter that immerses players in the Warhammer 40k universe.I'd say the game is a bit pricey for its current content, but a roadmap has already been released with content through to the end of 2025.The single-player campaign, is the sequel to the first opus and can be played solo or in co-op for up to 3 players. It's really good, but rather short (I'd say 8 hours of play). Then there's a less scripted co-op campaign where you can customize your space marine and play different classes. It's fairly short, but is designed to be played several times to improve your characters. There is also the 6vs6 PvP mode, which is really cool. Progression is pretty good, and you want to keep playing to unlock the next weapons and cosmetics, but unfortunately there are only 3 maps and 3 game modes at the moment.In conclusion, I'd recommend it to all fans of the 40k universe or anyone looking for a good shooter, but I'd advise you to buy it at a reduced price or wait for the developers to add a little more content.

2022 Genre - Souls Open World Game with Summons+ Runs great on my 3 year old PC+ Variety of Weapons and Foes+ Character Creation at start+ Looks Sweet+ Fast Travel+ Map helps a lot+ Feels like an open world+ Things to discover as you go+ A limited but useful guide on direction of travel+ Active community at moment (long may it continue)+ Summons can be smooth- Summons can be temperamental- Early bosses seem a bit too hard (even with 2 summons)- Feels like it might need too much grind, although that's fun at the moment- To progress in some areas you literally have to take a leap of faith- Can be difficult to spot your lost Souls...I mean GraceOverall I'm not disappointed by what I got on release day, although it's not perfect

The style of the game is on point with satisfying gameplay, but it has some GLARING issues. I'd recommend it, but I hope it gets some polish soon!Pros:Style: The feel of the 40k universe is really hit on the head. This alone has probably gotten me through the game. I just really adore it.Audio: Crunchy sound design is very satisfying.Weapons: The gear you use feels pretty good, the design is limited, but it's loyal to the universe.Gameplay: Fairly rhythmic fighting with parries, counters & dodges.Big enemies: Boss fights can be tough ( Angel of Death difficulty ), but typically manageable ( caveat below ).Story: The story is a bit shallow, but good enough.Cons:The most glaring issue is ally AI. It's horrendous, pathetically bad. This can make some boss fights an absolute slog when you're trying to balance yourself to proceed through the fight. It also destroys immersion seeing an Astartes knuckle f***ing himself in the corner while you're fighting for your life.Hit boxes: The hit boxes are bad. You'll get hit at bizarre ranges & you'll often shoot invisible walls when attacking enemies. I've also been struck countless times through cover from ranged attacks.Homing Melee Attacks: One the most annoying things in this game is enemies leaping at you ( not talking about parry counters ) & having them turn in the air or have them YA YEET themselves after you when you dodge.Stun Lock: Though I understand it's a swarm hitting you & that's sort of the point, getting stun locked is just a poor choice. No one likes stun lock. No one likes losing control of their character. No one wants to have 2/3 of their health gone from 3 gaunts.

2022 A Dark Fantasy for the Ages...» Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling. It is vastly different from other open-world games I have experienced such as The Witcher 3 and Skyrim, which are story and questline driven. From the get-go, Elden Ring does not impose any particular playstyle or route on you. You are completely free to do what you want to from the very start of the game. You can finish the main storyline and beat the final boss, or you can explore the entire map without ever seeing the main bosses. It truly is up to you with no outside influence. This sense of freedom in choice and exploration in any open-world game is refreshing.Not to mention, Elden Ring has also mastered the art of subtlety. For example, for a game like Skyrim, there are various elements such as the character dialogues, leveling system, and various landmarks that I could clearly point to in contributing to the game's success. However, this is not the case here. It is hard to place a finger on one specific thing that makes Elden Ring so enjoyable. Many times I have gone in to play this game for half an hour, only to become immersed, losing track of time and playing for hours on end. I believe that the game's features, i.e. the combat system, transportation, landscape, lore, storytelling, etc., complement each other in a way that none of them are overbearing. At the same time, these elements come together in such a fluid manner that I, as the player, cannot notice it and am drawn into a level of immersion that I have not felt from any game before.Environment» This game has one of the most enormous and intricately detailed worlds I have ever seen in gaming. I have not had a single moment where the map felt desolate or empty; there was always something to see and explore. The castles, cities, and fortresses that you must traverse in this game are truly awe-inspiring. They are all massive, unique, and filled with a plethora of secret areas just waiting to be uncovered. The landscapes of the world are also astonishing. The sheer variety and scale of the environments are a sight to behold. Players can expect to explore vast mountains, forests, fields, deep caves, ancient ruins, and even hidden underground civilizations. It is clear that a great amount of work went into the design of all of these areas, as they are all exceptionally detailed and have complex lore, realism, and beauty to them that makes them a joy to explore.Combat» The combat in this game is utterly masterful, blending elements from many of FromSoftware's previous works including Dark Souls 3, Bloodborne, and Sekiro to create an extremely tense, fluid, and customizable combat system. The amount of variety in terms of different playstyles, build variation, and weapon types are enough to make the combat in this game endlessly enjoyable.You also have more freedom in how you approach combat than any previous souls game thanks to a bunch of familiar new systems that are used in interesting ways here. Stealth is a more viable option thanks to the addition of crouch-walking, which finally lets you sneak by tough enemies or get behind them for a critical hit; there’s now horseback combat in large, open areas which gives you more mobility and the ability to attack on both sides with your right-handed weapon, but has the drawback of taking away your ability to roll out of the way of big attacks; you can craft items on the fly using materials found in the world so you can be ready for whatever a situation calls for; you can summon a large variety of creatures to fight for you, each with their own unique abilities and situational advantages; and most substantially, you can equip Ashes of War to your weapons and completely change their affinity and skill.The Ashes of War system essentially combines two elements of prior Souls games – weapon affinities and weapon skills – by making them items that you can freely equip to your armaments. For example, let’s say you find a really good rapier and like the moveset, but are building your character with a focus on the Intelligence stat, which means it won’t get the kind of damage bonuses it needs to be a viable weapon. If you find an Art of War that bestows a magic spell onto a weapon, you can equip it and transform it into a magic weapon, thereby giving it Intelligence scaling on top of whatever skill the Ash of War has. Best of all, if you eventually decide to re-spec into a different build, you can still keep the same weapon and just put a different Ash of War onto it. Of course, you also have to find a specific item to unlock the different affinities, but it's nonetheless an incredibly smart addition that allows for a ton of variety in your preferred weapons.Bosses» The boss roster of Elden Ring is also extremely difficult and unforgettable. Most of the boss battles are remarkably challenging, rich with lore, and breathtaking. The complex fighting style of the bosses cannot be overlooked. Many of the bosses have extremely intricate, fast, and punishing attacks that are both tough to avoid and fun to fight against. This makes the battles against the bosses feel like a dance, as you rhythmically dodge their devastating combo attacks before finding small windows to go on the offensive. This is nothing new, as this style of boss encounter is exactly what the Dark Souls series pioneered. However, Elden Ring perfects this age-old formula by giving the bosses bigger movesets, greater speed, and more complex combos than ever before. Some of the bosses can hammer you with 10-hit long combos with little margin for error, and the player must master a boss' moveset if they ever hope to come out on top. When you combine this with the grotesquely stunning visual design, you get some of the tensest and most engaging boss battles in history.On top of all this, the epic scope of the boss encounters and vast areas is further heightened by Elden Ring's stellar musical score. It perfectly conveys the emotional connection that you should have with whichever boss you are fighting. Many of the soundtracks in this game are utterly blood-pumping in a way that few other video games can match.Conclusion» Overall, in my opinion, Elden Ring more than lives up to the enormous hype surrounding it, proving to be one of the most memorable, challenging, and complex gaming experiences of the last century.Score: 9.8/10Was this review helpful?» If so, please leave a rating. Awards are also greatly appreciated!

2017 Absolutely not recommendable because of the insane ammount of hackers.Today i dropped From Global Elite to supreme and lost 3 games on SMFC against Rage Hacking kids. In one game we were 8:4 ahead and 1 opponent left, joined back 3 rounds later jsut to announce he quickly downloaded a hack. So after he ragecarried the remaining rounds getting 11 MVPs we obviously lost. Don't get me wrong there are some strong players in this game who hit insane shots but with my almost 6 k hours of Counterstrike experience i can tell you that at least 5/7 matches have one hacker +, not even counting the insane amount of players using some kind of radar hack. In fact Valve doesn't even care. Do they try getting rid of the Hacker Problem? No, not really. Instead they keep adding skins and cases you have to pay for. Overwatch function seemed nice in the early state, but watching an overwatch session, you can't hear the ingame voice chat, which pretty much makes it useless. How do you want to hear if some1 keeps playing music ingame, uses a microphone of 1937 or keeps flaming? Or a hacker calling ingame? No, all you can see is a Scoreboard and the PoV of the Suspect, of course you are not able to switch the teammates. Counterstrike Anti-Cheat is so damn useless, a friend with 1 year programming experience was able to build a hack, which was undetected for over 2 years.Another problem ist the community. Most players below LEM are queueing with 2+ mates only speaking their own explicit language. So why the hell is there no "Team-Language" Option ingame to fix these kind of things?All in all CS-GO is a nice skill-based shooter with high potential, being ruined by a company only interested in milking the cow and a highly toxic community. To enjoy this game you would actually need to buy ESEA or just not play any kind of competative matches, which would make cs go kind of senseless.Cheers

2023 I've been a long time player of counterstrike. I was known as Stumpsy or sTuMpS, I was born with a disability (no hands) and I stumbled across CSGO around 2013. I was obviously really bad when I first started and only played CS as a casual game with friends who were much better than me. It wasn't until I started messing around with mouse/keyboard settings that changed everything for me. I discovered the setting Raw Mouse Input on/off and for me, not being able to pick up the mouse with no fingers, what this setting did literally changed the way I was able to play and literally accelerated gameplay for me. If I flicked fast in a direction I was able to navigate around maps and aim without having to lift my mouse off the pad. So say if I was turning right it would be a fast flick to right, back to center, fast flick to right again etc. Doing this I could basically do a full 360 within like 3-4 swipes. If i had raw mouse input turned on, that setting negates as it only follows where the mouse moves. It really bummed me out that removing this setting has pretty much ended my entire csgo gaming experience and considering they deleted csgo altogether with the replacement of CS2. I was looking forward to playing the game with friends and I've tried so many different setting to try and replicate what raw mouse input did for me. This game was the only fps game that offered a setting like that and its the only reason I stuck around playing csgo for so many years. It sucks watching all your friends play without you and it sucks feeling like you can no longer enjoy a game that gave you so much joy for so many years. I hope the devs at Valve see this and add the setting back into the game.I have included a video explaining how I play and why mouse raw is so important for me. YouTube™ Video: How I Play Explained (Sorry If I'm hard to understand, I tried my best) Views: 4,722 So I finally got around to making this video cause heaps of people have been requesting it. It took a lot of guts to even talk in front of the camera as I'm so conscious about my speech problem. and another video of my twitch compilations to show off actual gameplay. YouTube™ Video: Old CS Twitch Highlights Views: 1,084 Found some old clips and decided to make a clip of some stuff people haven't seen. Enjoy.

2022 Imagine if they took Markus Wulfhart's campaign from TW2 and made it the entire game for TW3. CA took one of the worst design elements, random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ spawning in your territory, and cranked it up to 11.Problems?Minor settlement battles are a grindUnit balance is off by a considerable marginDemon unit roster feels lacklusterKislev is "recommended start campaign" but is cancer.More cases of a mediocre item (Katarin's Ice Cloak) having one of the most cancerous quest battles, while awesome items are given for free or little effortThe debuffs from chaos corruption is BS. -300 growth, -20 public order, and more at 90+ corruptionThe demon portal stuff can eat away so many turns for your army you send in. Worsen that by pissing away more time after they get out to sit in a major settlement to get rid of the corruption. 50% chance so will it be 3 turns? 10? Pray to RNGesusYou are so pigeon-holed into playing the campaign the way they want that they somehow made the game feel linear to play. The playing "tall" incentive also plays into that problem.I was hoping Legendary Lords would have more uniqueness to them. It's still just okay. The regular lords still have obvious worst and best (like Cathay's dragon lords vs their normie lords).Autoresolve is as punishing as ever, if not worse.Certain spells are just garbage. Like the ice magic having an overpriced version of Spirit Leech which was already overpriced.I don't understand how CA was working towards such a great game with TW2 and then just nose dived this one. It feels like so many of the problems from before just persist in this and while there are improvements, it's just too many issues to be having a good time. This game is not worth $60. It was one of those situations where I was like "Oh how can they screw up TW3. They just have to take TW2 and improve on it." but then they goofed up.The potential is there, but it's getting a big thumbs down from me until they make some serious changes.Update:So they have made a lot of big changes. The big thing is that Immortal Empires is out and most of the good stuff is associated with that. The main campaign has also been improved. Settlement battles are still bad, but they're not nearly as frequent. Overall, I'd still give it a thumb down until more improvements are done. (Like fixing normie lords vs actually good lords)

Pros: - Fantastic visuals that capture the 40k aesthetics- Good variety in playstyles among the classes- Good visual customization by individual armour parts- Satisfying gunplay and melee, visceral finishers- Large arsenal of weapons, each with minor variations along their own progression paths- Tyranids are extremely well realized. They nailed the scope of the swarms. The Gargoyle swarms absolutely managed to convey the scope of a tyranid invasion. While it should be even worse than this, it’s a perfectly fine approximation given limited computing power. Tyranid dynamics were translated nicely into gameplay. Take out the warrior, so the gaunts collapse, take out the Hive Tyrant to bring an entire assault to a screeching halt. All the special bioforms feel distinctive and accurate, with the Lictor being my favourite. The fact that auspex scan reveals him, that the initial boss encounter is basically Predator and the sound cues whenever a lictor is lurking make it a great experience.Cons:- Characters are cardboard cut-outs you cannot customize. Wanna play the vanguard? You gonna be playing as Decimus Jackson Jr.- Cast and general cutscene presentation:The cast is tragically flat. Titus being a miserable cu** is fitting, but Gadriel is needlessly antagonistic just to construe drama, and Chairon is alright, I guess. Also zero facial expressions on Gadriel.Captain McAngus is the usual trope, hates your guts at first, but comes around when he realizes you were right all along. Boring, no air about him, probably just a GW mandated Phobos Captain miniature insert.Amon-Ra was so-so. He had some glimpses of personality and an overall interesting design, but there was just not enough screen time to really explore his character. I’d have wished for a more fleshed out characterization because there was good potential there, especially for a tzeentchian manipulator.Worst of all was Calgar though, no gravitas nor intensity, looked comical fighting. Could’ve had a badass scene of him 1on1ing the Swarmlord or something. Anything really to mark him as the chapter master. Quite disappointing.In general, it seems like they couldn’t match the intensity from the actual gameplay in the cutscenes. They feel lifeless, often uncanny and unfinished. I really wanted to be done with the campaign asap to enjoy ops mode without spoilers, which is not a good sign in my book.That being said, the actual meat of the game is good. Melee and shooting feel great, once you’ve gotten the hang of the combat flow. Tyranids are more developed on that front, with Tzeentch providing a slight spike in difficulty while lacking the satisfaction of gory finishers and internal faction dynamics.I’ll probably spend a good amount of time playing operations, as the classes feel distinct enough to get fresh experiences out of them, even with the limited mission set. A solid 7/10 for me as a Warhammer 40k enthusiast. Probably more of a 5-6/10 for tourists.

This is one of those times when I wish there was a middle ground between Recommended and Not Recommended. Aside from what are largely circumstantial issues, such as the Epic Games integration and performance problems that some people are having, neither of which I have personally had a problem with; there are things that this game does right, and things that it does worse than the first game. I don't normally write reviews, and especially ones that are longer than a few sentences, but I feel like I have to say at least a few things about every general aspect of the game here.To start with the good sides:- Story: It serves its predecessor well, it answers a lot of questions with some subtle references which I really liked, and is overall well written, especially when compared to some of the recent 40k lore.- Visuals: The sense of scale is impressive, the fidelity is as you would expect from a AAA title, and the animation work is unique in the sense that it doesn't necessarily copy from either Space Marine or Astartes, but has its unique take on depicting space marines which is fluid and satisfying.- Audio: It's not on the same level as Darktide, especially in the soundtrack, but it gets the job done quite well in a lot of places. There are a few disappointing sounds, like the heavy bolter, but it otherwise manages to feel atmospheric.Now the bad or mediocre sides:- Gameplay: It's so hit and miss. When you break it down on paper, it sounds good, but the execution leaves something to be desired. The ranged combat is okay; the weapons are a bit too inaccurate during longer bursts for being carried by the superhuman warriors that space marines are, and most of them feel the same, with a lot feeling like they're less powerful than their counterparts in the first game, or fulfilling a purpose that another weapon can fulfill better. It's the melee combat that is the main problem. You're better off playing it like Dark Souls and rolling around, both in PVE and PVE, because parry is simply too inconsistent. It doesn't matter if you perfectly time your parry if you are already playing an animation, like an attack, because you cannot cancel that animation. This problem gets worse when the attacks, even for the knife and chainsword, are much slower and clunkier than their counterparts in the first game. Additionally, in PVE, enemies can interrupt your attacks by hitting you, but you cannot interrupt theirs using the same method, which makes it not only feel unfair, but also weightless. The animation-pause does more to hurt the experience than help, as timing gets offset every time you hit something. Finally, melee in PVP can be cheated easily by just rolling, kind of like you can cheat the PVE by just rolling. Do not even try for parrying, it's a gamble. All of this makes the combat feel unfinished or badly designed, and I really hope this is addressed because it is currently my biggest pet peeve about the gameplay.- Customisation: Nonexistent for Chaos, and practically nonexistent for space marines. With Chaos, each class is limited to a warband, so if you're playing a raptor for example, you will be a Night Lord. You can change colours, but you will still retain Night Lord model pieces, same goes for the other classes and warbands. As far as I'm concerned, it doesn't exist for Chaos. For the Primaris, it is also very lackluster. There are less options than there were in the first game, and they're lacking in the variety department, especially when it comes to chapter-specific content. Also, please, for the love of the Emperor, give us back Space Marines. Not Primaris. Space Marines. Not everyone likes the Primaris designs, and I certainly don't. But I feel like this would fall on deaf ears, it's not like GW ever listens to what the community wants.Overall, it's a decent game. It's hard to judge because there are parts that are very good, and then there's a couple parts that are really bad, and it's hard to dictate which one outweighs the other because they're largely dependent on what the user expects from the game.
As a Sabermarine, I stand with Chapter Master Karch.We defend the Imperium of Gamers against the heresy and chaos that has befallen our precious Imperium.

2022 []~(￣▽￣)~* :praisesun:OVERWATCH OPS is the first and only roleplay event by Argentinian RP connoisseur Agent Smith. It was published posthumously, as Smith disappeared and was declared dead some time after writing it. Critically acclaimed upon release, OW: OPS is considered the first HL2RP opera. Semi-autobiographical, the event's first stage dubbed "SMITTY" depicts Smith discovering he is wanted for murder. After he is taken away at the end of the first scenario, the rest of the event reveals aspects of his past and ultimately the crime which he is being hunted for in OPS. This circular narrative has been noted for its resemblance to the Roleplay Cycle™; some reviewers believe Agent Smith to be teaching others the secrets of ROLEPLAY and a way to evolve roleplay itself through this structure, while others decry him as a would-be Kuropixel.

2023 So, my history with Total War Warhammer is complex. Since Warhammer Battle March, i was dreaming of Total War picking up this setting. When TWW I released, i bought it instantly and was in heaven. With TWW II i ascended beyond mortal planes of bliss as a Skaven Main. For real TWW II just made TWW I look like a tech demo. Mortal Empires and the excellent DLC content was just another cherry on top. TWW III actually did not excite me that much, but i was optimistic. Yes, i don't care for Ogres, Kislev and monogods. But its TWW and it will be fun. When it came out, i was pretty happy with it. There were tons of bugs and bad design decisions, but it was still fun and lots of content for it's price. At this point, many people were already vocalizing their discontent with the quality of CA's work, but i didn't (yet) share their opinion. In reality, the same thing that had happened to titles like Battlefield V or War Thunder happened to TWW: The developer studio disconnected from their players. Since Grace left the Community Management, relations worsened more and more. Player feedback was largely ignored. Praised features were discontinued. Bugs weren't adressed. In short, CA's modus operandi shifted from "quality game to produce player goodwill and thus steady longterm income" to "make as much money as possible in as short a time frame as possible". The deal with TWW used to be that the base game was very price efficient, lots of good content for 60 €, and that the DLC were less price efficient but freshened up the experience and stretched the base game content out. And this is the crux of the story: With the old race pack DLCs you got ~ 1/8 of the content for 1/4 of the price of the base game. That is fine and i have to date bought literally every single DLC. With the Chaos Dwarfs DLC that shifted to 1/8 of the content for around 1/2 half of the price of the base game. Understandably, people were upset, but at least they got a completely new race with great mechanics and 3 lords. Now, with the newest DLC, they charged the same price, but with way less content. In the old lord packs (those that dont introduce new races) the players got one new lord per faction and a few new units and heroes, that changed the whole playthrough. One additional lord was also released for free for all players. Lord packs always had a cost of 10 €. The new lord pack, Shadows of change, introduces three lords, but no free lord for everyone. The few new units are in part reskins. There are no heroes that shake up the playthroughs. The units are at best support units and are pretty irrelevant (Vortex beast maybe excepted, because it is cool). For this they charge 25 €. That is a 150 % price increase. CA has not taken the opportunity to overhaul mechanics the community has been calling out since release as unfinished, unfun or annoying. They have not communicated on player criticism. Even the content creators in CA's creator program have called this DLC out as a cash grab. So should you buy Warhammer III? Maybe, but the promise of TWW will not be kept. You will get no DLC you can stretch the base game with for a reasonable price. The bugs that plagued the game from release are still not fixed. We as consumers have only one way to vote and that is with our money. So no, i would not recommend you buy TWW III. Maybe CA wakes up and changes it's direction, like Gaijin has done with War Thunder. Maybe it will fall flat like Battlefield V. I wouldn't get invested if i were you.

Played enough hours to form thoughts on the game, a summary Campaign is basically what I wanted from a sequel to Space Marine 1 but it exceeded my expectations, offers one of the most epic and cinematic experiences I ve had in gaming and especially in 40k sense, meticulously crafted with detail, you could have read about these stories in 40k books but to feel it on this lvl is something else entirely If you dont like the gameplay loop, dont bother as its one of the main factors that makes the game enjoyable, you feel like a space marine, visceral and chonky combat with power fantasy it expands in pve with various perks but as pve is connected to the main story, it remains to be epic and still fun to do with unique missions and things to strive and grind forpvp is quite fun due to the gameplay loop, reminds you of Halo times of quick and easy pvp, fast rounds, fast killsthose modes do need more love with balancing, more content and features but already some good indicatorsnow if the modes do not appeal to you as well as the gameplay loop, it wont be worth for youand as a bonus for warhammer fans the customisation looks incredible, it looks like i am actually painting minis without investing 10k (ofc it wont replace the whole thing) but damn its the best visual 40k fashion fest you could possibly find in gaming, cant wait for more chapter sets, cant say enough how much i love looking at the variously customised and painted models game is not perfect, it has a few things to work on to reach that goty, but an easy recommend from me, loving it for what it already has, might be goty for me in the end of the year in terms of feelings it invokes while i am playing it and how much i appreciate some of the things it did just care as it has some multiplayer stability issues as of now

So far the game has been a fun experience and i could easily recommend it. The graphics are absolutely gorgeous, it was a pleasant surprise that the game's performances runs as well as it should. The sound effects and music has been on point to make you feel immerse in the mythological setting. The gameplay has been pretty good, dodging feels fluid and attacking have a nice responsive feeling. Most of the bosses i have encountered have been pretty unique each with different movesets that it feels refreshing and fun when you encounter a new boss. The characters and story so far has been pretty intriguing, the lore especially has been pretty good in introducing newcomers to the mythology while for others who are already familiar, with references and tie in to the original sources material.For the negatives i have is the environmental and map design can get pretty confusing especially after chapter 2 and the lack of map contributes to me often being lost although that could be my horrible sense of direction. Lastly, the placement of the invisible walls after act 1 can be quite jarring as i have encounter paths that i thought could be traverse while other times i missed a path thinking that there is an invisible wall there. Anyway, monkey game gud.

2022 Review Recap:After a few patches, the game has received some balance changes, fixes and etc.As it stands right now, it still is a PVE beauty, but that's not to say it doesnt have problems at all. In terms of PVP it still is a mess, even though the "Dueler's code" has gained awareness in the community, with some of the playerbase leaving due to "DiFfIcUlTy". (The game has issues in this regard, yes. But nothing that the casual playerbase or the not so good players are complaining about).Lets start with my personal issue, Don't worry, its just this one. (It has been patched slightly but it still stands) - The blood Katana: This weapon is just too much. Its a bleed proc weapon that does an insanely fast combo with fairly good range, minor FP consumption (not that it matters since you will win or die before that becomes an issue) and far too much damage!I've just finished fighting Miquella, and one of the summons I got (Two, in fact. Due to multiple attempts) used this Katana and shredded the boss's health in a couple of attacks.So... This weapon is insanely good for bosses, paired with pose and less damage on the mixed physick.Now... This is for PVE... For bosses... So as you can imagine, in PVP, the issue is about as problematic as it seems. Long range, bleed, tons of damage and fast.... Might as well just turn on an instant kill hack, and the effect shouldn't differ too much.Alright, so now what are some issues with the game itself. - The bosses are a bit uninspiring some times. I can't fully blame them for this though since there are so many, and quite a few are amazing, memorable and weird in a dark souls standard. However, this is not a dark souls game, so expecting to see a major dragon like Seath the Scaleless, just doesn't add up. - The movesets. Ok... So each boss seems to have taken a different take on their moveset than dark souls. This meaning that while in dark souls, the boss had moves that went well with each other and had certain rythms to be followed, Elden ring thought that this rythm in dark souls was already too familiar and decided to change. So attacks are slow with lingering hitboxes that don't make a ton of sense sometimes, or are just annoying, that and the combos are either insanely fast, or ridiculously slow.What do I mean with all of this? Well... Elden ring was tailor made to screw up with Souls gamers timings... Really screwing with what we had known from previous games to prevent it from being "too easy for legacy players". While I accept the difficulty change, and the rythm shifts, some moves still feel like they are robbing the player with how long the hitboxes last on some of their slow moves.- Some areas are also problematic since their design seems to be beginner level, with the difficulty being set by simply adding too many enemies in one location with what seems little thought to it (Mogh's area for example).- Some enemies also share this crappy design with them spamming and spazzing attacks at incredibly annoying speeds and more. They feel more of an annoyance than a challenge and that really hurts this game compared to previous souls games.Its a shame but I think Myasaki is losing his touch.I still very much enjoy the game and think it is absolutely fantastic in so many regards. Easily my GOTY choice just because of the sheer ammount of content, exploration, and everything else that this game does right.The exploration is mindblowing, the quest lines as mysterious and amazing as ever (No we do not need to know where they are. Searching is part of the fun), it just does everything else right.So despite everything bad mentioned above, the game still stands as a fantastic experience worth double the price it asks, at least for me. Keep in mind the things above are just the ones I considered bad, along with some community members. But regardless, the game is still a peak experience with gameplay, story, builds, creativity, everything else. And BY FAR, one of the best Worlds the Souls-Like Series from Fromsoft has ever had.Why the negative review then? Because most people search for the negatives to see if its worth buying the game or not, despite the bad things mentioned in these reviews.I hope this helps you all

It also makes it difficult to find things when going for 100% •Very minor graphical bugs •Bad hitboxes on certain bosses making them WAY harder than they need to beOverall:I haven't had this much fun playing a game like this in years. As a die-hard Warhammer fan, I approached Warhammer: Space Marine with cautious optimism, trying to set my biases aside. So, what's my verdict? It’s… just okay. But let’s dive deeper into that.First off, it was undeniably fun to role-play as a badass Space Marine. Mowing down hordes of Xenos was incredibly satisfying, and every execution felt intensely gratifying. The PvP mode brought a wave of nostalgia, reminding me of the old-school shooters from the 2010s. Simple, but effective—and despite being a bit undercooked, it was highly enjoyable. Admittedly, I spent most of my time in PvP after finishing the campaign. The different classes felt distinct, and each had its own utility without any glaring balance issues.On the PvE side, it’s a solid option for some casual co-op fun with friends—perfect for those laid-back Friday nights. If you're a Warhammer fan, especially one who loves Space Marines, there’s a lot to appreciate here. The customization options for your Space Marine are extensive, letting you personalize your character as much or as little as you want, which is a nice touch.Visually, the game is impressive, though the controls can feel a bit clunky at first. Thankfully, customizable keybindings help smooth out the experience. However, some of the animations feel stiff, and the AI companions can be frustratingly inept, especially during defense missions on higher difficulties.The real highlight is PvP combat. While the mechanics are simple, the execution is satisfying, and the customization options, especially for loyalist Space Marines, are deep—giving off a “dress to impress” vibe reminiscent of classic games. The Heretical Astartes, though, don’t get the same love in terms of customization, which is a missed opportunity.But this is where the praise tapers off. The story? Basic, with a straightforward premise that doesn’t leave much to chew on once you’ve put the controller down. PvP, while fun, is limited to just three game modes and a handful of maps. And, despite the engaging core gameplay, the lack of meaningful progression holds it back from being something truly special. I also encountered a few bugs that don’t seem to have been widely discussed yet. For instance, my character would sometimes randomly fly across the map, or worse, every character—including mine—would start clipping through the floors. Fortunately, reloading from the last checkpoint or restarting the game usually fixed these issues, but it was still a frustrating experience.The final boss, especially on higher difficulties, dragged on far too long, making it feel like it overstayed its welcome and left a bit of a sour taste by the end.In the end, Warhammer: Space Marine is a decent experience, but it falls short in key areas that could have made it great.Remember, brothers: the Emperor helps those who help themselves

2022 At the time of this review I finished the prologue and 1 campaign as Kugath.Good:- Animation work has to be the best in the industry- Fleshed out story and lore- Graphics improved and the art direction is fantastic.- Siege rework, not perfect but a huge improvement to the old style- Diplomacy rework seems perfect. Everything needed and more included (I love the outposts) but it should be noted that I didnt play around with it too much yet.- Lots of content to keep you busy till the (im)mortal empires update- Clearer information for pretty much everything (like the values for diplomacy, which stats increase during level up etc.)Bad:- There is no option to turn the tutorial off in the prologue which is a shame for experienced players because the story is good but for veterans its quite annoying to learn how to right click an enemy.- The chaos realms are visually amazing but survival battles at the end of each realm really drag (Luckily you can autoresolve these).- Some changes seem for the sake of changing things. The UI is a mixed bag. Some changes are an improvement some others are worse than in WH2 (there is SO MUCH red)- Lighting can be a bit buggy- Icon in library does not match WH1 & 2Optimization:I had no major issues with optimization. Played with 1920x1020 resolution playing on Ultra, there really might be some issues with higher resolutions, but I didnt encounter any.I did had some stutters after the AI took their turns but it wasnt a big deal as these were 1-2 seconds at most.Nothing that wont be fixed in and optimization patchWH1 I had 200h WH2 I had 900hWH3 will easily beat both.

Once Human is the Chinese offspring of Rust and The Division, who's goth/horrorcore phase never ended. The game design and flow are well thought out. Between the timegated progression and seasonal wipes, casuals have a chance to stay competitive with the hardcore crowd. Offers both PvE and PvP, although the PvP servers are mostly 95% opt-in while playing. F2P with no P2W, only cosmetics. A lot of well designed quality of life features already on release. Seasons change with different scenarios and challenges which will provide fresh gameplay despite the wipes. Important progress carries over between seasons, so your efforts are not in vain. The game does have it's share of bugs, as is typical for a new release, but nothing game breaking. The development team are incredibly active and seemingly work 24/7 to fix bugs with transparency on Discord. For the price of free, you cannot go wrong by giving it a try.
