This game feels like its from a bygone age, one where Microsoft and Xbox were putting up a fight (and maybe even winning) against Sony in the Console Wars. Its great.An entertaining linear story mode at around 5-6 hours (on Normal mode), though for maximum enjoyment you should have played or at least seen a recap of Space Marine 1. (And/or understanding Warhammer 40K lore)A 3 man Co-op "Operations" mode that sees you play as your own different Marines that you can customize head to toe (from 6 different classes) and go on missions with other aspiring recruits/players trying to level up and score better gear.Though at the moment there are only 6 missions to complete. They mostly feel good to play through, and multiple runs are needed to upgrade and level up your Space Marine.(This is also the live-service, seasonal part of the game so expect content updates unless something completely unexpected happens).There is also a very fun but very dry no nonsense PVP akin to old COD lobbies but without the vulgarities, racism, and probably no no-scopes (yet). Hope the devs update this "Eternal War" mode as well cause there is some good building blocks to work with.Combat is very fun, consisting of dodges and parries to outmaneuver and counterattack the enemy respectively. Not too much to learn other than the timings of parries/dodges and melee combos of each weapon but the chaotic horde-style gameplay will still sometimes give you problems even if you have mastered the intricate art of murdering other Alien lifeforms.8.5/10 or 9/10 if you are already a fan of 40K.

The good: The game is amazing, especially for one so fresh from early access. There are loads of things to with high, med, and low intensity so you can do something to progress no matter what kind of content you're looking for. The story is great and very compelling. Every single bug or issue I've had with the game has been such a minor thing that it honestly doesn't take away from the game for me at all and the support team is VERY good at responding. Sometimes they use cookie cutter responses but I see no issue with that either because its generally just for things like when they're acknowledging your ticket. The bad: I've experienced multiple bugs but given how small they were I'm honestly not even bothered. None of them prevented me from doing any content in any way. It was small things like, for example, sometimes resources don't stack properly. I had 2 stacks of gravel that should have stacked together but they would not so the result of the bug was losing a single storage space for a short time. Overall: This is easily one of my favorite games that has come out in a very, very long time and would love to see it become more popular.

2022 I love the total war games, especially the Warhammer franchise. This is my first ever review on Steam, I usually don't even bother to review bad games. But this game is UNPLAYABLE. Warhammer II was hands down the best total war ever. However, this is a disaster.1) Performance issues- Running this game WILL KILL your PC. There are hundreds of Redditers have already mentioned, this game will bring your PC to 90C or even 100C. The game will crash, your PC will crash, it's a sh*t show.2) Campaign bugs - Siege- Siege battles are unplayable. The over all campaign and new mechanics are good. Siege battles are more difficult which is reasonable. Warhammer II was also fun cheesing all the siege battles. But Warhammer III is just broken, AI's towers just keep rebuilding unlimited amount of towers regardless of the timer. Sometime, it allows you attack during construction but sometime it doesn't.CA ruined the franchise, when all these fans waited years for a finale of the series, they decided to give us an unfinished product, in every aspect, from optimization to the gameplay itself. CA should be ashamed of what they've done to us. And I think after this game, all the players have lost their faith in them until they fix the issues.

2022 The main campaign has just so much annoying stuff in it, if you just want to conquer the map on your own pace.Enemy armies are spawning every few turns right in the middle of your territory, so you have to keep multiple of you own armies just sitting inside settlements to defend them if needed. For Khorne this is especially stupid, because every idle army will reduce all your cities growth by 10, so you can't level them up.Enemy armies that are raiding your territory somehow always have enough movement left to escape if you try to fight them.I really hope that Immortal Empires will have the good old "do what you want and conquer the world" without all the annoying campaign stuff based around a big, sad and lonely ice bear.EDIT: Immortal Empires is the good old sandbox mode. Game is fun now.

For almost a decade, I wished for a sequel to Space Marine.I was afraid it would never happen. THQ crashing and burning had left the possibility of a true sequel in limbo. In spite of Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on Steam, and a fairly large cult following, I had doubt that anyone would pick up the ball, and finish what Relic started.Then, to my shock, a couple years ago, a trailer drops.I wanted to shout for joy, but almost instantly, I became skeptical. Worried that my beloved game could never have the sequel it deserved in our current development culture. The new studio would gut it of what made it's soul, insert contrived modern tropes and disrespect the source and setting. I have NEVER been so happy to be wrong.Space Marine 2 is Marvelous. Jaw-Dropping.Saber has taken Relics Masterpiece to new heights, added new mechanics that enhance the experience and expanded the multiplayer, seamlessly weaving it into the campaign, making it far more interesting and addictive that it's predecessor. It's BIGGER, BLOODIER and even more BAD*SS.Titus' story continues, wonderfully connected to the previous installment, ending it's chapter with a promise of more, and leaving me READY for the next sequel. SM2 NAILS the vibe of Warhammer 40k, outright stunning at few moments. The setting and the previous game are treated with reverence and attention to detail.For hours, I lost myself, engaged, immersed and awestruck at the spectacle, even more so because I had come to believe it would never happen.Bravo, Saber, Focus, GW and Everyone who made this happen.

This game was bit of a let down after seeing a lot of hype. The combat feels like a sloppy version of a 'souls like' with weird hit boxes and extremely limited options on how you wish to fight. The game is very linear pushing you from one boss to another, you fight each one with a loadout the game wants you to have, there is no variety, there is no choice beyond the talents. You pickup the minimal items between bosses and that's it. It becomes a stale boss grind extremely quickly with very little else to it. Boss -> few npcs, 2/3 items on ground - > Boss -> few npcs, 2/3 items on ground - > Boss etc, repeat for entire game. What I enjoy in souls games is that you can go to X location for this weapon and Y location for this armour to make a build fun, you can grind stats to do specific things, wield specific items, whereas wukong has none of this.The game looks nice, the graphics are very good but performance is not brilliant with quite a few areas causing stuttering or lag however this type of issue will likely be patched out in the future so i don't give that much weight in my overall opinion. I would give this game maybe a 6/10, it was fun for a few hours but got stale very quickly even when progressing rapidly through bosses. I haven't felt compelled to go back and play more at any point, the game hasn't drawn me in at all, in fact thinking about the cost it feels very meh for what i paid. If you enjoy an endless boss spam action game this will be your cup of tea, if you want something with a bit more depth and variety i think you will be disappointed

There are no words to appropriately describe the immense joy and fun I have while playing this game. Elden Ring takes concepts from other Soulsborne titles, improves upon them, and goes beyond expectation. The open world is beautiful with a lot of locations to explore and goodies to grab. The bosses are fun, challenging, and always satisfying to beat. With such a wide variety of content to explore, it is very difficult to run out of things to do. It's why I have so many hours in this game: I never got bored of it.My main criticism come more from personal experience rather than concepts the game has. Notably, the world feels smaller when you learn where everything is and avoid places to fight bosses or get items you don't need. This is to be expected as with other entries to the franchise, the experience feels linear and shorter with each playthrough. Despite this, I am still amazed at this beautiful world each time I ride through it.Please do yourself a favor and try this game. It is difficult, punishing at times, but the immense satisfaction and relief from beating a boss you've been stuck on for 5 hours never fails to make the mood better. Who knows, you may just find a personal favorite encounter.

2020 Product received for free No wonder CS is 20+ years old. This game is so addictive. I was never really into gaming but this game changed my opinion. This game requires passion, dedication, hardwork, skill & a lot of practice because every pixel counts when you trigger you gun. Rumours say CS:GO is going to shift on Source 2 Engine within 2 weeks, really excited for it. When you will play on low tier like Silver & Gold Nova you may lose many games because of your teammates. I know this game involves lot of emotion but keep your calm & make sure to teach the beginners. Our community is already toxic, lets not make it more.You win or you learn, you never lose. 2022 solid game, very enjoyable and worth your time. I write this review after beating the game twice with one character, and a third time with a second character using a different build. I also have all achievements which tells you that I like this game enough to do that.As much as I like the game, some of the late game bosses are just not fun.I'm a big souls fan, and have played and beaten each and every souls title including DeS and BB, and this is the first game in which there are bosses that are just not good. Defeating these cheeselords doesn't make you feel like you overcame adversity with your own skill and knowledge, it makes you feel either very lucky that you didn't get hit with a 20 second long combo with giant aoes and teleporting sweep attacks, or very mildly happy that you just cheesed the boss with a mimic tear and a moonveil + 10. I don't think the game is 'too hard', just that it literally is not fun for me to fight some of the endgame bosses. I'm hoping that there are some balance patches to address some of the balance issues present in the game, hopefully a few bosses get some tuning, and hopefully moonveil gets a much needed damage reduction because ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ why use anything else as an int build when you can one shot invaders lol

7ish hours, not for me.I'm assuming much of these will feel better later on in the game but I don'f feel the drive to want to get there.Every positive aspect has an equal negative aspect.Its very pretty, but very busy.Navigating the world is fine when you're on flat ground but there are a lot of collision issues and hang ups, no climbing mechanic. I want to explore because its so pretty, but its on rails with a lot of underwhelming rewards, dead ends and invisible walls for doing so.No map.The moment to moment combat is what kills it for me.I feel like it wants to be God of War and Souls, but doesn't know which one, and is missing the best of both.The combat is floaty and restrictive, unresponsive, clunky and tedious.Some attacks feel nice and weighty, but this is rare.No other weapon types than the staff. Spirits and transformations are cool but they are flavor, not foundation.Main light attack is essentially required. The initiating attack is fast, but then you sit through a big flashy animation waiting for the next hit/s to show up in the middle of some spinny nonsense.Heavy attack has some nice unlocks, but they all require a set up and a waiting period to get it out, unless you pepper them in with your combos, but the chances of you getting interrupted are high.Crowd clearing is rough, there may be some AOE heavy hitters later but being limited to mostly single target to clear trash mobs gets tiring quickly.You get interrupted very often. You have to hit this basic wolf guy 30 times, and you get stunned for a whole day if you get poked in the middle of your baton expose.Props for being pretty, but eh for the rest. 7/10

2022 A modern masterpiece Fromsoftware took everything they learned from the Souls series, applying it towards a game that redefines what an open world game can be. Consistently, I found myself wondering how they could have packed so much incredible content into the game, while not sacrificing the immense scope, and having killed the final boss, and roughly 29 other bosses (my play time is actually much longer than steam says, for some reason the playtime, I still find myself wondering. Although performance issues are a problem on PC, I have been relatively lucky since launch, even thought my system is far worse than some other reviewers who have experienced issues (Ryzen 7 1700x, and a GTX 1080). At this point, however, what few performance issues I did have are gone, and I'm able to run the game buttery smooth at high settings, with only the occasional dip when exploring the over-world. The game isn't perfect, however. There are a few too many repeated boss encounters, and some of the boss encounters rely a bit too heavily on taking another enemy and multiplying them, instead of adding a new boss entirely. There is also a recurrent problem of certain enemy types appearing too often. This is helped, however, by the remarkable number of enemy types that are wholly unique, to the point where, after beating the final boss, I went exploring and happened across a new enemy type I hadn't seen before, even though I had thought I had seen everything that wasn't a reused asset. All this said, the game is most definitely flawed, but the flaws do not detract from the game in any meaningful way, and you would be doing yourself a disservice not to play the game, and see if the Souls genre is right for you. Tl;DR The game is a flawed masterpiece. Not so flawed as Dark Souls 1 was at launch, especially on PC, but certainly not perfect. A must play. yes. 9.5/10

I guess this is a hot take, so bring on the clown awards, but in my opinion, Black Myth Wukong does not live up to the hype. It's absolutely lacking in so many ways I couldn't believe what I was playing based on the reviews I read and I'm sorry if that steps on the toes of your new favorite game, but it's true. I was in no way compelled to continue playing this after the first session and here's why:For starters, the game's performance is unstable at best, even on my 3080ti, i9 CPU, 32GB RAM, liquid cooled machine. It constantly and unexpectedly dipped down to laughably low frame rates to the point that I thought the game was being ran by Microsoft Power Point, even with most of the settings on low and medium, RTX off, DLSS set to performance and frames capped at 120. Unacceptable.Looking past that, the world traversal is some of the most boring gaming I've done in decades. There is nothing to do other than fight a handful of trash mobs, find some meditation spots and then fight bosses. And I mean like every 10ft, there's a new boss. I never even understand why I'm fighting them half the time and they're super forgettable. The title should really be "Wukong: Boss Rush" or something more accurate like that. I learn the fights just long enough to beat them and then I never think about them again after they're over.And the game's scenery is so ridiculously bland that everything looks the same to me. There are no useful land marks and no map/minimap, so you're constantly getting lost and back tracking in circles. On top of that, they do absolutely nothing to make you 'feel' like a monkey God while running around. You have a basic sprint and that's it. No cool flips. No world interaction. No wall runs. No climbing. No swinging. No staff tricks. Not even a double jump... It is painfully boring to run around in this game and OMG the amount of invisible walls and dead ends that should be explorable is infuriating.The core gameplay loop is:1. sluggishly traverse through an uninteresting area2. kill trash mobs until you stumble across a boss3. spend an hour learning its gimmicky move set4. finally beat it and repeat, that's itThis game is just way too shallow and bland right now. I got bored in the first sitting and I have no will to even finish it. I will admit though, that the bosses are beautifully crafted and have very imaginative designs that ultimately don't matter because they all seem to have the same basic concept: Rush-down AI, spam attacks, then reset every so often. It felt like I was fighting the same boss reskinned over and over and over, even after 7 hours of play time. Not to mention that some fights are literally just ripped from other games with almost zero changes, like Ornstein and Smough for example.Moving on from that, the game's main draw (the combat) is extremely hollow. There is no block system. No parry system. No backstab system. No stealth system. You literally have a dodge and a stick. The rest comes from a handful of spells, stances and transformations (which are also inconsistent, like, why can't I even JUMP while I'm transformed???) The dodge windows feel awful. Enemies will stun lock you constantly. Tons of CC. Input scanning. Animation locks. Overpowered status effects like poison and fire. Spongy enemies with inflated health pools. Bosses become impervious to your attacks, but they can still hit you. Every cheesy trick in the book to create artificial difficulty and prolonged encounters. It is more frustrating than rewarding and when you finally beat something, you won't feel accomplished, you'll just be happy you got lucky enough to beat the enemy's gimmick one time after hours of failure with nothing to look forward to except doing it all over again in about 10ft.Wukong, to me, is desperately trying to be a mash-up of Dark Souls and God of War, but it fails on both counts. I think the potential is there, but it still needs a while to cook before it gets to the level that these botted reviews would have you believe it's at. Make the areas/maps more interesting and less linear (a true open world would be even better). Bring these beautiful characters to the forefront and really lean into the story. Make the boss mechanics feel more unique in each fight. Improve the traversal. Optimize the performance. Fix these issues and the game's underlying potential will start to shine through.It does some things well, like character designs, musical scores, graphics and beautifully cinematic moments, but it falls flat in so many other ways that I genuinely can't recommend this game in its current state. I really wish I hadn't purchased it yet, as it might be worth playing sometime late next year or in 2026. If not, maybe the inevitable Wukong 2 will hit the mark in ways this one couldn't, but as it stands, this ain't it for me. I would refund if I could.-----Edit: For anyone who might be wondering why my playtime keeps going up after a review like this, it's quite frankly because I paid $60 for the game and I don't want that money to go to waste, so I'm going to finish it. Still VERY disappointed with what Wukong COULD have been though.

2022 The best word to describe this game is "AGAIN??!!!" Everything overstays its welcome, everything becomes a chore. The other reviews will tell you everything you need to know about the portals and why they're bad.But the thing is, the portals just exacerbate problems the series has been struggling with for a very long time.There's too much busywork. Too many pointless magic items to collect, too many followers to assign, too many dumb AI agents wandering around the map pointlessly sabotaging empty settlements.At a deeper level, victories and defeats just don't mean enough. Kill the greater chaos demon of whatever and he'll pop back up in no time at all. There are no pivotal battles. Everything comes down to attrition: can you minimise your losses enough that you don't need to spend too much time recuperating and can therefore outpace your rivals in the race for the 4 souls? That's it.I think that this all stems from the fact that managing an empire isn't really fun in Total War games in general, and certainly not in the Warhammer series. There are just too many towns and cities to conquer, looking after them is too much of a slog, and there aren't enough interesting decisions to make: you're under constant assault, so there's not much you can do but pump out the most cost-effective armies you can and march them at the enemy.Surely the campaign side of Total War should be about positioning your armies to get the jump on your enemies? Like you would in, y'know, a war! There's hardly any of this. You can go into ambush stance, but that's about it: the rest is just walking one army into another. It could have been so much more exciting: what if an ambush involved actually plotting a stealthy route to intercept an enemy army instead of pure rng? What if you could wall off chokepoints, or make decisions about what time of day (or night) to make a move etc.? Without this, you just have watered-down Civ with great battles that get repetitive because there are just too darn many of them.

2023 CA are starting to turn the ship around with more frequent hotfixes, and as of 4.1, I think it's worth playing again.There's still the spectre of the recent absurdly over-priced and under-cooked DLC, so while there's plenty of fantastic DLC from games 1 and 2 you can use, the quality and value of future DLC is still in question.Overall though, I think this game is in the best condition it's ever been in since release. Still more work to be done, but at least they're heading in the right direction after a rough year.

2017 This review was changed for the third time so far. The first review was made when the CZ was a rifle, second review was made in 2019, and i believe the third and last review will be found all the way in the bottom Let's give this game an honest review.Okay I wanna start by saying that I am a CS series Fan. I have countless hours in CS 1.6, CSCZ (LuL i know) and CSS. And from all these titles I think CSGO is the worst of them all.I will explain my negative experience with "Garbage GO" by splitting this entire topic into 3 sub categories: Community, Balance, Developer Support.Community:The community pretty much consists of 3 main groups of people:1. Easter European Children,2. Normal People,3. Cheaters.CS never had a problem with toxic and annoying communities however it all changed when CSGO came. I mean Jesus I cant join Casual because there is a ♥♥♥♥ load of kids running around and screaming, I can't play on community servers because they are usually 64 people cancer, and competitive just doesn't cut it I mean I like it but I don't want to try hard every time I play this game.Don't get me wrong you can find your occasional good people. But out of 10 matchmaking games 9 times you wish you never met those people.Gun Balance:Okay this one is good.Gun balance doesn't really exist in this game anymore. See back then we used to have the AK, M4, AWP, MP5 and Deagle. Everything else was either situational or a miss click.... See even though these 5 guns where super good and where the only ones used they where perfectly balanced with each other. Meaning that the top tier guns where BALANCED!!!!This is not the case in CSGO. AWP is stiff asf***!, pistols are pure PTSD!, riffles have either not enough damage or weird hit reg, and in general the gun balance considering SMG's, heavy weapons is just ........ JESUS!Take the gun balance of CSGO, but only the gun balance don't look at the brand only the gun balance. If any other game had this type of balance it would be reviewed to DEATH! The gun balance is garbage and everyone who remotely tells me that the gun balance makes sense I just wanna say that what they are saying IS BLASPHEMY!!!! Developer Support: After the AUG being overpowered as ♥♥♥♥ and the Revolver being a pocket AWP it is clear to see that Valve doesn't test updates like ever.... How can such a big company on one of their most sold games not test updates before they release them it is a mystery to me. Even after millions valve received there is no working anti cheat system, and the only good content that is being released are skins which some of them cost into the thousands when kids in Africa starve. It is disgusting!!!!All the major tournaments, money and skins will never make this game good.If the gun balance and Developer Support is not there this game will awlays remain MEH. I am not a little kid you can feed of with some shinny fade skins. I am very very VERY! sorry what happened with CSGO. I don't recommend this game. Try it out yourself and loose faith in big gaming companies. 2019 review >>>Steam offered me to revise my review after additional 86 hours played on this game. The game still is taking weird turns facing the tides of time. CSGO is in one of the best situations a CS game has ever been (beside 1.6, but taking 1.6 is simply unfair towards any game in the gaming industry). Maps are constantly improved and guns are kinda balanced after a lot of mistakes done prior. The game is healthier especially after fooooorknight zapped most of the kids out of this cursed community over here. I am a casual player and my casual needs are satisfied. I have only 220 hours in this game because i have other choices, however if those other choices would have not been there id have more hours in this game. I am a CS series fan and always will be :). I follow the majors, and follow updates and changes mad. I watch CSGO related videos, and here and there i chip in 1 hour of play time either comp or casual. The game is in a waaaay better position than it was last time i gave an opinion on it. And dare i say i can recommend it. for the money you'd pay for being able to do matchmaking and stuff its alright. 2020 >>>The game has picked itself up from the fire. Volvo finally put some elbow grease into development and the game was luckily saved from the shambles it once found itself in. There are new operations dropped every now and then. Even though I'm not a friend of the season pass type of content drop concept I do not mind it as it does not keep me from enjoying all the different facets of the game. Still in 2020 we find the usual problems: hitboxes, hitreg, running ak headshots etc. However things are less annoying than before and vac actually works halfway decent nowadays. Beside that prime matchmaking does keep lobbies clean to some extend due to overwatch etc but still you will run into cheaters. With all of that being said. The game is good. The game is back because the competition almost zapped CS:GO out of gaming world. If Valve would have not tried to turn the game around the entire Valorant will be the CS:GO killer would have become the trough, Imagine a game with such a rich history being killed by an arcade anime shooter. Gun balance is normal again. Even though that still to this day the negev being 1.7k bothers me as it actually makes no sense. The game is enjoyable. Not perfect but it has gotten better thank god for fortnight because we would have still been stuck with the actual pile of garbage CS:GO was back in 2017

FOR AUSSIES/KIWIS:Once Human has been INCREDIBLY fun so far - the exploration, combat and quests are incredibly immersive and you can easily lose time playing. Plus, it's free and no way near P2W, which is a MASSIVE bonus (hopefully this doesn't change). The only downside (primarily for Australians/Kiwis) is that there are no Oceania servers. I've had to jump ship to the EU and play on a server that gives me between 280 to 300 ping. I am lucky that I am accustomed to this with another game I play, but I know that others were easily feeling frustrated with the lag/ping issues. I'd love to hop into a server with my mates where we have decent ping, but even that was a struggle connecting to other servers like Southeast Asia or Japan. Not to mention the fact that my timezone forces me to play when the server activity is low, so I have to wait for EU pals to wake up, or play with my other friend who has to deal with the ping spikes. Massive drawback. It hasn't fully ruined the game for me, but the low "population" within the server list and then it's actually full is another issue entirely, you have to coordinate with your friends that day of joining a server, any late joiners? Good luck finding a spot on that server. Hopefully the character limit is expanded upon and potential Oceania servers are introduced. Overall, so far there's been bumps, but it's been fun so far. However, there is room for improvement. If there was a middle ground recommendation, I would click that. I will rate it "yes", but it's honestly mixed.

The game is great and i enjoy it, but i can't recommend it. Aside from the fact my computer is starting to get random issues ever since i played the game (yesterday my wi-fi completely shut down while playing the game, forcing me to reset the network card for the first time in years), the game encounters some difficulty spikes that would be frustrating for player not as determined that i am. The game felt fairly easy until the tiger boss, as a souls veteran, but this boss was like going from fighting mouses to fighting a rock giant, compared to any of the other bosses. And the next one, that follows right next, is the same kind of difficulty without anything to really fight in between to upgrade your character.Until now, the game pace was flowing, offering you to craft a new armor before a major boss, get new points to spend in the ability trees. What you would expect from an action RPG as the devs claim the game to be. But now, all of the sudden, the game became a souls like out of nowhere. And if i enjoy soulslike, this game is not advertised as one so i can't recommand this game as an action-RPG to any people who do not enjoy difficulty, as you will encounter a wall mid playthrough.Edit : So after spending a few more hours in it, a few bosses later, i'd say the biggest issue of the game is the basics of the fighting gameplay. The parts that are added, like the spells, are really enjoyable. But the core of the gameplay, the combos, the dodging, all of it will start getting repetitive once you've spent some hours getting used to it. To start with, not being able to dodge while stuck in some combos animation is a real bother, in a game like that where bosses will punish you a lot. The animations of mixed combos are way to slow to be able to use it when you really need it, because it will either miss the opponents or cost some chunk of life by the time the animation processes. And though you can get some new finishers by spending points in your ability tree, none really feels interesting, they're all kinda slugish.So overall, i definitely can't recommand getting this game for such a high price, because being beautiful and being inovative is not enough nowaday to make a good game. No point in having all of these if the game fails to keep the player in for a whole playthrough. And this come from a guy who usually play the hell out of these kinda of games.

I AM A SON OF VULKAN AND BY MY HEAVY FLAMER THE HERETICS AND THE XENOS SHALL BE CLEANSED BY THEIR SIN FO EXISTENCE! FOR THE EMPEROR!Edit: For the love of the Emperor, fix the focus enemy function and all the imputs, because I get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up just because the character won't respond to my imputs. I wanna shooty shot the marked enemy, guess what, Titus just stands there and watches.Edit2: The lack of the report button in PVP is mind boggeling. Do you honestly think no one will ever cheat in this game? As Sseth put it: "Easy Anti-cheat is a very good anti-cheat, because its very easy to turn off". In almost 30 hours I've encountered at least 10 cheaters and there is no way to report them. If I have to edit this review one more time, I'd have to make it a bad review, and I honestly don't want to, but you give me no choice.Edit3: After finishing the campaign and maxing the wins for the Heavy in PvP, I have to give this game, an overall 5/10. The game looks fantastic, the combat is mid, but satisfying enough to keep you going for more, all the armours and weapons look extraordinary, and the customisation is behind a grind wall and I am rather ok with that since its just cosmetics and no actual gameplay changes (except for multiplayer), but that is about it. This is what I find good in this game.The story is dog water, and its an absolute waste of time, there is no intrigue, there is no stakes, its just under mid-story bits and pieces here and there, the writing is ass, the characters are 1 dimensional (yes, even Titus), the voice acting is better for the Cadians and Imurah than the space marines we play as (even in multiplayer this argument still stands). And what stings the most is the Season Pass. You need to pay 40$ to have the PRIVILEGE to grind your ass off to get the Ultramarine skins. I know they will add more stuff later, but I hope I don't have to buy Season Pass 2 for another 40$ in 2026 just to have the PRIVILEGE of grinding my ass off again. I dont understand this pay-for-more-grind mindset, I understand that the main gameplay will be PvE operations and PvP sop you will always have a lot of currency to use and all that, but in PvE you need to pay the same currency for upgrades that make you more OP. Having to choose between upgrades and customisation should be illegal in this day and age. Not to mention a lose in PvP is like 15 gold and a win is about 25 gold... in 1 hour of PvP you can gain between 90 gold and 150 gold which is enough for 1 chapter unlock, and with dosens of chapters you are asking for hundreds of hours of PvP and PvE just to unlock every customisation possible.I dont mind the default customisation, that is whatever, but the Season Pass is a waste of money, 40$ for 12 ultramarine skins to grind is not worth. Maybe if it was already unlocked then you'd have a maybe, but this is just trash.

2022 The game was rushed to release and that is painfully easy to see not only by all the performance issues and bugs at the release date (even after the delay of the original release date from 2021 to 2022), but also by reading through the Roadmap that was revealed today, in which reflects how poorly the release is actually going when it comes to fixing issues and getting basic content out for players.With the game not being in Early Access or tagged as such, having loyal consumers having to wait at least 6 months just to have what you would call "staples" or "basics" of the TW Warhammer games such as the Blood DLC pack and the Immortal empires mode (and only a Beta at that time with the final and proper release only at the end of the year in Q4) is truly inexcusable.Update: After one year in "Early Access" the game keeps having a lot of unresolved issues and they are getting more greedy and trying to gouge fans as they go you just need to take a look at the upcoming Chaos Dwarves DLC pricing.Just check the new DLC Shadows of Change to be released soon, they keep gouging prices for DLCs that have a low amount of new content with recycled units.Update 2:You know developers and the entire company lost their plot when they are putting official statements to their community with phrases such as: "The right to discuss is a privilege—it is not an entitlement you earn by playing the game"The only thing I wish is that they start on capitalizing on a massively opportunity for their own IP, "Total War: Clown Fiesta" complete with a gazillion overpriced DLCs to compensate for the failure of Hyenas, the ongoing Early AccessTM for Total Warhammer III and copy paste Total War Pharaoh.

Once Human is a mix between The Secret World and Pal World with camp building mechanics. It is a lot of fun but this is barely past the Beta stage. Still, it's still one of the best F2P games I have seen.Pros:++ Story Line: It's a post-apocalyptic world with a pretty straight forward plot, but there are some good moments in the story.++ Combat: Combat is actually fun, with a lot of different weapons. Players are free to use different types of gear and weapons, so there is plenty of opportunity to experiment and try new ways in combat.++ Graphics: The world is beautiful and diverse, with very detailed models.++ F2P without P2W!: There is a cash shop in this game, but it is for cosmetics. The game itself is far from P2W, with all the gear being in-game. I was very pleasantly surprised at the lack of P2W that usually plagues these types of games.Cons:++ Bugs: This game is Early Access at best. Voice acting fails often, bugs in quests pop up fairly often. That said, the development team is working around the clock to resolve many issues, with numerous fixes being released almost daily.TLDR:I really like this game and it's worth the time that I have invested so far. I hope the devs continue to iron out the bugs and are active in refining the game. Basically, it's a Free to Play relative of The Secret World but with camp mechanics and "pets." Great game, just watch out for the bugs!

My honour is my life.My duty is my fate.My fear is to fail.My salvation is my reward.My craft is death.My pledge is eternal service.What is there is truely excellent and if you're looking for a satisfying feeling, power fantasy that offers up a surprising amount of difficulty, this is exactly for you.The only disappointment so far (27 hours in) has been how the content does seem to run a bit dry sooner than expected. I expected the game to have a similar lasting power as Left 4 Dead games, that offered short "Campaigns", yet it was just fun even repeating the same levels.The problem the "Operations" PvE missions seem to face, is that there is no real reason to scour through the corners of the map very well in hopes for something cool or different. Yes, health pickups and the like are valuable, but they don't change the game in ways that different weapon pickups, adrenaline shots, chainsaws, gas canisters, defibrillators etc. seemed to change things up in L4D.The different grenades offer a tiny bit of variation and so do the somewhat randomized enemy encounters, but that's about it in terms of variety. Even the most valuable things, the Armory Data is always(?) in the same spots. With that said, the gameplay loop itself is ridiculously fun and trying to tackle new difficulty levels has been exciting and I don't see myself dropping the game any time soon. But it has left me wishing there was more to discover, rare armor piece finds or.. just a little bit more intrique to level exploration itself.Right now it seems there's a "meta" building up that some players only dodgeroll through the level to the objective areas, skipping fighting anything that isn't necessary and I'd say that's a big indication of the levels not being interesting.I don't regret a fully priced purchase however (bought the standard edition, with no season pass and other stuff) and have had a truely fun time with an action game that has me admittedly a little bit addicted.Glad that the devs will be adding things in gradually. :) Hopefully it's concrete enough to offer variety once things start getting too repetitive.

The first impression of the game is very good. Haven't seen much yet, 5 hours in, but grafics, controls and combat seem nice. The atmosphere is very good, except for millions of player shacks everywhere, which does ruin the atmosphere quite a bit. They should reduce the number of buildings per world, drastically. The real problem is the monetization, which is completely off. The prices for items to buy is just insane to a point, where we just won't spend a single cent on this game. Instead of having a monthly sub that enables you to get what you want, there are multiple paywalls, even if you get the battlepass or monthly sub. For example they are asking 50€ for a set of walls/doors/windows. This is insane. Not only that 10€ is the absolute maximum this should cost, you should be able to require a set like this, via your monthly sub, plus a few smaller things. Fallout76 didn't do it very well, but even they did it better than Once Human. In fact, items to build your base are a major longterm incentive to keep playing, if you can farm them ingame. Not via a battlepass though, but from dungeons and bosses, even if the drops require a monthly sub.In once Human you got an insane monetization overkill. A battlepass for over 23€. A monthly sub for 5€ and on top structural base sets and character skins for 30€ each, which you don't get via your sub and battlepass. I am sorry, but this is sick and should be boycotted, because this predatory way of monetization is about as demotivating, as your typical p2w mobile game. So unless there will be a reasonably priced monthly sub, which allows for getting one of those structural base sets or character skins plus some smaller furniture items and skins, my gf and I won't spend a single cent on this.Update 20 hours in: The game is twofold. The gaming part is fine. It is pretty much a combination of "The Secret World" and "Fallout 76" and it does a good job at that. The monetization, however is appalling. You got 2 different subs, a whole bunch of different currencies, gambling mechanics and even with both subs, you don't have it all. This is sick and i suggest not to spend any money in this game, until they come up with something decent and less invasive and greedy. The game is good though. I would gladly pay 15€ per month for a sub, but then i expect full access and no paywalls that require more money. Even the most expensive item or set, should be obtainable via a currency that you get with the monthly sub and no item or set should be more expensive, than the amount of currency, that you get per month from your sub.So while the game is good, it is impossible to recommend, due to the completely appalling monetization. For now though, you can play the game without needing any money. A nice move, but that by no means compensates the sick way, they approach monetization.

2022 The game came out and i was completely ready to go and enjoy it. it didn't think that they could go wrong but as it turns out you can take a winning formula and massively mess it up. Where to begin with Major issues:The factions are not fleshed out at all and it feels much more like a minor faction from Rome 1 total war.The old game factions have not had any balancing done so they are terrible and AI simply obliterate them.CA messed with the upkeep on certain factions so the AI ends up a silly number of armies right away and on Leg difficult its just a joke.The base game making you send an army into the realm of chaos every 20ish turns but on higher difficulties you tend to only have a single army so you can go in and have no empire or protect your empire which just sucks as the AI doesn't seem to have this issue at all nearly getting one of the 4 souls each time this happens without fail.Major factions are once again just running roughshod over everything so that update from warhammer 2 to stop that apparently wasn't goods.AI armies are still just flying into your territory and being untouchable and burning cities all over the place STILL.Major power locations are just terrible, Ogre kingdoms are the worst as there isn't really anyone for them to fight so if your not them they always turn into a huge issue. Its either no one around or getting real chummy. Minor issues:Not a great selection of unique buildings locations, feeling abit spares with that even though warhammer 2 just ended putting more and more of these in as it makes locations important rather than "oh i just lost a city, meh its one of hundreds".provinces that are just villages, i mean seriously who sat down and decided that people wanted level 3 capped areas?!?!Few updates have been put in but the game still feels like it incomplete and tbh they haven't even touched the sides of the issues this game has so far. 3/10 so far but will update this score as hopefully CA has realised they have delivered a shiny turd.Update after Immortal empires and 1st DLC.Some updates have been made and the chaos factions are now somewhat fleshed out, I feel however this is more things that should have been in the game at release but didn't make it till much later.Older factions have started to get a rework but this varies wildly between the factions and CA seems to be taking the blunt hammer approach to development and simply removing and adding buffs almost at random.Diplomacy is better but the AI still hold a massive player bias and again still march their armies across the map to fight you and only you. CA appear convinced they have fixed this but evidently they haven't.The immortal empires map is very big and has every faction in it and that's its selling point really, kinda wish they still had the realms of chaos in it though, feel that was a step backwards really. The new crisis events are quite interesting and we are seeing more happening with this in each update.Overall I think there has been improvement with the updates but some of the core issues are still flagging up, hopefully with further updates things will continue to improve. Revision score "6/10"

After finishing the game with 100% of achievements, I can definitely say that the game lives up to the hype and I highly recommend playing this game. Of course, there are a few flaws that I shall mention, but overall I've had a great time playing. It looks amazing, the combat is fun and smooth and the story managed to get me emotional at certain points. My final score for this game is 9/10.Regarding performance, I had to play on medium settings, since I ran the game with an i7-6700 processor, 16 GB RAM and a Nvidia Geforce GTX 1070 graphics card, which is far from ideal. But with the right settings, the game ran smoothly most of the time and even on medium settings it still looks quite good. I've only had one crash on day 1 and a bit of stuttering during the prologue. Other than that, there were no issues. The story takes place after the events from Journey to the West. I won't spoil the events that take place in the game, but at the end of each chapter we get cutscenes related to the story of that chapter, each one being done in a different animation style. Also, there are different endings to the game. The path we follow in the game is, for the most part, quite linear, but it has enough branching paths and secret areas so it doesn't feel boring, or like we are stuck on rails. The environments we explore over the course of the game are quite varied, ranging from forests, deserts, frozen lakes and mountains, labyrinthine caves, volcanic mountains. Regarding exploration, I've seen some people complaining about the lack of a map, but personally I haven't felt lost or like I would have required help orienting myself, perhaps with the exception of the final chapter, that takes place in an open area. My biggest complaint about exploration and navigation is that there are invisible walls (which is understandable, since it's not an open world), but sometimes it's difficult to tell if something is inaccessible or the path to a potential secret area. When in doubt, just bonk all the fences I guess. But other than this, I've had no issues with this part of the game.The game is an Action RPG, with challenging combat (still, it feels a lot easier than a souls-like in my opinion) and plenty of bosses to fight. There are, in fact, over 90 different bosses and mini bosses that we can encounter in the game and they have different looks and move sets (yes, there are few frog bosses that only differ through their elemental type, but even fighting those is worth it in the end), so combat will not get stale. By doing the secret areas in each chapter, you get an item that can make the final boss of said chapter a lot easier. For example, gain flame immunity against the first one, or cancel one of their abilities. Of course acquiring these items and using them is optional, so if you prefer a harder encounter, you still have that option.Regarding combat, it is fluid and responsive, with light/heavy attacks and combos, three stances, transformations and varied spells. The skill tree is generous with its options and re-allocating skill points is free, so experimenting with different builds is encouraged. Stats and resistances can be boosted through alchemy after you meet a certain character and you can reallocate these points whenever you want.Armor sets give certain bonuses which buff various play styles. Equipment progression is mostly linear, at least to a certain point where you gain the option to upgrade older sets of armor, which allows you to continue using the bonuses you prefer. There is only one weapon type, the staff, but there are spears that can be obtained and they have a somewhat different move set.The mini bosses we fight can be absorbed and used in combat, each one gives a passive buff and a brief transformation that executes their signature attack.Now, regarding my main issues with the game... As I've said above, it is sometimes difficult to tell whether you will hit an invisible wall or start down hidden path.Chapter 4 in particular has a lot of secret content that can be accidentally missed, which can be quite frustrating if you are a completionist. The game requires playing through NG+ anyway if you want to 100%, so I guess it's not that much of an issue, but it's still annoying. For example, to unlock the secret area (that contains missable stuff too, of course), you need to fight an optional boss twice. But during the first encounter, that boss can drop a piece of armor that is needed for the achievement. It only drops that item IF you attack it from behind and break 4 of its arms. If you accidentally kill the boss before that, you are unable to obtain the item in that playthrough.And the final complaint, which again matters only if you want to 100%: the drop rates for seeds and armor pieces are a bit too low in my opinion. Sure, it depends on RNG and luck, but I spent 2 full days trying to farm the last type of seed I needed for the [Seed to Sow] achievement. And that is while wearing the items that boost drop rates too. And for this reason alone I give it a 9/10 instead of a 9.5/10 like it would otherwise deserve.

2022 As I'm entering my 50th hour in the game I think it might be suitable to start writing a little review.This entire week (besides of the times I spend sleeping, eating, doing mundane household chores and ofcourse work) I spend inside of elden ring, and boy what an week it was.First of, While I am in fact a gamer, and spend most of my life in games, I'm not the type whom tends to go looking up guides, tricks, etc... to understand my games any better, guess this has changed a bit, because never, AND I MEAN NEVER EVER. have I been invested in a game as much as I have been in this one.The world is gorgeous, the gameplay (just like any souls game ofc.) is unique, intresting and challenging.Each and every one of the bosses feels completly different, every time I start a bossfight with a little (healthy amount) of fear, scared what challenge awaits me this time.Like I said before, I'm entering my 50th hour in the game, and I still feel like I know so little about this game in the best way possible, it engages me to look up guides, look up info.It encourages me to re invent my play style, learn new moves, learn new weapons, change up my specs etc....I'm sure the next couple of weeks I will spend even more time inside of this marvelous world, and I'm sure I won't regret a single moment of it.I adore it, I love it, and this game truly brought me back inside the magical world of games.Thank you for another suitable entry in the souls franchise.Thank you for giving me a truly magnificent world to explore.Thank you for bringing joy into a mundane life.

2017 Rating: good (7/10) Introduction Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a First Person Shooter set in a comptetetive scene where two teams battle for an objective. It is a stand-alone follow-up to the famous Counter-Strike mod from Half-Life where terrorists battle the Counter-Terrorists on different locations. Gameplay & Story: 6/10 The gameplay consists of buying weapons and shooting your opponents. Easier said than done actually, since your opponents are either human players sitting on the other side of the world wide web or some AI programmed to shoot you first. CS:GO is for a reason the biggest competetive shooter on the market for years, since it offers great weapon balance, tactical possibilities for teams to approach and a large player base that keeps growning each day. The story behind the game is based on the oldschool Counter-Strike game, where one side takes the approach as terrorists either trying to plant a bomb or protect the hostages and other being Counter-Terrorists either try to protect a bomb site or trying to rescue the hostages held at Terrorist base. Combat & Challenge : 8/10 The combat is absolutely fluid in CS:GO and there are barely any moments, that you could blame the broken hitboxes or the bad netcode for dying. People tend to rage and blame the bad balance on maps, weapons or programming of the game, however the success of this title proves that it is the best competetive shooter on the market. The challenge in this game is definetely to be able to rise through the ranks in competetive matches, playing against hackers on opposite team or some players on your team that want to teach you some bad words in russian or french. I am always thankful for such opportunities to improve my language skills and consider it just a chance of becoming even better if I did not win the match no matter the team stacks. Reaching Global Elite rank after around 200 hours, I can safely say that it is possible to rise to the top even when the odds are stacking against you. Graphic & Interface : 7/10 The graphic when set to higher settings is actually pretty good, sadly the competetive scene barely allows it since there are certain tricks like setting your resolution lower on purpose to be able to aim better, that crash the feeling of this game in graphical matters. Most of the maps contain some details that make them distinguishable, like certain grapphiti on some maps. The interface is kept simple and almost transparent so that it does not disturb the concentration. Progress & Mini-Games : 8/10 It is possible to consider progress by rising up the account level that comes from simply playing CS:GO in any form, there are forms of rising up your ranking by playing competetive or gathering skins for the weapons you are using or want to sell. Some people actually make money by playing this game and selling the skins on the steam market, so different ways to progress in and outside of the game. The biggest progress for me was improving my hand-to-eye coordination by playing it competetively. Audio & Immersion : 8/10 Each weapon sound is unique for itself, and since the sound plays a great role in this game it is really important to get to know the sounds and be able to distinguish where the shooting is coming from. CS:GO fulfills its task really well. The music is played only in menues and during the highlights. The game music is nothing special, but since you can get/buy music kits to fit your music taste, Valve found a good workaround for not creating amazing music by themselves. Side-Notes This game offers single player, multiplayer and co-op modes that can be played either against other players or AI.This game offers different modes, some of that are just for fun, for example gun mode, while others are played in E-Sports.This game contains steam achievements.This game offers great optimization and updates to technology with time (updating their network code, updating the hit boxes, balancing the weapons). Summary CS:GO has its reasons to be the Number One FPS in the ESL Scene and its popularity is currently only rising. It is great to see that it has not been abandoned by the developers after reaching its peak state, but still keeps getting updated. I would recommend trying CS:GO to every game, just to know what this game is that defines the global FPS market so much and while FPS fans might love it, some might well get turned off by the hardcore players or the cursing and spitting wanna-bes.I hope this review helps you making the decision if its worth buying and installing this game. Rate and leave a comment if you enjoyed reading it.~ForestWolf

Introduction I completed the game 100% last week (about 60 hours in), I'm on NG+4 and I just recently actually "completed" the game as in reaching max level, maxing all the important gear, all the important spirits, I've found every secret there is to be found, and there are still things to do (maxing every spirit/gear, reaching NG+9 which according to some people is where the stats of the enemies actually cap etc). I've tested various builds and pretty much gave everything at my disposal a try, I wanted to do all of this before writing my review.I'll be honest, at first I wanted to give this game a negative review right from the start, reason being that they are lying when it comes to the minimum/recommended system requirements. I have 2 rigs, a 3060 laptop and a 4080 pc, I Installed it first on my laptop and even tho everything on it is above the recommended system settings, I didn't got more than 20-25 FPS in the first area (higher in the other areas), this was with RT off, minimum settings, FSR on 50, on 1080p there's no way a 1060/2060 will handle this game at anything above 15-20 fps in certain areas. But then I installed it on my pc and I decided to play the game to see what the hype is all about.I'll start first with the negatives: - They lie about the system requirements (I would say you would need at least a 3070/4060 to enjoy a decent framerate at 1080p). - The RNG drops in this game can be really really bad (sure this can be ignored if you don't plan on 100% the game, but you will be missing on certain items) - You lack the means to move faster when exploring (you get a transformation near the end of chapter 3 and a spell in chapter 6-don't wanna spoil anything- which allows you to move faster but you can only use them in those chapters, and at first it wasn't so bad but the more you play the game, especially when you're going for 100%, the more you will feel frustrated at your overall slow pace)- The large bosses in this game have janky hitboxes - Some enemy attacks can go through the terrain - The general lack of direction in chapter 6 (the only open world chapter) can be disorienting And this is pretty much all the negatives I can think of.Now lets debunk some common negative criticism this game is receiving:- Combat is basic and boring you only do light attacks and a heavy attack. If you hear anyone saying this know that they haven't played this game for more than an hour and their opinion is irrelevant, either that or they don't have the mental capacity to understand the basic mechanics of the game. You have light & heavy attacks sure, you also have a staff spin attack, thrusts, parry (spell), parry + counter while attacking with heavy if you time it perfectly, dodge, perfect dodge, skills that let you go invisible and counter, immobilize, immobilize + perfect dodge if your timing is perfect, self-buffs, cast clones that later on can do coordinated attacks with you, different stances with different heavy attacks(3 basic ones which you can change at will + 1 secret one), spirits who can do massive one hits, or multiple lower-dmg hits, spirits who can block/dodge, spirits who can heal you, spirits which depending on your current light attack phase can do a different combo of their own, you can apply debuffs (freezing, poisoning, shocking or setting the enemy on fire), you can use vessels to keep your combos going, you have various transformations at your disposal with their own unique weapons and combos. Like you can literally do god-tier almost infinite combos if you know what you're doing and you have the required items, or you can dodge + parry and focus on counter-attacks and massive hits for no-hit runs, or you can literally no-brain it and just go full nuke and one shot pretty much anything even in ng+ while risking to get one-shotted yourself, or you can stack elemental debuffs on your enemies, you can literally play anyway you want. Sure there isn't a lot of weapon variety (you only get staves and spears) but you're playing as wukong.... what did you expect, twinblades?- Game is a boss-rush ... literally no, this game probably has the most amount of unique bosses BY FAR out of all the single player games, they are literally everywhere but that doesn't make it a boss rush games, people who say that either don't understand what that means or they just hate because they wanna hate.Ok, now to the positives: - Graphics + Soundtrack are simply 10/10, UE5 really shines in this game, and the soundtrack is just eargasm- This game has probably the best bosses out of any game ever, the sheer quantity of unique bosses is nothing short of amazing, but to take things to the next level, almost all of the bosses are incredibly fun to play against (except the large ones bc of their janky hitboxes), they offer a good challenge with varying degrees of difficulty, from very easy up to hard or very hard depending on your playstyle, level/items or experience with videogames in general. Its literally a perfect balance between quantity, quality and difficulty.- The story is really good, but what really stood out for me is the way it is presented, not everything is served on a platter, a lot of key information is presented in the form of subtle hits from dialogues (mostly from the secret bosses and quests) & from the animations we get when we finish every chapter. The relationship between various characters in the game is absolutely mind-blowing once you figure it out (small spoilers ahead, some of your enemies are actually your allies, they are brothers who test you and guide you in this game to obtain certain items, access certain areas and become stronger, you have a lover which is never mentioned at any time during the game etc)- The animations from the end of the chapters are god-tier- They stayed true to the source material while managing to add their own twist to the tale of wukong without butchering the material, but instead enhancing it- The combat is really good, if you just figure it out....- No hand-holding. There's no real combat tutorial, no mini-map or map, no quest indicators, no quest journal, the tooltip is very basic, there's a lot of hidden maps, arenas, bosses, items that most people will just miss out. Ofc this can make some people mad at the game saying stuff like the combat is basic because they don't have the capacity of figuring stuff out, but this game lets you explore and figure out everything on your own, which is what a good game should, the experience just hits differently once you figure stuff out on your own and makes the game many times better.- Has great replayability value- Well polished, in my 84 hours of playthrough as of writing this review the only bugs I encountered were some enemy attacks that would phase through walls.- No MTX Final Verdict Overall I give this game a 9.5/10, and I recommend getting this game for yourself however it does come with a buyers beware because they lie about the system requirements, I would say you need at least a 3070/4060 and even then I'm unsure if you're gonna get constant 60+ fps at 1080p, but I guess you can figure this for your own pretty fast and you can always refund.

Amazing ARPG which has lots of unique bosses with their own move set, the graphic of this game is top of the line. Combat is definitely fun, and more in line of GOD OF WAR than soul-like games. You would have access to all kinds of spells and transformations, which are fun and very helpful to overcome some of the more challenge bosses. Even thought the map level design definitely has some room for improvement, the overall exploring experience is satisfy. The Lore and story in Wukong is deeply rooted on the original story "Journey to west". However for the short animations, side quests, back stories, you can understand just fine with a little bit of reading from the in-game journal. Honestly, it's a gem in this game if you are interesting in Chinese methodology.The short animations are some of the biggest surprises, its a Chinese version of "Love,death&robot". Nevertheless to say, this is my favorite game so far this year.

LINUX/STEAMDECK USERS: WORKS, WE ARE EAC- Must disable Steam Overlay- add "+noIntroCinematics" in launch options- gamemoderun %command% helps with compositor issuesFOR LINUX USERS WITH NVIDIA- PROTON_ENABLE_NVAPI=1 DXVK_ENABLE_NVAPI=1 %command% +noIntroCinematicsThis is a known fix for crashing to desktop if after disabling the Overlay you are still crashing. I use gamemoderun as well. REVIEW:Incredible so far. With the tweaks above im getting a solid 80~ FPS on Linux Desktop and EAC works without issue. Product refunded TL;DR: Solo players beware, this is very much a game balanced and intended to be played with a group despite having the option of Solo. If you have at least 1 friend you can bring with you i'm sure the experience is 1000x more enjoyable and fun, otherwise i would stay away until they announce significant improvements to the AI. Be aware there are no private lobbies either until later this month it seems, so no way of doing operations solo either at the moment. I can't speak for Anything PVP as i have no interest in that.Rant Below:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I wanted to like this game...I Really REALLY wanted to like this game... Warhammer is very cool and i was looking forward to this for months...Hell the game looks good, seemed well optimized, and i'm sure is such a blast with friends as everyone is saying...But the current status of solo play is ABSOLUTELY ATROCIOUS!!! AI Companion behavior is as follows:- They Do Not Help with the objective.- They Do Not Kill a noticeable amount of enemies at all, often just peppering various enemies before swinging wildly.- They often stray far from Titus and waste time with random fodder in the distance- Likewise if you are doing an objective and require defense they will NEVER BOTHER TO DEFEND YOU! - They have a habit of leaving executable enemies alive (This is supposed to let the player come over to gain some armor and is always done when the player is below 100% armor, but when i'm like 40+ feet away thanks to their behavior and still dealing with all the active mobs this can get VERY ANNOYING to deal with as you can imagine.- They do not draw aggro from the horde AT ALL!!!! Even if they are in front of titus they often just get skipped over, leaving the ENTIRE SWARM DESIGNED FOR 3 SEPARATE PEOPLE!!! all for the player to deal with.Literally Their sole purpose at this time is to come and revive you when you get downed thanks to them not doing ANYTHING ELSE!!!! And by the way, you have limited revives so have fun seeing the same checkpoint over and over. At least you don't have to backtrack much.This is by far one of the WORST Companion AI's I have seen in a PvE game. Even with this price tag and all the hype behind it I was never gonna expect them to create something that could feel like a legit fill-in for a player but WOW this is just ridiculous! They really are THAT bad.... Keep in mind that this is on veteran difficulty, which the game states is the Intended difficulty. Yes, yes I know I can just lower the difficulty to absurdly easy levels and probably 1 tap everything myself and try to stick to listening to the story. But gameplay was like 85% of the reason i picked the game up. The story, while i'm sure interesting enough for groups pushing through the game , is simply not gripping enough to warrant neither slowly dragging my feet through hordes of easy creatures with no challenge Nor Play the intended difficulty or higher and suffer with the two basically non-existent AI allies. The bosses themselves also seem to be intended as a challenge to deal with, would have been fun to at least see them and take a good try at them but sucks I wont get around to them thanks to dying due to lack of defense, being swarmed and just generally left for dead by the companions.One thing to note is that the developers are the same people who created the World War Z game, Seemingly Notorious for its own AI also being awful...Hmmm....At that point as someone who has zero interest in modern PVP games/modes, and doesn't wanna get kicked out of lobbies constantly nor generally leave how much fun I can have up to randoms in said lobby, I ultimately bailed.Private lobbies are coming later this month it seems, which should probably allow solo in operations but with the dev's poor AI record from the WWZ game and of course only 6 PvE missions to pick from at the moment, it really doesn't bode well. I WANT to be proven wrong so badly, I want the experience to become smoother regardless of how many play. But this is just NOT IT right now. Definitely not for 90 bucks at least. I would hope that their top priority is adjusting the AI but considering this is being treated as a primarily multiplayer game currently, i'm not gonna hold my breath for it.I leave it to you whether or not its worth 60 bucks, I mean there are many (cheaper) games that offer more significantly more playtime but assuming you dabble in the PVP and Don't get tired of doing the 6 missions over and over you could probably squeeze 30+ hours or more depending on when you finally get tired of it.As for me? I think the foundation is there, but there is much to be improved and it really sucks we aren't getting a proper replayable PvE horde mode until a year in. Oh Well...If they make the improvements to the companions and reviews start glowing about it I will go back and switch it to positive. Hell, if they are SIGNIFICANTLY better maybe i'll even pick it up and try again at some point...but until then I leave very disappointed for now.

After really taking my time with this game, I can't ignore that while it starts super strong, it all kinda falls apart in the second half. By the time you hit chapter 4, the narrative starts to lose coherency unless you're a diehard journey to the west scholar, any sense of creative fight design is out the window and replaced by scammy gimmicks designed to nerf your progression and force you into basic play where your only tools are dodges and light attacks, and it's so riddled with minor bugs that while you can play mostly unperturbed, any extra exploration or effort towards 100% will inevitably slam you with a bugged quest line or boss fight. It's just straight up sloppy for a game presenting itself as a AAA experience, Ubisoft finishes their games better than this, and that's saying something. It's hard to say don't buy this game since the first half is so strong, but if you're on the fence, my best advice is wait for some patches.

Worthwhile MMO-like Survival Gameplay for FreeEnjoy it now, at least until this NetEase-owned Chinese developer decides to make it P2W or drops development in the future, as they've done with a lot of their games. Only time will tell. That said, OnceHuman right now is an awesome survival game. It's sort of an MMO cross between Nightingale and Left 4 Dead. You can create hives or warbands to play together with your guild/clan, or you can just play solo and still have a ton of fun.Servers seem pretty reliable right now, and I'm playing with my gaming community that's more EU-based, while I live in NA. The EU servers are still fairly responsive for me. That's a huge plus. I've been impressed in that I've experienced absolutely no rubber-banding, stutter, or hiccups... yet. I have played with a few others around, but no massive parties or groups yet.And I'm impressed with the game's performance. I run at 2k on a gaming rig from 2016/2017 with a GTX 1080, so I wasn't expecting any sort of good performance. I turned down AA, shadows, and set VFX to medium. It runs very smooth with a 60Hz Vsync at 2k resolution on my system. Kudos to the devs for having the game perform this well at launch.As for gameplay, I was only planning on playing for an hour since I had other things to do on launch day. But I couldn't stop playing and ended up foregoing all of my other tasks to play this all evening long. It's really enjoyable and addictive. That's coming from a rather grumpy gamer who's very choosy about what I play. Progression in the beginning (first two tiers) seems balanced and doesn't feel like a grind. I'm not sure if that will become more of a grind or not over time.Controls are intuitive, but key bindings need more work. I'm ok with F for interactions, but I usually remap things like roll/dodge to Q or E. Shift for sprint is nice, but haven't bothered to find a way to toggle it on/off yet (not sure if that's possible?). Sprinting reduces your stamina(?) meter which is shared with mining and chopping down trees, so I'm not a fan of that. And being able to craft vehicles and explore while driving around is fun, but gas usage really needs to be turned down quite a bit.I love the post-apocalyptic feel of the game and the environment, along with looting junk to deconstruct for basic components/materials. Some mobs are very easy to fight while others are a bit annoying (e.g.: flying mobs are a pain). And I don't really see the need for base defensive structures yet, as nothing is attacking my base. May be these are for later progression or PVP? I'm playing on a PVE server, so as long as you don't do chaos, you don't have to worry about PVP. On PVP servers they're only PVP once you hit level 10.Constructing your base is fairly straight-forward, but sometimes orienting pieces to fit is painful. Fortunately they have a "fly" mode where you can move about freely to make placement easier. Still, some fitment of pieces is restricted when it shouldn't be, but most things work well together and handle edge overlap just fine. The first roofing you get is fugly, but it gets better later. Also, it's not good to give absolutely no lighting options early on, as interiors can get quite dark, even with windows.There was a 14 minute queue just to login to your selected server on launch day, and that's even before you get to create and customize your character (and that customization is insane for its amazing level of detail). Hopefully that queue wait will improve, especially since my server was only listed as a "Mid" population server. The servers are just numbers with PVE or PVP prefix, so it's rather dull to tell your guild/clan/gaming community you're on server PVE01-000XX. It would be nice it servers were not split into regions, but global with regional yet seamless zones. Picking regional servers is so 2000s to 2010s.The intro video was very vague and did a horrible job (no job at all) in providing a back story to the current world and state of things. And it only gets worse from there, as there's nothing explaining the reason for moving in and out of different realities/plans of existence/whatever. All of these terms including deviant, star dust, star fall, rifts, etc. is just terminology stolen from other IP that don't seem to have any special back story or meaning in the game. And apparently you collect, nourish, and equip some sort of magical/ethereal butterflies to help you along the way, all while getting advice from a holographic/pseudo-real talking bird that's visually annoying. But the most frustrating, immersion-breaking aspect is that your character replied to NPCs during dialogs with no speech but feigned head movements and gestures even though the NPCs are speaking with decent audio clips.To sum it up: no story, weird dialogs, and sloppy, disjointed explanation of your purpose. But the gameplay is addictive and fun. Both network and game client performance is excellent. No P2W (yet?), and developers are on top of addressing feedback and complaints (like giving us the ability to create more than one character now). This is a Chinese developer with a poor history of P2W and abandoning games, along with a questionable privacy policy, but that can be overlooked with the way things have progressed in Once Human so far. Since it's free, it's really a worthwhile experience.

I wish there was an option "Recommended for 40k Fans"Short review: Do I recommend the game? Yes. But to people who are interested in Warhammer 40k. And not the expensive editions, just buy the regular one.Long review: I loved the first Space Marine, actually, I beat it last week for the first time in anticipation for the sequel.Space Marine 2 leaves you in awe of how amazing the environments look. The hordes are stunning and give you the "oh shi-" feeling when you realize that the hundreds of Tyranids running towards you aren't some backdrop but the actual enemies you'll have to fight.Some gameplay mechanics are questionable. Executions now replenish armor instead of health unlike in the first game, this makes sense from a Co-Op point of view but in the campaign it really pulls you out of the moment and frustrates you. In fact, if you fully die, you just restart from the previous checkpoint with reset to your "downed" limit. Which means that if you got into a boss fight with just "down" left, it's better to just let the boss kill you to restart the fight with a reset "down" count.I'm also not a fan of the limited weapon slots. In the previous game you had your pistol, your primary and two other slots for big guns. In this game, you have your pistol, your primary, and an occasional big gun which you can pick up but have to drop if you want to switch to the others. This left me wishing I had picked another gun as my primary before specific boss fights.There were very few bugs, and I had encountered only 1 soft block during a mission, but luckily I had a checkpoint right before so I reloaded and didn't lose any progress. Checkpoints in this game are very generously provided.The game is great for 40k fans, but some of the gameplay mechanics make it frustrating to play on the higher difficulties. I played on the "Veteran" difficulty which is the second highest and the intended one by the devs, and I do wonder if people were even more frustrated with the highest difficulty.Tl;Dr: Space Marine 2 is a great game for 40k fans but will likely leave non-fans frustrated due to a handful of gameplay design choices that really piss you off. Only the standard edition is worth it, don't waste your money.
