2022 If you are like me and hate the Souls games for being overly difficult and for always working against and not for the player, do give Elden Ring a try, you might end up loving it as much as I did.Before getting into the review I'd like to give my opinions some merit by saying that I played over 50 hours of Demon's Souls in 2010 on PS3, made decent progress too, then I played Lords of the Fallen on Steam(Not a From Soft game) and gave Sekiro a try and hated it. I also played a bit of the PS5 Demon's Souls remake.I have also tried other games with Souls mechanics and did not care for them one bit with the exception of Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order which had multiple difficulties and I loved from beginning to end.With that in mind, let's get into my Elden Ring review.Elden Ring is the single, best action RPG I have ever played bar none. I even took the time to "Platinum" the game which I pretty much never do. Sure it had its shortcomings but the overall experience was simply unmatched by anything.In order to keep it clean and easy to understand I will post pros and cons of the gamePros:- STUNNING Art Direction, the game looks like a moving painting at every turn. I was in awe from beginning to end- Even though the game has a rather sparse and vague storytelling, if you stick to quest lines you're actually going to relate to the characters and that's very sweet. They all have very little dialogue yet it's well written and acted enough to make the player care about them.- The game is full of AMAZING Random moments you wouldn't even think could occur- Incredible, epic, amazing boss fights- Fantastic gameplay that works FOR and not against the player unlike other Souls games which do everything they can to screw the player over- Essentially infinite healing items that only increase and get stronger as you explore the world- Weapons and armor don't break! Maintaining your equipment ruined so many games for me including Demon's Souls and even Breath of the Wild (I still finished BotW at least)- Very frequent checkpoints, a checkpoint before every major encounter- Specifically dedicated Farm Zones that make leveling up a breeze, they also have checkpoints right next to them- The world is full of content yet never once felt overwhelming or boring much less like some kind of a checklistSense of discovery like no other game before it, I was genuinely happy and excited to discover new dungeons, places, items, characters, vistas, everything is just so well put together it's incredible.- Brilliant eerie somber music and ambience that fit the world perfectly- Satisfying sound effects, from the sounds the main character makes as they walk or roll around to weapon clashes, hits, everything it's just perfect. With headphones on the game's sound helps with gameplay too.- Elden Ring lets the player make mistakes, experiment with fights, take risks without punishing them by wasting their time which is something other souls games doCons:- Quest lines could and should have been clearly outlined IMO, unless you follow a quest guide you have pretty much no chance of discovering or progressing through these quest lines- Some bosses were idiotic, mainly the 2nd form of the final boss and 2nd form of that one other boss tho her I dealt with by summoning two other players to help withMaking it complicated to get all three endings on a single file for console users, fortunately I was on PC so it was a nonissue for me- TERRIBLE CLUNKY MOVEMENT AND JUMPING which sadly comes into play in 2 optional areasMost spells, armors, items and weapons are fairly useless and only a few are worth using, so that's pretty disappointing- Unable to respec an unlimited number of times, you need respec items, I had 10 and used two I believe, but it would've been so much more fun if I could infinitely play with my build. You also need to find these items tho I seem to have found them without trying so there's thatMy final rating - 10/10An absolutely amazing experience, only marred by the final boss' 2nd phase for me----------------------------I still strongly dislike Souls Games for the following reasons, none of which are present as much in Elden Ring:- Even the slightest mistake can and will mess up your run in other Souls games, but not in Elden Ring- HP and MP healing items cost souls, souls take time to farm up, it's not your choice to farm, the game essentially makes you- Dying sets you back to the beginning of a level, if you opened up shortcuts cool but some levels don't have them, fighting the same damn enemies over and over is tedious when it is NOT your choice to do so. Meaning you are either perfect or you mess up, end up wasting healing items and what not just to die at the end of the segment and try again and again to no end.I play plenty of retro games, they give you far more room for mistake than the average Souls game.- Demon's Souls for example LOVES putting the player in small, narrow spaces with enemies. If you're melee good luck becuase your sword will bounce off walls, if the camera decides to mess up and it will, it's even worse. Elden Ring very rarely did this. Tho there were some camera issues in Elden Ring as well here and there but nothing major. - IIRC the more you die in Demon's Souls for example, the more difficult the game becomes, something about world tendency getting darker but I can't confirm this for sure, Elden Ring does none of this stuff.

2022 I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

2023 It is painful to write this review since i play total war games since rome total war yet here we go, again.. In order for someone to enjoy everything that this game has to offer, he has to pay 🥁🥁🥁 263€..Seriously, that's amazing that they can get out with this, but is it?Who enabled them to get this far? Well, we did it. Thinking that things will get better..With every broken release, we rewarded them with our money and they just kept going, and going without fixing any of the bugs, addressing the balance between the factions and so on.The first Warhammer total war was released back on 2016, it had its bugs yet it was a fresh installment in the franchise and most of us were exited with what was to come. Then came the first DLCs which were alarming but the "hype" was still strong.With the release of the 2nd Warhammer total war, they added a couple of factions and a new campaign and here is where it gets interesting. In every other title in the franchise that would be an expansion/DLC for the core game like the Age of Charlemagne in Attila total war yet here the majority accepted something like that and yes, it is awful. Then came the extra DLCs with additional lords that were also overpriced yet people still found my review back them as funny even if at that time i stated the obvious missing features and bugs.Now after so many years we still have (without mods):- random crashes in battles - random crashes in changing turns- awful siege battles, the outer walls are like decorations, the inner towers are like a joke and it is pretty weird since they created Empire total war and they could just place towers manned by missile troops and have extra barricades by the units in order to actually feel that you have ground control- awful battle optimization, create a doomstack of strong missile units and you are good to go even if your enemy has armored knights or infantry since the ai is weird focusing on the lord most of the time.- awful bonuses for the ai in battle map and campaign, i mean if i played against someone that uses cheats then i would just stop playing yet in almost every total war title and here there is no exception, the ai will probably beat you but only because it's cheating, so if you play against a hard ai it will not just outsmart you, it will get the bonuses and beat you, challenging isn't it? I thought that a strategy game is all about finding the most fitting strategy to overcome your opponent- no formations for the troops like shield wall, testudo, schiltron, pike phalanx, fire by rank and so on, and the long requested mix between melee and missile units which will be useful for the starting troops to counter the beasts of this world- no meaningful upgrades for the units, it feels that the experience bonuses are like a joke with no real impact in the battle, same goes for the technology buffs of the units- no visual unit upgrades by the armory like in medieval 2 total war or like in Attila through the technology tree- awful balance between the factions, no counter strategies for certain skills/abilities- very few lord in accordance with the lore of warhammer universe, i can think of almost 40 khorne heroes yet the game has 2, well, we actually know why- poor compatibility with the mods in workshop. sometimes it's the modders fault but most of the times that comes a new patch then all of the mods need to be reworked in order to be playable- Governing systems between races are missing and the one that the empire has it's still not fixed with each electoral faction almost acting on each own without being able to allied with each other..At the end of the day, they just lost a costumer since i will never buy another of their titles if they insist on the same money grabbing practices...

2023 The game isn't perfect, there are areas to improve. However this is almost a new game compared to how it was at the release of total war warhammer 3. Its in a decent state. Generally gameplay, and fun has only improved as post release development has happened. The DLC is expensive. To get the most out of it you at least should own the DLC for the factions/races you enjoy the play of. If it is a game 2 faction in IE it will cost you a bit. I should assume by end of the dev phase of 3 it will be the same with a lot more factions.Be aware of this before going in. Theres no way to test factions as DLC, a try before you buy function, and the price can add up. However the gameplay is fun, it has good visuals, the over world campaign has a lot to do. The AI needs a bit more work, but even that is getting to a good point. The DLC team as well consistently does good work. If you enjoy total war, or at the very least strategy this game has something to offer you.

Game Review: A Journey Worth Every SecondGood: This game hooked me like no other, and I found myself immersed for five days straight. The combat is exhilarating, the graphics are stunning, and the story is captivating—one of the best I’ve seen in a while. However, it’s not as straightforward as most games. To fully appreciate the narrative, you need some background in Chinese mythology, particularly the classic tale "Journey to the West." I had to watch a few YouTube videos to get up to speed, but it was worth it.The boss fights, in particular, are nothing short of spectacular. Each one is unique, challenging, and utterly insane. The best for me was the ERLANGGGGGGGG boss fight. I had to do the same fight for 6 hrs straight. Some times the theme plays in my head when I go sleep.The music also deserves special mention. The soundtrack perfectly complements the action and story, heightening the emotional impact of key scenes. The music team absolutely nailed it, delivering hype and tension exactly when needed.Bad: While the game is nearly flawless, there are some technical issues that can be frustrating. Occasionally, I encountered glitches that required a quick restart to fix. It’s a minor inconvenience, but something I hope gets patched soon.Conclusion: Overall, this game is a masterpiece that’s absolutely worth the price. The storytelling, combat, graphics, and music all come together to create an unforgettable experience. Even with its minor technical hiccups, it’s a solid 10/10 in my book. If you’re a fan of mythology or just looking for a game that will consume your time in the best possible way, this is it.

2022 At the point I refunded this game, it had no mortal empires campaign, and no Workshop support. This is probably the most barebones Total Warhammer release by far; it lacks content, lacks diversity in the content it does have, and suffers from performance issues. These performance issues are due to the very strange choice of CA's to use Denuvo. I wonder which came first: these people having disastrous launches every time they release a game, or people pirating their games at release. It seems to me that they could resolve their piracy woes by just releasing their games when they're finished, rather than ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the game's performance with Denuvo.

2022 Finally, after two years of slogging through painfully poor optimization, lackluster content updates, and inane design decisions, I can finally recommend this game. Sort of. The game still has massive issues. Pathing for units is a bit borked, particularly in siege battles. Sieges themselves, while no longer overbearing, are still not great and are long slogs to get through. There are still many noteworthy bugs. I recently started a skaven campaign, only to realize about 20 turns in that and entire lord option was just missing from the UI, and had to restart my campaign from scratch which somehow fixed the issue. There are massive terrain deformations, ranged units have to do a little dance before they acknowledge a new attack order, and plenty more. But things are in a much better state than 2 years ago, and CA do seem committed to fixing up the game and adding new and better stuff. After some content updates, the Shadow of Change and Thrones of Decay DLCs are a lot more appealing now. It is now a more complete Warhammer Fantasy experience, where the positives have begun to outweigh the negatives significantly. CA still have a lot of work to do, but if you love Warhammer and strategy, you probably won't find a more robust game to get... but you should still probably wait for a sale.

2022 The game seemed to be going in a good direction with the past two DLCs, but with the new developments, it's curving away from its positive trajectory quite significantly. The game is still very buggy and the pace of bugfixes being tied to DLCs is far too slow. This latest DLC being short on content and particularly pricey, it feels particularly bad. As such, I am switching back my review to negative, as I don't think it's a good time to get in the game right now. Wait and see, and definitely wait for sales if you are going to get anything.For reference, my old review after the Champions of Chaos DLCWith the release of Immortal Empires and the new narrative campaigns for the champions of chaos, fixes to autoresolve and anti-player bias, the game has recovered from its disastrous launch. Just gotta wait for the workshop to get all the essential WH2 mods transferred and this will be the must have sequel that it should have been at launch.For reference, my old review at launch:As it is now, you will probably have a better time in WH2 than in WH3. At least the mod workshop got activated so modders can fix the game for CA.Early final verdict: If you're pretty much done with WH2 and itching for something new, find it on sale and you'll get your money's worth, if not now then over time. If you're not done with WH2, wait for a bigger sale.Such a weird launch for this hugely anticipated sequel to one of the best game series ever. Everyone had high expectations since Total War: Warhammer 2 has done so well with releases with the recent DLCs. Unfortunately, the WH3 teams dropped the ball in many aspects of the game:- Implementation of the narrative: It is not engaging. You have to wait for rifts, then you "lose" your legendary lord to race for souls in a format that is hugely biased for the AI (Tzeentch being the worse, but attrition in Nurgle's realm, or battles in the other two because of major faction auto-resolve bias), then if you finally get through, you get a pretty flavorless reward (why not boons tied to the identity of the souls, CA?!) or, if someone succeeds first, you just wasted your time and get kicked out (except in Tzeetch's realm if you mapped a part of it. The God of Change's realm is surprisingly static so next try will be faster)- Reciprocity of the game mechanics: Many mechanics in the campaign are far more punishing in the hands of the AI than for players. Most glaring of all is the auto-resolver which favors the AI so much you're forced to fight meaningless battles to not get your army (not unit(s), army!) wiped out by a clearly inferior opponent. Waiting 2x load times to fight a boring one-sided battle is not a good experience. It doesn't add to game difficulty either, just tedium. The anti-player bias is also stupidly strong. Then there's the faction stuff: Nurgle plagues aren't very effective for the players as the AI recruit armies from nowhere, barely suffers attrition and rarely relies on replenishment, but devastating against the player who has fewer armies, generally tries to not lose units and normally relies on replenishment. Similarly, the changing of ways is absolutely unfun when yielded by the AI. Spend the next turn not doing anything? Come on... Bombardments being easily dodged by the AI (but not wind/vortex spells??) but devastating for the player who can't keep an eye on everything. The list goes on.- Building design and balance. Buildings that are useless, other far more useful. Overall, the selection is bloated and building upgrades are often not worth it. (Ex.: Khislev markets: 4000 gold for a 50 gold income increase? That'll take 80 turns before it's useful. I probably can do something better with that gold right now, that will benefit me much sooner).- Tech tree design and balance. Some techs and tech trees are far superior to others. There is a big difference between choices because it's all good, and because it's all meaningless. Both are present for different factions.- Quality: SO many bugs and problems. Whack-a-tower is not a fun game to play in the already overly common minor settlement battles. Abilities not working. The *awesome voice* docking areas being a trap that nerf your archers. and more. This looks rushed.The game does certain things well though (faction identity, graphics), and it is still a decent game. But it's barely now in the stage it should have launched in and still worse than the current state of its predecessor. Overall, it seems like CA spent a lot of time working on engine stuff and graphics, but very little on making sure the game is actually fun to play. Works ok, looks good, release! We need money now and we'll patch it later, maybe.

i wish steam had an in-between option for reviews, because while the gameplay is fun, i don't think it's worth the price with the current level of content. there's a fairly short (6 mission) campaign, 6 operations missions which play out alongside the main campaign, and a barebones PVP mode which is okay. The combat is good but can be a bit janky, especially the melee combat. the control scheme isn't great for mouse & keyboard and was obviously designed with console controllers in mind. I had a few weird bugs, including character/weapon/enemy models becoming invisible & connection issues trying to play operations with a friend, but i appreciate it's still very early days and these will likely be fixed. i'll almost definitely come back to this game in future if/when they add more content, but currently it's far too expensive for what you get.

It feels like I'm doing chores then the developers come into the room and throw paint on the walls and say, "We've reset the map so it can feel fresh."GraphicsYup, good graphics. The scenery is beautiful.StoryThe underlying scenario is good enough that it hurts so much that the story is absolute dog poop. There are literally only two characters in the game (everyone else acts like a mannequin).The first character is a woman named Mitsuko dressed in all white who is heavily selling a combination of damsel in distress, amnesiac, and demure. Except this doesn't work at all! She's a mary-sue who has incredible psychic powers; is never once actually in any real danger; and can cross dimensions at will.Some gross creative director leaned over the modeler's shoulder and told them, "Make her look like she's 18 then make her shirt just every so slightly transparent." It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ creepy as hell.Mitsuko is obviously supposed to make the player want to protect her, but she's so aggravating. The player is never given any reason at all to care about this person, but the story keeps trotting along with the main character expressing ever more concern.I am trying to express just how badly this story is written. It's so divorced from the reality of events around you. The stakes are never there. Like the awful Star Wars prequels: I keep getting told by the narrative what my character feels and never shown any reason to back it up. I completely tuned out after a while. It's a slog to get through the story sections. I cannot overstate just how uninteresting the story for this game is.The second character is your robot bird thing that's always around you. The voice actor did a good job. It's doing the amnesiac thing, too, which was super annoying.Meat was attempted to be given to the story by adding groups like Rosetta, Mayfly, and Vultures. They're talked about but are completely indistinct from each other. Every single group member simply stands around and shoots you when you get close. Look, this guy is wearing a torn jacket and is behaving exactly like every other NPC. Incredible environmental story telling!Don't forgive bad stories. Bad stories mean that the developers thought so little about your intelligence that they assumed they could shovel nonsense and tropes at you and you'd still spend money because they have women in tight clothes and spent almost their entire budget on lots of special effects.EngagementThe core gameplay loop is to run around collecting things and shooting enemies so you can craft better gear and survive the next area. It's generally enjoyable There are two main types of areas. A boss arena and an overworld.Collecting weapons is done by receiving a random drop (rare) or by crafting the weapon. Crafting and upgrading weapons requires blue prints and the rarer blueprints are the entry point for taking real world money from you. There is a punishing durability aspect to each weapon that further encourages you to spend more time and money on getting more weapons or gathering materials to repair your weapons so you can ... keep gathering materials.All the things!I am impressed at how many distinct features and interfaces are shoved into this game! There are 3 rewards screens. Three. There is so much here that I was still discovering new menus and interactions months into playing. It doesn't need to be this complex. Does complexity equal fun? Nope.OverallThis is a product that spent a lot of money on graphic design while skimping on the things that would make players feel good about playing.Even given all that I've written, I'd still enjoy the game while playing with friends except that the world gets reset every six weeks so what's the point?

2022 Good entry to the souls like games. 8/10 game. Feels like it is Dark souls 3 the sequel. FromSoftware didnt really take too many risks with innovation aside from a free roam map and a new skill system for your weapons this plays exactly like other souls like games. They have learned from some mistakes in their other games but some frustrating issues are still present from other games. The hitboxes in this entry are finally good, you can duck under swings from a sword, jump over attacks its honestly pretty cool but then you still have the same issues that were present in previous games such as enemies being able to hit through walls, AOE projectiles will hit you through floors etc. Performance has also been quite inconsistent. They are still using their really poorly designed (at least imo) summon system. For some bosses if you wish to summon a player but theres not many players currently on that boss (or at least want to be summoned for the boss) then you will see only a small handful of summon signs and by the time you have interacted with them someone else has summoned the player so you missed them. It happens constantly in areas with few summon signs and it is essentially a race to the sign. Summoning your friends has now been made "easier" with a password mechanic so only you and your friend can see eachothers summon signs which is fine but if I want me friend to help me with a boss that they have not discovered yet I have to wait for them to get to the area and clear it and get to my location before I can summon. Its just time wasting and it would be so much handier if they could for example just join me through steam to fight the boss and they go back to their own game instead of wasting 30 minutes of both our time. Its an issue iv had with all the souls games I just think the summon mechanic is really bad.Invasions have also been changed in this game to the point where I honestly thought they just got rid of invasions. Instead they have been changed. You can now only be invaded if you are exploring with a coop partner or if you happen to have found and used a specific item that allows players to invade your solo world (why even call it Invasion if you allowing it? Its not really an invasion if you have a choice to be invaded). Most players (or at least among my friend group) do not summon for simple exploration but to fight bosses and seeing as you cannot be invaded mid boss fight we have essentially seen no invasions.The world and dungeons are once again beautifully crafted and if you loved the older games big dungeon design you will feel right at home. The game does suffer however from a few smaller dungeons/caves that are in my opinion poorly designed. You will notice that these smaller dungeons/caves are essentially copy and paste jobs of one another with just a different layout. Some of them are even the exact same layout. There are a few really fun ones that have the most different layouts or require you to do some thinking on how to progress but for the most part the dungeons are quick, easy, and very similar to one another.Enemy and boss designs are once again amazing looking however I still do not understand why they put Margit as one of the first bosses as he is far harder than even some late game bosses.The Horse is fine. It is mostly used for traversal. Mounted combat on horseback is very basic and aside from using the horse to help with fighting the games many Dragons (mostly using it to dodge firebreath attacks when the Dragon flies) it is pretty boring to fight whilst mounted.Overall it is probably one of the best of FromSoftwares games. Is it a masterpiece? No. The devs have improved on nearly every aspect of the series but have taken few risks in innovation and actually doing anything new. I think FromSoftware can do better as this just feels like a souls game but with an open world.

Black Myth Wukong Review I played 9 hours but 4 were offline so I think it will say I played 5 hours, I didn't beat the game, yet I still made this comprehensive review to explain the core aspects of the game and it's quality. This review uses my own experience and those of my friends who got ahead in the game. I am 30 years old, and I don't enjoy souls likes anymore in the long term. Still, I did my review objectively and I think you might find it useful. Cheers!~Black Myth Wukong is a soul-like game that adds some interesting elements to the genre by incorporating new ideas into its gameplay through the legendary tale of Sun Wukong. Players can transform into bosses they defeated before (with some limitations), and Wukong's tricks are plenty. They can range from transforming into rock to making multiple clones of themselves or freezing foes in place, unable to move or fight back.The player will explore the tale of the legendary monkey king while fighting challenging bosses and recovering the artifacts of Wukong. The game starts easy but rapidly reaches difficulty levels of your most popular soul games, requiring skill, strategy, and wits to defeat fearsome foes. What Makes It Worth Playing?If there is something people hear about this game, it is two things: transforming into bosses and ray tracing. The ray tracing of the game looks beautiful, as reflections and environments look superb on the screen. The requirements are quite bulky, as I used an RTX 4070 Super and could either go 2k with Ray Tracing at medium with settings on very high for 70-90 FPS or 4k with no ray tracing at the same frame rate. Explore the story of Sun Wukong in a blockbuster fashion! A Screenshot of Black Myth: Wukong By: Nirhildija The story is surprisingly very good and interesting, voice actors do well in their assigned roles, and the opening of the game is similar to a blockbuster movie. The tale deals with wanting to be free, which Wukong wants, but the Celestial Court won't let him be. In addition, the court enjoys mocking him and other beast-like creatures, angering him as he rebels to prove his might. The difficulty is another aspect that might attract players looking to establish themselves and face off against challenging foes in exciting and nerve-wracking gameplay.Core GameplayThe game's core combat focuses on options and the availability of resources. The player has multiple avenues for choosing how to fight enemies, such as spirits that they can summon and take their form to unleash special attacks, becoming bosses, using skills such as invisibility, or using their pole to get above the enemy and avoid attacks. Having so many assets to use on foes and see what works best against certain enemies is incredibly fun and rewarding. Fight fearsome foes that will make your blood burn hot! A Screenshot of Black Myth: Wukong By: Nirhildija The premise is that the game is a boss rush; you go to a place, explore it, beat the boss, and move on. If you defeat bosses effortlessly, you run into a lot of bosses on the norm, and each combat is intriguing and unique. Battle monks that summon the fallen, rat siblings in a 1vs2, giant tigers that bathe in the blood of their foes with big swords, etc. The game action is fast, so you have to act quickly before enemies resume the onslaught of attacks. There is no co-op for this game (so those that like souls games with co-op experiences, be warned, it is only going to be you!), and there is no punishment for dying in-game, so you are stress-free and don't have to pick up your "souls" or currencies of other types.My ExperienceI enjoyed my time in the game, as brief as it was (I am getting old to be playing this hardcore game, I swear, haha~). I didn't find the stances attractive, as the default stance worked better for me than the other two. The tricks of Wukong are fun to use, and in boss fights, you need to use all of your arsenals intelligently to emerge victorious on the challenging boss fights, which is a great gameplay design. Enemies often have their particular bag of tricks they will use on the player. Defeat enemies and take their form to use to your advantage! A Screenshot of Black Myth: Wukong By: Nirhildija I used many points in the foundation, mainly HP and stamina. I also used some points in transformations and the immobility spell, as they are instrumental. The gameplay is like a combination of souls, like in action games. It is hard, but you are as powerful as your foes, making the soul-like experience less stressful and difficult. The game's presentation is fantastic; enemies react to your boss's transformations, and the dialogue in fights is on par with the rest of the game. Long Term Appeal A game playthrough will last between 40-60 hours, depending on your skill, and you can always replay the game after beating it to challenge even stronger foes. I am getting burned out of the genre. Go there, fight a powerful enemy, get destroyed, do it again until you succeed, and repeat for another 40 hours. I may have been playing too much Elden Ring, but I don't enjoy Souls games as much as I did before.Back to the review, if you like challenges meant to block your progression and prove your skills, this game is impressive. It excels at all its facets and is incredible to experience. If you prefer to avoid difficulty, be wary. It is a marathon to get to the end of this title, as the mountain is rather tall and complex to climb. Price Point AnalysisIt is an easy buy for its asking price. If your computer can run it, you are guaranteed to have a good time with this game.ConclusionIn a genre so cluttered with so many games that it feels oversaturated, Black Myth Wukong succeeds in adding a new spice to the genre by revolutionizing the gameplay and rewards of its core experience. It is a must-play for all souls, like fans who enjoy this title, and an invitation to try it out for those who feel braver and confident in their skills. This game's graphics, music, story, gameplay, and design are superb and worth all the praise it's been getting.10/10 MASTERPIECE:) If you enjoy and find the review helpful, please follow my curator! StarsDeck

2022 There's a lot of new and good things they tried which is a net good. However as most reviews point out, the game is unfinished and non-functional at times. Ranged units stand around even when their default state is fire at will. If there's a large corpse on the battlefield, units struggle to pathfind around it to the point of them being stuck in a walking loop. Campaign gets stuck if you so much as click at the wrong time. Prologue / tutorial as good with the amount of voice acting and cutscenes - main campaign feels bare-boned in comparison. Summed up, people are frustrated that CA "broke" stuff that was already working fine in TWW2 in trying to remake the wheel. Here's to hoping they fix it soon but yeah, can not recommend it at in its current state.

Lets talk about their privacy policy:https://protocol.unisdk.easebar.com/release/latest_v475.html Over-collection of Personal Information and security risks: The policy collects a wide range of personal data, including sensitive information like government-issued IDs, which is typically excessive unless specifically required by law or for a legitimate purpose. Collecting and storing extensive personal and sensitive information like government IDs, credit card details, social media data, and communication history poses significant security and privacy risks. They also list numerous third-party recipients of personal information without specifying how these parties will handle the data.Lack of Transparency and Purpose Limitation: It's unclear why such extensive details are needed for "correction of personal information." Transparency about data collection purposes is crucial for users to understand why their data is being collected. There's also little to no mention of user consent or control over their data. GDPR and similar regulations require clear consent mechanisms and user rights, such as the right to access, correct, and delete personal data. While it mentions consent in some contexts (e.g., marketing), it's unclear how users can exercise control over their data, such as accessing or deleting it. GDPR and similar regulations require clear mechanisms for users to manage their data. The policy also doesn't specify how long different types of data will be retained, which is essential for users to understand their data lifecycle and rights regarding data deletion.Legal Basis and Justification: Although the policy mentions legal bases for processing personal data (e.g., legitimate interests), it does not elaborate on how these bases apply to specific data processing activities, which is crucial for compliance and user understanding.TLDR; this privacy policy is problematic because it lacks clarity, transparency, and appears to over-collect personal information without sufficient justification or safeguards for user privacy. regularly, privacy policies should prioritize user consent, data security, limited data collection, and clear communication of data usage purposes.Personal peeve: You also cant claim closed beta rewards on steam unless you download their NetEase spyware launcher. This was never stated during the closed beta, I would say I wasted nearly a hundred hours on the closed betas just to get smacked in the face with a "due to limitations" account linking bs that was never mentioned before, all to get me to download their launcher. Dont risk your privacy as an individual. Stay away.

I recently had the pleasure of diving into "Black Myth: Wukong," and I must say, it stands out as a breath of fresh air in the souls-like genre. While many games in this space are known for their punishing difficulty, "Black Myth: Wukong" offers a more casual experience that still retains thrilling combat and exploration.The gameplay feels fluid and accessible, allowing me to fully enjoy the stunning visuals and intricate world design without being stuck in a loop of frustration. The combat mechanics are engaging, with a variety of moves and combos that make each encounter feel unique. What truly sets "Black Myth: Wukong" apart is its captivating storytelling and rich cultural references, drawing from the classic tale of the Monkey King. The game beautifully integrates myth with action, resulting in an experience that’s both entertaining and thought-provoking.Overall, if you’re a fan of souls-like games but prefer a more casual approach, "Black Myth: Wukong" is a must-play. The blend of accessibility and depth makes it not just a worthy competitor, but in my opinion, an even better experience than other souls games. Highly recommend it!8.5/10

2022 This title, including its two predecessors, is my all-time favorite game. I'm certain that it's a once-in-a-lifetime experience, as I don't think I'll ever be as invested or hyped for a game again.Let me provide a little backstory. Back in 2004-2006, my cousin and I spent all our time and money in a local paint store that sold Warhammer. We would arrive in the morning and stay until our moms would come take us home for dinner. I don't think the store owners liked us much, probably because we were broke kids who spent hours just staring at the box art, imagining epic battles. In 2009-2010, I got my first Total War game, Empire Total War. It didn't take me long to realize that Total War and Warhammer were a perfect match.Around 2013, I saw a blog post on the Total War forum or CA webpage (I can't remember exactly where) that said CA had obtained the rights to make a game for a GW IP. I was beyond excited. Then, in 2015, the first trailer dropped, and since then, I've easily spent over 300 hours listening to lore videos and prediction videos. Every single DLC announcement feels like Christmas to me. I think I've spent more time imagining what will come next for the title than actually playing the game. Without overreacting, I can say that I've thought about this game at least once every day since the first announcement.Another thing I appreciate about this game is the community. It's full of fans who are just as excited as I am, and what's unique about this community is that everyone seems really pro-DLC. People are begging CA to release more DLC and new content more often, which is a rare sight in a lot of gaming communities. But it's for good reason that people praise DLC for this game. I've bought every game and every single DLC without regrets, and I'll continue to support them until it's over. Everything they deliver is worth it in my opinion, and the game is a dream come true for Warhammer Fantasy tabletop players.If you're a fan of Warhammer fantasy and video games, Total War: Warhammer is a must-have. I feel sorry for the 40k community because there is no 40k game that can compete with this. CA, please make Total War Warhammer 40k!

2022 Just like any other Souls game in the series, there is something so lovingly hated about the best and worst parts of this game. Your cookie cutter favorites will never live up to the hype of this title. A mash up of all the desired pieces of gaming history has created a hodgepodge of pure bliss. Love or hate the title, it's a game that has truly become the foundation of "Souls-like" titles. Never has there been such an accessible title in the Souls franchise that many can enjoy to their heart's conten--- YOU DIED --- as I was saying, this game is great. Let's start with the mechanics: thoroughly improved over some of the older classics. Crafting? Got it. Death? Pffft, it wouldn't be a Souls game if your monitor didn't have the words YOU DIED burned into your screen. Ashes of War is something relatively new to the franchise. Customize your favorite weapons to better suit your build. Scale your weapons to fit your attributes, and voila: you have a recipe for pure chaos. They have expanded on some of the earlier concepts, turning this title into the mega-ultra-super --redacted-- version of what a Souls game could have been 15 years ago. It truly hits home in so many aspects that I was engulfed by it's Flamed Frenzy for 200+ hours before I finished the game. In fact, the game is so accessible that people who would generally hate titles like this, or maybe even hated Souls games a decade ago, are now playing this game and realizing, "Hey, this game is HARD AS ♥♥♥♥. But WOW, I killed that boss after 15 tries and it FELT SO GOOD". It's Euphoria to say the least. The open world has really garnished a new set of players that, to be honest, would never play a Souls game. Now that there is an enormous player base, there is more love to share when--- YOU DIED ---- well, I think you get the picture.Masochism, sadism, religion, destruction, it all behests the title of Elden Ring.But honestly, do YOU have the balls to become the Elden--- YOU DIED --- ....um, ya. I think you get it.<3

Space Marine 2 is a long-awaited, much-hoped-for sequel to the first Space Marine game. You play as <REDACTED> (jk it's freaking Titus like that wasn't obvious enough) who starts off using Primaris-styled equipment as a regular first-born marine. Hmm. Can't say that's particularly lore accurate, but whatever, it's Titus so that's cool. Unfortunately he's no Mark Strong this time, can't blame him after everything that happened. Be aware. I tried playing the campaign missions on Angel of Death difficulty. This will color my breakdown below.The 'nids are, as expected, annoying ass space bugs that swarm you faster than skaven do at a Warpstone rave party, and they're fairly dangerous. In fact, each of them individually might not seem like a problem but start throwing in 3 or so hormagaunts and you'll start having more stab wounds than a mugging victim in London. The termagaunts, those little annoying freaking shooty bugs, appear to not wield regular fleshborers, since the damn things flash green like miniature rapid-fire venom cannons. If you don't know what a venom cannon is, I'll explain it further down below in the Warrior section.All of these swarm mechanics overwhelming you through sheer numbers is really pronounced. I started having to take engagements carefully and seriously right from the get-go. You can't regenerate any health from simple executions this time either, you need to have taken damage recently (a la Bloodborne) and this makes Titus not only feel like tissue paper, but unable to recover easily. You need to use the medical stims and those are far and few in between, so they definitely took the 'its too easy' critique about the first game too much to heart. Titus will find these enemies dangerous and annoying in equal measure as a result, so don't go thinking you can charge into the jaws of hell and not get tarpitted harder than Abbadon facing a 50 block of guardsmen backed up by a Commissar Lord. They are just as fearless as said guardsmen and unlike Abbadon, Titus can't ♥♥♥♥ out like 10 attacks in a single round of combat, so you better hope you're good at parrying. Note that while parrying or dodging or attacking, you are more or less animation locked. You can't cancel easily, and this honestly makes you feel a lot more sluggish than Captain Titus, who is now obviously the best version of Titus there was. This means you have to thin their numbers at range, hopefully reducing the 'gaunt variants down to less than 3 by the time the Warrior rushes you down.Let's talk about Warriors. Warriors are the big 'nids that have that annoying ass whip, that annoying ass paired boneswords, that really annoying ass devourer, or that annoying ass venom cannon (that long snout thing).The Whip is not too bad in a 1 on 1, just make sure to either stay clear of it while wiping out the small forms or...dunno, charge in and beat it to death before it can get really annoying. When it does that lash combo attack, it's very hard to parry so you're better off just trying to keep your distance and shooting it down.The twin boneswords is just tanky. That's it.The devourer is basically a rapid-fire fleshborer, and the Warrior who uses it is the most irritating PoS you will ever encounter. It will constantly skate away to the backline to pepper you with clusters of projectiles and it adds up a lot of damage very fast. Snipe this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as soon as possible. If you try to close in melee, it will sometimes unload every shot into you at point-blank range and you can die from this.The last one, the venom cannon wielder, is the sniper variant. A venom cannon is like a biological railgun except instead of shooting a metal projectile it shoots this venomous acidic crystal that is superheated by the electrical discharge (yes, this is how it works in lore) and is launched at high speed to penetrate vehicles...or something. It didn't really work against real vehicles, but it definitely works against MEQ (shorthand for 'marine equivalent') like Titus. You will get a warning in the form of a sickly green laser tracking you and you can dodge the shot quite easily with good timing. The real problem is when one of them shows up and you are fighting a swarm or two and their Warrior melee cousins all at the same time, which is when things get nasty. Even then, its particular attacks are not hard to avoid, so either trust in your mobility or kill them off first, your choice.There's more bug variants and their stupid tactics but I'm tired of talking about bugs so let's talk about weapons.Gunplay and melee aren't mutually exclusive, it retains the general fluidity of the first game and you can swap between the two styles of combat very fast. Pistols are actually useful, they take their own slot and can help offset some disadvantages of your primary, while also serving as a way to perform kill shots on parried enemies.Bolters. Holy Emperor the bolters. There are so many bolter variants, and some of them being very cross purposes with their actual function to the point it makes you wonder who needs this many variants. They are all lifted from the Primaris arsenal, and you get the whole freaking line of them (except Assault Bolters). Bolt carbines, heavy bolt pistols, auto bolt rifles, you name it they have it. In fact, I would argue that there are simply too many bolters. In the first game most of the same roles were replicated by unique weapons, such as the plasma gun, the lascannon, the vengeance launcher, and so on. Now you get...bolters.Some of them are effective and some are not, but all of them are only average on Angel of Death difficulty so I didn't really find them to be that unique. What stood out were the non-bolter weapons, the Plasma Incinerator and the Melta Rifle.The Plasma Incinerator is like a cross between the regular plasma gun and a very small plasma cannon, and it performs well enough in that role. It's plasma and it hurts.The Melta Rifle is basically just like the melta gun from the first game. Tight AOE cone that does more damage the closer to the center of the aiming circle you get, huge shotgun blast that can melt anything.There's some other stuff like the Las Fusil, which is basically just a lascannon if they scaled it down and in-game it's basically a Charge Rifle from Titanfall. It's still a good weapon, but they clearly learned their lesson from the first game where the lascannon's instant shot could utterly destroy an unfortunate enemy's face at close range.Melee weapons unfortunately all feel a little samey. The chainsword is effective but it only swings in tight arcs and relies on a charge attack combo to stun enemies, which is extremely awkward compared to the first game where your stun/charge attack was another key altogether. This means it is very easy to start a chainsword combo then get hit for your trouble because you have no way of interrupting your enemy.The power sword is a little more forgiving as it has actual stances that emphasize AOE or single target combat. It still has the issue of not being able to stagger big creatures reliably, or having a charge attack combo that matters, but it is reliable enough with its large sweeping attacks to actually outperform the chainsword on a regular basis.The thunder hammer took a big hit from last game. It is just as sluggish and slow despite Titus' better augmentations, but is weaker. You can put a lot of hurt on enemies, but you have too many gaps open that leave you unable to defend yourself properly. Compare that to the first game, where the hammer's instant-kill damage and reliable stun combo can AOE wipe out hordes of daemons or whatever. It's very weak in this game.The power fist staggers most enemies. Good enough.So Is game gud? yes. Get. Play. Keel bug.

It's a good game sir. Only real issues I have with it are that Tyranids just can't compete with the Space Marine 1 Orks, and that single player almost feels like an afterthought when you look at all of the multiplayer only stuff like classes, perk systems, better weapon selections, armor customization. There are certain sections while playing the highest difficulty solo in campaign that I felt were definitely designed around having multiple players and the AI just wasn't cutting it so I had to get creative on just surviving. Not a gigantic issue and I'm sure playing the highest difficulty wasn't helping me.Something I do want to mention is that the story is not as interesting as it could have been. Space Marine 1 had an ending that could have a much more interesting followup. Instead a more interesting short story was put in White Dwarf to kind of get Titus to Space Marine 2s starting point, and Boltgun was created to cover the other half of the story stuff they needed to put in place.Otherwise the game is generally an improvement over 1.

2022 My advice at this point is to wait for the immortal empires release to see if this is worth playing.Pros-Relatively fun units, lords and faction mechanics.-The graphics are about what you would expect from a sequelCons-The campaign just fails on so many levels. 1) The actual campaign mechanics don't feel rewarding and are oftentimes more punishing as you progress. Realm of Chaos is just a torturous bore that doesn't really offer any reward and particularly in Tzeentch's realm its a crap shoot of racing the enemy AI and hoping you randomly choose the correct portal path. 2) Random warp portals. This is just monumentally frustrating and with limited armies can often lead to positions of you just hoping you've lucked out in having the appropriate forces in the right position if the AI goes for any kind of jankiness. Expect to waste an army or several dedicated to sitting in your important economic/production territories. This is particularly necessary if the AI decides to build up a few stacks before bumrushing a city.- City battles. The AI does not interact well with cities offense or defense. Units defending points that you aren't attacking or wandering units back and forth at random between points. -The AI in general is just... bad. Easily abuseable at all difficulties on the battle map and there are many times you will have to abuse it because the AI cheat stats at higher difficulties makes trying to play with basic tactics moot. i.e. spears/anti-large infantry don't really do anything to units they supposedly counter. Melee infantry is basically useless in the face of more ranged units. Regular cavalry units are generally not good. So basically the strat tends to wind down to hide the army exposing a single fast moving unit usually a lord and break the AI by luring out a unit at a time to pound into the dust via mass range spam/magic. (khorne has some leeway with the free armies they can spam out for disposable melee but yeah ultimately not a good time)-The campaign AI is just bad with the cheats to compete with the player. Also anti-player bias is hilarious watching the AI ignore 6 full stacks of another AI they are at war with to come barreling down at you the player's out of the way undefended minor settlement while they get utterly ransacked and it doesn't mean anything because the AI isn't playing under any of the constraints that the player has to deal with on the campaign map beyond movement.

I know I going to be on the unpopular side here, but I just want anyone thinking of buying the game to get the chance to see a review that tells it like it is.I have never played a 40k game before, so without any passion or connection to the universe, I only can judge this game off of what it provides to me. This game is... not horrible, but it certainly isn't great either.The campaign is short. Very short by today's standards. Like 6 hours, short. I finished in one sitting after work. Now, this isn't horrible, but it since the campaign is arguably the best part of the game, it being that short doesn't really bode well. Fun combat, great visuals, and an entertaining story... that you'll be done with at the end of the day. Multiplayer is, well, not as great. The operations are interesting at best, monotonous at worst. You essentially get to play through a co-op mission of the campaign as the "B-team" that you would always order to go do stuff. It provides an interesting and new perspective, but is certainly nothing great. The "endless" war multiplayer, I.E the PvP, is fun for about, well, 2 days. Afterwards you realize you only have 3 game modes on 3 maps. It gets repetitive instantly. Now I know what you're gonna say, "oh but there will be updates, and look at the roadmap!". My brother, you are paying $60 at least for a 6 hour campaign and lackluster multiplayer that you will get tired of in two days.

2013 Initially I was very hesitant about this game; it seemed very risky to make so many fundamental changes to a formula that was barely changed through Counter-Strike: Source and Condition Zero. However, seeing how much Valve has listened and continues to listen the community, and how quickly they make changes in both the short and long term, it has completely restored my faith in the game. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is incredibly fun and feature-rich, with plenty to do for both casual and competitive players. On top of this, there is also plenty of ways to promote and support eSports, which is a much-needed and fundamental step in reinvigorating Counter-Strike in the competitive gaming scene. However, the most important thing with this game is that the community is incredibly nice and friendly - and with a game as difficult and intense as Counter-Strike, it's extremely welcoming. Good stuff!

2022 Sieges and battles: Sieges are full of choke points, little open space. Any units can scale the walls, they aren't equippable and the units don’t have to drag the ladders to the walls. Battles more generally are more simple than other Total War titles. Feels like they took some of the challenge out of the game, in order to make it appeal to a wider audience. Graphics: This is the best aspect in my opinion, the game looks gorgeous. Map(s): With the immortal empires patch you get the entire world, which is great.Lore: I feel the game could tell the story a bit more, in Three Kingdoms, there are cut-scenes when you reach certain goals, you get an idea and feel for the events around you. Heroes: Sometimes the heroes can get a bit jarring. I wish there where a “records mode” type of option, not because I don´t like heroes, rather because it would bee more challenging in certain situations to have a generals retinue. The Daemon Prince for example is kinda weak and tends to be useless. Balthasar Gelt can almost alone defeat armies with his magic artillery spells. Another solution would be to rebalanced the heroes.Unit size: I also find the unit sizes of the different units quite small, this is important since this game is supposed to be an fantasy epic, but with tiny battles. Well, what about fixing this with mods? You can, there are mods in the workshop that increase the unit size, however, the AI tends to get stuck at the gate and exhibit odd and often devastating (for them) behavior. While, in three kingdoms I use similar mods and have massive battles with a full stack army almost reaching 10,000 warriors. The AI in Three Kingdoms doesn’t exhibit the same issues.AI: I personally find the AI a bit lackluster compared to other titles, though not as catastrophic as Thrones of Britannia. It’s not bad, just not cutting it for an experienced player like me. I also tend to be against increasing the difficulty to legendary, due to the AI getting modifier boosts, thus I prefer to use a AI mod that makes the AI smarter instead. Found that Hecleas AI Mod works well. Diplomacy: I find that the diplomatic options to interact with other factions are a bit limited. Currently you can sway someone with giving them money, but you can’t for example trade ancillaries like in Three Kingdoms. Sometimes I might be just short of getting that trade agreement, but not enough money to to finish the deal, while sitting on a pile of old/useless ancillaries that I could do away with.Linux: Works great, I personally have used it with Proton and played with my friends.SummaryHmm, it’s a good total war game in my view, but not a great one. The game looks just gorgeous and is pure eye-candy, the fantasy setting is also interesting. If you really love fantasy, stuff like Lord of the Rings etc. then you might find the full price justified, but if Fantasy is cool, but not your absolute favorite thing then, I would personally recommend waiting for a -50% sale and then get it.

2023 I was in a Tomb Kings Mortal Empires campaign on WHII when I bought Warhammer III, I started the same campaign to compare. The difference was instantly noticeable, especially in terms of the diplomacy system. The improvements are so significant that going back to WHII felt like a step backward. The diplomacy in WHIII actually makes sense now!Outposts makes complete sense in the context of the game, whether you're building them yourself or getting them from allies. It adds an extra layer to the strategy and alliances.The Quality of Life improvements are also great. Things like auto-building and an easier level-up system have made the gameplay smoother. However, there's still no auto level-up feature, which is a shame. But hey, Middenheim wasn't built in a day, right?The game world is also significantly larger this time around, which is a massive plus. There's so much more to explore and conquer, adding to the depth and longevity of the game.That being said, the campaign map leaves much to be desired in terms of performance. It's not as big of a deal as some people make it out to be, but it's certainly not a highlight of the game. While the map struggles to maintain 40-50 FPS, the battles are a different story altogether. The battles run at a crisp 60+ FPS, making each clash a visually stunning spectacle.So far I had one crash during my battle, one that stopped happening once I disabled 'Control by AI' for my alliance army.In the grand scheme of things, Warhammer III is a huge step forward for the franchise. Despite its flaws, it's a game that I wholeheartedly recommend and I would now finally recommend as the only game to get for a newbie out of the 3 in the series. I'd wait for a discount, since the price is steep, but it does offer a ton of content. Looking forward to the future updates and improvements!EDIT: turns out there is auto-level up feature in the top left corner of each character!

2022 The game has teething issues for sure, but any game of this size is going to. The first patch smoothed a lot of the corners and the roadmap demonstrated that they're in this for the long haul of improvements and content drops as things go on. In terms of its improvements over TWW1 and 2, the game has mostly shown improvement, a few things have stayed more or less the same, and there's been a couple of declines, so overall good. The map design is improved, the campaign map is one of the largest and most interesting in the series, the unit variance is nice, there are very distinct factions and races, diplomacy is better, battles are better, magic is better, and there's generally more content in here at launch than either of the two predecessor games. The main campaign is iffy in terms of its goals and how you get there, but ultimately plays out fine. It has a lot of potential to be better but hard to say how far out they'll develop the ideas. The RoC has a lot better potential than (and to me is more enjoyable than) the Vortex campaign of game 2. If the RoC Campaign doesn't get hugely expanded it's still mostly fine, just isn't sure how to get its ideas together. The combined map will ultimately be good, so like game 2 I'll be able to go between them to keep it fresh. One of the best improvements this game has is in the Co-op campaign aspects. FINALLY we can do 3+ player campaigns and it is glorious fun. Co-op campaigns have been vastly improved, the way turns work and alliances etc. is far more nuanced and interesting than it was. Playing co-op often improves an average campaign, but the Realms of Chaos main campaign almost feels like it was designed with co-op in mind, as it makes the race for souls more interesting and factions can work to cover each other as others do the race. The race itself is usually over within 150 turns, and from there you have a giant map to conquer so it's not a big deal really and we've been having a lot of fun with it. I've seen people disappointed over how long it's going to take for the combined map between the games to come out but anyone with a basic grasp of reality can see that this is a monumental sized project so of course it's going to take time for things to happen. That's kinda just physics at play really, but as with the other two games things will come out as they do and the game will only get better. WH2 at the end of its cycle was an amazing game and WH3 will likely be no different. Overall, I recommend the game and I'm looking forward to what's coming later this year.

2022 FIrst of all: i still play this game casually from time to time, it's good but still, the release was a total mess and now that IE (Beta) dropped out a few days ago, there's a bit more content and there is still so much potential.If you play co-op campaign with more than one other friend, very often from round 30-35 there will be a desync error and this can break the entire campaign for you and your friends. No previous save file or restart of the game will help you. It's like there's that one specific timer triggering the desync error and you can't play beyond that point. This happens in RoC and IE. In other words, you have to restart but as long as 3 people play this campaign, this will happen almost every time. If you play with just one more friend it's ok and the error won't occur.Gameplay is sometimes very tedious. Factionwide, all Units suffer some sort of Alzheimers and they will forget orders in a battle. Sometimes they stop midway, sometimes the won't even react in the first place. In this case, you will have to molest your mouse with rapid clicks and start frantically checking the whole map for your units if all of the commands reached their brain or got lost in their track and start sending out commands again. Rince and repeat... until you develope some sort of paranoia. Damn those foul chaos gods of bad programming.They changed the minor settlement fights so every battle will be a siege (with walls to climb, gates to destroy an points to take) and it's just time consuming. Auto-resolve is still a joke even when you have a good and experienced army, so enjoy fight from now on manually. Imagine playing past round 100 and still expanding your faction. Of all Battles, 80% will be at settlements and therefor a siege battle. Optimization of this game could be better. There were some tweaks but with the release of IE, frame drops and long loading screens are more common again.The current price tag is too damn high for a game that is still in Beta and probably will be for the next 1-2 years, so I don't recommend it in it's current state. If you're about to get your first total war: warhammer, don't let it be this one. There are still two others to chose from._______________________________________________________________________Update after the "Shadows of Change" Update:it still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sucks. CA ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up and there is nothing they can do to fix it or redeem themselves. They ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up. DLC pricing is them spitting in your face after the horrendous launch because "inflation". DON'T BUY. This game has nothing to do with pleasing it's fans, it's only about the money and nothing else. The only good thing that came out of this piece of ♥♥♥♥ is the community that's fed up with this game and review bombing it back to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that ♥♥♥♥ this game out.

2022 Okay, I think it's okay to say now. Having gotten through those first two patches, (1.1 & 1.2) the game is now safe to recommend. Initially, I think CA had botched it. The patches that addressed the build to reduce portals (1.1) and the auto-resolve (1.2) have saved this game. It is now in a place where I can more enjoy the mechanics and tempo of the game.Yes, once the big map that joins the three games AND all the races together will be what we've all been waiting for. But for now, getting familiar with the new and very different races and race mechanics, the minor settlement rework, the constant threat of the portal race that means you can still lose even when steamrolling. Yeah, this is a good game and I'm enjoying it.Would I have said that a month or so ago? Well, let's just say there's a reason I've waited before submitting a review.Long live the DLC team that are the real geniuses that breath life and longevity to this epic game

2022 Reason for PurchaseI love the entire Souls Like series. I started with Bloodborne earlier and then moved on to Dark Souls. After that I played Demon Souls which I thought was fantastic. And then I heard that ''From Software'' is releasing a new part which should even have an open world. At first I was a bit skeptical because I didn't know how ''From Software'' would deal with this new idea but I could say... They exceeded all my expectations.GraphicThe graphics are truly stunning. Everything is designed in such detail. Both the world (which I still haven't fully explored) as well as the NPS's, enemies, bosses and much more. What I want to say is that I can't see the graph difference between Low and Maximum. From that point of view, I mainly play on Low so that everything runs smoothly.Game MechanicsI haven't played a Souls Like part on PC before. However, I have to say that it was implemented very well. And besides, I love this game more than any other Souls Like parts and for a reason. There is a separate jump button! In the other parts it was or is quite annoying and sometimes hectic when you have to press several buttons at the same time.Positive and negativeFrom my point of view, there is nothing negative anymore. Previously, for me, the negative was that it came to such frequent game crashes. Now there is nothing negative for me anymore. The price of Elden Ring does justice to the game in everything. So ''From Software'' has really surpassed itself.FutureI'm going to play Elden Ring for a very long time, as I haven't fully explored the Big World yet. My goal will be to reach the maximum ''99'' for all stats. I also hope that there will be DLC expansions at some point. In addition, I would like to see a few more achievements because I now have them all.Game RatingGraphic: 10☆ <3Game Mechanics: 9☆Spielspaß: 10☆Recommendation of the gameElden Ring is in my opinion a good game to get in because you can get a lot of support from the incantations of ghosts. If you add another player, the boss gets even more life than usual, which is why I would prefer the ghosts. So anyone looking for a ''Heavy Game'' with stunning graphics is absolutely in the right place with this game.

1440p, RTX 3080 user here.The game is awesome, and it runs very well if tweaked correctly - below are my suggestions.First of all, download DLSS Swapper, as the game is using an older DLSS version you can improve on it by swapping to the latest version (3.7.2).About the graphic settings, these are the 2 most demanding ones:Shadows > going from VERY HIGH to HIGH I was able to gain 8-10 fps on averageGlobal Illumination > same as shadows, going from VERY HIGH to HIGH I was able to gain 10 fps on averageSo with only these two settings I went from 55 to 75 fps.All the other settings give minor fps returns.My suggested settings for people with an rtx 3080 / 3070ti are:- DLSS at 80%- Textures on Cinematic- Shadow on High- Global Illumination on High- Everything else on very high (you can crank up Hair Quality and Vegetation Quality to Cinematic with just a 2-3 fps loss)The only downside for me at the moment is the lack of a FOV slider.I'm very sensitive to narrow FOV but so far I was able to play without getting sick, will update this review if things change.

2018 How to learn when a game dead, five easy signs-1. It becomes Free to Play2. The people who owned it before it became Free to Play basically get nothing for it3. Battle Royale4. Hackers and Smurfs galore (p.s you thought it was bad when the game was 15 dollars, now guess what...?)5. BATTLE. ROYALE.

What we have here is a weird mixture of various other games with some unique ideas thrown in. The problem is that it all feels really just slapped together. Your character isn't overly responsive and feels like he weighs 8 tons while you're moving around. The general combat is okay though, its nothing amazing but its a very solid foundation that they can build on.The building is terrible, its just bad. The basics are all there but the building itself is uncomfortable and very very finicky. They at least have a free move building camera and that does help but the snapping is troublesome and not intuitive. Having to get the exact right angle on something like a roof panel is cumbersome and it took me about three times as long to just get a roof over my head than it should have.There is a decent variety of things to build and you've got pretty free range to build as you see fit. However the build radius itself, at least where I was at in the progression was very small so I felt very limited. Placing things works well enough, easy enough to rotate things around and there is a decent tech tree to work through.Resource gathering is more or less painless and its what you would expect. Hack at trees to get wood, go find copper or whatever else to mine. Nothing felt like it took too long to amass if you just spend a few minutes doing it. I do like the crafting queue feature at each of the crafting stations, frees you up to go do whatever while you wait for it to do its thing and nothing took all that long to complete.The skills system itself... is a bit confusing. There is this whole what I am guessing is like a pokemon type of system. You can obtain new little critters or deviants I guess they call them to put in your backpack and each has its own skills to use. I only found 2 during my time, the butterfly and a little jelly guy. The butterfly was just some extra dps that would do it when you toss it at something, the jelly guy could turn into cover or act as defense. I honestly forgot I had them most of the time. I got to around level 12 and only fought one thing that put up any sort of resistance. The first rift boss, big thing with some basic mechanics that I was able to match make into..It wasn't hard or anything, had some bare minimum mechanics and it fell overEvery other enemy I came across wasn't a threat.. like at all. The general zombie like guys you see everywhere all are dead before they even know you're there. Couple of weird big cat things with a tarp over their head? They also die easily all you need to do is back pedal while you fight them and they can't hit you. the AI is on a level of PS2 games. Although i genuinely think some PS2 games had better enemy AI than this gameCouple of other larger creatures, couldn't even tell you what they do because they all just fell over dead with nothing but the basic pistol you get shortly after the tutorial. Most enemies seem to have 2 or 3 different attacks that they just spam at random and very slow.What bothered me the most was that you could just see everyone's structures.. everywhere.. you can't go anywhere without seeing someone's little base or forward respawn point. Its just urban sprawl on an active server.. stuff built everywhere and it just was goofy to see. I mean I get it, its going to happen in a game where you can build if its a public server but this was just obscene. Anyone who had played something like old school starwars galaxies know what Im talking about.. houses.. houses as far as the eye can see concentrated around the major areas. It just.. feel bad and sorta takes me out of the whole thing. There is no point in finding a cool place to build or even a unique base design because there is just stuff everywhere and everyone's place looks more or less the same. Im sure that gets better in the later areas but its just a pretty big turn off for me.Graphically, its pretty good. No real complaints. Game looks and ran great. Its not the best visually but in the genre its in, its a good contender for good visuals. No real visual glitches or anything weird happening. Very solid on that front.I might give it another go later, but I think I saw everything I needed to see. It just didn't grab me, For a free game? Seems okay, but there is just too much competition out there that do what they're trying to do but better. Since its free, id say pick it up if your curious, but don't expect something that is just gonna draw you in and make you want to keep going. I lost stream really quickly on it and its a real shame, had alot of potential but alas. Not for me.

This game has overshadowed all my expectations of a strategy game.It is expensive yes! If you want all the dlcs. But would also say it's worth it more or less. I never got to play warhammer 1-2 because of bad pc, but now I'm even more excited to skip the other 2 parts and see everything in immortal empires.What i like ++ Graphics (i play on ultra), it's amazing how detailed a strategy game can be these days+ Choice of units is so big that i already forget which unit it was xD+ The diplomatic system has everything you need, it's not as complex as a crusader king, but it shouldn't and doesn't need to be because the game is focused on the battles.+ I find the build upgrade system complex, just like the skill system of the heroes.+ It runs so smoothly and i haven't had 1 bug so far.+ Game gets supported by devs, and watch community feedback rarely nowdays.What i not like so much -(but that is complaining on a high level)- Dlc price is a bit to high 25 euro why not make it 20 :)- Story i mean it give a story mode and much lore, but its not so cool like the amazing trailers total war makes. I would love it if they make in future a campain with such effort of cutscenes.My wishes for future alot more dlcs! or Warhammer IV for Immortal Empires II

2022 Overall its a fine Total war game, but is not as good as Warhammer 2 on its own. The reason to get it is to play Immortal Empires which requires you to own all 3 warhammer games.Edit: You can now play Immortal empires just owning this game, which is a pretty good deal.

The game itself is also super fun. The PvP and the campaign are a joy to play. Your actions feel deliberate, almost as if you're controlling an Angel in a 1 Ton metal suit. I love it.-------------------------------It's sad that I have to say this, but it's wonderfully refreshing to be able to boot up a game, play for an hour or two, and close it again. Rather than boot it up, do my dailies, check my weeklies, check my season pass etc.You boot the game up, and you play it. It doesn't try to open your wallet at any point.While this should not be something to be praised in the year 2024, it is refreshing to see.

2023 Orginal review:The game has enormous potential and lets you play a lot of completely different factions with unique playstyles, but unfortunately there are simply too many issues for me to be able to recommend it. It launched in a pretty sorry state and hasn't really gotten better since then. There are a lot of bugs, some of them still present since launch. The AI poses no challenge whatsoever, since it wastes a lot of time running around just outside of your attack range and it loves to sack or raze your weakest settlements, rather than going after cities that actually matter. Units in battle tend to circle each other forever instead of attacking, the list goes on. And while the game is in dire need of improvements and bugfixes, all it's getting right now is absurdly overpriced DLC, alongside a lackluster free patch that seems to break at least as many things as it fixes.Update:While the AI issues persist (though the game did get harder thanks to the AI getting huge bonuses in lieu of being actually taught how to play), the game has begun getting regular free fixes and new features, to the point where I'm comfortable saying that it's a great experience, and chances are it's going to get even better.
