Listen, I might get flak for this, but this isn't a $60 title. The campaign is 6 missions, the post campaign PvE is 6 missions. You could knock this out in a couple days, maybe an afternoon if you're really good or have friends, and if you don't much care for PvP (which has 3 maps and 3 modes in total) that is all of the content you have aside from what they're going to dripfeed over several seasons, and I just don't really consider that acceptable for the price point, unless you REALLY like the combat system, which I personally am not particularly in love with. This could've been like $40 and I'd have less issue with the barebones amount of content here. I'm not saying it couldn't improve over the seasons, but if you want to buy it at the time of writing, I think you'd be at risk for being disappointed like myself.

2018 I was very young when I first got to know Counter-Strike back in the early days of Counter-Strike 1.5.It was in an Internet-Café during Holidays where I even got to play the game for the first time. Some years later some friends from the area were playing CS 1.6 and thats where I joined the Steam and Counterstrike-Community on January 8th, 2006. We formed a team, trained about two years and climbed up the ladder of our local CS-League here in Switzerland.However, due to insufficient capacity (private life) of some members and a lack of Morale we split up.I've seen Counter-Strike in all of its states from 1.5 on, 1.6, Condition Zero, Source, I even had my hands on the old mod called "CS Promod" where people tried to get the gameplay from 1.6 with the graphics of Source. Which was something I really liked.After a long break I decided to reroll in CS:GO and check out how the game had evolved. It took a while but the more I played and did matchmakings (good mm's ^^) the more I wanted to set foot in E-Sports again. CS:GO is the perfect balance between the gameplay of 1.6 and the graphics of source (while its not source, definitely and luckily not.), to most efficient CS players ive talked to graphics dont matter and it explains why many Pro's do play with low resolutions and stuff like that because it reminds them of the good ol' days (from what i've read).Though it still has its harsh and sometimes frustrating learning-curve, it is worth the effort because if you truly stick to it and learn about it each time you play and try to learn from your mistakes the better you get. Since all those years i've tried out almost all other game titles in the FPS genre, nothing could ever stand up against the simplicity and competitiveness of Counter-Strike for me. If you're looking for a great team-experience (which you first need to create or join) in where every man counts, every round counts and has a big community involved with tournaments and stuff, this game is for you.However if you're looking for a realistic shooter that compares guns 1:1 like in real life, with bulletdrop and things like that, this game is definitely not for you.I hope my shared thoughts on the game where helpful and gave you a bit of insight whether you want to join our community. Best RegardsKnight

2022 I have not played since launch day, (other than 5 mins to check if it ran better with a new GPU, it did. Still significantly worse performance than WH2) and will not play again at least until Immortal Empires, and maybe not then. The fact that the lukewarm reception to the Vortex campaign should have been an indication to seek to emulate the mortal empires experience, not double down on the vortex type mechanics.Any game that requires mods to have a good gameplay experience does not deserve a positive review. I appreciate that the modding community has been so quick to make so many good changes, but does not change the fact the modding community should be for creativity, rather than fixing blatant issues in the game itself.Somewhat ironically, the tutorial campaign was one of the best tutorials I've ever seen in a game. I didn't need it to teach me, but I play ever TW tutorial anyway, and this was definitely the best one. But, the tutorial campaign is a one-off thing, and does not compensate for the lacking of the main campaign.For newcomers to Total warhammer, WH3 is likely completely fine. But for those who played many, many hours of WH2, it falls flat, well short of what it should've been. Based an what we've seen so far, the game should've been kept in development for at least another year. A poor showing.

9 / 10 For me, this is one of the best games in history! This game is proof that a project doesn't need battle passes, paid cosmetics, or in-game shops to be successful. This is probably one of the most passionate games released in the past decade; the creativity and attention to detail are absolutely insane.Starting with one of the top selling points: the graphics. The graphics are absolutely absurd; Unreal Engine 5 is the best-looking engine on the market as of 2024, and this game makes very good use of it. Yes, using UE5 means that the game sometimes has some high optimization problems, although they're minor compared to other UE5 titles released recently.The combat and enemy variety in this game are simply absurd. Elden Ring is an amazing game, and even a game of that caliber still struggles to keep up with this game variety-wise. Every single enemy in this game is unique and original, with highly detailed models and movesets; there's only a very small amount of reused assets among the enemies and bosses. Some of the boss fights are creative enough to make your jaw drop. The game has a lot of different skills and movesets, transformations, and items to make the combat feel unique in each encounter. Although I gotta admit that I wish it had more spells.The biggest problem with this game compared to other action games is definitely the limitations on exploration of the map. This game has an absurd amount of invisible walls and limitations on the terrain blocking exploration, sometimes even on clear paths that look like they'd be explorable otherwise. And this is the reason i'm not giving this game a 10/10.The soundtrack fits very well with the theme of the game; the OSTs are magical and epic. Each chapter has an animation at the end with different art styles and music, with different stories and meanings. For a person who is not used to the main theme portrayed in this game, it's a magical experience for sure...I would definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in Chinese folklore and mythology. The story is amazing; I was totally unfamiliar with anything related to this theme, and after playing it, I gotta say I really want to know more about the general theme and meaning behind these stories.I genuinely believe this game will be remembered throughout the years as one of the most passionate and successful projects in gaming history.

2022 Elden Ring, O Elden Ring. You already know why it's so good, but like Dark Souls, the game is a sad tale of two halves. The first half is absolutely brilliant; an open world experience that encourages a lot of exploration. It really took me back to the good old days of playing video games with a sense of wonder and curiosity. The second half of the game however, is really all the bad things about the new Souls games. Unbalanced and unfun, just stacking "le epic" boss after boss and making them difficult for the sake of difficult. Gone are the memorable bosses of True King Allant and Gwyn, but now replaced with bosses who have to be a "spectacle" and "action-orientated" for the sake of the fanbase. Still a great game though and way better than any of the drivel of open world games out there.-- Score: [9/10] --

2022 Alright so first of all this, despite all the backlash, isn't an awful game. I'd much rather play release tww 3 than the original, that being said it's not a good game either. CA has pulled the classic 2020s razzle dazzle of releasing a game unfinished and patching it until the backlash stops. With every update until now the game has improved overall even if the bugs kept multiplying. Without a doubt the biggest improvement (at least for me) so far has been the implementation of the mod support which allowed the community to fill negative space in the design and improve the balancing overall. This may change soon though as the immortals empire patch looms over the horizon. Now would I recommend people to buy this game before IE drops? No. That doesn't mean it's not worth playing cause I do like playing it and the implementation of IE will bring such a breadth of content to the game that I have no doubts that it will shake up the reviews however I am both excited and scared of how this will turn out because while I have no doubts IE will have me playing hundreds more hours regardless of quality I can't as of yet make comment on how well implemented it will be and how much love will be shown to it (and future releases). I strongly believe that once this game has gotten the DLC support of TWW2 it will be a good game, perhaps even a great one however I shall leave this review on negative because let's be honest here. This game needed another year of dev time and should have released with more content (tho not necessarily IE) and way more polish.

I am only on chapter 3 but I already feel like I can recommend this game.Forget the vague "souls-like" definition, this is an action game that's almost a boss rush with some cool exploration and some regular enemy encounters between each boss. I honestly love the idea of fighting so many 1vs1 fights, against beautifully designed enemies that are different from each other (so far I only found 1 reskinned boss out of 20ish).The combat system is solid, the game doesn't have many combos (which I don't mind) and it requires you to use dodges and skills with the right timing, while you focus on building your own meter for stronger heavy attacks that will also help you to stagger the enemies. Imo it's simple but effective, and you will find a lot of satisfaction in chain-staggering stronger foes with a series of heavy attacks and skills.One thing I have to complain though is navigating the world: the game has no map and a lot of areas that, while visually stunning, don't look too different from each other when you have to remember where something, like a locked door you left behind, was. The enormous amount of invisible walls also makes it hard to tell where you can and cannot go.And since the game has tons of secrets (some of which are very hard to find without a guide), all of this makes finding them even harder and somewhat frustrating.

2014 Basic GameplayYou play as either a Counter-Terrorist or a Terrorist, both of which are deployed into a battlefield and each round are giving a small allowance to purchase weapons of their choice.You can make extra money by winning rounds or you could also hold a knife up to the enemy demanding their money, Although that would be risky since the enemy would likely just to shoot you.On the Terrorist team your goal is to plant and explosive near some uhhm.. important boxes?.Anyway, once plant wait You patiently for it to explode.As a Counter-terrorist you must eliminate all the Terrorist forces OR defuse the bomb, thus Protecting those ever important boxes from certain destruction.Being a honourable opponent, Terrorists are sure to set the bomb timer just long enough to give the Ct's the chance to Slaughter the remaining T's, and defuse the bomb.I'll list some positive/negative attributes of this game here.Positive attributes :- Matchmaking - Teaches children the harsh reality of gambling (although some never seem to learn even after $500 later)- Ranks - Cool looking skins- Fast growing population of players - Fat stacks of loot dropped somewhat often- Chickens- High replay value- Deathmatch game type (I could go into more detail on negative parts of it, but that would make this review too long and boring)Negative attributes :Although I Do love the single player campaign, it could use some work. I REALLY wish it were longer.. And that final Boss fight is pretty lame. It only lasts around 27 seconds, and during that time the only way to lose is by taking offense from the old man that constantly insults you, and how his "7 year old could beat you, blindfolded."- The game mode "Infernal" played on the map "de_inferno"Some people like this game mode however I personally dislike it, For those of you that have not yet had the chance to experience it I'll explain for you.It seems like any normal de_ map However, The real goal is to scurry around finding any shred or scrap of rego, Normally it's hidden in obscurer unused sections of the map, and has the ability to shift/move around to different locations, Or even leave the game entirely for up to 10 minutes at a time.- Demolition, Also known as "jokemode" Added purely as a joke that volvo was supposed to only unlock on every April fool's day, However some hacker probably that "4_chan" guy, permanently unlocked it. (Volvo have been working on a fix ever since)Demolition is the game mode which automatically gives everyone amour and then requires you to get kills with weapons that do extremely poor damage against armoured opponents. Also no block is Enabled And Whoa?, So is team killing!The volka StrategyYou could just play this game like a noob and spend hundreds of dollars on skins, OR you could play the game correctly like me. Here is my strategy :- Don't buy skins to start with, Seriously it's a waste of money.- Play for a good 50 hrs or so and sell any drop you get.- Wait for a steam sale and Invest in as many copies of csgo you can.- Work your way up to about 5 copies or so But make sure you don't get too many otherwise you won't have enough time to harvest all your csgo account drops (having more than 7 accounts may have diminishing returns) [Note- it takes about 20 hrs gameplay to activate the drops].- Keep playing on all copies frequently to maximise drops.- Once you have your economy built up with this method you can now buy skins with all that free income you have. Remember to Never gamble with opening cases. I've made about $100 with this method. I think it's about time to quit my day job.In a whole, I do love this game And would recommend to anyone, Good half, Good half.

2023 I want to recommend this game. I do - I enjoyed WH2 a lot and have some fun moments in WH3. But there are just stupid problems in this game considering it is a direct successor to WH2, and design choices that are just not good.There are still bugs in the game well over a year after release. Ranged units have a hard time firing at targets correctly. Armies can get stuck on agents and be frozen indefinitely. Random crashes can happen in battle maps. Several unit descriptions just don't even match what they actually do/are functionally.The AI are brain dead during sieges. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I think the main settlement sieges are the worst in ANY total war game since Empire. The defender is actually WORSE off than the attacker with the new capture point system. Defenses don't work all that well. Walls are still worthless. The AI can't defend their settlements for ♥♥♥♥. It is such an epic fail and makes sieges just a pain on both ends. I hate them.Several of the older races (Empire, Dwarves, Dark Elves especially) just feel bland now in immortal empires. The Empires mechanics are terrible. Cathay isn't a finished race. Bretonnia needs attention. Realms of Chaos is a bad campaign, pure and simple. It just isn't all that good. Id welcome arguments to the contrary, but it wasn't well executed for the original characters on release and was insulting that they released WH3 with the game being UNFINISHED. Immortal Empires wasn't out yet. And Cathay wasn't finished and still doesn't feel finished. The new chaos dwarves feel much more fleshed out than they do.CA is half assing a lot of their content. It is infuriating to see. They are capable of doing a much better job, and I cannot recommend any product from them in good faith while they keep putting out games, DLCs and other updates that just aren't up to snuff. Unfinished, unpolished, untested. And they expect us to accept it for what it is, test it for them and wait for months to have proper changes. By which point we've "moved on" to the next paid title they've released where they can take in more money.

Yes No Funny Award504 people found this review helpful4416 people found this review funny 2 7 8Hobo Joe109 products in account1 reviewRecommended35.9 hrs on record (25.9 hrs at review time)POSTED: 18 FEBRUARYAs of now, Total War: Warhammer III does not exactly stand on it's own compared to Total War: Warhammer II due to a lack of content owing to its current infancy and lack of expansive addons and updates seen in Warhammer II. This likely would not be the case if it shipped with Mortal Empires on day one, and did not elect to release without add the very least a skin-and-bones placeholder version of the Chaos Dwarves, instead using Orks as a placeholder.The game itself runs somewhat poorly, it is not well optimized, however this can be mitigated by running at a decreased resolution and lowered textures. This, however, is entirely temporary, and shouldn't factor into your interest, but only your interest *immediately*. Unless you're a huge fan of Kislev, Cathay, Chaos, or the Ogre Kingdoms, I would highly suggest DELAYING your purchase until the future when there is more content to be had, as your time will likely be better spent in Warhammer II where you will still have access to the content from Warhammer I and II.That being said, Chaos is an extremely well designed faction from a gameplay standpoint and has some unique mechanics that stand out from anything else Creative Assembly has ever made. Having tried out the first several turns of most factions by now, I can safely, but unfortunately say that the Legion of Chaos is by far my favorite, which is unfortunate to me because I was mostly looking forward to the Ogre Kingdoms.As for the Campaign, it is about as sandboxy as Vortex was, but with a new mechanic involving the invasion of each realm of Chaos to slay a Daemon Prince, as opposed to completing rituals as in Warhammer II. I personally enjoy it.Lastly, the minor settlements and siege battles. I am not as adverse to the change as other people are. While the supply system is bizarre at best, I'm not convinced that it is entirely detrimental to gameplay, after playing a few rounds, however, I would appreciate a setting to be able to disable this mechanic and return to the old design. I do enjoy the designs of the maps, though, and I really like the new survival mode for custom battles.At it's current state I would suggest waiting for further updates unless you're a die-hard fan of Total War Fantasy or any of the Races in Warhammer III, barring of course Chaos Dwarves.I run an old AM3 CPU, 8gb of DDR3 RAM, and a GTX 1050ti, which is an extremely obsolete setup for this game. However, after twiddling with the settings, Im able to run the game at about 57fps, which is tolerable to me. It is possible for me to gain almost 100fps at very low settings, but the blurriness strains my eyes.I'd give it about a 7/10 right now. You might enjoy it, conditionally, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.READ MORE Was this review helpful? 2017 Product received for free After playing the game for roughly 500 hours, I have come to a point that I should express my opinion about the game's current state.Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a highly competitive game that focuses on team wo--. Really? You REALLY think im going to describe this game as the perfect cut gem of an E-Sports title?.... well, you came to the wrong review comrade!In essence, CS:GO in its current state has some things you really wouldn't want in a game of this type:-Cheaters/VAC:Most of them obviously have been cheating for a long time, but what does valve care? The only thing useful they do is milk their games for money until they are bone dry and deserted. I just can't get over that fact that valve hasn't actually "noticed" that their anti-cheat has flaws, but instead they keep releasing more useless items than bug fixing updates for the game itself.-Griefers:They are not really common nowadays, but back in the day every 5/10 - 6/10 competitive matches i went would have atleast 1 griefer that didn't do anything but insult,generally discriminate or just flat-out do absolutely nothing to help the team win a single round. These individuals are most commonly found on the lower ranks, from my experience.-SMURFS:I have seen more smurfs in cs:go matchmaking than in the actual cartoon itself.Basically this ruins the game for new players by giving them the appearance that CS:GO just isn't worth playing if you don't know how.-THE SALTENING BEGINS:Do you want to experience more highly concentrated amounts of salt in one match than in a salt mine, followed by a community of 12 year olds more cancerous than the radiation levels at Chernobyl? Well my friend, CS:GO is the game for you! (Warranty for broken mice, keyboards, screens, headsets, desks, windows, and possibly hands from hitting your desk too hard not included.)-Servers:When I mean servers I don't intend to talk about the ping/lag, but instead about how most of the time I get matched against/with people from the other side of the damn galaxy. (This is good if you want to learn how everyone has had sexual intercourse with your family members/pets in diverse languages, while you simultaneously proceed to lose the match.)TL;DR:CS:GO is a game that gives everybody a different experience (Unless you are playing in russia, then it's always B rushed every round). Cringy jokes aside, I think this game is somewhat addicting and pleasant in the long run, despite the initial steep learning curve. If valve ever decides to ACTUALLY update their anti-cheat system I will be more than happy to play this game more often.Cheers,James.

2022 Elden Ring is, without a doubt, one of the best open-world games ever released, and among the gaming "Hall of Fame" of the past decade - among the likes of Skyrim, Witcher 3, Red Dead Redemption 2, God of War, and Breath of the Wild.The best features, among many, have to be its unique and refined artistic style and direction, detailed world and lore, mysterious yet alluring characters, incredible bosses and visual effects, and the wide array of weapons and magic at your disposal.The biggest area to nitpick is the graphical fidelity, which, for this time, is outdated. However, as mentioned before, it has an unparalleled artistic design, with a look and feel that more than makes up for its shortcomings in texture quality. The way the color palettes blend and contrast with the beautiful lighting, along with the sheer grandiosity of The Lands Between, culminate into a remarkable masterpiece.The difficulty is punishing. Let me be clear - I am not a fan of such types of games. But as an RPG and open-world lover, with a penchant for medieval fantasy settings and huge swords, Elden Ring hits every other spot for me. A tremendous title for the ages.

F2P game. Ingame Shop that only provides cosmetics. No P2W at all! All these critics regarding the EULA are completely irrelevant and shouldnt be regarded! These conditions are completely normal!Started Phase 2 today. So far the game is quite fun! The game loop seems like this: Discover a new area, complete 1-2 quests, use a certain amount of some stations in cities scattered around the area. In the end you defeat a boss and go to the next area. In the meantime you farm resources and build your base, craft weapons/ armor and slay!Difficulty: So far its not really difficult at all. Difficulty increases by region. To be as strong as before youll have to craft new armor/ weapon. Nothing new here.Cons: It kinda feels like a mobile port. But its not thaaaaaat bad .... Result: A fun game thats actually kinda addicting. Its a kind of a Valheim\Rust survival game but combined with raids and bosses that you know from MMORPGsedit: After a while some more input:I do still recommend the game BUT it has issues! For example- You get warnings, when you click your mouse too fast. So using the furnaces and getting all your stuff out may be more problematic than you might think. - Water Pumps behave VERY weird. - There isnt that much content if you think about it. Every region has like 10 quests in total and maybe 6-8 "cities" (towns with 10-40 buildings) to discover. So by now i more or less have done everything for Phase 2 of the Season. And that phase started yesterday! Phase 3 starts next week! - Yes you are gated by phases that disable lots of content to keep you playing for the whole season!- There are bugs! (I was running below the world yesterday, i fell troguh the floor and ran across the void for example) (stopping a craft destroys all already completed materials in my opinion a bug, destroying the crafting building also destroys all materials that were still inside as well)- There are lag issues!- Also even tho its a game with mining, farming and so on in it. There isnt that much you can craft actually. Most things are just improved version of others.- The "grind" isnt really grindy ...- Wipes every 6 weeks (wipes are good for these kind of games but 6 weeks may be a bit short for a lot of people)- Most bosses are (so far) simply bullet sponges and easily killed solo. There are exceptions but just because you wont be able to move if you would carry all the ammo you would need to kill that thing!- Its lacking a LOT of QOL features (you can for example drop all items in a chest but cant empty the chest immediately. But have to empty it to destroy it) Thats it so far. I would still recommend it just because its F2P and still fun to play! But beware that you may experience it a bit different!

Ok Review Time!!First of all this game is amazing and absolutley a worthy sequel to the first game.I love the direction the game went with its choice of Enemies, The Tyranids have been rarely used outside of the RTS genre and a small splinter fleet of Hive Fleet Leviathan was the Ideal Choice!!Slightly disappointed at first with Chaos (Again) being used as the second antagonist, but quickly changed my mind when it was Revealed that it was the Thousand Sons, which have been criminaly underused in gaming and instead of one of the more "Safe" options such as the Black Leigon in the first game!!I also Loved the part where you are Underground on an Imperial Tomb World, which ironicaly enough was a Necron Tomb World, so here's hoping in the Future we get some Necrons (My fave Faction) to fight!!I hope Saber Interactive continues this trend of using underrepresented and overlooked factions and armies into the future!!All of that being said the game is not without some issues, Mainly being how the Dodge and Parry system doesn't work most of the time, there are many times I've pressed the Parry/Dodge button with the prompt/during the indicator window up onscreen and I still got hit, it got so frustrating that i was doing all the steps to not get hit and I get hit and take damage anyway that i simply gave up trying to use the system about halfway through the game.Secondly Melee Combat was at the forefront of the gameplay which left the Shooting aspect of the game to feel quite weak and underpowered in comparison.Third is the customisation of your multiplayer Character, while it seems like Sabre have nailed it it first which they totally have, they have missed some key aspects upon closer inspection. These are quite major things if you think about them and they are as Follows:Bulwark's Banner, for some reason its always the Ultramarines Standard, NOT the Chapter that you want or expect to be representing, example a Salamanders Space Marine Planting down a Ultramarines Standard Flag.This makes zero sense and I want to see this Fixed ASAP as its increadably annoying, especialy when you are a fan of other Chapters.Voice Shouts using the Voice Wheel again suffer from the same exact problem, I dont like the fact that (Insert Chapter's Marine) is shouting out stuff like "For Guilliman!" when thats not even there Primearch!!Finally some Chapter Based cosmetics would be really great to have such as Imperial Fists or Blood Angels based wargear with corect Heraldry. Finally ♥♥♥♥ Leandros(Sorry for any Spelling Mistakes, Dyslexia is a ♥♥♥♥♥)BIG EDITNow that I have played the game for a while, I feel the need to add this.Solid game, but in my opinion it has a lot of problems that make it hard to recommend in its current state. I completed the game on Angel of Death (AOD) solo for reference. I played all the operations coop at least once. I played a few rounds of PVP, I won't comment on that since I didn't really enjoy it.The good is that it's a direct continuation of the first. I was happy to see show up in the game in a role that made sense. Overall the lore, environments, and audio were fantastic. The hordes of enemies were impressive and some of the set pieces were neat. Just like the first I loved using the jump jets and thunder hammer to crash down on enemies.There were so many things that combined made this game just not that enjoyable compared to the first for me:The game feels like it was designed for coop first and everything suffers for it. The campaign is filled with generic objectives like hold the location, press these buttons, etc. They don't feel tailor made for campaign experience but a cooperative one. Everything is forced to load to the useless battle barge before you load into an actual mission. This could easily have just been a UI menu.The AI teammates are abysmal. They do not focus on completing objects (ex. defend the chains). The enemies almost entire ignore your allies and routinely rush directly to the player. This is doubly terrible on AODThe game introduces a somewhat more fleshed out dodge and parry system and a kill shot system. In my opinion this is completely out of place. I wasn't looking to play Dark Souls, I'm looking to play a third person shooter. This is doubly bad because the timings on them are so inconsistent. Sometimes you can simply hold the defend button and you will auto parry, others you have to be very precise. The indicator doesn't match the parry timing at all. The kill shot system is also terrible. Both of these share the same problem of parry, dodge, and kill shot not having the ability to be used at any moment in time and interrupting whatever action is currently in progress (ex. a melee attack or shooting). It makes the game feel incredibly clunky and unresponsive on AOD, In general the whole Melee Combat System feels like it was originally designed for a much faster paced combat system which was cut and we then ended up with what we have now.Similar to dodge and kill shot not interrupting all actions, neither does your tactical ability. This is nonsense, that is the whole purpose of the single ability you have for 95% of the campaign, to heal and protect yourself.In general the combat feels like it misses the point of what made the first one great. It should be larger swarms of weaker enemies, not bullet sponge enemies that require dodge/parry/kill shot to do any damageAll of the guns feel too weak. This might be an AOD problem but it feels terrible to have to use 50% of your las rifle to take down one terminator. This is doubly worse because you carry less guns in this game compared to the first.The new health and armor system feels like a step backwards. On AOD you are constantly at 1% HP regardless and there is almost no way to heal yourself through combat like the first game. Everything that touches you will immediately remove your armor so it feels pointless. I would have rather had no armor, more health, and a means to regenerate it through combat (past white damage).You can't queue for a new instance of an operation, it always puts you in one in progress if available. If you are playing for the story, like the campaign suggests, this means you may start at the very end of one if the game decides. When you leave the operation, it forces you to watch the useless scenes in the battle barge over again to return to the campaign which is incredibly annoying.The assault class (the most fun one) is also the most weak one. This is likely a combination of all the above issues though. You cant fly over basic ledges and overhangs, it just feels so weak in operations.I assume most of these issues could be patched for sure and some of them may actually be realistically improved. As it stands though at full price, it's a steep ask for what you get in the package. There is most certainly no longevity to the operations, they are largely static with no variation aside from where/when enemies spawn. PVP is PVP, nothing special. This is a sale game for sure. It does so much right, but the wrong stuff just makes the whole experience feel off.

2022 First of all, in short this is probably the best modern "Soulsborne" cinematic universe game we've gotten thus far in PC (Bloodborne when? pls). The addition of certain micro mechanics like jumping, the horse riding (and battles) and now an actual open world that gives you freedom from where to explore to a much higher extent compared to the other games is honestly just great fun. I would not be surprised If the average playtime til completion in Elden ring is at least 2x of the other games and even as an entry into the series it does the job just fine (I do think Dark Souls 3 is a little better as an introduction to the series)BUT, It's been confirmed several times that FromSoftware/Bandai Namco and whoever else is making money from these games. They make A B S O L U T E bank money when they release these games on PC (And If Bloodborne ever got ported to PC that game would also absolutely be bank money). As FromSoftware is literally one of the few Japanese game studios that is so widely recognized and loved in the west I just wish they actually cared about this market as much as *we* love them. Other people that played the game know this, all the reviewers have mentioned this in their YT videos, I have a computer that is quite literally way more powerful than any console running this same game yet I'm getting the stuttering, frame drops. And this entire thing is a reocurring thing with Soulsborne games ported to PC and the kick in the balls is, while this game is absolutely beautiful, it is not the most "graphically" challenging game in recent times at all.Should this previous complain deter you from trying out this game? Actually? Absolutely not, I would still recommend it and while I have other minor complains about certain game design things themselves it's still an absolute blast, I'm not even half way through the game yet as for people that are completionists this will really make you want to explore every nook and cranny but this is just a warning and just to get the message out there because I don't know how else you get Bandai/FromSoftware to care about the Steam market that actually makes them drown in money.TL:DR: fort night

Nobody will read my review, so I'll just say ♥♥♥♥ anyone who starts their comment like that (except me). This game deserves way better than cheap, lazy spam. I’ve 100% completed Elden Ring on PS5, got the platinum trophy which was an absolute blast, and now I’m diving into it on PC. FromSoftware, you’ve seriously outdone yourselves. Elden Ring is nothing short of phenomenal, and it's hard to imagine how you'll ever top this.From the moment I stepped into this vast, mysterious world, I was hooked. The blend of deep lore, challenging combat, and stunning landscapes is just incredible. The gameplay is smoth and perfectly balanced, making every fight feel like a rewarding test of skill.Exploring the world of Elden Ring is pure joy. It's packed with secrets, hidden paths, and lore that keeps you wanting more. The environmental storyteling is so rich that every corner of the map feels worth investigating. Each region has its own uniqie look and feel, so exploration never gets boring.Now, let’s talk about the only thing that annoys me: the catacombs or dungeons. This has been a problem since Bloodborne (my favorite game of all time). Even though Elden Ring does it better than Bloodborne, every dungeon still feels a bit like an AI-generated copy-paste job. But hey, they’re still fun.The character builds you can create in Elden Ring are better than in any Souls game before it. Whether you’re into melee combat, magic, or a mix of both, the depth here is just amazing.In short, Elden Ring isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. FromSoftware has set a new standard for the genre and maybe created a new genre, and I can’t wait to see what they do with the DLC. If you haven’t played it yet, do yourself a favor and dive in. You won’t regret it.

It's pains me to say this as a huge warhammer fan but I overall found my experience with this game to be less than superb and not worth the money.For a high triple-A price tag it has far too many bugs, connection issues and sloppy optimisation that weigh down a game that, whilst isn't bad, doesn't feel like it does anything too spectacular. Combat feels very stiff and cagey where you transition awkwardly from spamming melee moves and swinging wildly around the place to firing off one or two mags of your current weapon (before it ultimately runs out of ammunition because of the ridiculously low amount of ammo the player is allowed to retain). There isn't anywhere near enough variety in execution animations, and enemy variety is sorely lacking. The single player campaign is just "good enough"; It has some cool standout moments but it's mostly bogged down with lots of sub par segments and bickering between squadmates that gets tiring to listen to very quickly. Titus feels very watered down and flat in this game, and most of the supporting cast of characters don't stand out too much save for a handful. Operations CAN be good...When it's working and you can connect to a game, which is a struggle to achieve at the best of times. The PvP multiplayer is laughably unoptimised and has some of the worst ping issues I've played in a multiplayer game in years (a massive shame as I was a huge fan of the first Space Marine game's multiplayer which had better ping and servers almost a full decade ago) as well as a veritable host of balance issues with classes and a score limit for matches that's far too short for how long it takes to get into the match in the first place. All of these modes, unfortunately, also have the misfortune of being tied within a very obtuse and sluggish overworld/hub interface. If you want to customise your characters for the multiplayer modes it requires you to matchmake in those modes, which 9/10 times usually leads to you getting into a game before you can even customise your classes or loadout and forcing you to sit through several load screens (that is if you actually ever load INTO whatever you matchmaked for with how bad the connection issues are.) before you can so much as determine what colour you want your space marine to be or what weapon you want them to use. The hub exists to be a diegetic and seamless way for players to experience the game but it manages to do the complete opposite since it brings with it a whole host of problems that ultimately ruin the immersion of the hub in the first place.I really want to like this game but in truth I've derived no joy from playing it to completion, and I feel no motivation trying to finish up the last 3 operations when the game is fighting me at every opportunity to stop me from getting to do so and is just wasting my time seemingly out of spite. At a FAR cheaper price tag and with some tuning up, I could definitely recommend this game, but in it's current state and with all it's baggage and pricing, I'd advise steering clear of this one for now. You'll get more fun out of playing some of the other equally, poorly optimised 40k games that at least don't take too much of your cash.

2022 'Posted: 20 Feb @ 4:02amIncredible gameBuggy at the minute but still worth the purchasecba making a full on review, if u like total war grab it if u have the money idk im not ur dad'I made this review when I was off the first high of finishing a Legendary Slaanesh campaign. I love it, it was fun. I can't say that I still feel the same way. Patching and fixes for this games many problems is abysmally slow. I don't agree with simply calling the game trash and moving on because the actual races, maps, etc. Are all pretty cool, but they just do not play well at all.Infantry is hardly responsive and pushes you to doomstack monsters even moreso than Warhammer two already didTowers are frankly broken and most siege battles are unloseable chores due to god awful AI, in my last run I played pretty much every defense in triple speed waiting for the enemy to die on my tier 2 ♥♥♥♥ infantry as towers bricked them.AI rebuild siege defenses with basically no delay. As soon as you destroy a tower they start rebuilding it. Fighting minor siege battles is legitimately unfun, there are fewer land battles on the map which is where this franchise truly shines.There are a lot of really, really bad performance and visual issues which people experience at different levels. Some people have mid-tier rigs and are completely fine, others are super high end and get abysmal performance on the campaign map.The soul-run campaign just isn't fun. An overwhelming majority of the community would probably agree to this. It is a linear experience of expand, consolidate, expand. Turtle, turtle, turtle. Rifts are cancer and your legendary lord spends the majority of his/her time in either the Realms of Chaos or sitting in favoured corruption settlements to get rid of cancerous corurption traits like -5% replenishment which can severely hamstring certain factions. In my Slaanesh run I had a Keeper of Secrets with this trait and he was literally unable to replenish outside of tier 5 settlements. ♥♥♥♥ game design. The narrative isn't that interesting because its very impersonal, whereas Vortex' story felt very personal to your faction despite the overall plot being the exact same. Supply lines lmaoThis game has potential but I've recently uninstalled it. It just isn't fun, it hardly works. Its difficult enough to get through a campaign even ignoring the absolute tide of bugs that this game has.CA is still displaying a trend of poor management post launch and frank disrespect for their games. Again, this is a good game. Its in a broken state, so I can't recommend that anybody buy it atm.I sincerely hope that I'll be changing this review in a few patches. But from the way things are going I can't see myself changing that.

2022 Game is solid.UPDATE: 2/24/2022HOWEVER,if you are on the fence about buying the game, I'd wait. This game has good bones, and will certainly be a masterpiece in a few years. Once Immortal Empires is released and there have been several updates, it'll be a thoroughly enjoyable experience.In my first co-op campaign, my graphics card failed 5 times. Screen went black, then eventually came back but with black boxes and half the colors gone. This has not happened in any other game, including Total Warhammer II. My graphics card is struggling far more than it should be, and that's on a 1080Ti with settings at medium-high. Simply put, something is wrong here. I don't know if it's the rumored Denuvo, or if there is more optimization that needs to be done. I even have the Nvidia drivers that were designed with this games release in mind.Gameplay wise, it's great. The few nitpicks I do have, I'm sure will be ironed out in the patches to come. Warhammer II had many issues on launch as well, and now that game is very refined and enjoyable. I'm very confident that game 3 will also receive the love and attention it deserves, but it will take time.I look forward to the future of this game with updates, DLC, and mods. It's enjoyable now, but the Ideal Total War: Warhammer 3 experience is probably a year out from now.Regardless of whether you have the game now or are choosing to wait, I hope you enjoy the games you are playing, cheers!

Product refunded Space Marine 2 feels like playing a classic AA Xbox game, one that you'd rent from the local Redbox for a week and try to finish in a few sittings. A game that feels catered to rental services, but not worth a full $60 purchase. In one way, I found my playtime oddly nostalgic and charming for the aforementioned reasons, but in another way, I found myself totally uninspired, questioning why I had just spent $60 for a game that, despite its great visuals, felt oddly antiquated. Ultimately, there just isn't a lot of depth here - I don't need games to be complicated, but this one felt sorta mind-numbing at times. Hoard-combat sounds like so much fun in theory, but often has a similar sensation to mowing the lawn: an exercise in patience, as you direct your big mowing machine towards the next patch of unkempt grass, once you're there, there isn't much 'strategy' involved - it's just grass. That being said, the graphics are great. I wish it had ultrawide support, and I'm not sure what about this package requires them to take a month post-launch to officially add it. The environments and hoards look particularly amazing - the lighting can also look incredible under the correct circumstances - it's then a shame that the first 2 hours of this game are set almost entirely on a beige planet filled with swamp-fog and mud. Speaking of hours - I know this campaign is only 6 or so hours long. This isn't an issue in principle if the package is really condensed and well-made, but Space Marine 2 is just so damn average that it becomes a much harder pill to swallow. I personally have no interest in online game modes, so for me: someone seeking a strong single-player campaign the likes of Halo 3, Reach, Wolfenstien, Doom 2016, etc, .. I am left comparably underwhelmed. There isn't enough here for me to sink my teeth into. It's a $60 game that feels as though it's resting a bit too much on its graphical laurels to justify an amateur game experience. Shallow combat and an aggressively short campaign emphasizes the mediocrity of the package, and even if it wasn't true for everyone, it was true for me. The draw of the 40k universe isn't endearing enough for me to overlook the inadequacies of this experience.

Take this with a grain of salt. I ultimately refunded it because of various small issues.1. Performance while stable felt bad on my 3080. DLSS turned on by default with no way to turn it off... not a good look and many other games have had drama just for this, games shouldn't need DLSS to function. (Examples: Remnant 2, Cyberpunk2077). I can't play this game with DLSS forced on, with optimized settings (a combo of mid-very high settings) and RT off at mid to high settings. This gets me around 70-75 fps at 1080p around 65-70 at 1440p. I spent $3000+ on a gaming computer last year to play games at max settings, and high frame rates. Watching 2023-24 games come out and turn a $3000 pc into something thats comparible to a console is just sad.2. Difficulty had weird spike you either beat everything down pretty easy or you get pooped on. In the two hours I made it to the area with the first official fire boss with a side boss (big headed blue guy) couldn't beat either in the time I had with the game. The combat is action based but I HATE that I can't dodge out of an attack. I can't tell you how many times I would attack the game ques the attack but even if I see something coming I can't dodge out of the way instead stuck in an attack animation, speaking of heavy attacks feel weird as I try to implement them into my light attacks but without a "focus bead" you can't string a heavy into your combo and instead have to come to a stand still before you can ques up a heavy attack. Combat feels both clunky and fluid at the same time with difficulty spikes in both directions as well.3. This was the deciding factor: Time... unfortunately because games have a 2 hour limit before they can't be refunded I take that time seriously as $60+ investment isn't so small in 2024 with costs rising. From the time I hit "play" Steam's timer keeps track of shaders compiling (about 5-10 minutes), and then me looking at options (mostly graphics) and bench marking for optimized settings took another 20-30 minutes before I even hit "new game". There I am already 45-ish minutes into a game I have yet to truly try. I fortunately watched a couple people start it up and was able to skip the opening cinematic and a couple cut scenes saving me valuable time and still left me in the starting area as my 2 hour limit came along.Unfortunately because of the time constants and the few little issues I had I can't say for certain whether this game is good or not but it's issues were enough to make me refund it. I wasn't going to lose out on money for a game I wasn't crazy about. I think we need to talk about opening up the refund window on games that boast dozens of hours of content and only having 2 hours to demo that content. I truly believe if I had another 2-3 hours I might have found something to love but as is I couldn't bring myself to spend $60 for a game I was meh about with the 1 hour 15-ish minutes I had with it.

2022 Well what to say about this masterpiece, the magnum opus of From Software?It is just GREAT! Provided you like the general 'soulslike' approach and setting, this game is a wonderful step forward and truly takes the whole thing into an open world. There is so much to explore, to uncover, to find... and to get pounded into the floor.If you are absolutely new to From Software's approach on difficulty and gameplay, then Elden Ring is the most userfriendly one. A really slow paced tutorial (compared to: this is how you move... YOU DIED.) so even newcomers have can get accustomed to the core mechanics.But don't get me wrong: the difficulty spikes are still there, and you WILL DIE A LOT! But this is actually part of how these games work, so do not falter when your health runs out yet again.It is really hard to write a lot about it, without spoiling anything. So to be brief: imagine Darksouls, just in a huge open world, with a metric ton of bonfires and small dungeons and challenges everywhere.Welcome to Elden Ring :)Don't turn hollow <3

2022 As you've probably noticed, some people have really enjoyed this game and others have not. I fall into the category of one who doesn't mind the Realm of Chaos campaign that many others despise. Yes, at times it can be annoying, but as someone who has plays the Vortex campaign in Total War Warhammer 2, I'm quite used to this type of campaign and don't need to wait for Immortal Empires to come out.Some pros to the game:- Decent Faction Selection (base game has 9 Legendary Lords from 7 different factions).- Map is very large and allows for diversity in what enemies and friends you come across.- Individual Faction Mechanics for every faction that adds some flavor to each one.- Skarbrand the Exiled punting most characters across the map.- Graphics are pretty good especially on higher settings.- Modding Community is wonderful.Cons:- Immortal Empires isn't out yet. Less sandbox-ish for now as you are kind of forced into playing the Souls Race unless you have a mod that turns it off.- Limited Units as of now for each faction, especially the Daemonic factions.- Cannot play as the Warhammer one and two races. This doesn't faze me, but I know it affects a lot of people that fancy playing the Empire for the 50th time.- Anti-Player Bias still is strong, but much better than what it was at release back in February of 2022.Conclusion:Personally, I think the game is worth it and it is only going to get better as we progress further into the year. If you are waiting for Immortal Empires, then I would hold off until later this year when the beta gets set up for that. If you really want to try out new factions like Cathay (which is new-ish to lore) and the Daemons, then I would recommend getting this game. I hope this helps you all make a good decision!

2023 I've bought every DLC from WH1 to WH3, with the exception of your newest 25$ DLC pack.For that price I'd expect a new, fully fleshed out faction. What do we get? 3 Legendary Lords and a unit roster that does very little to pad out the existing races you chose to feature in that DLC pack. You lot must be really getting ribbed hard by your investors to destroy all the good faith you've built with your community these long, long years. I waited patiently for WH3. I waited patiently for the DLCs to release -- because I thought it would get to a standard that would match WH2. I was wrong.Warhammer 3 was supposed to be your magnum opus. The king of kings. CA, you can still fix this. Your management just need to pull their heads out of your investor's buttholes and actually support your developers on this project. Help them help you. If you lot screw this game up more than you have, there will be no relevancy left for you. You think anyone will buy anything from you goobers again if you let this beautiful idea fail from mismanagement? Respect our time, respect our money. Inflation has hit everyone. Products are shrinking in size everywhere, prices are going up across the board. I refuse to believe inflation has hit a game company as hard as it has the rest of us. Maybe in your bottom line in the fact you actually have to pay your employees, CA. But I doubt they hardly see any of the benefits of your increased prices, hence - I don't give a damn about any PR speech related to your hardships. Your workers don't get any extra pay, only your crappy management do. I bet your management aren't even game developers. I bet they're just scum sucking bean counters who wormed their way up in the game industry through their sales experience. Guess what, people want a good game. Just give them one and they'll pay. These bad reviews aren't just because of your awful, awful DLC. The game itself is not in a good state. Promises that were made have been under-delivered. There has been an extremely long gap between DLC and updates. People have expectations, hopes - and those two things can only be betrayed so many times.Then you give them Shadows of Change? More like Shadows of the Underwhelmed. There's only one way to teach a bean counter how to invest in a good game. Make bad game. Numbers go down. No need for any of us to invest our time and money in disappointment.Make a good game, numbers go up. I know investors are like children in that they're used to instant gratification. But maybe they can learn how to wait like the rest of us are forced to? At least they wont be disappointed by the cold hard cash you dummies will make if you actually pull WH3 off right. It'll take time. Just show the community good faith, transparency and a willingness to veer back onto the right track. Prices to match the content provided, bullcrap about 'inflation' aside. 3 LLs and some units meant to slightly pad out some base game faction niches? 14.99$.Hey you know what I'll even be generous and offer some solutions, it'll make your desk jockeys heads spin.Change your Shadows of Change DLC to 14.99$ and offer those who've bought the DLC a discount on the next content pack you decide to release, equal to the 10$ they have lost. I mean, it's practically ensuring returning customers!!! If you can't do that? Offer them all exclusive beta access to your next content pack for testing/enjoyment. Wow, a band-aid and it's practically free. All you'd have to do after that is fix/tweak what's already there in between your DLC projects. Maybe fix some bugs and features you promised.I know, I'm a genius. You're welcome.

Now that we know what is going to be wiped each season, (every 6 weeks) this game is basically ruined for me. I can not sweatlord my way through from the very beginning and grind out memetic progression, world progression, and unlocks every 6 weeks. I get that they want to set a level playing field around the PVP part of the game, but how are people that have other responsibilities like family / work supposed to ever get anywhere when you require a restart from a fresh character every 6 weeks. If the season wipes are changed to not sh*t on our time spent exploring and unlocking new areas of the map, and character progression isn't completely wiped, I would recommend this game with 2 thumbs up, having been in every closed playtest since the first one. This game has so much to offer and can be absolutely incredible to experience, but they are absolutely ruining it for what I suspect will be a sizable portion of the would-be player base with the season wipe stance they are taking. Hopefully they are open to changing things, because this game went from a 9/10 to a 2/10 for me. I was actually going to dump about $50 into the game at launch just to support them bc of the play tests and I expected it would be a great game to support, but I will unfortunately be holding off to see if they come up with a better system for seasons. Some people are fine with these types of seasons/wipes, and that's fine, but I don't have the time to get reset like that over and over.

2022 Elden Ring is a good game but unfortunately it's very poorly optimized.I kinda dismissed the other reviews saying how bad the frame drops are thinking they're exaggerated but I experienced them myself throughout the whole game.I'm not sure whether it's just bad optimization or because of the Easy Anti-Cheat but the frames stutter constantly, some areas more than others but it's just something you have to deal with through the game.This is also something I heard from pretty much everyone I talked to, this is not an issue of hardware (RTX 2070 and Ryzen 2700X)Elden Ring takes a lot from FromSoft's older titles and improves on most of them.The game is way more accessible with a LOT of ways to make the experience easier and also some very welcome quality of life changes, which I hope they will continue with and expand on future titles.Being an open world has it's draws though as if you're a fan of Dark Souls' old world design then you're not really gonna find that here.Another thing to note is that there is some cut content that's still half in the game and while it's not much, you do notice something's off, as well as a few bugs here and there.Online play is terrible, in coop and especially invasions you're gonna have a bad time. If you even manage to connect, and stay connected throughout the whole thing.One time I even got an "Inappropriate activity detected" error and was booted to the menu unable to go online.This probably was caused by some sort of false positive in Easy Anti-Cheat as I understand it happened to many people during that time and was later fixed but still an unpleasant experience.As much as I like FromSoft I expect better from a Triple A product.

2023 Total War: Warhammer will go down as one of the all-time great RTS franchises. The scope of this game will never be matched in the RTS genre.1) Insanely beautiful graphics. The best in a fantasy RTS game.2) Tried and true battle system with massive unit variety. Players can build defensive, offensive, balanced or meme armies.3) Ridiculous replayability - campaign. 24 Races (w/DLC). 90+ Factions each with a unique starting lord and location on the world map.4) Extremely high production quality. Sound, UI, Detail - everything exudes quality.5) Extremely deep multiplayer scene that is quite dependent on both game and meta knowledge and micro. 24 unique factions mean 288 unique matchups - everyone is always learning.

The game is indeed beautiful, and the controls are pretty easy to pick up. But man is this monkey weak! It takes a dozen hits from his rather heavy looking staff to take out trash mobs, who can kill you pretty easily with just a few hits. I've not made it out of the first mountain, but so far this is not open world; you are confined to a narrow corridor. And for the bosses, the game is basically grind trash in this hallway until you level up to beat one boss, and repeat this cycle forever. "Temples, towns, and shops" have been replaced with a one stop do everything shrine system, and there's zero exploration. I guess this is China's answer to Elden Ring, except not open world. For the kind of people who like that sort of thing, that's the sort of thing that kind of people like. But if you're looking for an actual adventure game, instead of an Elden Ring/Souls trainer, this isn't the one, hype be damned.

2023 I have bought every xpac but SoC. I have earned the idiot crown I wear, and the right to speak on this game and the franchise's history - since I saw it happen. Way back when TW: WH1 was released, I was hesitantly critical of some things. The usual microtransaction stuff I figured was gross but mildly tolerable for a game I enjoyed. Locking units behind pre-orders? Less tolerable. Units basically just swinging swords at one another, nothing ever connecting? Oh.. Not like I liked to zoom in and watch the lads fight or anything.. (/s) No real incentive to play multiplayer except some momentary fun? I still think a currency from MP battles which can eventually be used to buy factions which I suggested all those years ago could have saved us from this timeline. Now I hear the team in charge of fixing the game was so so small, and the cuts to the workforce reaching like 40%. Where did the money even go then? And saying things like "the right to discuss is a privilege" and banning content creators who are justifiably upset? Yikes.This should be a lesson to all dev studios. When you strike gold with something like Total War, treat it like what it is: art. Pour yourself into it, and make it something you're proud of.If you treat it like a business, your product will rot and you'll be left with a brand that leaves a bitter taste in fans' mouths. Of course I'm sure the ones making all the bad decisions will receive their golden parachutes, and go on ruining other projects. But this franchise could have been something incredible if it had been done right.Thanks for everything, Creative Arts. It was.. enlightening. Enjoy the hundreds (thousands?) I gave you over the years.

2023 Update April 2024 I decided to change my recommendation to positive in view of recent news regarding layoffs at CA, the rampant rumors around Total War: Warhammer III being scaled down from what was originally planned, and lastly because the additions to Shadows of Change were pretty good. Despite the fact that multiplayer campaigns barely function, despite the random CTD's, units having seriously bad pathfinding around gates and ladders, Warriors of Chaos and Cathay tech not working properly, or that there are heroes with not enough skills to put their skill points into, I still love this game. A lot of that love lies in thanks to the modding community, but the love and work that CA the Warhammer team have put into it is undeniable.Finally, a message to SEGA. Do not let this game die before it gets a chance to redeem itself The whole reason we're here is due to CA leadership being incompetent, out of touch, greedy dirtbagsPunish them, not the game that makes money despite their best efforts to gun it down while it's laying the golden eggs. Update Feb 2024Since I posted this review, CA made a public statement "apologizing" (quotes because the wording of the apology was very corporate and didn't really make the point of owning up to mistakes) but also promising to be better. In this vein, they cut the price of Total War: Pharaoh, refunded all owners, and promised to add content to Shadows of Change to match the asking price. This all happened in late December. They are currently coming out with a series of blog posts detailing the added units/lords/heroes in every race (at the time of writing this, only Cathay and Tzeentch are out) and the update is due next week. However, I will not be changing my recommendation yet, as this whole ordeal has been going on since the game was released. I'd like to have them be consistently good for a good long while before I can honestly recommend the game. Plus, it's still riddled with bugs. Original Review in November I'm sorry, as many hours of entertainment this game, which I truly love, has given me, I cannot in good conscience recommend it. Unfortunately, Creative Assembly have been treating it as a money maker that will always make money no matter what, essentially abandoning it in the process. Their idea of "support" is to let a haggard, poor dlc team of, I would wager, less than twenty people to maintain, patch, AND produce content, while at the same time increasing prices to absurd amounts for lesser quality content than for every other dlc ever. In the meantime, as the team is stretched super thin, glaring problems (which the community has addressed in mere days via mods) have been left in the game for months at a time. Imagine buying a faction dlc focused on a specific unit, and that faction being completely unable to recruit said unit FOR THREE ENTIRE MONTHS.And to top things off, they came out with a statement as a response to community backlash for the latest price increase, basically saying "we want more money, buy the dlc or we drop support entirely" Tldr: CA have abandoned this game. QA is non-existent, major bugs are in the game for months on end, and CA came out with an ultimatum to buy the dlc at an absurd price or they'll drop support.

2023 I've updated my review to reflect the good work CA have made over the last few patches. You can no longer win a siege by sneaking in some units via the backdoor, you are no longer required to defend 2 completely different areas of the base in order to successfully repel a siege.There is still a massive issue with AI being far too passive, they no longer build massive empires. The AI no longer confederates (even the Empire rarely seems to confederate their elector counts) which prevents any factions becoming powerful. This might be ok for lower difficulties but Legendary players need more of a challenge. I also can't say how much I despise them making all minor factions just free wins for the AI. The glorious re-playability of WH2 was finding out who survived to the mid/end game. Now it's the same factions every single playthrough as they removed the ability for minor factions to sometimes get the upper hand on their larger rivals. Finding Marienburg had wiped out the Empire or Mousillon had conquered Bretonnia was the joy of starting a new campaign. There's none of that now, bring back aggressive AI empires and none whipping boy minor factions and you've restored my faith.

2022 New factions are fine addition to Total War Warhammer, however the campaign itself is absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Game really discourages you from fighting the other factions and expanding. Also realm of Tzeentch is the worst ♥♥♥♥ they came up with. AI straight up cheats and walk to the end. If you follow the same path and go to the same portals, they throw you to different locations. Also somehow they made sieges even worse now. I don't think it's a good idea that you can build towers etc in middle of the battle. I think they should only be done in battle preparation phase. Guess I just have to resort to autoresolve the siege battles. At least they made Military Alliances somewhat useful now as you can build outposts and recruit units from your allies so that's cool I guess. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Man, I really dig the new update. Added late game encounters is really darn pog system which i'm looking forward to. However it still baffles me that siege battles remained the same, they're the worst dogshite they came up with. Whether it's "unlimited" tower ranges or being able to build towers mid combat, that's just ♥♥♥♥ game design imo. I played as Volkmar and generally loved the campaign. I just wish it was easier to get special units from elector counts. When I unlocked 4 books out of 8, the late game event usually starts at that time, and elector count units practically become "obsolete" or come in way too late to make any difference in campaign. + It takes way too long to recruit more of them. I wish you could recruit them through military alliances maybe? Or simply just lower the cooldown for the special units.

2023 Hundreds of hours and almost every single DLC purchased at full price since TW:WH 1. I'd love it if I could convince my friends to play. Lately I wouldn't want to, even if I could. Responding to the community with patronizing language and blaming increased costs (without acknowledging those costs certainly aren't going toward THIS game's future), with a track record of abandoning games and broken promises to the playerbase is a great reason for CA leadership to change career paths. Senior executives really don't have that much meaningful good they can do, but they sure can do some damage. Give your dev team more money and time. Stop plucking the golden goose.For a deeper dive: DLC as of writing this tops out at $260. That alone should make anyone new to the franchise wince. A new person would be playing pared down, outright incomplete, or unbalanced versions of a very small percentage of the total game. Mods would help, some. But CA doesn't pay modders.Further Problems I have recommending:1. Updates and core upkeep of the game: anything that is not DLC gets very very little attention. Includes everything from bugfixes to balancing (especially for single player), new free content, QoL passes especially on older factions.2. Reworks of non-DLC factions are few and far between, and each DLC introduction seems to get implemented without accounting for how it impacts existing factions. Includes obvious things like broken faction mechanics going unpatched for weeks or months, but also basic campaign "is it fun" sniff tests (the least fun campaign starts happened from neglect as DLC was added), under the hood core gameplay mechanics (diplomacy, trade) addressed or overhauled for DLC lords or factions but left 2010 "functional" for the rest, AI cheats in lieu of meaningful challenge etc. Even map design.3. Modding community left to carry the load for creative reworks and revisits, QoL changes, fun factor.4. The reason for all the negative reviews currently: three lords for three of the least played factions makes sense on a corporate balance sheet. It even made me hope that it would include reworks and comprehensive retooling of the factions in question as a whole to make them more attractive to play. Win win for CA and the player base. Without that, without -well implemented- unique new mechanics, core faction overhauls...but maybe even WITH that, frankly, the three factions I would be least excited to see a DLC for, one lord each... $25 was always going to be a stretch, especially without FreeLC or meaningful changes to other factions or universal mechanics. But for friends new to the game? For friends who stopped playing looking for an excuse to dust this game off? This is part of a trend that has me wanting nothing to do with the company OR this game in particular.

I absolutely cannot understand why there are so many rave reviews for this game. In my opinion, to get straight to the point: Blackmyth Wukong is a solid game but by no means outstanding or a Game of the Year contender.First, the positive aspects:- Graphics & Atmosphere: This cannot be taken away from the game. The graphics are by far the best I have ever seen in a game. The texture details, the light-shadow balance, and the general look of the game are simply breathtaking.The animations are incredibly well done; for example, the animation changes when you swing into an attack from a dodge move compared to a normal attack. This creates a high level of realism and atmosphere.- Soundtrack: The soundtrack is wonderfully composed and greatly enhances the boss fights and overall atmosphere.- Cinematic Presentation and Cutscenes: The animations at the end of a chapter are absolute masterpieces. (Though I didn’t understand how 4 out of 6 of them relate to the story, but fine), and the cutscenes during a fight (like in the intro or the final boss) are top-notch. This was actually the main reason why I found the game so cool.- AAA Title without Extra Costs: Few to no bugs, no cost traps, no additional content locked behind a paywall.The negative aspects:- Story: I have no knowledge of Chinese mythology and therefore perceived the story accordingly. The intro is absolutely fantastic, it really hooked me, and I was highly motivated to learn who these “gods” are, the “court,” and how to fight them. Unfortunately, this becomes completely irrelevant. You go through chapter after chapter searching for relics, and each chapter basically contains its “own” storyline. The storylines are neither interesting nor exciting. Even when you develop a connection or interest in a certain aspect of the story, the chapter ends and a different, new storyline with new characters begins. There are very few characters that span across multiple chapters. As a result, at least for me, I had no motivation to continue playing. The end of the game is, in my eyes, completely nonsensical in terms of the story and only underscores how cryptic, disjointed, and boring the story is. I feel like the game is trying hard to be like Elden Ring but fails to deliver the story like FromSoftware does.- Map and Level Design: The level design is complete garbage. You wander around for hours, there is no map, and you constantly get lost. Most of the time, the places also look so similar to each other that you almost can’t find your way around anymore. Since the game relies on very few HUD indicators (which I generally think is cool), you don’t know where to go and get lost even more. This wouldn’t be a problem if the world at least gave you a reason to explore: It doesn’t. Everything you loot consists of crafting materials. These give no motivation for exploration. Armor and weapons are only unlocked as part of the story and cannot be found in any chests.The fact that invisible walls border the map doesn’t make it any better, as you often think, "Oh, it must continue over there," and then you run into an invisible wall. In my opinion, that doesn’t belong in an AAA title.- Bosses & Gameplay: The bosses are a topic of their own. Firstly, apart from the intro, the final boss, and a few exceptions, I find all bosses to be completely forgettable. They are boring, there are waaaay too maaaany of them, and they look boring too. In 90% of cases, it's a human with some animal head. Don’t get me wrong; their attacks and all the visuals are more than fantastic. But if you think you’re getting bosses like FromSoftware delivers, you’re in the wrong place.The gameplay is one of the biggest criticisms for me. Extremely monotonous and boring, especially for a game with at least 20 hours of playtime. The combos are very limited (feels like there are about three of them), and you do the same thing all the time. This not only looks boring in the long run but almost killed my desire to play. The dodging feels very satisfying but also partially very random. Often, it happened that a boss clearly hit me with an ability, and I dodged a second later, but the game registered it as a perfect dodge. Also, the hitboxes are so random; I don't know if these are bugs or just poor hitbox design. And when you've been hammering away at a boss with the same three moves for 15 minutes and then die from a hit that clearly misses, you lose your mind. Or you fight a boss who spends 90% of the time flying and is unhittable, and you're basically playing a dodge simulator.- Difficulty: As a big Soulslike fan, I love that the game is not easy. But it's a different kind of difficulty compared to the Souls series, for example. Elden Ring feels very fair in its difficulty. You learn the bosses’ patterns, their moves, and abilities, and you make it on your 50th try. In Wukong, I did not get that feeling. The game is certainly not easy, but it’s not really "fun difficult" either. It feels artificially hard when every boss rushes at you with endless combos, or every second boss turns invisible, or creates six copies of itself, or ten tornadoes that sweep across the map, and just touching one catapults you into the air while you still have to dodge the boss itself. Most of the time, the bosses have AoE attacks and love to dash across the entire map at you. This feels artificially and unfairly difficult. It’s like saying, "Minecraft is the hardest game because you spawn with a wooden sword in a 10x10 room against 100 Endermen." That’s not fun hard; that’s boring and lazy. That’s how the bosses in Wukong feel.I am very, very disappointed after having looked forward to this game so much. You can really see—and I never want to deny this—how much love went into making this game. But sometimes passion and love alone are not enough.
This game is art. Masterpiece. So much fun.

2022 I am huge fan of Souls game, so i was so hyped. For me this game is most worthy for that anticipation of 3 years of date. When i first heard on E3 in 2019 of this game i thought it will be good Souls game, but after they announced freemode and stuff i've had great hope that this will be most rated game ever. I can tell you that 48 hours before game was released i was counting every second of it and when i saw from early reviewers ratings for game seconds got just double up longer. DirectX 12 is breaking every game so this one hits it to with bad peformance, but still game is playable and we haved issue with even more games with peformances of DX12.Game on PC with AMD configuration for me is peforming well without any issue of FPS drops or stuttering, but i see alot of ppl having that issue only on Intel and Nvidia.I don't have alot of hours in this game so for now these are My Ratings:Soundtrack: 10+/10 (I gave on previous souls games 10/10, but this one is really special)Gameplay: 10/10Graphics: 10/10Physics: 10/10 (This is probably causing alot of FPS issue, but still ragdolls and physics in game are so satisfying)Map exploration: 10/10 (There is alot of places that needs to be explored and game is much longer for real souls players now)Boss Fights: 10/10Character Customizaton: 10/10Online Mode: 10/10 (Multiplayer comparing to others is much better and there is alot of improvment, cheaters doesn't exist)My final thoughts about this game: Game is good and it will probably be GOTY for this year, so who ever like challenges and tough boss fights he should try this game. After additional nearly 300 hours and 100% achievments i can confirm this game is worth giving a try and to spend alot time on exploring.
