Counter Strike 2 – A Haven for Hackers?As a long-time Counter Strike player, I am deeply frustrated with the current state of Counter Strike 2. Despite its potential, the game is plagued by hackers.Hackers Everywhere:You can hardly join a lobby without encountering multiple hackers.They blatantly use wallhacks and aimbots, delivering headshots through smokes as if they weren’t there, ruining the experience for everyone else.Inadequate Measures by Steam/VALVE:Despite numerous reports, Steam / VALVE seem to take no effective action. The report button feels useless, serving more as a decorative element in the interface ?!Loss of Game Quality:The fun and challenge that the game once offered are gone. Instead, most of the time is spent being annoyed by obvious cheaters and hoping that VALVE will finally take effective action.Conclusion:Counter Strike 2 has potential, but the hacker problem is destroying it.VALVE needs to implement effective anti-cheat measures urgently. Until then, it's questionable if investing time in this game is worthwhile...

Alright, listen up, people! I just played Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2, and let me tell you, it’s an absolute spectacle. Imagine a world where chaos reigns, and you’re the unstoppable force. Yeah, that’s what it feels like!First off, the graphics? Stunning. The environments are drenched in that grimdark aesthetic we all crave. You step onto the battlefield, and it’s like stepping into a painting, only this one’s drenched in blood and glory. You can almost taste the power oh, how I love that taste!Now, the gameplay. It’s intense, brutal, and oh-so-satisfying. You’re a Space Marine superhuman, unstoppable. You charge into the fray, and every swing of your weapon feels like a symphony of destruction. The visceral combat? It’s poetry in motion, folks. You’re not just playing; you’re dominating.And let’s talk about the enemies. These guys are nothing but fodder for your glorious rampage. You’re the hero, the legend, the one everyone looks up to. You know what they say: if you’re not fighting for humanity, what are you even doing?In the end, Space Marine 2 isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. It’s a reminder that power is everything, and in this universe, you’re either a god or you’re dust. So, grab your chainsword and unleash chaos! This is what it means to be a Space Marine.Remember, if you want to be a hero, you’d better be ready to step into the fire and trust me, it’s glorious!

2022 FromSoftware not only integrated all the different core mechanics that they have created through the years but also added some basic(crouch, jump) and new mechanics(spirit summoning, guard counter) to enhance the core gameplay deeply. If you are new to the FromSoftware's souls formula this game is the most accessible title you can ever get. There were some optimization issues here and there but it wasn't that game-breaking at least for me. Fromsoft's artwork as fine as ever. Sometimes you just stop your companion Torrent and take a look at The Erdtree's greatness and magnificence and you might say "Holy S*** this game looks beautiful" despite the fact that graphical quality has never been FromSoftware's primary concern. Mounted combat is the best one I have ever seen in any game. Torrent can do double jump and this made the mounted combat far more enjoyable than I expected. Although I have to admit sometimes it gets frustrating because some bosses can knock you off from Torrent with one hit. Spirit summoning is fun and all but some bosses are way too hard(Malenia, Godfrey, Radagon,) without summons especially for melee users. They have lots of AoE(Area of Effect) movesets and insane health and stamina pool. Sometimes bosses never stop attacking. If you do use spirit summons you don't feel rewarded(at least in my case) after destroying Malenia with +10 Tear Mimic. Even though the bosses aren't that great I loved their themes that's for sure. Fromsoftware's one of the signatures is the boss themes. Even the ambience music tries to tell you a story. As soon as you entered the Caelid you know you are in a rotted and corrupted place to its very core because of the ambience music. Overall, Elden Ring exceeded its predeccessor and changed the meaning of "open-world" and "difficulty"From Software's magnum opus.Thank you for this beautiful piece of art.

I wish the lore bits in the journal are just descriptive of why and how the characters are what they are instead of some story snippets.

2022 For the first time, I am doing a revised review for a game. Originally, I had given this game a negative review because I felt the cons outweighed the pros. But after patch 1.03 and continuing to play the game, I feel Elden Ring deserves a revised review which I will be giving it a positive score. However, I do have plenty of cons to mention regardless.Graphics:Game is breathtaking to look at. So many moments of me wanting to take a screenshot and enjoy the scenery of it all. Even the 'worst' of places in Elden Ring still looks great, and the visuals are top notch. Out of all the From Software games, they really made this game incredible on the eyes. Absolutely jaw dropping to say the least.Gameplay:Soul games have always been linear and well designed, so I was afraid of how From Software would handle an open world. Gotta say, they did a very excellent job. You can pretty much almost go anywhere you'd like with a few exceptions, and Elden Ring took all previous games before it and placed them all into this one, the best traits anyways. So much variety of builds to go with, a lot of ways to fight, Ashes of War are incredible since they truly spice up combat and the fact you can fight while on horseback is so fun overall. Also every part of the world is filled with something- not a single place is empty. So many secrets, discoveries, unique bosses, and hidden lore that it is brimming. I'm very impressed to say the least.Also which ever employee came up with Spirit Summons, give them a raise. They're a super fun concept and the best solution if you somehow can't (or unwilling) to play online. Fantastic concept and well executed for sure.Difficulty:It's a Souls like, it is going to be hard. While I would even say Elden Ring is the hardest Souls yet, the devs have given people so many ways in approaching a fight. The game rewards players for exploring, getting stronger, finding better weapons or loot, and coming back to a boss to overcome it. While some builds are far superior depending on what you optimize, every build is good enough and so long as you're experienced and patient, the game can be beaten even with a lvl 1 character. It's all about how you go about a fight and learn from your mistakes.NPCs and Quests:Perhaps the most depth of any previous Souls game as well, since there's so many NPCs to interact with, telling a story, having quests, and these ones actually move around the world which impacts the story. Some will be more of a fan favorite than others, but each NPC is well written and I definitely loved their dynamics, including the fact some outright help you in fights you would of otherwise struggled with. Doing and completing their quest lines not only rewards you with loot, but can even lead to changes and some secrets that wouldn't be possible otherwise.Cons:So ... despite Elden Ring is a very good game, great even- there are a lot of issues I have with the game even after patch 1.03 which fixed or improved the problems I had beforehand.Vagueness:To explain, the game gives little to no hints on how to progress certain NPC quests, what they'll do next, where to go at times (apart from main mandatory bosses), key items, very essential items, and so forth. I understand Souls games in the past have held back secrets but because they were linear, it was easy to check every corner and not miss too much. Here? The game is open world and the devs went out of their way to hide a lot of stuff, to the point you WILL need a guide or go into NG+. While I get they want you to replay their game and invest, it isn't properly executed. I know fans will say it rewards players for discovering stuff on their own, but the fact there's no quest markers, completion entries, or anything to let you know who's gone where, it takes me out of the game by a lot since I hate missing stuff.Multiplayer:So this is a big one. I can't seem to co-op with friends, much at all. I can help strangers but if I use a password, game often disconnects me or downright crashes. Then you have people who are cheating often in PvP, using the most meta stuff that makes you die instantly (bleed builds ...) and honestly it doesn't feel like the devs balanced it well at all. The game is amazing in PvE, but PvP? Very unstable and not exactly good. Only plus side is helping those struggling with a boss but that's if the game lets me do so. No other game in my library has this issue with me doing multiplayer.Crashes and Stutters:Game will at times crash or stutter hard. It is at random, and nothing fixes it. I am not too upset due to the fact it isn't often, but when it does happen- it is quite terrible to experience. My graphics card is up to date, newer version, and again no other game in my library (besides infamous Skyrim) has this problem. I personally think they need to do more patches to fix this since so many are facing this issue still.Meta:This game is obsessed with certain builds, as they're very strong and can make the fight trivial even. If you do a bleed build or hyper magic build, you will destroy both PvE and PvP. If you do a strength build, you are hindering yourself sadly as so many enemies are fast, hit harder, and can tank against your heavy hits. Also some Ashes of War are outright broken. Also the meta for this game is very off putting- rather than earning your stuff, you can easily run around collecting upgrades and get your weapon to +9 or even 10 before killing a single boss. I know you don't have to do this, but knowing it's possible makes me wonder why handicap myself and struggle when I can just be overpowered off the start. I'd rather struggle and be forced to like previous games, even if there was cheese-like methods this game has too many opportunities to make you feel you need to be meta to just keep up in PvE and PvP.Conclusion:Game is great, very good I would say. A lot of downsides, with mostly it hiding important information and key items from you, forcing you to scout and possibly become overpowered to just win early. Not exactly the best, but for those who like to do whatever- it does benefit those people since they can just get to level 45, 10+ weapon before fighting the first boss (after the tutorial boss). Game's balance is questionable, and a lot of issues with multiplayer with meta and disconnections / crashes. But otherwise, game is very fun, engaging, has so much content, awesome bosses, and so much variety to the builds if you don't want to be meta. I am giving this a positive score but it was close to still being negative like the first review I did.Still hoping DLC comes out for this game i'm waiting with baited breath!

2022 I had enormous expectations having put a thousand hours into Dark Souls 3 alone. Sadly, ER is tainted by design decisions not fully thought through, and a refusal to question the ideals of a framework first established with Demon’s Souls in 2009, and I ended it wishing I hadn't played it at all (more on this later) - or that Steam would finally add a neutral rating.For context, excluding a discarded run and multiplayer, my completionist and almost entirely guide-free solo run lasted around 150 hours, beating every boss barring Malenia without summons.Let’s open positively: Elden Ring inherits DS3’s DNA, particularly combat: The same crunchy brawls, responsive controls and top-tier animations that characterised DS3, aided by expanded enemy, weapon, and ability variety with magic being more diverse than ever.From’s signature storytelling returns, requiring piecing together environmental details, item descriptions and other vague information to decipher the full picture, avoiding interminable cutscenes or overbearing HUD notifications.The Lands Between is geographically impressive. It fuses aesthetically and mechanically diverse biomes into vertiginously stacked layers, threading interesting discoveries through challenging navigation, aided by a time of day and weather system that adds subtle gameplay changes.So why the thumbs down?DS3 is great because it’s meaningful. It’s an incredible fantasy brawler, but shines with its premise of a cursed world having its blighted existence artificially prolonged by an age of fire unnaturally lengthened by Gwyn and his tragic legacy’s followers. The Ringed City DLC literally warped and smashed the series together until only ash remained at the end of the world and time itself in a manifestation of cosmic decay from a realm prohibited from moving on. Its creatively defiant metacommentary rejected a pop culture engorged on commercialised nostalgia and humanity’s obsession with the past impeding a new, better world being built, using From’s own ludography to show stagnation blocking progress. It had to innovate to avoid hypocrisy, so it repurposed old combat mechanics and weaponry into new rhythms, and tonally shifted from quiet hope in the face of graceful sadness to crushing desperation - not to fix its cursed world, but to euthanise it and start anew instead - while retaining the series’ unrelenting melancholy and heart of gold.ER ignores that. It retroactively invalidates DS3’s message of moving on from an unsustainably tired world by repurposing years of content, and when it does deviate, it does so uncharacteristically clumsily for From. This is why I wish I hadn’t played it: DS3 made me laugh, cry, and stuck in my mind for years, and was ultimately about something bigger than itself - and powerfully resonated for it. ER contradicts DS3’s critique of wheel-spinning by indulging repackaged nostalgia in the same way Disney’s maligned Star Wars trilogy has left people feeling worse towards the franchise than if no new films had been made at all.The story is shockingly conservative, with almost identical plot points, settings, characters, and themes to From’s back catalogue. We again have well-intended rulers cursing the world in an attempt to save it, religious fundamentalists, spurned vengeful offspring, agents of chaos, and a tarnished (now literally!) player enforcing a new world order. The biggest change is a bloated chain of divine command, expanding DS' demigods with Empyrians, Fingers, the Elden Beast, aliens, and cosmic gods, but it brings few new ideas. This is the reanimated corpse of a concluded story that meta-commented on such narrative necromancy, and is immensely disappointing for it. Worse, what little new exists is often explicit and definitive, trading the intriguing mystery of DS’s nebulous motivations and history that still produce seismic theories a decade later, for a story nearly entirely resolvable in a single playthrough.There is a tonal shift from quiet tragedy to bellicose grandeur of divine infighting exploding into total warfare - but if anything interferes with deep emotional investment, it’s unlikeable middle managers arguing over who deserves the office promotion. Conflict between irredeemable villains is a far cry from the turbulent power of DS’s Greek tragedy, particularly in a setting largely morally binary and with a less charismatic cast. Standouts like Rya or Blaidd don't impact like Solaire’s devastating misfortune or Siegward’s surprising nobility. Characters were the emotional core of DS, but are neutered here by worn tropes and the meandering pacing inherent to open worlds.Gameplay is also a missed opportunity. DS3’s combat is great, but Sekiro’s is easily the best ever in a game of its type - yet we’re back to DS3’s unbalanced weapon classes and abilities, inconsistent magic, and same old movesets, lacking Sekiro’s thrilling posture and counters mechanics. Dual wielding, ashes of war and guard counters are small improvements rather than an overhaul that had six years to materialise, and the camera is as bad as ever. Content suffers from repetition too: Dungeons keep cropping, with the same music, bosses and presentation, occupying a huge chunk of a completionist’s playthrough, and the non-dungeon biomes feel interminable as you’re incentivised to be extremely thorough in these needlessly enormous areas in search of equipment, lore, and quests.Quests are as obtuse as everyone’s saying, borderline impossible to complete without guides, a From staple magnified by the overwhelmingly gigantic map diluting quality even further. ER’s first areas are exciting, but fifty hours in become tedious, particularly with the second half’s environments primarily being single-level plains with occasional repeated giant assets.The initially impressive scope grows tiresome in its enormity, and leads to a game that’s harder to balance and populate with unique content, particularly evident in the later difficulty spikes and clearly unfinished areas and encounters, including final bosses that pale in comparison to the thematic or mechanical significance of DS3’s Soul of Cinder and Slave Knight Gael. Bosses are just bad across the board: Most movesets chain four or five attacks together leave you waiting for an opening far longer than actually fighting, and many require specific builds to overcome damage sponges, homogenising combat into a wait - wait - wait - wait - single attack - wait loop. ~150 bosses is too many for From to make each interesting, fair, memorable, or downright enjoyable.ER’s multiplayer is also From’s worst since DS1. Hits can sometimes take over ten seconds to register and disconnects prevail. Reduced summon counts neuters fight clubs, invasions are overly unbalanced and spawns are terrible, and with covenants gone, so too are the emergent player dynamics and roleplay.Finally, ER’s presentation is mixed. Its style is outstanding: Characters are strikingly creative and full of personality, environments are dense with detail, and sound effects are as satisfying as ever, though the music rarely reaches DS3’s heights and is often repeated. But From’s ambition far outpaced their technical capacity: ER is graphically antiquated, but the elephant in the room is the worst shader compilation stutter in years, paired with disappointing framerates, considerable crashing, and cheating aplenty. The stutter single-handedly ruined the first third of my playthrough, dissipating after about 70 hours but never fully resolving, and is bad enough to alone make this review a thumbs down.ER wavers between being a retread of old ideas and a failed attempt at new ones. It's such a missed opportunity. If all you want is killing enemies in brutal combat, it’s great - the DS template alone earns ER inherited praise - but if you’re after an emotionally and philosophically challenging story, pick up DS instead.★★★☆☆

First off, this game has been an absolute joy to play. The story missions are fantastic, and the cinematics really enhance the experience. The way the operations work in tandem with the missions is also impressive. I highly recommend tackling the story missions in order with the operations; doing all the operations first can spoil the storyline.I’ve maxed out two classes and can comfortably handle the hardest difficulty with ease. While the PvP aspect is a bit slow-paced by design and I haven’t invested many hours into it, it hasn’t been particularly engaging.Unfortunately, I’m nearing the end of my time with the game, aside from maxing out a few more classes and helping friends. I really hope they add another couple of difficulties beyond the upcoming lethal mode, as well as some extra challenging enemies during missions. I wish I could experience the first 15 hours of the game again.Replayability is somewhat lacking due to the limited number of operations and the absence of significant challenges once you reach level 15 on any class. The excitement starts to wane after completing the story and operations.It’s also disappointing that the horde mode isn’t coming until 2025. However, I would definitely recommend this game. Just don’t expect it to be a staple in your gaming routine; once you’ve completed the story and operations, there isn’t much left to keep you engaged.Overall, I’d give it a 9/10. ❤️

Product received for free I got this game for free as a promotion with a graphics card I bought, I hadn't watched any trailers for it and never really looked into it. I went in with no expectations or hype whatsoever, and frankly I don't get it.The game has terrible level design, you are bound to hit an invisible wall (even if the place you are trying to reach is part of the level, sometimes there's just an invisible wall to prevent you from going there from a specific angle for some reasons) no matter where you go, the paths are also not intuitive, I was actually going around the level trying to find what I had missed only to find out that there was a small gap to crawl in to progress hidden inside a cave, there was nothing to tell me this was there, I found it by pure chance, the combination of the invisible walls, non-intuitive levels and the lack of a map to find those paths on makes exploring very frustrating.The combat feels wrong, sometimes you do an input mid-roll and the character does the move related to that input right after the roll, and sometimes he does not, heavy attacks have ridiculous delay to them which makes them feel terrible to use. In some fights, you could start a heavy attack before the boss starts his attack and get punished anyway. You barely do any damage to bosses and kill regular enemies way too easily, which makes the bosses the only actual challenge, well except for actually finding them, unfortunately the bosses have terrible arena designs and sometimes attack fast enough to get you with a follow-up attack right after your dodge. The story relies way too much on the base material, if you have not read the book, none of it makes sense.The game does look pretty, but if its not fun then why would I play it.

2023 It’s a sad day when I have to write this review. TWWH is, in my very humble opinion, the best strategy game/trilogy of all time. There are grander strategies, I.E. the paradox titles, and there are more accessible titles, I.E. the Civ series. But no game does it quite like this one. Let me get my thoughts out the way, and then I’ll explain why I can’t recommend the game, although I’m sure you’ve already heard, despite me loving this title so dearly. Let’s start by saying, this is a good game. Phenomenal even. At it’s core, it’s in every sense of the word, fun. It can be brutally challenging, but is far more accessible than many of the paradox titles for example. I’ve dipped in and out of a range of strategy games (not just on steam, but Epic, GoG and growing up playing CD copies of games I still own to this day), and generally speaking, I love the genre. I grew up playing Age of Empires and Warcraft 3 before moving away from RTS games in favour of more 4X style games. Eventually moving onto grand strategy such as Total War. And let me tell you what a blast this has been. I adore this game, I’ve spent many nights up until 5/6am, just playing “one more turn!” And being late for work the following morning because I was so tired I just overslept. I’ve sat watching videos on my lunch breaks from Legend and General, I’ve fallen asleep to Total war streams, having it consume my life for a period of time. And I don’t regret a single second of it. I’ve bought copies of it full price for my friends to play so I can share that experience with others and bring them into this community. And I mention this because despite my low playtime, I genuinely love this game, and even when I’m not playing it, I’m consuming it in whatever ways I can, or being that annoying friend who pushes you to do the same. But why? Why do I think so highly of it? Well there’s just no experience quite like it. It’s easy to learn, hard to master. Despite what perceptions of it are, it’s incredibly easy to pick up and play, even if it’s a little confusing at first. The in game tutorial does a really excellent job of just teaching you the core of what you need to know, and the rest of it you’ll pick up as you play. Unlike a paradox game, it doesn’t feel like you need a YouTube guide open as mandatory training while you play (although I suppose that subjective based on skill and patience). All my research and external work has been because I’m invested and the game is so good, that it incentivises you to learn, not because it’s too complicated for it’s own good, but just because I want to improve and get better on my own terms. And unlike more casual games like Civ, where after a campaign or two, you just go through the motions, you actually have to keep atleast a small part of your brain switched on. Even at lower difficulties, you will get smashed by what can often feel like incredibly unfair AI. The game actually ends up almost feeling rogue like in nature, you play 20 turns, realise you messed up at turn 15, and then start again, using the knowledge you gained to progress further, this time getting to turn 40 and realising you made a mistake or didn’t account for something on turn 35 and repeating. It’s an incredible loop that never gets dull or boring based simply on the fact that every faction plays so uniquely to each other. From Skarbrand’s all out blitzkrieg on anything In sight, to my new personal favourite, Empire campaigns, where you slowly build up and out, playing politics and managing multiple states of affairs. I firmly believe there is a faction for anyone and everyone, and you WILL find something or someone you like in this game. I’m going to brush over gameplay and such, because I won’t lie, it’s great. As the ancient Chinese say, “It Just Works”. The overworld map is basically a relatively simple 4x style game. You have cities, ruins, towns etc, various sizes locations you can colonise to control regions, before setting out and conquering or politicking your way into others. There’s not much to say to it. It’s big, it’s fun, it’s a paint the map in your colour type of ordeal that isn’t particularly unique to this game. And then there’s the battles, where the game just blows you away. Hundreds and later at times thousands of individual units, all modelled and animated smashing into each other in the RTS style battles. You can watch as a giant T-Rex smashes it’s way through tiny little nurglings, small creatures that clump together to make large monstrosities, all while your massive great unclean one charges into ranks of lizardmen before tactically chundering and excreting all over them. It’s phenomenal and if you’re the type of person to watch AI battles on YouTube, you’ll absolutely adore it. Hundreds of battle maps, hundreds of unique units, with thousands of animations (I’m sorry I didn’t count each one but there’s a lot!). It’s immense in scale and spectacle in a way no other franchise can really rival. And most importantly, it’s fun! Winning feels great, but losing doesn’t feel bad when you watched as packs of rat men slowly swarm your empire city, each man holding the line as best they can, faith and steel binding them. It’s exciting and gorgeous. I’ve never enjoyed getting my ass handed to me so much. But onto why I can’t recommend the game. Two reasons, with one being an ongoing issue in the state of DLC, and the other being the recent actions by the developer. DLC for this game is kind of egregious. There’s going to be people who say, just buy the ones you want, but I’m not a huge fan of that mentality. The main draw of these games specifically is the immortal empires map, where all the factions across all three games play on one unified map. It’s huge, and really brings the grand into grand strategy. It’s a spectacle and genuinely an incredible feat, with 200+ factions on the map. However, of the around 80 playable lords, buying Warhammer 3 alone, only gives you access to around 15/20, which is a lot of gameplay don’t get me wrong, but with around half of those being chaos themed, and the rest being a take your pick between Slavic stew or ancient Asian hotpot, there’s not all that much variety in terms of visuals and aesthetic. To get the full experience and have the choice of playing whatever you want, you need to pay out hundreds of pounds just to get every dlc and every game and then every dlc for those games. It’s just all a bit much. It’s something total war fans have put up with, and it’s something I’ve financially supported due to having the disposable income and enjoying the games. However as a new player, imagine looking at the game thinking, I just want the complete experience, access to everything that’s in the game and finding out you’ll have to spend well over £200 just to have the option to play a race. And it’s not like you can try the races either, there’s no demo, and with campaigns lasting anywhere from 10 to 60 hours, you can’t try them and then just refund realistically. It’s something I looked past for a long time, but with recent events, I just can’t support this model anymore. And those recent events. You’ve heard about them, there’s a reason everyone is reviewing this negatively. Creative Assembly is now forcing unwarranted price increases on these already quite minimal DLCs. £20 (a third of the price of the game might I add) for three lords, no one was particularly excited or asking for, with very few additions other than that no real new units with issues coming with the ones they did add, serious bugs that they still refuse to fix or just ignore, and a frankly, quite disgusting response to fan criticism and feedback, vaguely threatening to cut support for the game should fans choose not to pay for the dlc. This is a company who’s revenue has increased by 20% over the last year, who release updates at a speed that it would be generous to call slow, all while claiming that they need to do this to keep up with the market

Excellent strategy and the simultaneous team play is a marked improvement from earlier versions, especially for combined assaults. I enjoy the huge map and the fact that the computer factions have varying results from their interactions making a new dynamic each time I play; will the high elves be eliminated before I meet them, or will they expand instead? I will try this game again in the future, but I have submitted a refund request for the time being. The game stutters frequently, and is especially bad with audio, mostly in cut scenes. I look forward to getting it again in the future once it has been more optimized, as the game play itself is very fun and satisfying, and the story and concept are very appealing. ALL OPINIONS ARE BASED ON ANGEL OF DEATH DIFFICULTY PLAYED SOLO. THEY MAY NOT BE ISSUES ON LOWER DIFFICULTIES This is a good game, a game with alot of issues but I do recommend it if you are even slightly interested in WH40KCombat is pretty good, the parry system can sometimes have issues if multiple parries come up. If you time one right but then another pops up it seems to cancel it sometimes and you get hit when you were not even trying to parry the 2nd attack. The dodge always seems to work, but the problem is this game has some really wonky hitboxes so you will get hit dodging and wonder what even hit you (espicaly with bosses oh god its bad with bosses) where they have invisible hitboxes that will hit you even if you arn't even close. The Carnifex was the worst for this but its manageable.The healing system is awful on Angel of Death, the melee to restore health becomes pointless because you take so much damage you never get any back with all the enemies jumping at you. And health injectors are so rare, for many sections of the game its laughable. Your fury mode becomes the main option for healing, where you want to avoid combat and stand there and recharge but it feels counter intuitive to what it was actually meant forThe guns feel great but they sound really, really weak. I don't know if its a mixing issue or something but they lack any real oomph to them and bolters sound more like you are firing a semi automatic pistol or something and it kinda sucks, but gameplay wise I found myself using almost all the weapons at one point or another and getting results with them. Which leads to alot of experimentation and exploring the systems which is really good.There are some major bugs, some levels glitch out and you cant pickup guns or items(looking at you cargo elevator) and also sometimes the AI totally bugs out and will just refuse to rez you, they will walk towards you then get distracted and run back and forth while your meter ticks down and its infuriating. Sometimes the AI just totally loses it and will just stand still and do nothing for large periods of time. Also randomly when Acheran was giving his speech in the hanger I walked up to watch it and a space marine came up behind me and trapped me and I had to reload the entire game because I got stuck which was really random.The game falls into the trap difficulty wise what alot of games do, which is just turning things into bullet sponges that do alot of damage as opposed to real difficulty. Ghost of Tsushima mastered this, and honestly on Angel of Death if they just lowered the health pools on some enemies and kept literally everything else the same it would be way more tolerable and actually fun. Having to put 4 clips from a bolter run to get a full reload and then another couple clips into a Zoanthrope to just get it to go down becomes a point of hilarity. Although this is remedied by just having Krak grenades(which the game seems to keep forgetting you have because grenade pickups basically become extinct in the certain parts of the game)The campaign at times becomes kind of a slog when many of the major set pieces s just stand here, and do the thing that prevents meter in the top corner from going down/up. Its distracting having to watch the meter while you want to actually look at whats going on, on the screen and annoying because it feels uninspired after you do it for like the 6th time.Now all my complaints I had though, are entirely remedied with the sections of the game with the jetpacks. I honestly think they should of just built the entire game as Assault Troops because it feels amazing. The quick movement to escape hordes, jumping in and out of melee, picking off enemies in the air. It feels like thats how the game should be played. It almost turns into a doom-esque with how fast paced it becomes and its glorious. The pvp is also fantastic and I think if they keep updating with maps and unlockables it has a real leg to stand on.Games like a solid 7.5 maybe 8/10 because I am a biased fan

2022 A fantastic game FromSoftware, probably the best game they've ever made alongside Bloodborne. While the gameplay formula mainly stays the same, they expanded exponentially on the world you get to play in,Unlike other Souls-like games where your options against a challenge are fairly limited such as farming up or become really good at reading a boss's movements, Elden Ring provides you with a plethora of options. You can explore the world and find new weapons, level up up, buy or find several unique items some of which are made to work against bosses like kryptonite.All in all, it's quite accessible more so than before so there's a lot to love here.That doesn't mean the game has become easy...oh no...It probably holds the largest amount of bosses in any games ever released. They're just staggering, with some of them being unique as well as recurring ones. While they do recycle a few, I have to say it doesn't take much from the experience as it gives you the feeling of growing and becoming more experienced showing that your struggle and effort was well worth your time.The items and weapons as well as magic gives so many options for so many builds and things to mess around with.You can now re-edit your character in case there's something you don't like about it as well as resetting your abilities in case you want to try out different builds. This addition was great and it doesn't mean you have to remake a different character just in case you want to try something different.The map is huge, enormous even and in any direction you will go, you will stumble upon something interesting. Those things can be either a quest, collectable crafting items, various dungeons, enemies, portals, weapons and merchants.I can't put my finger on it but this game truly has something special going for it. There are some downsides I'd like to mention that I wish they were different.First off...while, for the most part, the start of the game as well as the mid-game feels fun, challenging and everything you do is rewarding, the later parts of the game become absurdly difficult in a not-fun way.Vigor is a stat in the game and it's quite important unlike Bloodborne for instance. While Elden Ring provides you with fast moving abilities and spells, it still doesn't match Bloodborne speed....This means that the chances of getting hit are quite high unless you're going out with a shield. The thing is, enemies late game will one - two shot you and it'll make you feel that the effort you've put in the game was for naught.... it's not too bad but it's surely not fun. The exaggerated difficulty spike could've been reduced a little bit by maybe 15-20%. While the bosses are super cool, I found issues with the camera sometimes. Not too big but there are some large bosses that love to fly across your screen. The Lock On system is useless in such situations since it will mess you up. I wished they would innovate this part just a bit and take some risks such as zooming the camera out a bit.The PVP of the game is....not so good....broken builds, 1 shot, cheesing, cheating, the list goes on. You'll either love it and have a huge fun with it or...not care about that at all unless you're invaded while playing co-op. The likeness of this mode depends on the player. I don't mind that it's there, in fact it's good that it's there, it's just not for everyone. And the last negative I have to say isss....the story.It's...huge...complex, dark fantasy...but not too special. Bloodborne rocks that front...Dark Souls 3 too.And that's it... Elden Ring is a masterpiece of a game. It's not perfect, it has its flaws but the game's unique, it brings something new to the table and it'll be remembered.

2014 CSGO is a near-perfect multiplayer shooter. Unlike the previous versions, which were often difficult to get in to, this one offers a variety of modes that will appeal to all skill levels. It has a large community and a well supported workshop, ensuring that this discount-priced game will be around for years to come.In short, you either play as the good or bad guys and must either kill the other team or complete objectives to win the round, which will earn you more money to do the same thing again but faster. It's been around for years and has spawned many imitators.The game isn't much of a looker as it is based on the same engine as the original Half Life 2 was. However, Valve have polished it as much as they can and the community consists of lots of awesome mappers who have been churning out brilliantly imaginative and beautiful maps almost on a daily basis.Is it worth getting if you already own Counter Strike: Source? Yes. CSS was always Counter Strike shoe-horned into the Source engine. CSGO feels far more like a standalone game. Valve have very carefully listened to what people have wanted and have made a very appealing game. The best feature must be the competitive play. You cannot leave these matches or you'll suffer a temporary ban from the feature. After 10 wins in this mode you'll be ranked and will be paired up with people of the same skill, meaning that the game is challenging but fair regardless of your skill level. These matches are exciting, occasionally scary or frustrating, but are the most rewarding part of the game and improving your rank is one of the most satisfying experiences in any video game, ever.

What an incredible game. I haven’t felt the want to finish a game that badly in a long time; and do as many of the achievements and things I can along the way. The combat feels great once you understand how to use the different stances together, along with spells and spirits. The story is amazing, and makes me want to watch the 1986 show and listen to the audiobook to really understand everything. That being said, Chapter 6, and one other boss in Chapter 4 are not great. The Scorpionlord, a secret boss in chapter 4, along with the first and the final bosses of the Chapter 6, just feel very unfun. There’s a lot of flying and moving and the game takes what you’ve learned through the entire game and throws it all away and even punishes you for it. Along with that, Chapter 6 feels very unfleshed and is the first instance where you see copy/paste bosses (because they are literally the same), granted they are mini bosses. In any case, I still loved this game and my time with it. I plan on going through and doing at least NG+, as there are a couple missables and I don’t think I’m that tired of the game just yet.I’d rate this a solid 8.5 or 9 out of 10 for me. Incredible, fantastic, fair (except for a few instances), thrilling, and length feels great. I am excited for a future DLC!

2022 Elden Ring is an open world game set in a world ruled by demigods and populated with beautiful environments and structures, allowing for players to traverse the Lands Between, discovering secrets, engaging in battles, and mayhap get some maidens.There are some problems with the low fps being capped at 60 for PC users but there are solutions on the internet that can help rectify this issue, in addition there is also some fps stuttering at times, it can be annoying but other than that the game is still very much playable. But with that said let us get into what I think is great and what I dislike about Elden Ring.-Enemies-Bosses:The bosses are fantastic looking and have some fantastic flashy move sets, however most of the main bosses have attacks that are too fast to be dodged, insanely long combos, always have some sort of AOE attack, and always keep moving making them hard to hit with melee weapons. Malekith the black blade fits in most of these points vie stated, having ranged abilities, difficult to dodge attacks due to his wide range of attack also making it hard to run away to heal, and a DOT (damage over time) after being hit with his blade. And this trend continues for most of the bosses, making them quite unfun.Giant bosses:Giant bosses are also quite hard to battle against, it's hard to see when they are going to attack IF you’re using melee due to you needing to be up-close to the boss.Duo bosses:Duo bosses are not too fun to fight, considering that they can kill you within 2-4 hits and you now must focus your attention on 2 enemies which considerably increases the difficulty in a cheap way.Enemies:The enemies in this game are fantastic with a wide variety of epic designs making the world feel populated, however some of them are made to be quite annoying, the Rotten Stray constantly staggering you, the Lesser Kindred of Rot with their spammable ranged attack, the Bladed Talon Eagle being hard to hit for melee users and so on.Dungeons:The dungeons are fun areas to explore, containing resources that can help the player out by giving them better weapons or useful materials. However, some of the dungeons have bosses that are too large for the area it is placed in, mostly referring to the Tree Spirit enemies. Fighting in these small rooms is extremely difficult due to the combination of your third person camera, a large boss and a small room, making it quite a challenge to know what is going on, not to mention the AOE attacks this boss has that basically reach the entire room.Too long didn’t read:Bosses are too quick with too many AOE attacks to avoid, a handful of enemies are annoying to fight against, duo bosses are hard to fight without summons but possible, hard to keep track of when giant boss will attack, small areas with big bosses are hard to fight against.-Gameplay-World:The world of Elden Ring is fantastic, not needing to always rush head in towards a boss first, you can always explore and grind levels, get better equipment before trying to battle the bosses, in addition to better equipment, you can also use summons which dramatically makes the fight easier.Combat:The combat in this game is decent, having many different attacks, light attack, heavy attack, rolling light, rolling heavy, jump light, jump heavy, sprinting heavy, sprinting light, guard counter, block, parry, and unique weapon skills that can be applied to each weapon. You can also switch between two handing and one handing weapons as well as dual wielding weapons of the same type as well as mounted combat. There is also the introduction of the stance/posture system. If you are familiar with Sekiro, it is like the posture system. After hitting the enemies enough, it will cause them to stance break and leave them susceptible to critical hits, this is also applicable for bosses too. Some attacks will cause more stance damage than others such as jumping heavy attacks, counter hits and charged heavy attacks.Rolling is a little different in this game, rather than rolling on pressing the button, you roll when the button is released.Runes:Runes from bosses and enemies are a little low. The rune scaling also does not improve much for enemies when you progress to more difficult areas, but bosses do drop more runes. And the runes you get from bosses and enemies are increased permanently after NG+ as well.But aside from all these issues this game is exceptional, one of the best Maiden Pick up simulators I've ever played, a solid 9/10, definitely would recommend to anyone who wants to get into the Souls-like franchise or anyone who is a masochist.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Despite the fact that the review is positive, for me it's more of a "yellow" type of review (which I hope they will eventually add to Steam, though I’m starting to doubt it). The game looks expensive and polished, it's a good, not overly long action game set in the Warhammer universe, with excellent cutscene direction and beautiful visuals. The combat looks epic, and the gameplay on a gamepad is really well done. The joystick vibrates and even reacts to walking, giving the character in the Space Marine suit a sense of "weight." Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo However, that's where the positives end for me. Here's what really bothered me. First, the combat feels quite repetitive. While smashing enemies is fun in the first few hours, it quickly gets stale and stops being enjoyable. Moreover, I noticed that the difficulty seems a bit broken because on higher difficulty levels, combat turns into an unpleasant mess. You have to constantly spam parries, and even then, enemies will still flank you and "make your life miserable." But if you lower the difficulty just one notch, the game becomes too easy and uninteresting. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo The variety of enemies is small, and they're pretty dull, requiring no special tactics to defeat. The multiplayer PvP mode, by the way, is terrible - I didn't like it at all, and I don't recommend it. It feels like it's just there for the sake of it.The special operations that run parallel to the story can be considered a positive aspect, as they let you try out different Space Marine classes and include some progression. However, they don't add much depth to the game, though they do make it a bit better. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo For fans of the Warhammer universe or those who just want to switch off their brain and enjoy some action and shooting for a couple of evenings, I would recommend it. But it's best not to have high expectations, as they got in the way for me.

Warhammer 40K: Space Marine 2 at launch is a "good" video game that feels and looks very "bad ass" while playing it but it's also held back pretty hard in my opinion because of feeling very repetitive with gameplay that never really evolves from the first mission to the last. The game has a decent story (singleplayer or co-op) mode, good (co-op) operations and a PVP mode (which is surprisingly good) but the game at launch is missing simple modes like a survival/horde mode which feels like a no brainer for this sort of game so I can't help but feel a little bit disappointed that it's missing (among other things..)It also has some design problems in my opinion when it comes to the shield regenerator "execute enemy" system as it makes you compete with your own team mates in co-op about getting health back (if you played it you know what I'm talking about) which doesn't feel intended (but a lot more like a design flaw in the combat and health system)The 6 operations you replay over and over again at launch are not enough.So to keep it (somewhat) short.. As of right now (with the launch content) I'd give it a solid 7.5/10 but it can and likely will easily go up to a 8 or even a 9 with future content. I will definitely play more of the operations and PVP mode but for how much longer I don't know.

Black Myth: Wukong completely exceeded my expectations. Right from the start, the combat feels sharp and responsive, rewarding both timing and strategy. The variety of environments is staggering—each one is beautifully designed, with its own atmosphere and challenges, keeping the game feeling fresh as you move through different stages. And the boss fights? There are over 90 of them, and they aren’t just there to pad out the game. Each boss is unique and demands real attention, forcing you to adapt and perfect your approach.The skill tree is another standout feature. It’s not just there to unlock a few flashy moves—there's real depth to it. You can build your character in so many different ways, whether you want to focus on raw power, agility, or more technical skills. I loved being able to fine-tune my abilities to fit my playstyle, which made every fight feel different, even after hours of gameplay.Overall, the game kept me completely hooked. It balances challenge and reward perfectly, never feeling unfair but always pushing you to get better. If you're into action RPGs and love the feeling of mastering a complex system, Black Myth: Wukong is an experience you won't want to miss.

2022 Updated Review:I came back to this game after 9 months and overall I am mildly impressed with the changes. While the game still runs like a turd on my 11700K and RTX 3070 PC, it no longer crashes and there's a lot less bugs, none of which are game-breaking (so far). Plus your mouse now works in 2k/4k fullscreen mode, though I am not sure if they fixed legacy Xbox avatars crashing servers though.They've even improved the interface in a lot of key ways. Once again red means something is being destroyed and green means something is being built on the city screen. Gone are the days of every UI element being red for the heck of it. And, while Immortal Empires is lacking in its beta form, it is there, playable, and fun.If it only ran well I would be extremely impressed. As it is, mildly impressed and I will say it is now worth buying on sale.Old Review:Come back in half a year. Game runs poorly despite hardware that drastically exceeds the recommended spec. If you're on 1440p+ your mouse probably won't work properly in fullscreen mode and windowed mode won't support your resolution so you'll have to play the game in a window that doesn't fill your screen. Then when you actually get to play you'll notice the bugs. Bugs everywhere, terrible performance, if you're on Xbox and have a legacy 360 avatar (mine was a Daedra from Oblivion), it will crash any multiplayer lobby you join as the game can't load legacy Xbox avatars lol. The UI is ugly in general, everything is red so you can't even tell if you're building or destroying something at a glance, and it has its own bugs too—but PCGamer gave the game a 90 and IGN gave it 9/10 so whatever, I'm glad critics enjoy a barely functional game with a staggeringly ugly interface.

2016 Since the dawn of time, I have lost hope in fps games and life itself generally because of milked franchises. The sky had no color, food had no flavor. After playing this truly amazing life-altering of a game, I can honestly say I'm a changed man. CS GO has captured my imagination and took me into my unknown sub-conscious. This game has made a profound impact to me. Never before I felt like ripping another human beings head off. Uninstalling, reinstalling became a daily routine for the millionth time because of clueless teammates and their "cool skins" (I guess skin > skill matters more).I feel like everyone needs to play this game at least acouple of times because the thrill of clutching, fragging, etc is unlike anything I've experienced. It takes me back to the good old CoD4/ Gears of War/ Battlefield days, having clan battles either GB or underground rules blah blah blah. A true fps that is fun for all ages! For the casual players, you can just have fun with mods and for the competitive, you will def enjoy this. From the "your mom" 12yr old squeakers to the maturest people. This community is toxic as you'd expect, but from the smurf and hackers, you'll either quit or keep on trying.

2022 It's amazing. It's everything you've heard. It's open world Dark Souls. Please play this game.However.... I'm quitting before the end. Here's why, as briefly as I can put it:It's too hard. Not like, oh it's challenging git gud. It's too hard as in, the bosses towards end game (even some of the regular enemies) rely on exceedingly long combos WITH AoE's that will kill you in 1-2 shots. Many feel cheap, rather than challenging. Not QUITE Bed of Chaos cheap, but pretty close. I'm feeling like when I die, I didn't cheat the system or find the right cheese rather than build any skill for the next fight. 2016 Valve turned this game into a sausage fest... with hats.Currently, the game has taken on a F2P/P2W grind-to-collect rare items, playtime incentive system, which gives the game a cheap social-media-tool feel. The 'hat system' is a clear indication that it is time to move on, some 15 years after the creation of the original, and break free of the stale CS formula. Bring something new and engaging to the table... please leave your hats at home.(This game was decent when first it came out and a year or so after - it was a blast teaming up with randoms and making friends to play competitive. 2023 I'm writing this review because CA has gone back to warhammer 1 level of incompetence on this one. I loved Warhammer 1, loved Warhammer 2 much, much more. I had the highest of hopes for Warhammer 3, but so far CA did not provide. The game is stagnant, Warhammer 2 was a constant path of improvement, which, admittedly, did come out as a fairly bad game. The difference however is in the urgency of CA's actions. In Warhammer 2 they released content that was good and did it fast (while also charging reasonable prices for dlcs), Mortal Empires came out much sooner than Immortal Empires. In Warhammer 3 it's been like 1.5 year since launch and the game is very similar to the game at launch. They provided less, improved less and yet charge more while also removing free content. I will change my if at any point I feel like the game has come back on track, but so far I feel like I'm back in Warhammer 1 which I stopped playing after the ridiculous dlcs that were "The Realm of the Wood Elves" and "the Call of the Beastmen" dlc, which were overpriced (and yet, still cheaper than the new "just lords" dlc). When it comes to pricing, just look at the dlc tab, recognize there ain't no more free stuff, and acknowledge the game is rarely getting updates, so it's in a somewhat lackluster state when you realize what it should be at this point

Essentially, I went into this game not knowing what to expect. Be advised, many will cry and complain, disagreeing with my review, but it is 100% honest, and factual. This game offers some of the most fun I have ever had, however I cannot recommend this game to anyone, as it is deceptive. You could spend hundreds of hours grinding, farming, upgrading, collecting Deviants, and it is all for nothing. Apparently at every new season much of what you've worked for, will be removed, Deviants being one of the major ones. Had I known this, I would have never started playing the game. It's as if they're teasing the player or punishing them with that type of system wipe. Most people cannot play games 24/7, and many do not want to farm the same deviants or items over and over again and continue losing them every season. This game has alot of potential, but this is an extreme turn off, and believe me I'm not the only one who feels this way. The combat and harvesting/building bugs are the least of my worries, I accept that all games have bugs, and yes Server lag. I never wanted to leave a review such as this, for a game I loved with a passion starting out. To those involved with this game, production, creation and inception, Starry Studio, NetEase Games, Exptional Global, you're just plain wrong for this. I spent over $100 on the game via microtransactions because I felt you cared about your players, and were offering a solid product. I'm not angry, enjoy the money, you need it far more than I do.

2023 EDIT: The overtures made with the Shadows of Change update patch are a nontrivial step in the right direction. The community letter preceding it certainly *sounded* like it was coming from the right place, but the amount of content offered as a free update feels like a commensurate material change for a studio looking to truly change direction. As it stands now, I'm downgrading my outright concern to wariness, but I'm hopeful for where development is headed at this point.See below for my previous concerns.-----------------------------------------------"The right to discuss is a privilege"I normally don't like getting involved in dev drama, but so it goes. The price increase for the DLC didn't bother me at all, but the dev response to recent criticism indicates a level of delusion that doesn't bode well for any aspect of CA's work (development, community engagement, etc.). I've been a huge fan of the TWW series, but I don't know that I will make any future purchases unless there is a clear change in direction.

2015 I've played CS.GO for a thousand hours plus. I think, I've clocked in a decent number of hours to offer genuine and reliable thoughts/insights/feedback of the game. If there had to be reasons why i would not recommend this game, it would be for two reasons.Firstly, I have to say that the CS.GO community is horrible. People show no signs of mercy to those who are new (Including myself at times). There are plenty of rude people. Of course i've met really nice people who respect one another but that is just a small minority. Too many people kicking out starters from casual matches for being noob ( not forgetting many times people kick out random players to allow friends to enter the match) and many times sore losers who constantly restart the match just because they died/didnt get a kill/for fun.Secondly, the number of hackers and smurfs that are present now. These people are spoiling the game for those who enjoy some casual FPS and also in competitive mode. Especially for smurfs, I know of many who wish to rank up higher in competitive but simply cant due to the number of smurfs who are actively cockblocking them. And as for hackers, there are those who use it for personal glory or to use it to sell people ranking up services. These people are simply a real pain to the CS.GO community. Need I say more?CS.GO, honestly, is good fun. I do love CS.GO. I have spent many good hours with friends, meeting new people and killing chickens. However the harsh reality of the CS.GO is simply cruel and merciless with people constantly yelling at you and telling you that you're no good, along with a good bunch of hackers/smurfs who ruins your gaming experience.If you cant handle the harshness of the CS.GO community, dont start playing it. However if you choose to enter the CS.GO world alone, good luck. I hope you meet a few reliable and friendly comrades.Until Valve finds a way to counter the problem is hackers and smurfs (especially in competitive mode), I will not recommend it. (Suggestion to counter smurfs: If the IP address has been in a CS.GO server before, he/she will not be allowed to play in the same pool of players in competitive mode.)EDIT: Valve's implementation of having 24 hours cooldown after every 2 wins for fresh competitive accounts is a great effort in slowly down smurfs and catching hackers via overwatch, however i think a more full proof method would be required after once they reached 10 wins.ADDITIONAL NOTE: To the few who have disagreed with my review because 'It's the community you're unhappy about, not the game', here's what i have to say. I strongly believe for a game like CS.GO (in fact any game with multiplayer funtionalities), community is a very large contributing factor if the game is good or not. It is the community that makes the game whole and who it is, especially for a game like CS.GO. I highly doubt people buy CS.GO to play offline mode/bot matches.Though I understand your point of view, and that i should be reviewing the game base on its mechanisms/funtionalities like movement/gun bullet mechanics/matchmaking. However for my review, my aim is to offer my readers a deeper insight to the game than just what you see it on the surface/trailers.At first you might feel that the community doesnt affect you at all, however once you get into the game, i believe you'll change your opinion. If you still disagree, I think its either you havent been exposed enough or you're just darn lucky meeting really nice and legitimate players in your matches. @Shadowdance You're welcome. You gave me the push to write this reply.Cheers fellow comrades.

Servers are not based on players online but on characters created on a server from unique Steam accounts. The devs refuse to kick characters off a server even if they've been inactive for weeks. Because of this, if your friends had a head start on a server, you most likely wouldn't be able to join them because it's permanently full of offline randoms. Joining another server restarts your hard-earned hours of progress, and the server reset time is six weeks. Don't play this game with multiplayer in mind if you don't want to be sorely disappointed.

A fantastic follow up to Titus's Story from the first game, with many fun callbacks. It's a classic Warhammer 40.000 story that is easily digestible even for newcomers with gameplay so finely and tightly crafted that I still catch myself getting giddy at the gory spectacle even after 80 hours. A very ambitious, refreshing action-RPG that focuses on cinematic action and hyper dynamic combat while doing away with the usual open world fluff that has gotten way out of control since the mid 2010's.Its a little linear, cut in straightforward chapters and contained areas, almost in a retro / nostalgic way, but it really doesn't miss a beat thanks to stunning, epic cutscenes and frenetic, unique boss fights, constantly pushing the player forwards through the chapters, yearning for more. Sometimes pushing a little too far ahead, to the detriment of the story while at other times offering up some incredible characters and lore along with touching moments... And lots of research to do on Journey to the West and Chinese mythology.Combat is speedy and dynamic although quite precise and usually pretty clean / readable. It sometimes turns messy because of weird camera movements and even weirder hitboxes. A somewhat uneven localisation (at least in English) and a frustrating amount of invisible walls. Definitely old-school .It's spent a long time cooking and ultimately feels like a great first step in Chinese AAA gaming.

2022 In a few words: Amazing, but in moderation.Elden Ring - the latest From Soft entry - entered the gaming scene with one of the biggest hype trains ever seen. Now that the dust has settled at the station, we can mostly agree that the game has definitely lived up to that hype; albeit with a few small caveat. But first, the great: The game is wonderfully illustrated, both with the world building and its inhabitants' design: from the detailed local flora to gigantic enemies, they all feel unique and alive. It is almost guaranteed that players would stop in awe of the surroundings every now and then just to take in the world's grandeur.The NPCs that one meets along their journey also feel very colorfully animated and dynamic, most of which has a semi-hidden questline that the player can follow - as is the tradition of From Soft's games. However do be careful that some of these characters' questlines are either very easy to miss or to be messed up.A bigger world also means a much bigger variety in how the player can build their character. Weapons are definitely the strong suit of the game with one hidden in every nook and canny of the world, awaiting adventurous players seeking off the beaten path. And the special effects of weapons, spells, incantations... in the game feels extremely beautiful and in a way, badass. And now, the the not so good: While beautiful, the game on PC does suffer from performance issues like most From Soft ports to the PC. Patches have been released to iron out major problems but some remain. Most serious for me personally were the random crashes.Enemies do feel unique and boss fights are quite epic, but it is rather unavoidable that a game world of this scale will eventually have to resort to reusing enemies and bosses: turning bosses from early game to later game common enemies and vice versa. Though it does not ruin the experience as a whole, it does a get a little repetitive to see the biome changes but not the enemies we face.This game also has serious balancing issues with most of the later game contents being way overtuned, forcing players to invest heavily into HP in order to just survive from being one-shotted. Some bosses, ahem Malenia, feels very frustrating to fight against due to unfair and unfun mechanic. Some spells that the player can utilize also feels very broken turning some parts of the game a cake walk - but I do tend to stay away from such spells.And finally, with such a size, I do occasionally feel burnt out exploring the world's vastness. And the no hand-holding policy along with intentional vagueness in these games can disorient and discourage newer players from adventuring about. Hence, I found the game most enjoyable in short bursts rather than doing long playthroughs at a time. All in all: The game is great, despite some flaws. It takes all the goodness from previous Soulsbornesekiro titles and mash them together in an open world frame: an unforgettable dish that die-hard and new fans will definitely enjoy.

Give it a chance if you aren't used to this type of gamed.FromSoftware never fails to deliver with the quality of their games. The amount of though that goes into creating the background stories and the environments of this game is unrivalled. This is one of the finest open world games to ever be made. You may be familiar with the classic open world games that studios like ubisoft is making now, go here do this. go there do that. This game is not like that. Exploring is one of the best things about this game and it truly feels rewarding. This game is full of content not just filler. There are so many unique situations that are wonderful. From enemies to friendly npcs and their stories and to weapons there is a huge variety of content. Heck I'm 95 hours in and I havn't finished the game yet but none of it has felt like a chore. I've enjoyed all of it and it 's definitely my favourite game of all time.There are a lot of people getting stuck on this game either saying it's too hard or that it should have a quest log. Some people are seeing the first hard enemy they find and giving up because they can't beat it. You don't have to! It's an important lesson that you can leave that challenge for later and just explore the world. Not having a quest counter makes this game much better. As people have suggested if you really want to you can get a pen and paper to help you remember characters. Don't complain that this is dumb because you aren't in school anymore. I'm sure you can manage. It makes the game so much more natural. You aren't meant to complete quests perfectly and it Isn't really possible to. If you miss a character or a part of a quest it may change other npcs stories in doing so. This makes them so organic and unique to you. You have to puzzle together their dialogue and this world in your own way. If you find something too challenging there is always something else you can try in this game. A different sword, a ranged weapon, magic, a summon, bring a friend along!TLDR: This is one hell of a game with rich and vibrant environments with deep lore. With a lot of it written by George R R Martin adding to even more of what we've come to love from Miyazaki. At it's core this game is an epic fantasy open world with great solid combat and it goes beyond that and is so much more as it's elements have been refined over years of FromSoftware experience.

2023 I love this game, and I have spent hours modding it, but CA has done nothing but break the game and make it harder to mod. Each update adding new things that seems to make modding harder for no reason, or changing mundane things that break every single portrait for no reason. Why did you add "no_culture" when you had portraits done perfectly. Why is the database tables constantly changed?CA isn't a "small indie company" there isn't an excuse that they can't fix bugs and make the game more fun for certain factions. I supported the game to be a full game, not be a forever beta.Due to the recent DLC I can't support it, but if they change around and support the game I love I will recommend it again, I don't want abandonware.

ALMOST 400 HOURS! I have been here since just after inception, almost 400 hours on the game. Uninstalled it yesterday. The wipe and the forced server move and loss of progress, loss of many hours of mats collection and base wipe killed it for me. I don't want to play Tarkov or Rust. This could have been a great game that people could have specialties and go to the market and sell to people. Join strangers in open world and battle with them and be part of helping the working community. The novice servers when it first came out felt like that. So many people giving each other items they needed. Kindness in the chat. People willing to come help you do the Bosses and random people joining you in the open world and hanging out to do things with you for the day.They say this is a MMO game. It's not. They made it seem like essential items from the first season would be able to be transferred to the next season. That is NOT what happens. You are extremely limited to what you can bring over with you and you are basically starting from scratch without the leveled up armor and leveled up weapons you worked hard to get before the wipe. They made it seem like you could bring everything over for the next season and get bigger and better from there. Not so. You start like a noob again, have to level your character up again, don't have access to your blueprints until you have leveled up again and all the additional special items and hoard of mats you farmed the first time don't move over with you. It's insane. Who wants to bother with starting over again and again without being able to bring your progression and skills with you? You are not going into a new season server with your weeks of hard work, you are being thrown into it like a noob. I've put thousands of real hours into many different MMOs, picked my specialty, built my homes, castles, farms etc and carried on in the same fashion without being forced to lose everything. This game is a cash grab for loot crates and cosmetics the way it stands now. The wipes ruin your long term progression. The base you spent hours grinding mats for and making, gone in 6 weeks. The mats you grinded for hours and carefully inventoried in crates, gone in 6 weeks. The farm you made, the meat you dried, the specialty items, gone. The Deviants you upgraded so you could have 20 to help run your base. Gone. The give you a TINY AMOUNT OF ITEMS that can be transferred and even then, you can't use them until you have leveled up from scratch again.This is not an MMO. There is no purpose to try to do anything like you would on an MMO level to have it all removed from you in 6 weeks. The balance on the servers is borked. The FPS is borked. The community became uncomfortable and hostile and rude when the changes were made for hard servers and everyone was struggling with NO MATS OR ITEMS FROM YOUR HOURS OF GAMEPLAY after 6 weeks. The world chat is now full of trolling and abusive players. A massive amount of people left, including my mates, so you now get stuck without anyone you knew from before to play with. Servers became full without many people returning to the server so you couldn't even invite a friend to it. It's just a full server with no one on it now, and no way to invite a friend to it. Customer service is AI, not a human.I don't want to play a MMO that is a RUST or TARKOV server. That is ridiculous. I have no idea why they are saying this is an MMO. It's at best, a slow RPG with massive amounts of anime MMO items (teddy bear costumes, cat tables etc) that are pushed on you all the time. Why would I bother to spend massive amounts of hours trying to get mats to rebuild a home and can't even use my furniture I got because its locked behind my progression again and I don't have the mats to rebuild a home that cannot be rebuilt with your blueprint because you haven't unlocked that ability, that you already had unlocked before the wipe. Absolutely insane.Why would I build an awesome base to have it gone in 6 weeks? Why catch and keep animals only to have it gone in 6 weeks? The whole premise of this game is discombobulated and all over the place. What could have actually been a really pretty MMO with the ability to create your own kind of place in the community has become a loot box mess of a wanna be Rust server with the premise of MMO community that doesn't exist and MMO loot box cosmetics spammed at you all the time.Almost 400 hours. Yes, I played everything, twice. Then I left. I won't go back in the state it is in. The loot boxes, the lack of listening to what the actual game playing community wants and NOT JUST WHAT STREAMERS WANT is bizarre. There is no understanding by the devs that most people do not have 40 hours a week to devote to the game and don't want to come back to something they used their available time for to now suddenly be wiped. It is an epic disappointment in multiple ways. If you like wasting your time on restarting the game from scratch with no carry over progression, over and over again, then enjoy this free game. Otherwise, if they don't make a lot of massive changes to the structure of the game it will be played one time through and dumped.I am not the only one who has expressed these views, there are thousands of us that played and left. I just wanted to say that after almost 400 hours of this game, I'm out. And the people who have also expressed these exact same concerns are also out. This could have been a really nice MMO to explore and grow into. It's not.
