I really tried to enjoy this game, and even spend a little on the Meta Pass to support it, given the number of hours I put into a "free" game. But ultimately, Once Human just isn't for me, at least not yet.I was expecting this to be a Survival Crafting / Base Building game with shooter elements. But really, this is a shooter game with crafting and building elements. And that crafting / building is absolutely Early Access quality. Random scavenging gives random loot that somehow provides all my crafting needs, so long as I pick everything up. So there is little need for targeted resource hunting or exploration after the first few dozen hours of gameplay. Good luck getting roofs to snap to walls. And God-forbid you try to relocate your territory after building anything more interesting than a wooden box.Combat is okay, but there is little support for anything other than firearms. My dreams of being Kirito in Gun Gale are dashed. More seriously, hit detection for precision bow shots is endlessly frustrating and inconsistent, making every attempt at stealth missions an exercise in futility (or a two-hour endeavor to clear a single settlement for resources that can be found elsewhere).This is not a bad game. But it definitely should be treated as Early Access, not a full-release. I will probably come back to this game in the future after some hearty Quality of Life Improvements geared towards us solo survival crafting players. But so long as this is a shooter game first, it really just isn't the kind of game I am interested in.

2022 This is the best souls like experience From Software could ever grace us. From the very moment you start in Elden Ring you are introduced to the new and interesting world and it just becomes ever more confusing the more you play! You meet tons of characters on your journey who may be of service, betray you, give you a chuckle, or just call you out that you have no maidens. There are tons of bosses and challenges for you to face even after you beat the game because of how expansive this game is. I am just going to put some good things and bad things I have with the game as I do want to specify a big issue I have. First I want to start off with the good: The world design is fantastic as every area feels different from the rest. Certain places give you a sense of adventure while some may give you a sense of dread and fear of dying in .2 seconds. The weapons and armor are some of the best in the souls series. The combat is much more fluid than the previous souls game. Horse combat and gameplay is a very nice addition to the game. Most if not all the characters you meet feel unique and confusing as they all speak tounge. Now I could go on and on about how good this game is but I just need to point out my biggest issue. There are tons of reused bosses in this game. In addition, I have seen regular enemies become bosses later. Worst of all, there are bosses that you fight one on one and then they are reused as a duo boss. The three biggest culprits are the dragons, godskin noble, AND THOSE CRUCIBLE KNIGHTS WHICH YOU FIGHT 7 DIFFERENT TIMES. These of course are just only a few examples of reused bosses. Just a side complaint here is the performance in some areas of the game. I know this will probably be fixed later in a patch but man those stutters are common and have affected a boss fight or two. 2018 So what do we need to do to get good in this game?Step 1:Accept you aren't the best and make mistakes like everyone elseStep 2:Setup your Gear. Have a good Microphon and use it.Step 3:Warmup before Competitive Games. Doesn't matter if you kill 1000 Bots on an Aim-Map or play Deathmatch for about 20 Minutes.Step 4:Practice all necessary skills for the Game- AIM -> Deathmatch; Aim-Maps; Practice-Maps (Recoilmaster etc.)- Movement -> Climb-servers; Surfing, Prefire-Maps (Shortcuts from Yesber too)- Gamesense -> Matchmaking; Retake-Servers- Mapknowledge -> Callouts; Demos from your favourite Pro-Player,- Nades -> pls learn them- Roles -> Entry; Support; Lurk; AWPerAdditional Steps:- Train your Habit (first callout then flame)- play daily to to improve your aim- make pauses every 2-3 games to reset (go outside from the room with your Pc)- stop at the point you get mad (after a loss may)If you follow all these Steps you will be able to climb the ladder and improve fast.Have a nice day and start fraggin! P.S.: Last Step: Get friends to play with and play for the win not for stats!!!

2019 I originally played this game back when it was still in closed beta, when I gained access to it by bothering a Valve employee (sorry, Jeep). Back then I loved it, it felt great and performed great and everything just made sense. Since then, Valve took over the game where Hidden Path left off and only built on it - adding more depth to mechanics and gunplay and even movement. I fell out with the game around then, as the focus shifted to being a little bit too competitive for my tastes (yes, I am a casual, and I'm ok with that).Over time I saw more and more flaws with the game that turned me off. Weird premium passes, sprays that cost money, skins that cost money, lootboxes. Even gloves became a microtransaction. While I'm not anti-microtransaction (I understand that long-lasting games have to make money somehow), I felt Valve's approach to these microtransactions became increasingly anti-consumer. And that's what prevented me from coming back.But then something crazy happened: they shoehorned in a battle royale mode to cash in on a craze and made the game free-to-play. I thought this would be the final nail in the game's coffin, as I reinstalled it to "see how bad it was".Except it was really, really good.Danger Zone became my way back to Counter-Strike. I ignored the skins and sprays and stickers and gloves and who knows what else, and started playing with my friends and having a genuinely good time in this so-called tacked-on game mode. The mode is very tightly designed. Matches are kept small and quick, solving the big issue in other BR games where you spend 20 minutes looting copy/pasted houses in a map the size of Texas, only to be wiped out by some screeching 13 year olds. Now you spend 2 minutes looting unique environments in a map the size of a small island, only to be wiped out by some screeching 13 year olds. The small matches also meant quick queue times! Plus, they built a host of battle royale mechanics around CS's mechanics, instead of the other way around like every other game.And then they removed three player squads, for some unknown reason. Suddenly, I can't play with my friends, only a single friend. They even removed solo play, and began matching solo players against duos. This also resulted in much longer queue times, as people stopped playing it due to it no longer supporting squads and because of the weird new matchmaking rules. I'm not sure what drove this decision, but it actually did turn Danger Zone into the final nail in the coffin. Boutta head out.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 - A Review Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 delivers an exhilarating experience that both fans of the franchise and newcomers will find impressive. Developed by Saber Interactive and published by Focus Entertainment, this sequel successfully builds on the foundation laid by the original game while introducing fresh elements to keep the gameplay engaging and exciting. Story and Setting: Set in the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40,000, the game immerses players in a desperate battle for survival. As a Space Marine, you are thrust into the chaotic struggle against the Tyranids, a relentless alien species. The narrative does an excellent job of capturing the essence of the Warhammer 40K lore, with its dark and brooding atmosphere perfectly complementing the intense action. The storyline is well-crafted, offering a gripping and emotionally charged experience that keeps players invested in the fate of the characters and the broader conflict. Gameplay and Mechanics: The gameplay in Space Marine 2 is a standout feature. The game combines fast-paced action with deep combat mechanics, allowing players to engage in brutal, visceral battles. The combat system is robust, offering a satisfying mix of shooting and melee combat that feels both powerful and precise. The variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal ensures that combat never feels repetitive, and the ability to customize your loadout adds a strategic layer to the gameplay.The game also introduces new mechanics and refinements from its predecessor. The improved AI and enhanced enemy variety make each encounter feel unique and challenging. The level design is top-notch, featuring intricate environments that offer tactical opportunities and add to the immersion. The seamless transition between ranged and melee combat is particularly noteworthy, allowing players to fluidly switch between different combat styles depending on the situation. Graphics and Audio: Visually, Space Marine 2 is a treat. The game boasts impressive graphics that bring the Warhammer 40K universe to life with stunning detail. The character models, environments, and special effects all contribute to a visually striking experience. The dark, gritty aesthetic of the Warhammer universe is captured beautifully, enhancing the overall atmosphere of the game.The audio design is equally impressive. The sound effects are impactful, from the satisfying crunch of melee attacks to the deafening blasts of gunfire. The voice acting and soundtrack further immerse players in the game, with the voice work adding depth to the characters and the soundtrack heightening the tension and excitement of the battles. Multiplayer and Replayability: The multiplayer component of Space Marine 2 is a welcome addition, offering various modes that extend the game's longevity. Whether you’re teaming up with friends or competing against other players, the multiplayer matches are well-designed and provide a fun and competitive experience. The replayability is enhanced by the variety of weapons, skills, and loadouts available, allowing players to experiment with different strategies and playstyles. Conclusion: Overall, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a standout title in the Warhammer 40K series. It successfully builds on the strengths of its predecessor while introducing new elements that enhance the overall experience. With its engaging storyline, refined combat mechanics, impressive visuals, and immersive audio, it’s a must-play for fans of the franchise and a compelling entry point for newcomers. The game delivers a memorable and action-packed experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

To call the game "released", a long and fairly good quality beta test must pass (with a large team of competent testers for such a large open world and such a large number of mechanics), but when the company starts releasing in a hurry due to the fact that some group of sponsors or whoever rather started to get off their investments ...Then as a "game" we get a disgusting mixture of monotonous gameplay, with constant lags, bugs, inconsistencies with descriptions, broken crafting elements and not only, broken perks, absolutely raw events, illogical calculation and damage systems of buffs, and much more. I haven't seen such a RAW game in a long time. Apparently, we are at the stage called "welcome to the era of lazy and inexperienced gamedev without good skills(exmple: in optimisation/devops/put here what you experienced from nowadays games) and probably incapable of broad-mind game design."After spending almost 500 hours in the game, I can confidently say that, in the next month I will write a huge bug report without emotions but with raw information. Aaand, will monitor(gona post it elsewhere) the response to it and further actions regarding CRITICAL moments affecting the game experience EXTREMELY negatively for a lot of players(as i put some work to speak almost with everyone on my server to get feedback by this topic, and it's not good... if i say it soft...). Bottom line:At the moment, the game should add a BETA marker. Otherwise, presenting this abomination as a finished product is a deliberate deception, in my humble opinion - in my humble opinion, someone had an irresistible desire to release the product as soon as possible, the reasons, judging by what I realized during the game, are very prosaic. The potential of the game is huge. If not for all the bad things that it has, it would be just amazing with a competent dev approach. But we have what we have and it's very sad.I'm saying all this as a person with 6 years of experience in devops and 8 years in development (2 of which with django python, 4 with C, 1 with C++, 1 with ruby). I KNOW how it can be, I UNDERSTAND how it should be, and I've seen many times how NOT to do it, so the game is about 40% how NOT to do it.P.S. and ye, servers made of paper, working just terrible, load balancing on stone age level. It can't handle mass events, read the internet about PrimeWars... Terrible.

2023 I've really enjoyed this series but I can't recommend this game, despite it being its ultimate conclusion; what should be every warhammer fan's wet dream. It just wouldn't fit my ethics to do so.To put concisely, it just doesn't make sense to try and get into this series anymore at this point. The way this game's dlc works seems reasonable at first, with none of it *technically* being required, but this is just not true when we consider that even if you enjoyed only one faction; if that faction wasn't in this game you are buying an entire other video game to play that faction in this game. It's a sort of nickle and diming that doesnt feel as bad to someone whose been playing all along but the barrier to having a full faction roster in 2023 for a new player is beyond reasonable. This game is 60 dollars, and then asks you to pay at least 60 more to play some of its most iconic factions to their fullest. This is before we even get into how multiplayer adds extra pressure to this. The base versions of every faction are inherently incomplete and far less viable in multiplayer. If you're a skaven player, you're buying two games and somewhere around three dlcs to play your whole army. These expansion packs are another *technically* worth it sort of thing because beyond units they have unique campaigns but i just cant actually ask someone to do that. To top it all off, 3 is probably one of the least polished versions of the game to date, rife with bugs and poor decision choices; some of which that date back to the first game. Sieges are STILL not fun, the unique smaller map campaign is still annoying to play, if you bought the beastmen you still dont have the little mini campaign their dlc justifed its cost with from the first game, the AI is still unacceptably easy to cheat against, the strategic and empire building side of the game is still inferior to previous games, unit balance is still unsatisfying and skewed towards certain monsters and ranged units, and the new dlc model is the worst value and most toxic yet.Shadows of change upped the scale of lord packs to three new subfactions rather than two alongside a MASSIVE price increase and its just not worth it. Interestingly enough having more factions involved makes it feel even worse, because in this instance I only play one of the factions. So if I wanted to play kislev to its fullest id have to go buy the most expensive dlc of its kind while only enjoying less than a third of its value. Warhammer 3 needs a serious come-to-jesus moment on its current model because its only good at leaching off of existing long-term customers and at this point it's been this way so long I can't deny its at least mostly on purpose. I don't think we started on this road on purpose or out of malice, but we have had several opportunities to change course and still we go on. At this point in warhammer 2's lifespan we were getting several entirely new factions including ones that were only ever described through lore and side-games like the vampire coast. What gets me is that not only is it bad value for the customer it feels like extra work for the devs. Making three subfactions instead of two means they now need to make three new entire systems, and they now need to make one more massive big budget big ♥♥♥♥ box seller unit and its art assets which I feel is a massive amount of the time and money put into these packs, becasue they DO look amazing. They all do. This game is beautiful when the lighting doesn't mess it up. So why waste that time and money and dedication making something worse that people feel bad paying for because there's just only so much any one person wants to spend on a single dlc pack.If you're a warhammer fan, im sorry but don't tread here. You'll spend only slightly more money and make more friends collecting an actual army of minis and playing at your local game store.

2022 Elden Ring is an incredible open world experience for those who enjoy Fromsoft's approach to RPG games. The difficulty level is similar to previous titles by this developer such as Dark Souls. However, it is approachable to new players as there are many options available to make the game accessible difficulty-wise to those who don't want as much of a challenge. The game looks great, feels great, but there are some performance issues that are yet to be worked out. Things are looking up though, as the most recent patch addressed many issues players were having with the game and I imagine some performance updates are coming soon enough.

2023 Over a thousand hours combined in the Warhammer Total War series. More in other total wars.I want to add a counter point to the review-bombing happening with the recent Shadows of Change DLC. Yes, the value for money of the latest DLC is not great and has angered the community. Yes, CA has been slow to fix some long-standing known bugs with a patch cycle that some people wish was quicker. However, the above does not detract from the extraordinary scope of the game that is available. If you are a fan of either the Warhammer Fantasy world or the idea of a 4X style game with fantasy elements, then TW:WHIII is the definitive experience. The base game is much improved since the launch of it over a year ago. The immortal empires map, which is the combined world map of all 3 games, has been made available to owners of just TW:WHIII. It is truly immense. Some of the recent frustration has been missing the forest for the trees. If you are remotely interested in the Warhammer Fantasy setting (which is pretty deep with all the lore, books, and other games that explore the setting), then TW:WHIII is a phenomenal experience.

2022 Elden Ring reinvents the open world in the same way Breath of the Wild does. By breaking all the trends associated with modern open-world games. No hand-holding, no quest markers, no collectible-based progression, and no copy and pasted zones. You can explore any part of the world from the beginning, nothing (but a few tough enemies) is stopping you from exploring the farthest reaches of the world from the get-go. Build diversity is at an all-time high. With a plethora of play styles available, and with a generous ability to respec (around halfway through the game). I've played three wildly different characters, and each time I was able to make my idea come to life easily.Combat feels as fluent as ever. Strength weapons feel meaty and have a huge weight behind them. While dex-based weapons are fast and fluid. Int and Faith also shine with a huge arsenal of spells/incantations available to try.The only complaint I can levy against this incredible game is awful ultra-wide support and some choppy frame rates in certain areas of the game.

2022 Product received for free CS:GO review from a free account Counter-strike: Global Offensive is a game in which two teams (One Terrorist, and the other Counter Terrorist) try to prevail against the other. The Terrorists try to plant the bomb at one of two sites or wipe out the other team, and the Counter terrorists try to stop the terrorists from accomplishing their tasks.Pros:Can be free to play (with limitations)- If you choose to play CS without upgrading your account, you can still play all of the game modes. It is actually pretty good for a free game. You cannot receive drops or a rank however. Steam cards are also not available to free accountsGood multiplayer game- CS can be played with teams of 5 friends if you queue up in competitive mode. Cs also has the largest player base of any game on steam, so there are always people to play with.Game is updated regularly- CS receives updates on the regular, and operations are added yearly (as of the date of this review)Number of hackers lessened- In my experience, the number of hackers in this game has been greatly reduced over the years. I am playing on a new free to play account (an alt) to test this, and it does seem to hold upCons:hacking is still prevalent in csgoThe ranking system is hard to understand- You may lose a game and de-rank, then go on to win 5 games with no rank up. You need to be patient with the ELO systemThere are not many gamemodes- To be fair, they have been updating cs and introduced things like short comp matchesOverall, csgo is a fun game, and if you dont care about getting a rank, a free to play account works well for your needs. I initially played casual for the first 2 years of my csgo gameplay (back in 2015). If you dont care about comp and ranks, this is essentially what a free account can offer you. You can get into games, and even play competitive mode these days without it being ranked. It is a fun game, and I do recommend it :)

I wishlisted this game because the trailer and screenshots reminded me of The Secret World. I downloaded this game after watching a streamer play for 10 minutes and realizing it was a blend of The Secret World, Rust, and Palworld. This is one of those games you sit down to play for an hour or two and then look at the clock 14 hours later and you haven’t moved. It’s so fun. My only complaint is some rough FPS drops when you’re near a cluster of player territories, but apparently the official launcher has better performance than Steam right now so that’s an option too. Oh, and yes, servers wipe every six weeks so don’t be surprised by that. I’ve played many hours of Rust and Diablo and seasonal wipes are not as bad as people make them out to be. Honestly, after going through so many resets, I actually prefer them now. Also there’s a dinosaur costume and an outfit that looks like cowgirl Beyoncé.

Product received for free Contra todo pronóstico, Black Myth Wukong siendo de un estudio nuevo y chino, segun mi criterio y habiendo jugado mas de 50 horas es el mejor juego de lo que va del año. Para mí se merece el GOTY desde ya. habiéndolo concluido puedo decir que es una obra maestra. Desde la escenografía, los gráficos, la jugabilidad, hasta la narrativa, nos muestra una cara de la mitología china que muy pocos conocíamos. Sin duda estamos ante un juego que marca un antes y un después en el género "Souls" más o menos lo que pasó con Baldur's Gate 3 en su género el año pasado. De hecho, me atreveria a decir que esta es la evolución de ese género, por lo cual deberían empezar a llamarse los juegos que salgan similares a este "Wukongs like"Para los que quieren compararlo con Elden Ring en lo personal este me parece mejor juego; tiene un Lore muy amplio y lleno de vida, personajes entrañables, banda sonora exquisita y las animaciones al final de los capítulos son una delicia a la vista.Sin lugar a dudas es mi GOTY. Si tuviera que darle puntuación le daría un 9,5/10, solo porque algunos textos biográficos de enemigos aún están por traducirse al español.

2023 This game is a lifesaver; having recently purchased a house that does not easily accommodate the space needed for a game of Age of Sigmar or 40k, and having small children that will express their curiosity towards my ineptly painted models with reckless abandon, we've played an obscene amount of this instead. It's not perfect, but it's tons of fun and allows for a impressive variety of play given how dissimilar the factions are from each other. Immortal Empires really shows this off, as does our favorite activity: Battle modes with points determining the army lists.I consider this to be the ultimate fusion of Total War as a franchise and Warhammer as a franchise, and I would be hard-pressed to name a strategy game I enjoy more, as these two seem to be made for each other. The grit and variety of the Warhammer setting, bringing a plethora of unit options over the typical Total War PC game, and the focus and grand scale of the Total War skin really hones in on the best aspects of the tabletop version of Warhammer: the lore and the depth of faction options.You can distill the essence of this game to the following quote from one of my partner's favorite Robot Chicken skits: "I beat up the guy who owned this stuff, so now it's mine. That's called geopolitics."

Game updated for the DLC and now the game gives me "Inappropriate activity detected" and refuses to play online. Steam Deck-No mods. Total BS. Others are having the same issue and no word from FromSoftware...Updating my review, although the company really should have thought of this. The installation of the base game leaves out an empty file folder named DLC that the anti cheat looks for. So unless you bought the DLC you can’t play online. Dumb. You have to manually create the folder and put it in the right place. Then the anti cheat sees all the files look normal and allows online play. Leaving the review the same until Fromsoft fixes this.

I'm just going to type about the game because I am not a game reviewer, nor do I have expertise on Game Development. However, I've played video games consistently since the early 2000's. This game is good looking. The cinematic elements of the game are a nice touch but it doesn't make up for the fact that the fighting mechanics are not done well. The common enemies are eliminated by button mashing. While the elite enemies tend to have heavy attacks that you dodge once and then spam mash light attack until their HP is gone. This is early game that I'm talking about so it might be possible to have other abilities later on. This review has come to be after I fought the second boss (The water snake noble guy) and can't beat him. Is it because I don't want to be patient? Absolutely I don't want to be patient! But his attacks (I felt the same way about the first boss) are too difficult to read, and I spend my time spam dodging until he's done. I've played and beaten both Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring (DLC Included) and this game is just mechanically clunky. The fights just feel like you take turns attacking. There is not a defensive strategy early on. I can't block (except archers' arrows but I've only run into 2 of them), I can't parry, and I can't counter.The game looks good, feels ok, but overall the fighting aspect (at least early on) is mechanically impossible to actually feel like a Martial Arts Monkey. I think my only issues is how narrow and closed in the beginning feels. I get that there isn't an open world aspect and that it is very linear. Which in games like Sekiro are fine because it felt like there was some level of exploration. This game locks you into a path that says "Get good" but cares more about creating a challenging Fromsoft experience without the vast equipment or abilities that Fromsoft gifts to their players with their choices of character creation. Again, not a game reviewer, just a frustrated gamer that spent $60 on another game that doesn't feel fine tuned. (just feels like with all the open world games nowadays, companies don't know how to create efficient linear maps).I am not returning this and do plan on trying to beat it, but not because I love the video game, but because I love video games. I could recommend this game for certain types of players, just not ones like me.

2022 There isn't much new to add about this game at this point so I'll try (and fail) to be concise (which is hard because the hype I've had for this game in the past years is immesurable).Are you a Souls veteran? Welcome to the best souls by a long shot. Like, DS1 will always be in my heart but it's completely surreal the amount of joy, entertainment, "wow" moments like the very first time you reach Anor Londo in DS1, Drangleic Castle in DS2 or Irithyll in DS3. This game has that but every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 15 minutes. Literally pick everything you liked about previous titles and Elden Ring easily has that and improved.Are you new to the Souls series? Welcome to the modern gaming experience of your life. For the first time ever we have a product that is overhyped during its development and not only it met its expectations, but somehow exceeded them. Elden Ring is the culmination of everything FromSoft has learned for the past 10 years, all put together into their first open world game. Experience freedom, mystery, danger, an absurd amount of content and varied environments, a savage attention to detail and overall one of the most beautiful and dense open worlds this market has to offer.If you feel intimidated by the Difficult tag that precedes all FromSoft's titles, let me tell you that Elden Ring is the most accessible game of them all. And by accessible I don't mean easiest. While you were forced to stomp on an area/boss in previous games, this is an open world. Feeling stuck? Just turn around, keep exploring and get stronger (and boi, there IS content to explore)! Unlike your generic big titles, don't go full unga unga here. This is a game that you can perfectly beat by simply hack-n-slashing, but it encourages you to try your available resources to make fights much more managable; it treats you as a smart person. And this is something very important that I feel many newcomers ignore which has been applying since their old games. There are always many ways to make fights easier, or even trivialize them. Read your items, use internet tips to help you out, ask friends or summon them to aid you. The game encourages you to do so! "Easy Mode" exists but it's not a setting option you can turn on/off; you need to craft it by playing smart.I also want to highlight that Elden Ring is not perfect; a project this large will always have some flaws and there are many things I would've changed. Some examples are: some copypasted minor bosses across dungeons; some QoL improvements; better balancing (especially on the second half of the game)... The point here though is to say it the other way around: it is unbelievable Elden Ring has so few flaws given the scale of the game. With that aside, get ready to explore the (by a LONG shot) best open world map I've ever seen; the most developed combat system and builds (though some of them still unbalanced) FromSoft has ever tried; some of the best boss fights they've made; an staggering amount of content, incredible areas, and interesting characters. This is a new standard on this industry and hopefully the rest of the companies will study and learn the success of this game.As for now, just buy the most worthy $60 title there currently is and hopefully you will feeling the same as me: one of the greatest games I've ever played and the most magical experience I've had in so many years.

2022 I'm a total noob when it comes to Souls-Games. Usually I play RPGs on easy mode to enjoy the story in peace.Obviously there is no proper easy mode in Elden Ring, but the game allows you to play it in your own pace.I literally spent the first 12-14 hours just riding around on my horse which I named Dolly, picked up flowers & only killed some easy enemies. The more I played the more I got confident & noticed that I'm able to kill some small dungeon bosses, because the game allows you to level up without going for the big bosses. When I felt strong enough I went for my first story boss & it was fun, not too easy, not too difficult. Like that's the great part of Elden Ring: you don't have to be this awesome Souls-Veteran to be able to enjoy the game. You can just take your time with everything, explore the beautiful world from the get go & just enjoy the view & smaller bosses.The game doesn't push you to kill a certain difficult boss in order to get somewhere ingame. You're not forced to farm the same enemies for hours on end until you're strong enough to continue your journey. You can just keep exploring & will eventually level up in the mean time. & if you're not getting any further with a specific boss, then you can just leave it be for now & do hundreds of other things instead.I would also like to mention that the open world is done really good! 2022 I have a love/hate relationship with this game. I have hundreds, maybe even thousands of hours playing Total War games,and WH3 has the POTENTIAL to be the BEST game of the franchise so far. It could be the best game I've ever played...but it isn't. Here's why:1. Please fix the AI Undead. It is ridiculous how fast they reinforce and multiply. For example, I made several valiant stands against undead sieges in my towns, where I would totally destroy several units during the fighting, but it was pointless because even though the units showed that they were destroyed at the end of the battle, they would magically reappear at the beginning of the very next turn virtually unscathed. RIDICULOUS and FRUSTRATING! 2. Ambushed while my army is in camp mode. This is even crazier. If my army is encamped and not moving, can somebody pleeeease tell me how in the H.E.L.L. they can be suddenly ambushed walking around? I could see if maybe the camp had suddenly came under attack, and there was a battle map for that. But if the army is STATIC how can it be out walking around in the most vulnerable nonsensical formation that absolutely no commander who is worth his weight in pig dung would march his army out in? They really have to fix this. Because it makes ZERO sense at all. 3. Just take out the boost the winds of magic gamble feature. Has this thing ever boosted the winds in anybody's favor when the difficulty setting is on High or above? REALLY? REALLY?4. It seems like the evil factions are all one faction once the player's faction becomes a little powerful. I played as The Empire and Kislev and both times Orcs, Undead, Demons, and Norsicans would walk over, through, around and on top of each other to come after me. This makes no sense, especially when the factions are not allies. I could go on, but these are a few of the main things that really make the game soooo frustrating that it's hard to enjoy all the fun I'm having. The graphics battles and mechanics are outstanding on the game, but when a game has one too many major logic flaws it slowly grinds down the fun into frustration and eventually to walking away from it. I LOVE the TW games and I want WH3 to be the best game I've ever played. It has the potential and it is very close, but in the state it's in it ain't there.

2023 Total War: Warhammer 3 is a great game, but I can't recommend it in good conscience due to the recent DLC price controversy. The new Shadows of Change DLC is priced at $24.99, which is a 150% increase over the price of previous lord packs. This is especially egregious considering that the DLC only adds two new legendary lords and a handful of new units.Creative Assembly has defended the price increase by saying that it reflects the increased cost of development. However, I find this argument to be unconvincing. The previous lord packs were already well-priced, and I don't see why the cost of development should have increased so dramatically in the past year.The DLC price controversy is just the latest in a series of problems that have plagued Warhammer 3 since its launch. The game has been plagued by bugs and performance issues, and Creative Assembly has been slow to address these issues. The developer has also been criticized for its lack of communication with the community.I hope that Creative Assembly will reconsider the price of next DLC. Until then, I can't recommend Warhammer 3 to anyone. The DLC price increase is a slap in the face to the fans who have already supported Warhammer 3 and overall, the DLC price controversy is a major black mark on Warhammer 3. It is a shame that such a great game has been marred by such a greedy business decision.

2021 CS:GO review from a free account Counter-strike: Global Offensive is a game in which two teams (One Terrorist, and the other Counter Terrorist) try to prevail against the other. The Terrorists try to plant the bomb at one of two sites or wipe out the other team, and the Counter terrorists try to stop the terrorists from accomplishing their tasks. Pros: Can be free to play (with limitations)- If you choose to play CS without upgrading your account, you can still play all of the game modes. It is actually pretty good for a free game. You cannot receive drops or a rank however. Steam cards are also not available to free accountsGood multiplayer game- CS can be played with teams of 5 friends if you queue up in competitive mode. Cs also has the largest player base of any game on steam, so there are always people to play with.Game is updated regularly- CS receives updates on the regular, and operations are added yearly (as of the date of this review)Number of hackers lessened- In my experience, the number of hackers in this game has been greatly reduced over the years. I am playing on a new free to play account (an alt) to test this, and it does seem to hold up Cons: hacking is still prevalent in csgoThe ranking system is hard to understand- You may lose a game and de-rank, then go on to win 5 games with no rank up. You need to be patient with the ELO systemThere are not many gamemodes- To be fair, they have been updating cs and introduced things like short comp matches Overall, csgo is a fun game, and if you dont care about getting a rank, a free to play account works well for your needs. I initially played casual for the first 2 years of my csgo gameplay (back in 2015). If you dont care about comp and ranks, this is essentially what a free account can offer you. You can get into games, and even play competitive mode these days without it being ranked. It is a fun game, and I do recommend it :)

2022 As anyone following the game knows, it launched in a bad state. The campaign was annoying and one-note, the bugs were frequent and impactful, and the performance was terrible. Thankfully, the game has been slowly getting fixed and once modding support was released we could remove the worst parts of it.The game that is now available is in a much better state. The game has recently received the "Immortal Empires" update which has added a full world map that doesn't have the annoying campaign mechanics, a bunch of the more questionable design aspects have started being fixed, the performance is significantly better, and owners of the previous games can now access (almost) all of the old game's content in this one.Is it perfect? Hell no. Its still super buggy (although the bugs are more singular features not triggering and graphics issues and less gameplay breaking issues), the balance is off, and there are far too many siege battles. Despite all of this, I would now suggest buying the game. There is enough content in the base game to entertain you for quite a while, it can incorporate the previous two games (and all of their DLC) to give a frankly ridiculous amount of content, and the management change since launch seems to have fixed the development pipeline.---Well, that's what I said at launch. It turns out that they have not fixed their pipeline. New patches come out at a glacial pace, and even when they do come out they break more than they fix. Poor Nakai still can't recruit his most important units, the Brettonia update simply didn't work, and the map is so laggy that some people cannot run the game after turn 50!I'm not going to go into the price of the latest DLC, its overpriced and we all know this. However, the game just isn't in a state I can recommend. Is there a metric ton of content? Yes! Is a lot of it fun? Yes! Is it in a state I can recommend? Not even close. When I wrote my last review, I had hope that the game would overcome its poor launch state and become something fantastic. I just don't have that hope anymore.If you want to get the game, do it but make sure to get the unofficial patch before you even boot it up. If you are on the fence, I would probably get one of the other games on sale or look for a similar product elsewhere.

2022 After playing 9 hours of Elden Ring, I am going to give it a thumbs up. Despite the horrible performance issues, I'm not really getting great performance on a 3070 paired with a 10700k and 32gb 3600mhz ram. This game is at its core a Dark Souls game, I've thoroughly enjoyed exploring Limgrave and the surrounding area and I think it does a good job of combining aspects from Sekiro and Dark Souls. The addition of a mount is cool although a lot of the time I just find myself running on foot exploring the area anyway.Would I recommend this to your average open world game enjoyer? Possibly not based on the fact that this is quite a punishing game for anyone who doesn't have the patience to repeat certain areas a few times until you get that satisfying W and get to where you need to go.I don't think I'm anywhere close to finishing this game, but so far I'm having a blast being someone who is a big fan of the soulsborne series. There are even some Dark Souls cameos that make an appearance.Overall thumbs up and it's a great game but it needs a lot of polish in terms of optimising. Also for anyone looking to purchase this, it is locked at 60fps so keep that in mind.

2023 Picture this: You make a game, it's LOVED all over in the world. You then make DLC for it with a bunch of content, new factions, new leaders, Etc. People buy it! Repeat this, make a new game, and tie the old game and it's DLC's to it.People end up buying that, the old game, the old DLC's and everything, which is a pretty big moneysink.You release a bunch of DLC for that aswell, and same thing. Now, you do this a Third time, but this time, you start lowering the amount of content in the DLC's, and raise the prices.Then you pretty much stop communicating with your players, release a dlc with lackluster mechanics costing a ton, get retaliation and you, as a company pretty much throw a hissy fit that people aren't buying the DLC and that they're getting tired of the cost going up and the content and quality is going down, and then pretty much just blame that "We need more money and if you don't buy the DLCs we won't support the game anymore."The three games, just the base games, cost 179.97 Euros.Now, All the DLC excluding Shadows Of Change is 244.29 Euros If I counted correctly.And they claim it's a Money issue. And This is just one of the branches in the Total War franchise.It's not a finance issue, It's greed.DLC overtime overshooting the game's price is normal when it is out for quite some time, but it's getting stupid when the 2 latest DLCS are almost just as much as the base game. Now, Forge Of The Chaos Dwarfs I can pretty much understand, Cause it came with lots of content so the price was justified in my eyes, but the latest DLC is just insane.Now I'm not saying the price for ALL The DLC'S are bad, hell, for warhammer II we got a bunch of FreeLC and most of the stuff was reasonable for their cost, but if we are going to go down the path they are taking us down now, it's not looking good. The price for the Two latest DLCS only is 49.98. That's 2 DLCS for 50 euros, when the base game is 60.Seeing how I haven't even mentioned the bugs that come with these DLC's, The rare patches for bugs and how they've pretty much THREATENED THEIR CUSTOMERS to shut down support for Warhammer III Cause we're getting tired of their stupid way of dealing with this, It's just enough. There's no more respect for us, the buyers, to be found in the company, Just a toxic view of us as wallets.If this is where we are heading, I will not be supporting the future of CA. It seems like the beauty that was Warhammer II and the good times that came with it isn't their view anymore, the vision they have for Warhammer III, and us, is just...Sad.You had such a beautiful thing going, and you decided to just start Killing it off like this. Good Job CA.

2014 It's hard to argue that this game is probably the best CS release since 1.6. Some will disagree, might argue Source is a better game and they will have their own valid points. In my opinion this game is a true sequel. It brings the fun and nostalgia from the earlier versions of CS, the same flowing game play that made it popular and the heavy emphasis on team game play. It mates the old with the new; the expectations that a FPS be somewhat realistic if not fun to play. It's a modern game; it looks and plays like modern games should but it all looks a bit familiar, like the hot girl from years past that you bump into 10 years later. CS:GO is more technical and team oriented than previous games in the series. Shooting, movement, sound and grenades are completely different and you have to master them once again. Weapons now have a purpose - there's a reason to buy the 5-7 and P250, as well as the MP5 replacement, MP7. Team play is just as important as the economy; once you lose it there's no coming back.It's a demanding skills based that's as satisfying as any CS title has been. Pros: - Updated maps, visuals & sounds - Emphasis on team play - Valve online matchmaking as well as valve casual servers - Extensive customisability & player drops - More realistic player and game behaviour - CS:GO workshop - Pro players - Active development and regular updates - Listens to community - Low-end modern PC requirements for top quality & top resolutionCons: - Gungame isn't the same as CS:S - Because of different skills & tactics, CS:S players will feel like it's a familiar but new game. Skills are transferrable one way, not so much the other; when you play CS:S after CS:GO it will feel and sound like you're playing underwater. - Sound still seems like an afterthought - You will need to upgrade your video card to something made in the last 3 years if you want something that's playable and looks goodRatings:Graphics: 8.5/10, far improved on previous models but there's still room for improvementSound: 8/10, feels like an after-thought, if there's one complaint I have about the game it is that the sound quality and engine just isn't good enoughGameplay: 9.5/10, excellent and extremely playable game with very high replayabilityOverall: 8.5/10, it's a great game and could easily be 9.5 out of 10 with improved audio and slight improvements in visual quality. It's a modern twist on an old classic.Footnote:I lost my way with CS after CS:S and I turned to a variety of other games. Battlefield 1942/2142/2/3, Tom Clancy Rainbow 6, America's Army 2/3/PG. Before then I was an avid player of CS and I would play up to 100 hours per month. When I played CS 10 years ago I always asked, why can't this game be a little more realistic? Why can't they stop people from shooting through 3 walls 20 metres apart and killing with me an awp? Why do grenades act like balloons and float through the air? I can't really emphasise how happy I am that a lot of what shouldn't happen has been removed and the overall quality of visuals, sound and game play has been improved.In the first month of playing I managed to rack up 200 hours of gameplay and I've started contributing back to the community with maps.

2022 This has to be one of the best culminations of the whole "Souls Franchise" FromSoftware has been putting together. It feels like the elements of every game they have made so far have been pieced together to create this game. Along with this, it brings it to the next level being totally open world and filled to the brim with content. Since this is a continuation of the souls series, this game is still quite the challenge and feels similar to Dark Souls III in my opinion.In comparison to the previous souls games, this game is more forgiving with allowing for more variety in combat, however, to counteract this they made bosses more aggressive to take into account the new summoning system. In attempting to reach a wider audience of players, they had to make many of the bosses revolve around fighting multiple foes. This can cause a problem of balancing issues for those who want to run solo without the help if they wanted to.However, this game changes it up with how you approach the bosses. In previous titles, the mechanics of every fight would usually boil down to rolling and hitting, but now there is horse-riding, jumping attacks, a plethora of spells to cast, summoning and much more. I think that there is a huge emphasis on using all of the tools at your disposal because as you progress, the bosses will start to use different attacks that can't be killed in a certain way, causing for necessary readjustments in playstyle.Dungeons, caves, mines, and other kinds of loot are scattered across the world in various amounts allowing for so many different builds for your character. With this game being open-world, exploring feels not just necessary but rewarding for finding ways to progress further. All in all, I think this is a solid game, but I hope they don't follow this same path of having to make use of spawning multiple entities to win boss fights in the most effective way.(Sidenote: Performance issues at launch were terrible and I averaged around 30 FPS in the beginning area. While this issue has been mostly fixed, whenever I enter new areas I get huge dips in FPS until I reboot the game and have the new area loaded in.)

I had I lot of hype for Space marine 2, unfortunately the content is lacking, the classes in endgame operations are very imbalanced and DLC content such as armor skins and armor colors were not available as advertised. Main campaign is good however lacks any individuality, it is also very short, taking maybe 6 hrs in total to complete. Operations are the real draw for PVE endgame content, this is where you are introduced to the several classes you are able to play. This game does a horrible job at respecting your time through progression of each class. Classes themselves are very imbalanced with two maybe three being the dominate performers and the rest really feeling lackluster or even unplayable. Animations for parry's and dodges are not consistent, often punishing the player unfairly. Overall, this game feels incomplete, it needs more time in development. Content light, buggy and server issues galore. Do not recommend, and have requested a refund.

Campaign: one of the best I've played in recent memory - this is the only part I can recommendPvE: repetitive and loses steam after about 3 runs of each mapPvP: not my jam, no opinion, have not playedOverall the combat and general gameplay is some of the most satisfying I've seen since something like Gears but without all the cover nonsense and the first run of the campaign has some real jaw dropping moments in both visuals and reveals.However, if you're looking for more than the campaign, this is hard to recommend. Much like Left 4 Dead, Back 4 Blood, World War Z, Darktide, etc, there's just nothing to do in the PvE Operations mode except grind out cosmetics and passives. That might be enough for some, but it lacks any of the systems that make something like Destiny, Warframe, Deep Rock Galactic, Remnant, or the plethora of other rougelikes out there that do so much with mapgen and other secondary systems that make each run feel like a run, not just going through the same motions again. I'm never excited by anything that's gonna drop from a mission, it's just "cross the finish line this many times" for your next passive/cosmetic. Cosmetics are awesome, classes are fine, progression kinda sucks since you only unlock one row at a time. Not sure I'll be playing long enough to max a single class despite only playing two of them. Passives are... there? They all feel like relatively minor gameplay bonuses that help steer your playstyle, but not one so far has made me excited to unlock or feel it was worth working towards. They feel more like bypasses to some inconvenince rather than some Astartes-level power. I don't think I'd be able to tell an endgame level build from an early game one from gameplay alone.Would be awesome if in new game + you could play the campaign with your custom marine so 60% of the PvE missions were playable with the PvE classes. I think that's my biggest issue, the best PvE content isn't what you get to replay for progression and what's there to replay gets stale fast. Really hope to see some updates to the operations modes that make them more fun to replay. Modifiers, loot drops that persist after a play session, consumable buffs, unique mission rewards, map variants, mapgen, really anything except playing the same mission over and over with some different combat pacing each time. If campaigns are your jam, pick it up on sale. If you wanted something more replayable, wait.

2022 The long awaited strategy chaos prequel is finally out, but it has a lot to live up to and I don't think it quite makes the mark.The Good:+Great prologue which introduces both the story and eases new players into the franchise.+Presentation is fantastic, everything from music to monsters. The battles and overworld map are a visual feast.+Combat still feels punchy despite you floating above the fighting.+The new main campaign is slightly more arcady and plays faster, it's even better with the expanded multiplayer.The Bad:-The UI is way too red, add splotches of green and maybe some of that papery texture from the previous games.-Out of the new faction roster, I maybe only liked two (three if you include the DLC). It's hard to say why, but they just feel kind of underwhelming.-Which makes sense, because the unit roster is far smaller than the previous titles.-While the main campaign is faster, it also sucks that you have to wait until after beating it to paint the map.-Oh boy, bugs and crashes!Bottom Line:TW: Warhammer 3 is by no means bad. But, it is lacking the years of polish both of the previous titles have under their belt. If you're new to the franchise, I honestly think you'll have a better time by picking up 1 and 2 on sale, then playing it through the second game. If you've already played the previous titles to death, I can only recommend this if you can stomach less content and more than a few blemishes. Honestly, it might be best to wait for the massive map to get released.

Space Marine 2 is an instant classic. It harkens back to the days when games were simple but fun. The campaign, while short, is a breath of fresh air when it comes to story-lines. The voice acting is perfect. It has one of the best representations of the WH40K world and most importantly, the Space Marines and the Imperium of Man. The storyline is simple but executed perfectly. The characters are simple as well, stoic, stalwart Marines who will risk death for their fellow brothers and their mission, and that's ok.The devs and Saber should be proud of SM2. It's a return to classic gaming and what makes gaming fun. There's no hidden agendas, narratives or overt political messages shoved down our throats. There's no overly complicated characters with a plethora of problems pouring their hearts out and whining incessantly about how the world is against them. It's a simple storyline about brotherhood, duty, loyalty and just your basic good vs. evil. So refreshing.Buy it. It's worth it. The campaign is gloriously fun and gets your blood pumping with the amazing cinematics. The multiplayer is addictive and isn't overly grindy. You truly feel more powerful as you level up. I look forward to new missions, enemies and PvP modes.

2023 It makes me so sad to review this game with a negative, but in honesty there can't be any other choice with the current state of affairs. I played a lot of Warhammer 2 and it was one of the best games I've ever gotten my hands into, so I had high hopes with WH3. But since the beggining there has been numerous problems: the campaign was terribly planned and executed, sloppy, and it took a long time to get the sandbox experience from Immortal Empires. There was a lot of silence from the devs, and it looked like the game was doomed. Then they released an excellent rework of Warrios of Chaos and a pretty good Chaos Dwarfs DLC, and hope rose again: it looked like CA learned their lesson and started counting with the community to improve the game. And then, the new DLC dropped, at an exhorbitant price not justified for the content it offered, and when the community complained, CA went full passive-aggressive implying if we did'nt buy the product, they would kill the game, and giving explanations about inflation. They are killing the goodwill of the constumers with their actions.I had bought every DLC and game they released for the saga, but in no way I'm going to keep doing that, condoning with my money their terrible choices and threats to the community. The game is also bug riden, and it has been for a long time. They don't have a custodian team to take care of this stuff, and I would also bet that the money from the increase in price of DLCs (150%!) doesn't go either to their employees, but to the CEO and others.In no good faith I can recommend the game in its current state to anyone thinking about buying it. The DLCs are expensive and they will continue to be (as CA said themselves) and the base game experience is ruined by poor choices and bugs that have been there since the beggining. It is just really, really sad.

2022 While Immortal Empires certainly was a breath of fresh air for the game, there are still so many bugs and simply downgrades from game 2 that I would not recommend this game if you don't know what you are getting into. I still play it and enjoy it, but that's only because I can overlook the major issues that plague the game (and especially how incredibly slow CA has been at addressing any of them). Just go play Total War Warhammer 2 instead, which is in a great state right now.A few specific (major and minor) negatives for Immortal Empires (The twwh3 campaign alone is awful so let's just pass over that)------------------------------------------------------------>the ui is just straight up worse than game 2. I don't even know what happened here except that they wanted to change it for the sake of changing it. The faction selection is terrible, mission panel is worse to use, etc.sound design is good for the most part, but once again projectile units sound like *** with very few exceptions. Almost like someone else did them specifically (both blackpowder and bows/crossbows)>many factions have been nerfed and a lot of their interesting mechanics removed. While I do understand the need to reduce power in some cases, the big problem here is the lack of anything interesting in its stead. Just ends up making them less exciting to play.>Bugs, bugs, oh so many bugs. Yes that's to be expected, but they could at least have done some hotfixes by now. Some of them make certain factions nigh-unplayable or remove key parts of their identity (lack of items, heroes, quests, etc.).>Hero traits ... what the hell happened here. The vast majority of them are just straight up awful, while some are very good. I don't expect all of them to be great, but at least something decent. Rn the difference in power is astonishing Ogres are especially notorious here, with some default traits providing bigger benefits than their unique faction traits in the same attribute. Cathay similarly has some very weird traits ... all the good ones are of one type (Yin), while the Yang traits are just plain useless. That's not even to speak of factions that pretty much only have useless traits.>Personal issue, but the game is generally too easy right now. The AI is way too passive even at legendary leading to extremely fast campaign burnout (by turn 50 the campaign is basically over, cause nothing can challenge you anymore).>Lack of field battles. This is especially notorious on higher difficulties due to the ai sitting in their settlements as soon as they even get a whiff of your army. Additionally, since the autoresolve is as forgiving as it is right now, you barely ever fight any field battles past turn 20. It's always siege or minor settlement battles, which are both incredibly easy to defeat (easier than field battles in most cases). This has a lot of knock-on effects, such as gunpower units being generally awful in actual battle (due to the ai behaving smarter by avoiding LoS and targeting them with archers) or ranged units in general being subpar (again due to ai perfectly microing to avoid being shot as much as possible). This leads to sieges being either a melee slog or being cheesed in the vast majority of cases.>continuing with the gunpowder issue, the obstacle detection right now is so jank, that often those type of units don't even shoot if there is virtually nothing in front of them. It was already bad in game 2, but so much worse now. You often can't even shoot larger targets stuck in your infantry, because they seemingly don't realize that 60% of those trolls are sticking out above the heads of their comrades. Add to that the fact that most ai actively targets gunpowder units (such as handgunners, ironhails, thunderers, etc.) and you'll likely get a better performance out of any bow/crossbow unit. Those can shoot above your own units, have less targetting issues and most importantly don't require 10 seconds of micro each to get into a position where they can actually shoot properly.There are many other points that irk me, but I think these are some that might give you an idea of whether or not you may enjoy the game in its current state. I do believe it will get better with time, but as it is now I can't see this being anytime soon.

2023 I want so badly to be able to recommend this game, but I simply cannot. Whoever is directing this latest trend with the Total War franchise is milking the good reputation of the series for profit and eroding any good will their audience might have left over from the initial joy of seeing a game made with so much effort put into it. Leaving negative reviews is not enough if they are laughing all the way to the bank.One must simply stop buying products that are not worth the money. Go outside, watch a film or play an old Total War game instead. I won't be buying the latest DLCs until CA is done milking this property and Valve starts flogging them for 80% off, and I suggest you do the same.

You can draw a straight line between World War Z and this game. If anything, it leaves you wanting more. More maps, more enemy types, more everything. Nothing here overstays its welcome, and though the character writing is flat, it takes an already great formula from their last licensed game and faithfully applies a new license with a lot of attention to detail.It may need some optimization to play better on Steam Deck and older systems, and if the prior game is anything to go on, the monetization will be light.
